list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

hom.sense: The nineteenth letter of the alphabet: called gayonN. It is one of the letters termed Haloqiy-ap [or faucial], (L, TA,) its place of utterance being the upper part of the fauces, near to that of H, (TA in art. gyn,) the same place as that of x, (L, TA,) [from which it differs in being pronounced with the voice, for] it is of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal], (L, TA, and Ḳ in art. gyn,) and of those that are termed musotaEoliyap [q. v.]; one should not reiterate the voice in uttering it, so as to exceed what is right, nor neglect exactness in respect of its place of utterance, so as to render it obscure, but should make it thoroughly distinct, and clear: it is not an augmentative letter: and [it is said that] it is not substituted [for another letter]: (Ḳ in art. gyn:) [but this is a mistake; for] it is substituted for two letters; for x, in gaTara biyadihi, aor. yagoTiru, meaning xaTara, aor. yaxoTiru, mentioned by IJ and several others, (MF, TA,) and in gaTara bicanabihi for xaTara; (TA in art. xTr;) and for E, in lagan-a for laEan-a, mentioned by Ibn-Umm- Kásim and others, (MF, TA,) [and in naXuwgN for naXuwgN,] and in Airomagal-a for AiromaEal-a, and also in Algayonu as signifying “thirst” and “the clouds.” (TA in art. gyn.)
[As a numeral, it denotes A thousand.]

entry.sense: 1. gab-ati AlUibilu, (Ṣ,) or AlmaAXiyapu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagobibu}, inf. n. gab-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gubuwbN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) The camels, (Ṣ,) or cattle, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) came to water, (Ṣ,) or drank, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) on alternate days; one day and not the next day. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Hence, (IAth, TA,) gab-a said of a man means He came visiting at intervals of some days, or after some days. (AA, IAth, TA.) [See also gib-N: and see gubayosN.]

And gab-a Eani Alqawomi, (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yagobubu}, the verb in this case being of the class of qatala, [but this is contr. to analogy, as well as to the derivation,] inf. n. gib-N, with kesr, He came to the people, or party, day after day: (Mṣb:) or, as also Agb-↓ Alqawoma, he came to the people, or party, on alternate days, coming one day and not the next: (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he came to them once in two days or more. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Oagib-uwA↓ fiI EiyaAdapi AlmariyDi waOarobiEuwA Visit ye the sick on alternate days and after intervals of two days: (Ṣ, TA:) not every day, lest he find your visits to be troublesome. (TA. [See also art. rbE.]) And you say, Oagobabotuhu↓, inf. n. UigobaAbN, meaning I visited him [once] in every week. (A.)

And hence gab-ato said of a fever. (Mṣb.) gab-ati AlHum-aI and Oagab-at↓ signify the same: (Ṣ:) you say, gab-ato Ealayohi AlHum-aI, The fever came upon him, (Mṣb,) or attacked him, (Ḳ,) one day and intermitted one day; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Oagab-atohu↓ and Oagab-ato↓ Ealayohi. (Ḳ.) [See also gib-N.]

You say also, gab-a EinodanaA, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and Agb-↓, (L, Ḳ,) He passed the night, or a night, at our abode. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, ruwayoda AlX-iEora yagib-a [so accord. to the TA, Hat-aI being understood, accord. to the explanation of Meyd, but in the CK, and in one of my copies of the Ṣ, and in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 522, yagib-u,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. Leave thou the poetry until some days shall have passed, that thou mayest see what will be its result, whether it will be praised or dispraised: (Meyd, TA:) or it may be from gab-at said of a fever, and may thus mean, leave thou the poetry to be kept back from people, [or to be intermitted,] i. e. do not repeat it to people in an uninterrupted manner, lest they become weary. (Meyd. [See also art. rwd.])

And [hence] gab-a, (T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagobibu}, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. gab-N and gib-N and gubuwbN and gubuwbapN, (L,) said of food, (L, Mṣb,) and of dates, or especially of flesh-meat as some say, (L,) It remained throughout a night, whether it became corrupt or not: (L, Mṣb:) and, said of food, it became altered [for the worse] in its odour: (L:) or, said of flesh-meat, it became stinking: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Agb-↓: (T, Ḳ:) and it (a thing) became corrupt. (TA. [See also 2.])
gab-ati AlOumuwru means The affairs, or events, came to, or arrived at, their ends, conclusions, latter or last parts or states, issues, or results. (Ṣ, TA.)
And gab-a AlX-aIoCu fiI nafosihi, aor. _i {yagobibu}, inf. n. gab-N, [app. meaning The thing came into his mind,] is a phrase mentioned by Th. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. gb-b fiI AlHaAjapi, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. tagobiybN, (Ḳ,) He was remiss; or did not exert himself, or act vigorously or strenuously; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) in the needful affair: (Ṣ, O:) [and] so tgb-b↓ fiyhaA [if not a mistranscription]. (Thus in a copy of the A.) [Hence,] kataba Uilayohi yugab-ibu mino huloki Almusolimiyna, (TA,) or Eano halaAki Almslmyn, (thus in the O,) ‡ He wrote to him not acquainting him with the great number that had perished of the Muslims: (O, TA:) a metaphorical mode of expression; as though he were remiss, or fell short, in making known the essential state of the case. (TA, from a trad.)
And gb-b signifies also It (a thing) became very corrupt. (TA. [See also 1, last sentence but two.])

gb-b AlX-aApa, (O, L,*) inf. n. as above, (L, Ḳ,) He (a wolf) seized the sheep, or goat, by its throat, (O, Ḳ,) and fixed his canine teeth in it: (O:) or attacked the sheep, or goat, and broke its neck: and also left it with some remains of life in it. (L.) And gb-b Alc-iYobu fiI Alganami The wolf made, or did, mischief among the sheep, or goats. (TA.)
And [hence, app.,] gb-b Eani Alqawomi, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He repelled from, or defended, the people, or party: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) so say Ks and Th. (TA.)
4: see 1, in seven places.
You say also, laA yugib-unaA EaTaAWuhu His gift will not come to us on alternate days, but will come every day. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.*)
And Agb-t AlHaluwbapu The milch camel yielded milk on alternate days. (A.) And Agb-t AlUibilu The camels did not yield milk every day. (TA.)
See again 1, last sentence but two.
Agb- AlUibila He watered the camels on alternate days: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:*) from gib-N [q. v.]. (Ṣ, O.)
And Oagab-aniI is said by Th to signify waqaEa biI [app. meaning He fell upon me in fight]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. [tagb-b is app. from Algib-u in the sense of AlEaAqibapu, and thus syn. with taEaq-aba signifying He looked to the consequence, end, issue, or result, of an affair: see its part. n. mutagab-ibo, below.]
See [also] 2, first sentence.
8. Agtb-t Alxayolu see Agtv-t.
R. Q. 1. gabogaba He acted dishonestly in buying and selling. (AA, TA.)
gub-N A sea dashing so that it goes far, or runs, upon the land: (JK, Ḳ, TA:) pl. gub-aAnN. (TA.)
And Depressed land:pl. [of pauc.] OagobaAbN and [of mult.] gubuwbN (Ḳ, TA) and gub-aAnN. (TA.)

gib-N [a subst., like ZimoCN,] A coming (of camels, Ṣ, O) to water on alternate days; coming to the water one day and not the next day: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or after [being kept from it] a day and two nights: or pasturing one day and coming to the water the next day; and this is the gib- of the ass. (TA.) [And wirodu Algib-i signifies The coming of camels to the water in the second of two nights (as is shown by the context of a passage in which it occurs in the Ṣ and O and Ḳ voce TalaqN), or in the second of two days.] But the saying of a rájiz,
waHum-araAtN Xurobuhun-a gib-u
means And hummarahs [a species of birds] whose drinking is every hour or every little while (kul-a saAEapK). (Ṣ, O.)

Also [for sayoru gib-K] A journey of two days [whereof one is without any watering of the camels; i. e. in the case of which they are watered only on the first and third of three days]. (TA in art. nbj.)

And A visiting once in every week: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) so says El-Ḥasan: (Ṣ, O:) or at intervals of some days: after some days: (AA, IAth: [see also its verb:]) from the same word used in relation to camels. (IAth.) One says, zuro gib-FA tazodado Hub-FA [or, accord. to common usage, Hib-FA, to assimilate it to gib-FA, Visit once a week, or at intervals of some days; not frequently, or not every day: so thou shalt have more love: a prov., respecting which see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 587; where gub-FA is put for gib-FA]. (Ṣ, O.) [See another ex. voce taraj-ala, last sentence.] The saying of Zeyd-el-Fawáris
yaraAniI AlEaduw-u baEoda gib-i liqaAYihi
means [The enemy will see me] after the day of meeting with him by a day. (Ḥam p. 732.)
And The coming, or attacking, of a fever one day and intermitting one day: from the same word used in relation to camels. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.)
And A tertian fever; that attacks one day and intermits one day: (Ḳ, TA:) you say Hum-aI gib-N [a tertian fever]; using it as an epithet: (TA:) and Hum-aI Algib-i. (Mṣb in art. vlv.)

And The end; conclusion; latter, or last, part or state; issue; or result; syn. EaAqibapN, (Ṣ, A, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and MxirN; (Ṣ,* O,* TA;) of an affair, (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb,) of any kind, (Ṣ, O,) or of a thing; (Ḳ;) as also magab-apN↓, (MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and migab-N↓. (MA.) And [hence] gib-a means After; syn. baEoda: thus in the phrases gib-a AlOacaAni [After the call to prayer] and gib-a Als-alaAmi [After salutation or the salutation]: and one says,
gib-a AlS-abaAHi yaHomadu Alqawomu Als-uraI
[After daybreak, the party commend nightjourneying: but more commonly, Einoda AlS-abaAHi: see art. srI]. (TA.)
maMCN gib-N means Distant water: (A, TA:) and miyaAhN OagobaAbN distant waters. (A, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: gub-apN A sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and so guD-apN. (TA.)
And gub-apu, (Ṣ, O,) without Al, (Ḳ,) [and imperfectly decl.,] is the name of An eaglet that belonged to the Benoo-Yeshkur, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and to which a certain story, or tradition, relates. (Ṣ, O,)

entry.sense: gababN and gabogabN↓ The flesh that hangs down under the part beneath the chin and lower jaw: (Ḳ;) or what hangs down beneath that part of an ox or cow [i. e. the dewlap], and beneath the beak of the cock: (Ṣ, O:) and the wrinkled skin of the part where the lower hairs of the chin grow: and the former word, what hangs down under the part beneath the lower jaw of the ox or cow and of the sheep or goat: and the gbgb is [what hangs down under the part beneath the lower mandible] of the cock and of the bull [i. e. the wattle of the cock and the dewlap of the bull]: (Lth, TA:) and this is also used in relation to an old woman: (Ks, TA:) and, metaphorically, in relation to the chameleon: and in like manner in relation to the stallion-camel, [as meaning the part below the under jaw,] as the camel has really no gbgb: (TA:) [the pl. of gababN is OagobaAbN: see TimoTimN.]

hom.sense: gabiybN: see gaAb-N.

Also A small and narrow water-course, from the hard and elevated part of a mountain, or of a tract of land: or in plain. or level, land: (TA:) and a watercourse that is not deep, and in which are [trees of the species called] TaloH:pl. [of pauc.] Oagib-apN and [of mult.] gub-aAnN. (JK.)
[And An affair or a business (“res, negotium”). (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer.)]

entry.sense: gabiybapN Milk (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) of sheep or goats (Ṣ, O) drawn in the early morning, upon which other is milked at night, and which is then churned (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) on the morrow: (Ṣ, O:) [and] accord. to IAạr, camel's milk such as is termed muraw-ab [q. v.]: and the milk that is termed raAYib [q. v.]: (TA:) AʼObeyd is related on the authority of Sh to have assigned this last meaning to gbybp (TA, voce gabiybapN.)
gub-iy-apN and gib-iy-apN: see gub-iy-apN, in art. gb.
gaAb-N [part. n. of gab-a]. You say UibilN gaAb-apN and gawaAb-u Camels coming to water, or drinking, on alternate days. (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

And Flesh-meat that has remained throughout a night: (Ṣ, O:) or stinking flesh-meat: (TA:) or food, and dates, and, as also gabiybN↓, flesh-meat, that has remained throughout a night, whether it have become corrupt or not: (L:) and applied also to bread. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. byt.)
And najomN gaAb-N means A fixed star [app. because of its twinkling, or shining with intermitted light]. (A.)

hom.sense: gabogabN: see gababN.

Also A place where victims are sacrificed: (O, TA:) or Algabogabu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) particularly, (TA,) a small mountain, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) which is the place of sacrifice, (Ṣ, O,) in Minè: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the place in which was El-Lát, at Et-Táïf: or the place where they used there to sacrifice to El-Lát: or gabogabN is an appellation of any place of sacrifice in Minè. (TA.)

And Algabogabu is the name of An idol (SanamN), (O, Ḳ, TA,) which they used to worship in the Time of Ignorance, and upon which (Ealayohi) they used to sacrifice; (O, TA;*) and IDrd says that some called it Algabogabu [q. v.], with the unpointed E: (O:) or a stone which was set up before the idol, for, or [dedicated] to, Menáf, opposite the corner of the Black Stone [of the Kaabeh]; and there were two [whereof each was] thus called. (TA.)

entry.sense: tagib-apN False testimony: (Ḳ, TA:) of the measure tafoEilapN, [being originally tagobibapN,] from gab-aba Alc-iYobu fiI Alganami, or from gab-aba signifying “it became very corrupt.” (IAth, TA.)

hom.sense: rajulN magib-N [A man having a tertian fever, as is indicated in the TA,] is mentioned on the authority of AZ, in the form of an act. part. n. (TA.)
And Almugib-u means The lion. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: migab-N: see gib-N, last sentence but two.
magab-ahN: see gib-N, last sentence but two.

hom.sense: mugab-abapN A ewe, or goat, that is milked on alternate days. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And mugab-abN A bull having a gabab [or dewlap]. (Ḥam p. 293.)

entry.sense: [mutagab-ibN app. A man looking to the consequence, end, issue, or result, of an affair; like mutaEaq-ibN: see a verse in the Ḥam p. 154, and the verse next preceding it: and see its verb, above.]

1. gabava, (Ṣ, O,) aor. _a {yagobavu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. gabovN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) He moistened, and beat up, or mingled, [the preparation of curd called] OaqiT with clarified butter. (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) [See also Eabava, of which it is a dial. var.; and Eabavati AlmaroOapu, and Eabava AlOaqiTa.]
9. Agbv-, inf. n. AigobivaAvN, He, or it, was, or became, Oagobav, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) i. e., of a colour inclining to that of dust, (Ṣ,) or dust-coloured. (O.)
gubovapN [formed by transposition from bugovapN] A colour inclining to that of dust: (TA:) or dustcolour. (O.)
gabiyvapN [The preparation of curd called] OaqiT moistened, and beaten up, or mingled, with clarified butter. (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) [See also gabiyvapN, of which it is a dial. var.]
And I. q. gabiyvapN in its [other] meanings. (O,* Ḳ.)
Oagobavu i. q. Oabogavu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) from which it is formed by transposition, (Ṣ, O,) Of a colour inclining to that of dust: (TA:) or dust-coloured. (O.)

hom.sense: 1. gabara, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagoburu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gubuwrN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He, or it, (a thing, Ṣ) remained, lasted, or continued: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and (Mṣb) he (a man, JK) tarried, stayed, or waited. (JK, Zbd, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And He, or it, passed, passed away, or went away. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is sometimes used in this latter sense; (Mṣb;) and thus it has two contr. significations. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And It was future. (KL.)
See also 9.
gabira: see 5, last two sentences.

Also, this last, aor. _a {yagobaru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. gabarN, (Ṣ,) said of a wound, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It was, or became, in a corrupt state: (Ḳ:) or it became in a healing state, and then became recrudescent: (Ṣ:) or it was always recrudescent: and it became in a healing state upon, or over, corruptness: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) or it healed externally while in a withering state internally. (L.)
And [hence, perhaps,] gabira said of a man, † He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or hid enmity, or violent hatred, in his heart. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
2. gb-r Aln-aAqapa: see 5.
[Hence, app., as inf. n. of the pass. verb,] Alt-agobiyru signifies The milk's becoming drawn up or withdrawn [from the udder]. (TA.)
gb-rhu, inf. n. tagobiyrN, He sullied, or sprinkled, him, or it, with dust. (Ḳ.)
See also 4, in two places.

[Hence,] tagobiyrN signifies also A reciting of poetry, or verses, in the praising, or glorifying, of God, in which the performers trill, or quaver, and prolong, the voice; whence the epithet mugab-irap; as though the persons thus called, being affected with a lively emotion, danced, and raised the dust: thus accord. to Lth: (TA:) or the saying laA Uileha Uil-aA Qll-ehu, (IDrd, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA,) in the praising, or glorifying, of God: (Ḳ, TA:) or it signifies, (IDrd, TA,) or signifies also, (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA,) the reiterating the voice in reciting [the Ḳur-án], &c. (IDrd, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA) Esh-Shá- fi'ee is related to have said that, in his opinion, this tagobiyr was instituted by the zanaAdiqap [pl. of zinodiyqN, q. v.], in order that they might turn away [others thereby] from the [simple] praising, or glorifying, of God, and from the reciting of the Ḳur-án. (Az, TA.)
gb-r Dayofahu, inf. n. as above, He gave his guest, to eat, guboraAn [meaning dates thus termed]: (TA:) the verb thus used is like lah-aja [and lam-aja, &c.]. (L, TA.)
maA gab-arato Uil-aA liTalabi AlmiraMCi is a saying mentioned by AZ [app. meaning She did not oppose and then acquiesce save for the purpose of obstinate disputation]: see gabarN. (TA.)

4. Agbr He (a man) raised the dust; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also gb-r↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagobiyrN. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] gab-ara↓ fiI wajohihi [so, evidently, but written in the TA without any syll. signs, lit. He raised the dust in his face; meaning,] † he outwent him; outstripped him; went, or got, before him. (TA.)

And Agbr fiI Talabi AlHaAjapi † He strove, laboured, exerted himself, or employed himself vigorously or diligently, in seeking after the thing that he wanted; (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ;) he hasted, made haste, or was quick, in doing so; as though, by reason of his eagerness and quickness, he raised the dust. (TA.)
Oagobarotu fiI AlX-aIoCi † I set about, or commenced, doing the thing. (IḲṭṭ.)
Oagobarato EalayonaA Als-amaMCu † The sky rained upon us vehemently. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)
See also 9.
5. tgb-r Aln-aAqapa He milked the camel, drawing what remained in her udder; (Z, Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA;) as also gab-arahaA↓. (Ḥam p. 527.)

Hence the following saying, of a people who had increased and multiplied, on their being asked how it was that they had increased: kun-aA laA nalotabiYu AlS-agiyra walaA natagab-aru Alkabiyra † We used not to take the first seed of the young, nor the remainder of the seed of the old; meaning the marrying them, from eagerness to procreate. (TA. [But laA is there omitted in both clauses, and nalotabisu is put by mistake for nalotabiYu.]) [See also art. lbO.]

And hence, (TA,) tgb-r mina AlmaroOapi waladF (Ṣ, Ḳ) † He got offspring from the woman [she being old]. (Ḳ.) It is related that a certain man, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) an Arab of the desert, (Z,) ʼOthmán, accord. to the Ḳ, but correctly, as in the Genealogies of Ibn-El-Kelbee, Ghanm (ganomN) with gheyn moved by fet-ḥ, and a quiescent noon, (TA,) the son of Ḥabeeb (Ḳ, TA) the son of Kaab the son of Bekr the son of Yeshkur the son of Wáïl, (TA,) married a woman advanced in age, (Ṣ, Z,) Rakáshi the daughter of 'Ámir, (Ḳ,) and it was said to him, “She is old:” (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) whereupon he said, laEal-iI Oatagab-aru minohaA waladFA (Ṣ, Ḳ) May-be I shall get from her offspring: (TA:) and when a son was born to him, he named him gubaru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like gumaru; (Ṣ;) and he became the father of a tribe. (TA.)
tgb-r also signifies He, or it, became sullied, or sprinkled, with dust; (TA;) as also gabira↓. (L.) You say also gabira↓ Alt-amoru The dates, or dried dates, became dusty. (TA.)

entry.sense: 9. Agbr-, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. AigobiraArN, (Ṣ,) It was, or became, dust-coloured; of a colour like dust; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gabara↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. guyuwrN and guborapN; (TA;) and Oagobara↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UigobaArN. (TA.)
It (a day) became very dusty. (Aboo-ʼAlee, Ḳ.)

guborN A remain, remainder, remnant, relic, or residue, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of a thing; (Ḳ;) generally, of the blood of the menses, (Ḳ,) and of milk in the udder: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also gub-arN↓: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or gub-arN↓ is a pl. of guborN: [but if so it is extr.:] (TA:) or the pl. of guborN is OagobaArN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and gub-arN↓ is pl. of gaAbirN↓ [used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant]; (AʼObeyd, TA;) and signifies remains,, &c.: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA:) and gub-araAtN↓ is a pl. pl.; i. e., pl. of gub-arN↓. (AʼObeyd, TA.) You say bihaA guborN mino labanK In her (the camel) is a remain of milk. (Ṣ.) And gub-aru↓ AlHayoDi signifies The remains [of the blood] of the menses; (Ṣ;) as also guboruhu. (Ḥam p. 37.) And gub-aru↓ AlmaraDi The remains of the disease. (Ṣ.) And in like manner, gub-aru↓ All-ayoli (Ṣ) The last part, and the remains, of the night. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of ʼAmr Ibn-El-Ás, maA taOab-aTatoniI AlUimaMCu walaA HamalatoniI AlbagaAyaA fiI gub-araAti↓ AlmaMliI [Female slaves did not carry me under their armpits,] i. e., female slaves did not have the office of rearing me, nor did prostitutes carry me in the remains of the rags used for the menses. (TA.) And in another trad., falamo yaboqa Uil-aA gub-araAtN↓ mino Oaholi AlkitaAbi, or gub-aru↓ Oaholi AlkitaAbi, accord. to different relations, i. e. And there remained not save remains of the people of the Scripture, or the remains, &c. (TA.) And in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, bifanaAYihi OaEonuzN dar-uhun-a guyorN [In the court of his house were some she-goats whose flow of milk was a mere remain of what it had been,] meaning, little. (L.) [See also gaAbirN.]
giborN † Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or concealed enmity and violent hatred: (Ḳ, TA:) like gimorN. (TA.)

hom.sense: gabarN A remaining, lasting, or continuance; (TA;) and so magobarN↓. (Ḥam p. 225.)
[And by some of the grammarians it is used as signifying The future: see also gaAbirN.]
Also A certain disease in the interior of the foot of a camel. (Ḳ.)
And A morbid affection in a vein, that will hardly, or in nowise, be cured. (TA.) [See also gabirN.]

daAhiyapu Algabari (said by AʼObeyd to be from the phrase juroHN gabirN [q. v.], TA) means A calamity, or misfortune, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) of great magnitude, (Ṣ,) which, (JK, Ṣ,) or the like whereof, (Ḳ,) is such that no way of escape therefrom will be found: (JK, Ṣ,* Ḳ:*) or a trial, or an affliction, that will hardly, or in nowise, depart: (TA:) or a person who opposes thee, disagreeing with thee, and then returns, or has regard, to thy saying; (Ḳ, TA;) whence the saying, mentioned by AZ, maA gab-arato↓ Uil-aA liTalabi AlmiraMCi. (TA. [See 2, last sentence.])

Sam-aMCu Algabari, occurring in a verse of El-Hirmázee in praise of El-Mundhir Ibn-Járood, to whom it is applied, is expl. by Z as meaning The serpent that dwells near to a small water in a place where it collects and stagnates, and that will not be approached. (TA.) And [it is said that] Algabaru signifies Water little in quantity. (O.)
Also Dust, or earth; syn. turaAbN. (Ḳ.) [See also gubaArN.]
juroHN gabirN A wound in a corrupt state: (Ḳ:) or that becomes in a healing state upon, or over, corruptness, and then becomes recrudescent after having healed. (TA.)
Hence, EiroqN gabirN A vein constantly becoming recrudescent; (Ṣ, TA;) called in Pers. [and hence in Arabic] naAsuwr [q. v.]. (TA.)
naAqapN gadirapN gabirapN gamirapN A she-camel that remains, or lags, behind the other camels in being driven. (L in art. gdr.)

entry.sense: gaborapN A sullying, or sprinkle, of, or with, dust. (TA.)
guborapN Dust-colour; a colour like dust: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and a dusty hue of complexion arising from grief or anxiety and the like. (L.)
See also gubaArN.

hom.sense: gabarapN: see gubaArN:
and see also Oagobaru, latter half.

entry.sense: gaboraMCu: see gubayoraMCu. [For other meanings, see the masc., Oagobaru.]

guboraAnN Two ripe dates upon one base; pl. gabaAriynu: (Ḳ, TA:) so says AʼObeyd: or two, or three, full-grown unripe dates upon one base; and it has no pl. of its own radical letters: or, accord. to AḤn, several small green dates that come forth upon one base. (TA.)

guboruwrN A certain small bird of the passerine kind, (O, L, Ḳ, TA,) dust-coloured: (O, L, TA:) so says AḤát in the “Book of Birds:” pl. gabaAriyrN: (O:) it is the same as is mentioned in an earlier part of this art. in the Ḳ by the name of guboruwn↓, which is a mistranscription. (TA.)
guboruwnN: see what next precedes.

gubaArN and gabarapN↓ signify the same, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) as also guborapN↓; (IAạr, Ḳ:) i. e. Dust; syn. rahajN: (L:) or the first, dust raised and spreading: (L:) or what remains of dust raised and spreading: (B, TA:) and the second, the moving to and fro of dust. (L.)

You say Talaba fulaAnFA famaA Xaq-a gubaArahu † [He pursued after such a one but did not cleave his dust;] i. e., he did not overtake him. (TA.) And maA yuXaq-u gubaAruhu, and maA yuHaT-u gubaAruhu, † He is not to be outgone, outstripped, or got before. (TA.) [See also baAEa fulaAnN EalaI bayoEi fulaAnK, in art. byE.]

laA gubaAra Ealayohi † [There is no dust upon it; meaning, it (a phrase or the like) is clear, or perspicuous, or free from obscurity; like the saying laA Eafara fiyhi, or laA Eafora lahu]. (TA, in many places.)
gabiyrN A sort of dates. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: gubayoraMCu [dim. of gaboraMCu]: see Oagobaru, in two places.

Also A certain plant [or tree], (Ḳ,) well known, (Ṣ,) growing in the plains; (TA;) [the service-tree, or sorb: or its fruit: so called in the present day: as is also the “inula undulata:”] and so gaboraMCu↓: (Ḳ:) so called because of the colour of its leaves; the fruit of which, when it appears, becomes intensely red: (TA:) or the former is the tree, and the latter is the fruit: or the converse is the case: (Ḳ:) the sing. and pl. are alike: all this says AḤn, in his “Book of Plants.” (TA.)

Also A kind of beverage, (XaraAb, Ṣ, Ḳ, or nabiyc, Mṣb,) which intoxicates, made by the Abyssinians, (Ṣ,) from curap [or millet]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) also called sukurokap: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or wine [or cider] made from the wellknown fruit of the same name [the service-apple]. (Th, TA.) [See also mizorN.] It is said in a trad., Uiy-aAkumo waQlgubayoraMCa faUin-ahaA xamoru AlEaAlami (Ṣ, Mgh, TA) Avoid ye the beverage called gbyrAC; for it is like the wine that is commonly known of all men: there is no distinction to be made between the two drinks (Mgh, TA) with respect to prohibition. (TA.) In another trad., it is called gubayoraMCu Als-akari; to distinguish it from a kind of gbyrAC made of dates, or dried dates. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: gub-arN and gub-araAtN: see guborN, passim.

hom.sense: gaAbirN Remaining; lasting; continuing: (Az, Ṣ, IAmb, Mgh:) this is the sense in which it is used by the Arabs: (Az:) or it is the meaning most commonly obtaining among them: (IAmb:) tarrying; staying; waiting: pl. gub-arN: (Ḳ:) and the pl. of gaAbirapN is gawaAbiru. (TA.) You say qawomN gub-arN [A people remaining,, &c.]. (TA.) And guy-aru Aln-aAsi The later of mankind. (TA.) And huwa gaAbiru baniI fulaAnK He is the relic of the sons of such a one. (TA.) And AlgaAbiru mina All-ayoli What remains of the night. (TA.) And jawofu All-ayoli AlgaAbiru The last division of the night. (Mgh.) And AlEaXoru AlgawaAbiru mino Xahori ramaDaAna The remaining, or last, ten nights of the month of Ramadán. (TA.) And qaTaEa Qll-ehu gaAbirahu wadaAbirahu [May God cut off the last, and what remains, of him, or it: or may God extirpate him]. (TA.) See also guborN

Passing; passing away; going away: past: syn. maADK; (Az, Ṣ, IAmb, Mgh;) or caAhibN: (Ḳ:) so accord. to some of the lexicologists: (Az:) or so used sometimes, as, for instance, by the poet El-Aạshà: (IAmb:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (Ṣ.) You say, Oanota gaAbirN gadFAwacikoruka gaAbirN OabadFA [Thou passest away to-morrow, but thy fame remaineth for ever]. (TA.)

[Future time. See an ex. in the first of the verses cited voce Hayovu. The meaning of “remaining” seems equally appropriate in that verse: but gAbr is often used by grammarians in the last of the senses expl. above.]

entry.sense: gawobarN: see gubarN.
AlgaAbirapu means AlbaAqiyapu [The lasting, or everlasting, state of existence]; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. AlMxirapu [the latter, or last, state]. (TA.)
Oagobaru Dust-coloured; of a colour like dust: (Ṣ:) [fem. gaboraMCu: and pl. guborN.]
AlOagobaru † The wolf; (Ḳ, TA;) because of his [dusty] colour: like AlOagovaru. (TA.)
And AlgaboraMCu † The female of the Hajal [or partridge]. (Ḳ.)
Also (AlgaboraMCu) ‡ The earth; (Ṣ, IAth, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because of its dusty colour; or because of the dust that is upon it: (TA:) opposed to AlxaDoraMCu, which means “the sky,” or “heaven.” (IAth.)

And you say, jaMCa EalaI gaboraMCi AlZ-ahori † He came on foot: (Z, TA:) [i. e.] he came upon the earth, or ground; and so jaMCu EalaI gubayoraMCi↓ AlZ-ahori: (M, TA:) or the latter means, he returned without his having obtained, or attained, anything: (T, TA:) or he returned without his having been able to accomplish the object of his want. (El-Aḥmar, TA.) And tarakahu EalaI gubayoraMCi↓ AlZ-ahori † He left him in the possession of nothing: (M, TA:) accord. to Zeyd Ibn-Kethweh, it is said by one who has contended in an altercation with another and overcome him so as to become master of all that was in his hands: in all the copies of the Ḳ, [probably in consequence of an omission by an early transcriber,] it is expl. as meaning he returned disappointed, or unsuccessful; and so trkh ElI gaboraMCi AlZhr. (TA.)

banuw AlgaboraMCi † The poor, needy, or indigent; (Ṣ, IB, Ḳ, TA;) [to which is strangely added in one of my copies of the Ṣ and the guests;] so called because of their cleaving to the dust: (IB, TA:) and gaboraMCu Aln-aAsi likewise means the poor of mankind: or, as some say, the former means strangers from their homes: (TA:) or strangers, (Ḳ,) or persons, (TA,) who assemble together for [the drinking of] beverage, or wine, without mutual acquaintance: (Ḳ, TA:) or persons who contribute equally to the expenses which they have to incur in journeys: all of these meanings have been assigned to it in explaining a verse of Tarafeh: [see EM p. 85:] and it is also expl. in the A as meaning persons of whom one knows not to what family, or tribe, they belong: (TA:) and [it is said that] Aibonu gaboraMCa signifies the thief, or robber. (T in art. bnI.)
gaboraMCu also signifies † Land abounding with coverts of the kind termed xamar [q. v.]: (TA:) and land abounding with trees; (Ḳ;) or so OaroDN gaboraMCu; (TA;) as also gabarapN↓. (Ḳ.)
Also † Herbage in plain, or soft, land. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [This is said in the TA to be more probably with v; but I do not find any meaning like this assigned to gavoraMCu.]
And † A species of plant. (Ṣ. [App. that called gubayoraMCu, q. v.])
waToOapN gaboraMCu † A footstep, or footprint, that is becoming obliterated, or effaced: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or such as is recent. (Ḳ. [See also dahomaMCu, voce Oadohamu.])
And Eiz-N Oagabaru † Might departing; (Ḳ, TA;) becoming effaced. (TA.)

sanapN gaboraMCu † A year of drought; (IAth, Ḳ;) a year in which is no rain: (TA in art. Xhb:) pl. guborN: so called because of the dustiness of the tracts of the horizon therein from paucity [or want] of rain, and of the ground from there being no herbage. (IAth.)
And juwEN Oagobaru † Severe hanger or famine. (TA.)
magobarN: see gabarN, first sentence.
mugobar-N A camel the interior of whose foot is in a withering state. (Aṣ, TA.)

mugab-irapN A party of men praising, or glorifying, God, by saying laA Uileaha Uil-aA Qll-ehu, and reiterating the the voice in reciting [the Ḳur-án] &c.: (Lth, Ḳ, TA:) accord. to Zj, (TA,) so called because of their exciting men to be desirous of the gaAbirap, which means the baAqiyap [or lasting, or everlasting, state of existence], (Ḳ, TA,) and to be undesirous of the evanescent, which is the present, state (TA.) [See 2.]

hom.sense: migobaArN A palm-tree (naxolapN) that becomes overspread with dust. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
And A she-camel that abounds with milk after the abounding therewith of those that have brought forth with her. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mugobuwrN i. q. mugovuwrN [q. v.]: (Kr, Ḳ:) the latter is the more approved term. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. gabasa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagobusu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. gabosN; (TA;) and gabisa, aor. _a {yagobasu}, inf. n. gabasN and gubosapN; (IḲṭṭ, TA;)
and Oagobasa↓, (Ḳ,) in some copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, Aigobas-a; (TA;) and AigobaAs-a↓; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) It (the night, TA) was, or became, dark. (Ḳ.) [See also gabiXa.]
gabasa wajohahu He blackened his face. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.
Agbs Alc-iYobu, inf. n. UigobaAsN, [The wolf was, or became, of the colour termed gabas, and gubosap.] (TA.)
11: see the first paragraph {1}.

gabasN The darkness of the end, or last part, of the night; as also gabaXN: (Lth:) or the darkness of the beginning, or first part, of the night; and gbX, that of the end, or last part, thereof: (TA:) or the former has the first of the abovementioned significations; as also galasN; and gbX, the second of those significations. (El-Khattábee, MF.) [See also gabaXN.] And Darkness [absolutely]; as also gubosapN↓: or ↓both signify whiteness in which is a duskiness or dinginess: (Ḳ:) or the former, (Ṣ,) and ↓the latter, (A,) a colour like that of ashes; (Ṣ, A;) i. e., whiteness in which is a duskiness or dinginess: (Ṣ:) or ↓the latter, a hue between dust-colour inclining to black and dust-colour properly so called: (IDrd:) or a colour between black and yellow. (TA.) [See also galasN.]
gubosapN: see gabasN, in four places.

laA Mtiyka maA gabaA gubayosN means I will not come to thee ever: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but the origin of this saying is unknown: (Ḳ:) IAạr said that he knew it not: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to him, it means, while time lasts: it seems that he did not know it at first, and then thus explained it: (T, TA:) accord. to some, gubayosN is an abbreviated dim. of Oagobasu, and means the wolf; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) and gabaA is originally gab-a, the A being substituted for one of the letters of duplication, as in taqaD-aI for taqaD-aDa; (Ṣ;) and the saying means I will not come to thee as long as the wolf comes now and then (yaOotiI gib-FA) to the sheep or goats. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

Oagobasu Ash-coloured; (Mgh;) of a colour like that of ashes; (Ṣ;) of a dingy, or dusky, white; applied to a wolf: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it is an epithet applied to any wolf: or, applied to a wolf, light, or active, and greedy: fem. gabosaMCu: (TA:) pl. gubosN. (Ḳ.)
Applied to an ass, Black. (TA.)
warodN Oagobasu, applied to a horse, [app., Of a dusky bay colour;] i. q. samanod; (Mgh, Ḳ;) what the Persians call by the latter term: (Ṣ, TA:) it is [a colour] desired by them. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gabiXa, aor. _a {yagobaXu} (inf. n. gabaXN; TḲ) and OagobaXa↓; It (the night) had somewhat remaining of it: (Ḳ, TḲ:) or was dark in its end, or last part, (O, Ḳ, TḲ,) with a darkness intermixed with whiteness: (TḲ:) or both of these verbs; (TA;) or gabaXa, (aor. _i {yagobiXu} TA) and OagobaXa↓; (AʼObeyd, O, TA;) it (the night) was, or became, dark, (AʼObeyd, O, TA,) in its end. (O.) [See also gabaXN, below: and see Eabisa.]
gabaXahu, (aor. _i {yagobiXu} TA) i. q. gaXamahu [He wronged him,, &c.]. (Aboo-Málik, O, TA. [See also 5.])
And He deceived him, Eano HaAjatihi [of the object of his want]. (Lḥ, O, TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in two places.
5. tgb-Xhu He wronged him: (O, Ḳ: [see also 1:]) or he made a false claim upon him: (Ḳ, TA:) or so tgb-Xhu bidaEowaI baATilapK: (O:) so says Aṣ: (O, TA:) and tEb-Xhu is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)

gabaXN The darkness [or duskiness] of the end, or last part, of the night; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also guboXapN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) or of the part next to daybreak: or when daybreak commences: and sometimes in the beginning, or first part, of the night: (TA:) or the remains of darkness mixed with the whiteness of daybreak, so that the true dawn (AlxayoTu AlOaboyaDu) becomes distinguished from the false dawn (AlxayoTu AlOasowadu); as also gabasN and galasN: (Az, TA:) or a remaining portion of the night; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gabaXu AlS-uboHi: (Mgh:) or intense darkness: pl. OagobaAXN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.) OagobaAXu All-ayoli and OagobaAsuhu both signify The remains of the night. (Yaạḳoob, TA.) [See also gabasN.]
gabiXN: see OagobaXu.
guboXapN: see gabaXN.
Also Intense blackness with smoothness; like dulomapN; in the colours of beasts or horses and the like. (TA.)
gaAbiXN A wronger,, &c., syn. gaAXimN, (AZ, O, TA,) in the Ḳ, erroneously, gaAmiX, (TA,) of others: (AZ, O, TA:) and a dishonest adviser, syn. gaAX-N, (Ḳ, TA,) of them: (TA:) and a deceiver. (Ḳ, TA.)
OagobaXu A dark night; as also gabiXN↓. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
A beast or horse or the like of the colour termed guboXapN: fem. gaboXaMCu. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gabaTahu aor. _i {yagobiTu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. gaboTN, (Ṣ,) He felt with his hand his (a ram's) Oaloyap [i. e. rump, or tail, or fat of the tail,] in order to see if he were fat or not: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and he felt it (his back) with his hand in order to know whether he were lean or fat: (Lth, Ḳ:*) and in like manner the verb is used in relation to a she-camel. (TA.)

gabaTahu, aor. _i {yagobiTu}; (ISk, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and gabiTahu, aor. _a {yagobaTu}; (Ibn-Buzurj, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) inf. n. gaboTN (ISk, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and giboTapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) He regarded him [with unenvious emulation, i. e.] with a wish for the like of his condition, (ISk, Az, Ṣ,) meaning a good condition, (Az,) or for the like of that which he had attained, (Mṣb,) or for a blessing, (Ḳ,) and that it might not pass away, (ISk, Ḳ,) or without desiring that it should pass away, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb,) from the latter person: (ISk, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the doing so is not HasadN, (Az, Ṣ, Mṣb,) for this implies the desire that what is wished for may pass away from its possessor; (Az, Mṣb;) or it is a kind of Hasad, of a more moderate quality: (Az:) or giboTapN and gaboTN have the signification shown above, and are also syn. with HasadN; (Ḳ;) this latter meaning is assigned to gaboTN by IAạr; and it is said that the Arabs use gaboTN in the sense of HasadN metonymically; (TA;) [so that gabaTahu and gabiTahu may also mean ‡ he envied him;, &c.; see an ex. in a prov. cited voce baTonN; but it is said that] HasadN, when it is for courage and the like, is syn. with giboTapN, and then it implies admiration, without a wish that the thing admired may pass away from its possessor. (Mṣb in art. Hsd.) You say, gabaTahu bihi, (Ṣ,) and Ealayohi, (IAth,) and fiyhi, (Mṣb,) He regarded him with a wish for the like of it, meaning a thing or state which he had attained, without desiring that it should pass away from the latter person. (Ṣ, IAth,* Mṣb.) Moḥammad was asked, “Does AlgaboT injure?” and he answered, “Yes, like as AlxaboT injures:” or, accord. to the relation of AʼObeyd, “No, save as AlxaboT injures the [trees called] EiDaAh:” (Az, TA:) [see xabaTa:] by AlgyT meaning, accord. to some, AlHasad: (TA:) or a kind thereof, of a more moderate quality; injurious, but not so injurious as AlHsd whereby one wishes that a blessing may pass away from his brother; AlxbT meaning the beating off the leaves of trees; after which they become replaced, without there resulting any injury therefrom to the stock and branches: moreover, AlgbT sometimes occasions the smiting of its object with the evil eye. (Az, TA.) [See also giboTapN, below.]
Accord. to IḲṭṭ, gabaTa signifies also He lied; but perhaps it is a mistranscription for EabaTa, which has this meaning; for it is not mentioned by any other. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. It is said in a trad., jaMCa wahumo yuSal-uwna fayajoEala yugab-iTuhumo; thus it is related, meaning, [He came to them while they were praying, and he began] to incite them to wish for the like of that action: if related without teshdeed, [yagobiTuhumo,] the meaning is, to regard them with a wish for the like condition, because of their forwardness to prayer. (Nh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4: see 8.
AgbT Alr-aHola EalaI Zahori AlbaEiyri, (Ṣ,) or ElI Ald-aAb-api, (Ḳ,) He kept the saddle constantly (Ṣ, Ḳ) upon the back of the camel, (Ṣ,) or upon the beast, (Ḳ,) not putting it down from him. (Ṣ.)

UigobaATN also signifies The continuing constantly riding. (ISk.) And OagobaTuwA EalaI rikaAbihimo fiI Als-ayori They kept the saddles on their travellingcamels night and day, not putting them down, in journeying. (ISh.)

Hence, (A, TA,) OagobaTato Ealayohi AlHum-aI ‡ The fever continued upon him; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as though it set the gabiyT upon him, to ride him; like as you say, rakibatohu AlHum-aI, and AimotaTatohu, and AirotaHalatohu: (A, TA:) or clave to him: (TA:) or did not quit him for some days; as also OagomaTato, and Oarodamato. (Aṣ.)

And OagobaTati Als-amaMCu ‡ The sky rained continually. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)
And OagobaTa EalayonaA AlmaTaru ‡ The rain continued upon us incessantly, rain following close upon rain. (Aboo-Kheyreh.)
And OagobaTa Aln-abaAtu ‡ The herbage covered the land, and became dense, as though it were from a single grain. (Ḳ, TA.)

8. AgtbT He was, or became, regarded [with unenvious emulation, i. e.,] with a wish for the like of his condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him: (Ṣ:) or he was, or became, in such a condition that he was regarded with a wish for the like thereof, without its being desired that it should pass away from him: (Táj el-Masádir, TA:) or he rejoiced, or became rejoiced, in being in a good condition; (Ḳ;) or in blessing bestowed upon him: (TA:) or he was grateful, or thankful, to God for blessing, or bounty, bestowed upon him: (L:) and the same, (Ḳ,) or OagobaTa↓, inf. n. UigobaATN, accord. to the L, (TA,) he was, or became, in a good state or condition; in a state of happiness; (L, Ḳ;) and of enjoyment, or wellbeing. (L.) You say, laqiIa maA yugotabaTu Ealayohi [He met with, or experienced, that for which one would be regarded with unenvious emulation, i. e., with a wish to be in the like condition, without its being desired that it should pass away from him]. (TA in art. fwz.)

The saying,
xaw-aI qaliylFA gayora maA QgotibaATi
cited by Th, but not expl. by him, is held by ISd to mean [He (referring to a camel) lay down, or did so making his belly to be separated somewhat from the ground], not resting upon a wide gabiyT [q. v.] of ground, but upon a place not even, and not depressed. (TA.)
gaboTN [originally an inf. n.]: see giboTapN.

Also, and giboTN↓, Handfuls of reaped corn or seed-produce: pl. gubuwTN, (Ḳ, TA,) and, it is said, gubuTN: or [rather] accord. to Et-Táïfee, gubuwTN signifies the handfuls which, when the wheat is reaped, are put one by one; and gaboTN is the sing.: or, as AḤn says, gubuwTN signifies the scattered handfuls of reaped corn or seed-produce; one of which is termed gaboTN. (TA.)

entry.sense: giboTN: see the next preceding paragraph.

guboTapN A strap in the [leathern water-bag called] mazaAdap, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) like the XiraAk [of the sandal], (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O,) which is put upon the extremities of the two skins [whereof the mzAdp is mainly composed] and then strongly sewed. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

giboTapN A good state or condition; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a state of happiness; (L, Ḳ;) and of enjoyment, or wellbeing; (L;) as also gaboTN↓, in the saying, Aall-ehum-a gaboTFA laA haboTFA, meaning, O God, we ask of Thee a good state or condition [&c.], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and we put our trust in Thee for preservation that we may not be brought down from our state, (Ṣ, TA,) or that we may not be abased and humbled: (TA:) or place us in a station for which we may be regarded [with unenvious emulation, i. e.,] with a wish to be in the like condition without its being desired that it should pass away from us, (Ḳ,* TA,) and remove from us the stations of abasement and humiliation: (TA:) or [we ask of Thee] exaltation, not humiliation; and increase of thy bounty, not declension nor diminution. (TA.) [See also 1, second sentence.]
samaMCN gabaTaI ‡ A sky raining continually (Jm, Ḳ) during two or three days; (Jm;) as also gamaTaI. (TA.)
gayuwTN A she-camel whose fatness is not to be known unless she be felt with the hand. (Ḳ, TA.)

gabiyTN A [camel's saddle of the kind called] raHol, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) for women, (Ṣ,) upon which the [vehicle called] hawodaj is bound: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or an elegant kind of raHol, depressed in its middle: (TA:) or a vehicle like the pads (Oukuf [in the CK, erroneously, Aakuf-]) of the [species of camels called] baxaAtiI-, (Ḳ,) which is tented over with a [framework such as is called] XijaAz, and is for women of birth: (Az, TA:) or, as some say, of which the pad (qatab) is made not in the [usual] make of pads (OaqotaAb): (TA:) or a rHl of which the pad (qatab) and the [curved wooden parts called] OaHonaMC are one [i. e., app., conjoined]: (Ḳ:) pl. gubuTN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The pl. is also applied to the pieces of wood in camels' saddles; and to such are likened Persian bows, (Ṣ, TA,) because of their curvature. (IAth.)

[Hence,] † Depressed land or ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a wide and even tract of land of which the two extremities are elevated, (Ḳ,) like the form of the camel's saddle so called, of which the middle is depressed: (TA:) also † a channel of water furrowed in a tract such as is termed quf-, (Ḳ, TA,) like a valley in width, having between it and another such channel meadows and herbage: pl. as above. (TA.)

hom.sense: gaAbiTN act. part. n. of 1, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as expl. in the first sentence: (Ṣ:)
and also as expl. in the second sentence: (Ḳ:) pl., accord. to the Ḳ, gubuTN, like kutubN; but correctly, gub-aTN, like suk-arN, as in the L. (TA.)

entry.sense: farasN mugobaTu AlkaAvibapi ‡ A horse high in the withers; likened to the form of the gabiyT; accord. to Lth: in the A, as though he had on him a gbyT. (TA.)

OaroDN mugobaTapN, with fet-ḥ, (Ḳ,) i. e., in the form of the pass. part. n., not with fet-ḥ, to the first letter, (TA,) Land covered with dense herbage, as though it were from a single grain. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
sayorN mugobaTN † Journey continued without rest; as also mugomaTN. (ISh.)
Hum-aI mugobiTapN ‡ Continual fever. (TA.)
mugotabaTN and mugotabiTN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1. gabaqahu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagobuqu} (Ṣ, O, TA) and _i {yagobiqu}, (TA,) inf. n. gaboqN; (O, TA;) and gb-qhu↓, inf. n. tagobiyqN; (TA;) He gave him to drink an eveningdraught, or what is termed a gabuwq. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) laA Oagobiqu qabolahumaA OaholFA walaA maAlFA, in a trad. respecting the companions of the cave [to which allusion is made in the Ḳur ix. 40], in which the verb is thus written by El-Yooneenee with kesr to the b, means I did not give to drink to any one [of family nor of cattle] the share [of the evening-draught] of milk of them two. (TA.)

2: see the next preceding paragraph {1}. One says also gb-q AlUibila, and Alganama, He gave to drink to the camels, and the sheep or goats, in the evening: or he milked them in the evening: and Agtbq↓ Aln-aAqapa he milked the she-camel after sunset. (TA. [See also 5.])
5. tgb-q He milked in the evening. (Lḥ, O, Ḳ. [See also what next precedes.])
And He drank in the evening. (TA. [See also what next follows {8}.])

8. Agtbq, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. AigotibaAqN, (TA,) and mugotabaqN may be an inf. n. as well as a n. of place, (O, Ḳ,) He drank an evening-draught, or what is termed a gabuwq. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [See also what next precedes.])
And Agtbq labanahaA He drank her (a camel's) milk in the evening. (TA.)
See also 2.
gaboqapN A single case of the evening-drink, or of what is termed gabuwq. (TA.)

gabaqapN A string, or cord, (IDrd, O, Ḳ,) or a plaited thong (EaraqapN), (IDrd, O,) which is tied to the transverse piece of wood upon the hump of the bull [in the TA of the camel, or, accord. to the T, of the bull,] when he [draws the plough that] turns over the ground for cultivation, or is used for the drawing of water [to irrigate land in the manner expl. voce saAniyapN], in order that the piece of wood may be firm. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)

gaboqaAnu, applied to a man, and gaboqaI [for which the CK has gaboqaMCu], applied to a woman, (O, Ḳ, TA,) epithets similar to SaboHaAnu and SaboHaI, (O,) irregularly formed, for faEolaAnu is not to be formed from AifotaEala nor from tafaE-ala, (TA,) Who has drunk an evening-draught, or what is termed a gayuwq. (Ḳ.)

gabuwqN An evening-draught; i. e. a draught, drink, or potation, [and particularly of milk, but also applied to one of water, and of wine, &c.,] that is drunk in the evening, or the last, or latter, part of the day. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [See also SabuwHN.]) See an ex. in a verse of Khuzaz Ibn-Lowdhán cited voce kacaba. One of the Arabs said to a companion of his, Uino kunota kaAcibFA faXaribota gabuwqFA baAridFA [If thou be tying, then mayest thou drink a cold evening-draught]; meaning, may there not be milk for thee, so that thou shalt drink water not mixed with anything; this being called by him gbwq by way of comparison: or meaning, may that be to thee in the place of gbwq. (TA.)
And one says, laqaytuhu caA gabuwqK [lit. I met him at a time of drinking the evening-draught], meaning, in the evening; a phrase used only adverbially; like caA SabuwHK: (TA:) and caAta Algabuwqi [which has a similar meaning]. (T in art. cuw.)
Also, and with p {gabuwqapN}, A she-camel whose milk one drinks in the evening: or, accord. to Lḥ, that is milked after sunset: epithets like SabuwHN and SabuwHapN. (TA.)
mugotabaqN an inf. n. [of 8, q. v.]: and also a n. of place [signifying A place in which one drinks the draught termed gayuwq]. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gabanahu, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagobinu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gabonN (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL) and gabanN, or the former is [the inf. n. used in this case, i. e.] in selling [and the like], and the latter is in judgment, or opinion, (Ḳ, agreeably with a positive statement in the Ṣ,) He cheated, deceived, overreached, or defrauded, him, (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ, KL, TA,) in selling; (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ, TA;) he endamaged him, or made him to suffer loss or damage or detriment, (Mṣb, KL, TA,) in selling, (KL, TA,), &c., (KL,) or in the price, or otherwise: (Mṣb:) [or] he overcame him in selling and buying. (Mṣb.) And gubina He was cheated, or deceived [&c. in a purchase]: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and Angbn↓ [in like manner signifies] he became [cheated or endamaged or] overcome in selling and buying. (Mṣb.) And it is said that gabana fiI AlbayoEi, inf. n. gabonN, signifies He was unmindful, or inadvertent, [or perhaps gabana is here a mistranscription for gubina, signifying thus, and therefore meaning he was made to suffer loss,] in selling or in buying. (TA.) And one says also, gubina Alr-ajulu OaXad-a AlgabanaAni [The man was cheated or deceived, &c. with the utmost degree of cheating, &c.]. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) gabonN yasiyrN [A petty overreaching or endamaging] is one of which the rate is such as has been estimated [as allowable by custom] by one estimator, not by every one: and gabonN faAHiXN [An exorbitant overreaching or endamaging] is one of which the rate is such as has not been estimated [as allowable by custom] by any one. (Dict. of Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans.) [Algubonu waAlgabanu mentioned by Freytag as occurring in the Fákihet el-Khulafà, and expl. by him as meaning “Fraus omnimoda,” should, I doubt not, be Algabonu waAlgabanu, the two inf. ns. mentioned in the first sentence above.]

gabanahu, aor. _i {yagobinu}, inf. n. gabonN, signifies also He passed by him (i. e. a man) inclining, or leaning, [or bending down, so as as to elude his observation, i. e.] so that he [the latter] did not see him, and was not cognizant of him. (TA.)

[And it is said in the TA that gayanuwA Aln-aAsa means None but they obtained it: whence it appears that fiyhi or the like has been omitted after Aln-aAsa: with this addition, the phrase may be rendered, they overreached, or prevented, the other people in respect of it, by obtaining it themselves.]
hecaA yagobinu Eaqolaka, said to a man whom another had cheated (gabana) in a sale, means This [man] attributes defect, or imperfection, to thy intellect. (TA.)

qado gabanuwA xabarahaA, and gabinuwA, aor. of the former verb _u, and of the latter _a, i. e. lamo yaEolamuwA EilomahaA [meaning They have not know her case or state or condition, or her qualities], (ISh, Ḳ, ast; TA,) is a phrase relating to a she-camel, of which it is said that she is what one would desire a she-camel to be as a beast for riding and in generousness of race, but she is magobuwnapN↓, [i. e.] one of which the qualities are not known to be as above mentioned. (ISh, TA.)
gabanota raOoyaka [if not a mistranscription for gabinota (see gabina raOoyahu in what follows)] means Thou hast lost, and forgotten, thy judgment, or opinion. (TA.)

gabina AlX-aYo and fiI AlX-aYo, aor. _a {yagobanu}, inf. n. gabonN and gabanN, signify He forgot the thing: or he was unmindful, neglectful, or heedless, of it; (Ḳ, TA;) and ignorant of it: (TA:) or he made a mistake in respect of it; (Ḳ, TA;) as in the saying, gabina kacaA mino Haq-ihi Einoda fulaAnK [he made a mistake in respect of such a thing, of his right, or due, to be required at the hand of such a one]. (TA.)

gabina raOoyahu, inf. n. gabanN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gabaAnapN, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) means He was, or became, deficient in his judgment, or opinion: (Ṣ:) or he was, or became, weak [therein]: (Ḳ:) or his intelligence, or sagacity, and his sharpness, or acuteness, of mind, went away: (Mṣb:) the parsing of this phrase has been [fully] expl. voce safiha [q. v.]. (Ṣ.)

gabana Alv-awoba, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. gabonN, (Ḳ,) from magobinN [q. v.], (Mṣb,) He folded, or doubled, the garment, (T, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) it being [too] long. (T, TA,) and then sewed it; (Mgh, Mṣb;) like xabanahu [q. v.] (Ṣ, Mgh) and kabanahu. (Mgh.) And gabana Ald-alowa He folded, or doubled, [the edge of] the leathern bucket, to shorten it. (TA: but only the inf. n. of the verb thus used is there mentioned.)

And gabana AlX-aYo He hid, or concealed, the thing in the magobin [or armpit or groin or the like]; (TA;) as also Agtbnhu↓. (Ḳ, TA.) gabana AlT-aEaAma is like xabanahu [i. e. He concealed, kept, or stored, wheat, or food, for a time of dearth, or adversity.] (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 3: see 6, first sentence.

6. tagaAbunN signifies Mutual gabon [i. e. cheating or endamaging or overcoming in selling and buying: and mugaAbanapN↓ signifies the same; or mutual endeavoring to cheat, &c.: see 3 in art zbn]. (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ, KL, TA.) Hence, yawomu Alt-agaAbuni [in the Ḳur lxiv. 9], an appellation of The day of resurrection; because the people of Paradise will then overreach (tagobinu) the people of Hell, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) by the state of enjoyment in which the former will become and the punishment which the latter will experience; or, as El-Ḥasan says, because the former will attribute defect, or imperfection, to the intellects of the latter by reason of the preferring infidelity to faith. (TA.)

And tgAbn lh [i. e. lahu, but this, I think, is probably a mistranscription for bihi,] signifies taqaAEada [i. e. tqAEd bihi, meaning He did not pay him his due,] Hat-aI gubina [so that he was cheated or endamaged or overcome]. (TA.)
7: see 1, second sentence.
8: see 1, last sentence but one.
10. Astgbnhu and tgb-nhu↓ [app. signify He esteemed him gabiyn, i. e. weak in judgment, and therefore liable to be cheated or endamaged]. (TA in art. zbn: see 10 in that art.)

hom.sense: gabanN [mentioned above as an inf. n.,] Weakness: and forgetfulness. (Ḳ.)
And What is cut off from the extremities of a garment, and thrown down, or let fall. (TA.)

entry.sense: gabiynN Weak in his judgment, or opinion; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and in intellect, and in religion; (TA;) and magobuwnN↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ, TA.)
gabaAnapN [mentioned above as an inf. n. (see gabina raOoyahu),] Weakness of judgment, or opinion. (Ṣ.)

gabiynapN [The act of cheating, deceiving, overreaching, or defrauding; or of endamaging; in selling or the like;] a subst. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) from [the inf. n.] gabonN, like XatiymapN from XatomN, (Ṣ,) [or] from gabanahu (Mṣb, Ḳ) used in relation to selling, (Ḳ,) or in relation to a price, &c. (Mṣb.)
gaAbinN Remiss, or languid, in work. (Ḳ.)

magobinN sing. of magaAbinu, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which signifies The OarofaAg, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the MbaAT, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [i. e. the groins and the armpits, and the like; (see rafogN;)] or the places of flexure, or creasing, of the skin: the sing. is expl. by Th as signifying any part upon which one folds his thigh. (TA.)
magobuwnN pass. part. n. of 1 signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art. [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also gabiynN.
magobuwnapN applied to a she-camel: see 1, latter half.
1. gabiIa, aor. yagobaI, inf. n. gabFA and gabaAwapN, [the latter of which is the more common,] He had little [or no] intelligence. (Mṣb.)

And gabiIa AlX-aYo (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, in the CK [erroneously] gabaI,) or AlOamora, (Mṣb,) and gabiIa Eani AlX-aYo (Ṣ, Ḳ) or Eani AlOamori, (Mṣb,) aor. as above, (Ṣ,) inf. n. gabaAwapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gabFA, (Ḳ,) He did not understand (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) the thing (Ṣ, Ḳ) or the affair. (Mṣb.) And gabiIa Eani Alxabari He was ignorant of the information. (Mṣb.)

And in like manner, EabiIa EalaI-a AlX-aYo, inf. n. gabFA, [The thing was not understood, or not known, by me; or] I knew not the thing: (Ṣ:) [or] gabiIa AlX-aIoCu minohu i. e. xafiIa [the thing was hidden from him], (Ḳ, TA,) so that he did not know it: (TA:) and gabaA is used in the dial. of Teiyi for gabiIa in the sense of xafiIa: (A and TA in art. gbs:) or it is for gab-a, like taqaD-aI for taqaD-aDa. (Ṣ in that art. [See gubayosN: and see also gabiyapN, in art. gbI.])
5. tgb-Ahu: see 10.

6. tgAbI i. q. tagaAfala, (Ṣ, MA, TA,) i. e. He was, or he feigned himself, unmindful,, &c. (MA.) So in the phrase tgAbI Eanohu: (TA: [see tagaAfala and tagaf-ala:]) and one says tgAbAhu [also, app. in the same sense]. (IAạr, TA in art. EmX.)
10. AstgbAhu and tgb-Ahu↓ [app. He esteemed him unintelligent, or one having little intelligence] (TA in art. zbn: see 10 in that art.)
fiyhi gabowapN and gubuw-apN↓ and gubiy-N↓ In him is unmindfulness, forgetfulness, neglectfulness, heedlessness, or inadvertence. (Ḳ.)
[gabaApN Stupidity. (Freytag, from El-Meydánee.)]
gabaMCN Low, or depressed, ground. (Ḳ, TA.) And A thing that is hidden, or concealed, from one. (TA.)
And Earth, or dust, that is put over a thing to conceal it from one. (TA.) [See also art. gbI.]

gabiI-N Having little, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or no, (Ḳ,) intel-ligence: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or one who does not understand deceit, or guile, and the like: (T, TA:) or unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent: (TA:) and ignorant: (Mṣb:) pl. OagobiyaMCu (IAth, Mṣb, TA) and OagobiyaMCN: (IAth, TA:) accord. to J and others, (TA,) it belongs to this art.; (Ṣ, TA;) but Aboo-ʼAlee derives it from XajarapN gaboyaMCu, [see OagobaI in art. gbI,] as though his ignorance hid from him to whom it is applied what is plainly apparent to others. (TA.)
[And A hunter, or sportsman, concealing himself. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
gubiI-N: see gabowapN.
gabaAwapN an inf. n. of gabiIa [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
huwa cuw gabaAwapK means He is one to whom things, or affairs, are unapparent, or obscure; or from whom they are hidden, or concealed. (TA.)
gubuw-apN: see gabowapN.
OagobaI: see the next article.

hom.sense: 2. gb-Ahu Eani AlX-aIoCi, (TA,) inf. n. tagobiyapN, (Ḳ, TA,) He covered, veiled, or concealed, (Ḳ,* TA,) him, or it, from the thing. (TA.)
And gb-I AlbiYora He covered the head [or mouth] of the well, and then put over it earth, or dust. (TA.)
gb-I XaEarahu, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) He shortened his hair: (Ḳ,* TA:) of the dial. of ʼAbd-el- Keys, and sometimes used by others: (TA:) and he eradicated it (Ḳ, TA) at once. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Agbt Als-amaMCu, inf. n. UigobaMCN, The sky rained such rain as is termed gaboyap [q. v.]. (AZ, Ṣ.)

hom.sense: gaboyapN A rain that is not copious, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but exceeding such as is termed bagoXap [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) or a vehement shower (Ḳ, TA) of rain: (TA:) pl. gabayaAtN. (Ṣ.)
[And app. † A shower of arrows.] Xar-u AlgabayaAti gaboyapu Aln-aboli [which seems clearly to mean † The worst of showers is the shower of arrows] is a saying mentioned by Aṣ. (TA.)
Also An abundant pouring of water:
and likewise † of siyaAT [i. e. stokes of the whip, or lashes]: (Ḳ, TA:) thought by ISd to be thus termed as being likened to the gabayaAt of rain. (TA.)

And, as being likened to the rain thus termed, ‡ A running after another running: [but] AʼObeyd says, it is like a leap in pace or going. (Ṣ. [In three copies of the Ṣ, I find Algaboyapu kaAlwavobapi fiI Als-ayori as the explanation given by AʼObeyd: in one of my copies of the Ṣ, Algaboyapu kaAlz-uboyapi: and in the TA, Algayobapu kAlzbyp fI Alsyr: I have followed the first of these readings, as I cannot doubt its being the right.])

Also Dust of the earth. that has risen, or that has spread, or diffused itself; (Ḳ, TA;) as also gabaMCN↓; thus correctly; but in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ gibaMC, like kisaMC; [and accord. to other copies gabFA;] it is like dust in the sky: or, as some say, it is the earth, or dust, with which the head [or mouth] of the well is stopped up, upon the corer. (TA.) [See also art. gbw.]

One says also, jaAWuwA EalaI gaboyapi AlX-amosi, meaning gayobatihaA [i. e. They came at, or in the time of, the setting of the sun]: (Ḳ, TA;) in which instance it is thought by ISd to be formed by transposition. (TA. [See also 1 in art. gbw.])

entry.sense: gabaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph:
and see also art. gbw.

hom.sense: guSonN OagobaI, and XajarapN gaboyaMCu, A branch, and a tree, tangled, confused, or dense. (Ḳ.)
Audoxulo fiI Aln-aAsi faUin-ahu OagobaI laka means [Enter thou among the people, for it will be] most concealing for thee. (TA.)

entry.sense: samaMCN mugobiyapN A sky raining such rain as is termed gabiyap [q. v.] (AZ, Ṣ.)

hom.sense: mugab-aApN i. q. mugaT-aApN: so in the saying, Hafara mugab-aApF [He dug a pitfall which he afterwards covered over with earth]: and [hence] one says, dafana liI fulaAnN mugob-aApF vum-a HamalaniI EalayohaA [lit. Such a one covered over a pitfall for me, then urged me to go upon it], meaning † such a one caused me to fall in [or by means of] a stratagem that he had concealed. (TA.)
Also i. q. mufaw-aApN [A land (OaroDN) abounding with fuw-ap i. e. madder]. (TA.)
1. gat-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagotutu}, inf. n. gav-N, (TḲ,) He fatigued, or wearied, him, (kad-ahu,) biAlOamori [by, or with, the affair]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And He forced him to do a thing against his will, so that he afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, him. (TA.) And you say, gat-a Ald-aAb-apa XawoTFA Oawo XawoTiyoni or wearied, the beast by urging it to run a heat, or two heats. (Ḳ, TA.)
Also He grieved him; (Ḳ, TA;) and afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, him. (TA.) And gut-a He was grieved [&c.]. (Sh, TA.)

And He overcame him, or silenced him, biAlkalaAmi [by speech, i. e. by what he said]. (Ḳ, TA.) [Hence] it is said in a trad. respecting prayer, yaA mano laA yaguv-uhu duEaMCu Ald-aAEiyna O Thou whom the praying of those who pray does not overcome. (TA.) And [hence, perhaps,] one says, gav-a AlD-aHika (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) He concealed laughter, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) by putting his hand, or his garment, over his mouth. (TA.)

Also He squeezed his throat, or throttled him: (Ḳ:) and he squeezed his throat for the period of an breath, or of two breaths, or, as some say, more than that. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the mission [of Moḥammad], faOaxacaniI jiboriylu fagat-aniI And Gabriel took me, and squeezed me vehemently, so that I experienced distress as when one is forcibly plunged into water: inf. n. gat-N: and gaT-N signifies the same. (TA.)
gat-ahu fiI AlmaMCi, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) is syn. with gaT-ahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) meaning He immersed, or plunged, him, or it, into the water. (TA.)
And one says, gat-ahumu Qll-ehu biAlEacaAbi, inf. n. as above, God plunged them. or may God plunge them, with consecutive plungings, into punishment. (TA.)

And gat-a, aor. and inf. n. as above, He took successive draughts, keeping the vessel to his mouth. (AZ, TA.) And gat-a AlmaMCa, (Ḳ, TA,) and gat-a fiI AlUinaMCi, (TA.) He drank, taking draught after draught, or gulp after gulp, without removing the vessel from his mouth. (Ḳ, TA.)
And gat-a AlX-aYoCa AlX-aYoCa He made the part of the thing to follow another part thereof, (Ḳ, TA,) whether in drinking or in speaking [&c.] (TA.)

It is said in a trad. respecting Moḥammad's pool, yagut-u fiyhi miyzaAbaAni i. e. Two spouts were pouring forth into it with an uninter rupted pouring: or it is said to mean, two spouts were running into it with a murmuring sound; accord. to which latter explanation we must read yagit-u: and some say that it is ygT-. (Az., L, TA.) [See also another reading voce Eab-a.]
And one says, gat-ahu bijuXamihi He threw his breast upon him. (TA in art. jXm.)
gat-a,, aor. _i {yagotitu}, It was, or became, bad, or corrupt; said of food; and likewise of speech. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) [See also gav-a.]

entry.sense: 4: see what next precedes {2}.
gt-N [inf. n. of 1, q. v.]
[And] The interval between two draughts, or gulps, while the vessel is kept to the mouth. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gatima, aor. _a {yagotamu}, inf. n. gatamN, He had an impotence, or an impediment, or a difficulty, in his speech, or utterance; and a barbarousness, or vitiousness, therein, especially in speaking Arabic; i. e., a want of clearness, perspicuousness, distinctness, chasteness, or correctness, therein. (Mṣb.)
gatama, said of food (TaEaAm), It was, or became, wholesome, or beneficial. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Agtm Alz-iyaArapa, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK [erroneously] Agotatama,) He visited much, so as to weary. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, laA tugotimi Alz-iyaArapa fatumil-a [Do not thou visit much, so as to weary]. (TA.)

And they said, kaAna AlEaj-aAju yugotimu AlX-iEora i. e. El-ʼAjjáj used to make poetry cause much wearying: and it is said in the A, Oagotama Mlu AlEaj-aAji Alr-ajoza i. e. The family of El-ʼAjjáj recited much poetry of the metre termed rajaz; and he among them. (TA.)

8. Agttm He suffered from indigestion (Ḳ, TA) in consequence of much eating; and became affected by what is termed gatom↓ [app. meaning heat of the stomach so intense as to take the breath] arising from the distress occasioned by repletion. (TA.)

gatomN Intense heat that almost takes away the breath. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A rájiz says, (Ṣ,) namely, Mesʼood Ibn-Keyd [?] El-Fezáree, (TA,) describing camels, (Ṣ in art. fl,)
Har-aqahaA HamoDu bilaAdi fil-i
wagatomu najomK gayori musotaqil-i
[The pasturage termed HmD of tracts of country not rained upon and not having fresh herbage rendered them thirsty, and the intense and almostsuffocating heat of a star not high (above the horizon), i. e. not having become high so as to be concealed by the rays of the sun]; i. e. [a star] not high (gayori murotafiEK) because of the constancy of the heat attributed to it [at the time of its auroral rising]; the heat becoming intense only at the time of the [auroral] rising of AlX-iEoraI, [meaning Sirius, the star to which allusion is here made,] which is in [correctly after] AljawozaMC. (Ṣ. [See AlX-iEoraI.])
See also 8.
gutomN Thick pieces [or clots or lumps] of milk. (TA.)

gutomapN An impotence, or an impediment, or a difficulty, in speech, or utterance; and a barbarousness, or vitiousness, therein; i. e. a want of clearness, perspicuousness, distinctness, chasteness, or correctness, therein; meaning, in speaking Arabic; syn. EujomapN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
gutomiI-N: see Oagotamu.
Hence, applied to milk, [and so, accord. to Reiske, as stated in Freytag's Lex., Oagotamu↓,] Thick; the pouring forth of which is without any sound. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
And One who is heavy in spirit: from gutomN signifying as expl. above. (TA.)

HiyaADu gutayomK, like zubayor, (so in copies of the Ḳ,) [or HyAD gutayoma, for it is] a proper name for Almaniy-apu, (TA,) meaning Death, (Ḳ, TA,) like XaEuwbu, imperfectly decl. [as being a proper name and of the fem. gender]; so says Z; and, accord. to Lḥ, Algutayomu signifies the same, but ISd says, “I know it not save as from him.” (TA.) One says, Oaworadahu HiyaADa gutayom [He brought him to death]: and in like manner, waqaEa fiI OaHowaADi gutayom [He fell into death], expl. by Lḥ as meaning he died. (TA.)

Oagotamu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and gutomiI-N↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) [and OagotamiI-N↓, occurring in the fAkhp AlxlfMC, p. 151, 1. 18, as mentioned by Freytag, who explains it as meaning “barbarus,”] One who does not utter anything with clearness, perspicuousness, or distinctness, or with chasteness, or correctness; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) i. q. OaEojamu: (TA:) fem. of the first, gatomaMCu, applied to a woman: (Mṣb, TA:) pl. of the first gutomN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OagotaAmN, (Mgh,) or this latter is pl. of the second. (TA.)
See also gutomiI-N.
OagotamiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
magotuwmN, Burned by the heat. (TA.)

1. gav-a, aor. _i {yagovivu}; and gav-a, (originally gaviva, TA)) aor. _a {yagovavu}; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) said of flesh-meat; (Ṣ, O;) and gav-at; said of a XaAp [i. e. sheep or goat]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) inf. n. gavaAvapN and guvuwvapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or gav-N; (Mṣb;) and Agv-↓, (Ḳ,) or Agv-t, (Ṣ, O,) or both; (TA;) It was, or became, lean, or meagre: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or gav-at, said of a XAp, it was, or became, weak. (Mṣb.)
[Hence the saying,] gav-a AlHadiyvu ‡ The talk, or discourse, was, or became, [meagre, or] bad, or corrupt; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ;) as also Agv-↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See gav-N.]

And laA yagiv-u Ealayohi XaIoCN † [Nothing is bad in his opinion; so that] he does not say of anything that it is bad, and therefore leave it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And maA yagiv-u Ealayohi OaHadN † [No one is to be disregarded in his opinion; so that] he does not leave any one unasked by him. (T, A, O, Ḳ.) And gav-ato EalayonaA mak-apu falaA bud-a lanaA mino xuruwjK † [Mekkeh has become unpleasing (as though insipid) to us, so that there is for us no avoiding going forth]. (A.)

And gav-a, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagovivu}, inf. n. gav-N and gaviyvN, (Ṣ, O,) is said of a wound, meaning It flowed with thick purulent matter, as also Agv-↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and with dead flesh. (Ṣ and O in explanation of the former verb.)

2. gv-vt AlUibilu, (El-Umawee, O, TA,) inf. n. tagoviyvN, (El-Umawee, O, Ḳ,) The camels became fat (El-Umawee, O, Ḳ, TA) by little and little: (O, Ḳ, TA:) [or became somewhat fat; for] one says, gav-a baEiyriI vum-a gav-ava My camel became lean; then he became somewhat fat. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in three places.
You say also, Agv- fiI manoTiqihi ‡ He [was meagre in his diction; or] spoke badly, or corruptly. (Ṣ, TA.) And Agv- fiI kalaAmihi † He said that in which was no good. (A, Mṣb.)
And Agv- All-aHoma He bought the flesh-meat lean. (Ṣ, O.)

entry.sense: 5. Oatagav-avu maA OanaA Ealayohi Hat-aI Oatasam-ana means † I do what is of an inferior kind that I may find much; as also Oasotagiv-uhu↓: (A, TA:) or Oatagav-avu Hat-aI Oasotasomina, meaning † I deem my doing to be little that I may obtain thereby much recompense. (O.)

8. Agtv-t Alxayolu (as also Agtf-t and Agtb-t, O) The horses found, or lighted upon, somewhat of the [herbage called] rabiyE, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and became fat in consequence thereof after having been lean. (TA.)

hom.sense: 10. Astgv- AljuroHa He extracted from the wound the thick purulent matter therein, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the dead flesh, and treated it curatively. (Ṣ.)
See also 5.
R. Q. 1. gavogava, (O,) inf. n. gavogavapN, (Ḳ,) He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (O, Ḳ,) in a place. (O.)
[And it seems to signify also He washed clothes without an implement of the kind called miqoSarap (q. v.): for]

gavogavapN signifies also † Weak fighting, without a weapon: (O, Ḳ:) likened to the gavogavap of the garment, or piece of cloth, [which is] when it is washed with the hands [app. meaning with the hands only]. (O.)

entry.sense: gav-N Lean, or meagre; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ;) as also gaviyvN↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) both applied to flesh-meat; and the former, with p {gav-apN}, to a XaAp [i. e. sheep or goat]: (Ṣ, O:) pl. givaAvN. (MA.)

Hence, i. e. as being likened to flesh-meat thus termed, kalaAmN gav-N † Speech, or language, that is [meagre,] without grace, or beauty. (Ḥam p. 757.) One says, fiI AlkalaAmi Algav-u waAls-amiynu † [In speech, or the speech, is what is meagre and what is vigorous; or] what is good and what is bad [or rather what is bad and what is good]. (Mṣb.) And Hadiyvukumo gav-N wasilaAHukumo rav-N † [Your talk, or discourse, is meagre, or bad, and your weapons are old and worn out]. (A.) And qawomN gavavapN † [A people, or party, meagre, or bad, in speech: gavavapN being pl. of gav-N, like as bararapN is of bar-N]. (A. [The meaning that I have given is there indicated by the context.])

hom.sense: guv-apN A lean, or meagre, XaAp [i. e. sheep or goat]. (TA.) [See also gav-N.]
And A sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (O, Ḳ:) like guf-apN and gub-apN. (O.)

entry.sense: Algavivu and AlguvaAgivu↓ The lion. (O, Ḳ.)
gavaAvN [if not a mistranscription for the inf. n. gavaAvapN] Leanness, or meagreness, of a camel [&c.]. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: gaviyvN: see gav-N:
and see what here follows.
gaviyvapN, (Ṣ, O,) or gaviyvN↓, (A, Ḳ,) The thick purulent matter, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and dead flesh, (Ṣ, O,) of a wound. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ.)

And [hence, probably,] the former word, † A corrupt, or disordered, state of mind. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ.) So in the saying, labisotuhu EalaI gaviyvapK fiyhi [meaning † I consorted with him (see labisa) notwithstanding a corrupt, or disordered, state of mind in him]. (Ṣ, O, L, TA. [In a copy of the A, lasotu EalaI gaviyvapK, meaning † I am not in a corrupt, or disordered, state of mind: but the former, I doubt not, is the right reading.])
Also A palm-tree (naxolapN) that produces ripe dates without sweetness. (O, Ḳ.)
And Foolish, or stupid, in whom is no good: (O, Ḳ:) or foolish, or stupid: and also one who speaks that in which is no good. (TA.)

entry.sense: AlguvaAgivu: see Algavivu.

1. gavarati AlOaroDu biAln-abaAti i. q. maOadat (thus in the JK [app. meaning The land became flourishing and fresh with herbage]): or maAdat (thus in the O and Ḳ [i. e. without C; but the former, I think, is evidently the right: the meaning which I have given may be from gavarN, q. v., and therefore tropical: and it may be inferred from what here follows that the verb is correctly, or originally, gavorat, fem. of gavoraI↓]). The epithet applied to such land is mugavoriyapN↓. (JK, O, Ḳ.)
4. Agvr It (the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov [&c.]) exuded what is termed mugovuwr [q. v.]; (Ḳ;) as also Agfr. (TA.)
See also Eay-ara, last sentence.
11. AgvAr- It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) had much gavar i. e. nap, or villous substance, (Ḳ, TA,) and wool. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1. gavoraI: see the first paragraph {1}.
Q. Q. 2. tamagovara He gathered mugovuwr [q. v.]. (Ḳ.) You say, xaraja Aln-aAsu yatamagovaruwna, like yatamagofaruwna, The people went forth to gather magaAviyr [pl. of mugovuwrN]. (TA.)
gavarN The nap, or villous substance, of a garment, or piece of cloth; (Ḳ, TA;) and the wool thereof. (TA.)
gavorapN Abundance: (TA:) [and particularly] abundance of herbage, and of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; ampleness [thereof] (Ḳ, TA.)
And A portion of property. (TA.)

guvorapN A dust-colour inclining to xuDorap [which here app. means a dingy ash-colour]: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, [simply] dust-colour: (TA:) or it is like duskiness (guboXapN) mixed with redness. (Ḳ, TA.)
gavarapN: see Oagovaru, last sentence.
gavaAri, or gavaAru, accord. to the CK guvaArN: see Oagovaru.
Algawovaru and Algavawovaru: see Oagovaru, former half.

hom.sense: gayovarapN A threatening. (Ḳ.)

And Fight, or conflict; and commotion, or tumult: so in the saying, tarakotu Alqawoma fiI gayovarapK and gayovamapK [I left the people, or party, in fight,, &c.]: (Aṣ, TA:) or, accord to IAạr, it means the treading, or trampling, of the people, or party, one upon another, (mudaAwasapu Alqawomi baEoDihimo baEoDFA,) in fight, or conflict: you say, bayona Alqawomi gayovarapN XadiydapN [Among the people, or party, is a vehement treading,, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also Oagovaru, last sentence, in two places.

entry.sense:
Oagovaru, (Ṣ,) and [the fem.] gavoraMCu, (Ḳ,) Dustcoloured: (Ḳ, TA:) or of a dingy, or dusky, colour: (TA:) or of a dingy, or dusky, colour: (TA:) or [of the colour termed guvorap, which is] nearly the same as dust-coloured. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) 'Omárah says,
Hat-aI Qkotasayotu mina AlmaXiybi EimaAmapF
gavoraMCa Oagofiru lawonahaA bixiDaAbi
[Until I attired myself with a dusky turban of hoariness, the colour of which I concealed with hair-dye]. (TA.)

Oagovaru is applied as an epithet to a ram That is not red [or brown] nor black ner white; (IAạr, TA;) meaning of a dusky, or dingy, colour. (TA.) And it is so applied to a wolf. (IAạr, TA.) And AlOagovaru signifies The wolf; (TA;) as also AlOagobaru. (TA in art. gbr.)

And [in like manner] AlgavoraMCu signifies The hyena, or female hyena; (Ḳ, TA;) because of its colour: (TA;) as also gavaAri↓, (O, Ḳ, TA,) like qaTaAmi, (O, TA,) determinate; (Ḳ, TA;) [accord. to the CK guvaArN, which is wrong;] and accord. to IAạr gavaAru↓, imperfectly declinable. (TA.)
And A certain bird, (Ḳ, TA,) having confused, or disordered, plumage, (TA,) long in the neck, (Ḳ, TA,) in the colour of which is guvorap [q. v.], and which is of the aquatic kind. (TA.)
Oakalatohumu AlgavoraMCu [which may be rendered The hyena, or female hyena, devoured them] means † they perished. (Z, TA.)

gavoraMCu applied to [garments of the kind called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMCN] (Ḳ, TA) and qaTaAYif [pl. of qaTiyfapN] and the like, and to an EabaMCap, (TA,) signifies Having much wool (L, Ḳ, TA) and nap, or villous substance. (L.)
AlOagovaru also signifies The [green substance that overspreads stale water, called] TuHolub. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also † The ignorant man: and the stupid man: likened to the hyena, or female hyena, which is one of the most stupid of beasts, and of which one of the appellations is AlgavoraMCu. (IDrd, TA.)

And AlgavoraMCu and Alguvoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) which latter is the pl. of AlOagovaru, (Ṣ, TA,) † The low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid, or the refuse, or rabble, of mankind; as also Algavorapu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) said to be originally Algayovarapu↓, (Ṣ, TA,) which signifies the same: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and gavoraMCu is also expl. as meaning a mixed assemblage of people (Ḳ, TA) of the low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid, or of the refuse, or rabble, of mankind; (TA;) and so gayovarapN↓: (AZ, TA:) or a mixed assemblage of people of various tribes: or the unknown common people: or the commonalty, or generality, of men. (TA.)
migovarN: see what next follows.
migovaArN: see what next follows.

mugovuwrN (Ṣ, M) and migovarN↓ (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ) and migovaArN↓ (TA) [A sort of manna;] a thing [or substance] which is exuded by the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and by the EurofuT, (Ṣ,) and the vumaAm, and the EuXar, (Ḳ,) resembling gum, and sweet, (Ṣ,) like honey: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is eaten; (TA;) and sometimes it flows upon the ground, like dibos: and it has an unpleasant smell: mugovuwrN is a dial. var. of mugofuwrN [q. v.]: (Ṣ, TA:) the pl. is magaAviyru. (Ḳ.)
OaroDN mugavoriyapN: see 1.

wajada AlmaMCa mugavoriyFA Ealayohi means He found the water to be thronged: (Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to Ṣgh, (TA,) you say, wajadotu AlmaMCa mugavoriyFA biAlwirodi I found the water to be thronged by the coming thereto. (O, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gavaA AlwaAdiI, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yagovuw, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gavowN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and gavaI, aor. yagoviI, inf. n. gavoyN; (Ḳ;) the latter mentioned by IJ, but the former is that which is [commonly] known to the lexicologists; (TA;) The valley, or water-course, was, or became, full of guvaMC [q. v.]: (Mṣb: [and the like is indicated in the Ḳ:]) or had in a abundance of camels' or similar dung (baEor) and leaves and reeds or canes. (TA.)
gavaA All-aHomu, inf. n. gavowN, The flesh-meat was bad by reason of its leanness. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
