gavati Aln-afosu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. tagoviI, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gavoIN and gavayaAnN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and, accord. to Lth, gaviyat, aor. tagovaI, inf. n. gavFA, but Az says that this is post-classical; (TA;) i. q. xabuvat; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and jaAXat; (TA;) i. e. [The soul, or stomach, heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; or] became agitated so that the person nearly vomited, by reason of a mixture pouring forth to the mouth of the stomach: (Mṣb, TA:) or, as some say, gavayaAnN signifies a flowing of the mouth which sometimes, or often, occasions vomiting. (TA.)
gavati Als-amaMCu biAls-aHaAbi, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. tagoviI, (TA,) The sky was, or became, clouded, or covered with clouds: (Ḳ, TA:) or began to be so. (TA.)

gavaA Als-ayolu AlmarotaEa, aor. yagovuwhu, inf. n. gavowN; thus accord. to J, [in the Ṣ,] but accord. to the Ḳ and ISd, gavaI, mentioned in art. gvI; and in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, AlmarobaEa is erroneously put for AlmarotaEa; (TA;) The torrent drew [or washed] together the pasture, and deprived it of its sweetness; as also AgvAhu↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And hence, by way of comparison, (TA,) gavaI AlkalaAma, aor. yagoviyhi; (Ḳ, TA;) and gaviyahu, aor. yagovaAhu; (Ḳ,* TA;) the former verb of the class of ramaI, and the latter of the class of raDiIa; inf. n. gavoIN; (TA;) ‡ He mixed, or put together confusedly, the speech, or language. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And gavaI AlmaAla, and Aln-aAsa, He beat the cattle, and the people, and dealt blows among them. (Ḳ,* TA.)
gaviyati AlOaroDu biAln-abaAti The land became abundant in herbage: (Ḳ, TA:) or began to be so. (TA.)
And gaviIa XaEoruhu, inf. n. gavFI, His hair became matted, or compacted together: mentioned in art. gvI by IḲṭṭ: perhaps a dial. var. of EaviIa, with the unpointed E; mentioned before. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see the preceding paragraph {1}, latter half.

guvaMCN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and guv-aMCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) The rubbish, or small rubbish, or particles of things, or refuse, and scum, and rotten leaves mixed with the scum, (Zj, Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA,) borne upon the surface (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) of a torrent: (Zj, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or dried-up [or decayed] and broken pieces [or leaves and stalks] of herbage, that are seen upon a torrent: so in the Ḳur lxxxvii. 5: [see OaHowaI in art. Hw:] (TA:) pl. OagovaMCN. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence,] one says, maAluhu guvaMCN waEamaluhu habaMCN wasaEoyuhu xafaMCN † [His property is as rubbish borne by a torrent (see Ḳur xxiii. 43), and his work is as motes that are seen in the rays of the sun (see Ḳur xxv. 25), and his labour, or earning, is a thing that is unapparent]. (TA.)
[Hence, also,] guvaMCu Aln-aAsi † The low, or vile, and the refuse, of mankind. (TA.)
AlOagovaI The lion. (Ḳ.)
1. gud-a and gad-a, said of a camel: see 4.

hom.sense: 2. gud-ida: see 4.
gad-ada, inf. n. tagodiydN, He took his [gud-ap, i. e.] lot, portion, or share. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. Oagad-a (Ṣ, A, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Ougid-a, (O, L, Ḳ,) and gud-a↓, (Az, O, L, Ḳ,) this last heard by Az from the Arabs, (L,) [in the CK gad-a↓, but (though the phrase gud-ato Uibiluhumo occurs there afterwards) gud-a may be less correct than gad-a, for the part. n. of the former was disallowed by Aṣ,] and gud-ida↓, (Az, O, Ḳ,) He (a camel) had the disease termed gud-ap [q. v.]; (Az, Ṣ, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or had gudad [pl. of gud-apN] between the flesh and the skin. (L.)

Hence, (A,) Oagad-a signifies also ‡ He (a man, Aṣ, Ṣ, A, O) was, or became, angry, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, L,) or swollen by reason of anger, as though he were a camel having the disease termed gud-ap: (A:) and Oagad-a Ealayohi he was angry with him; (Ḳ;) or he swelled against him and was angry with him. (L.)
And Oagad-a Alqawomu The people, or party, had their camels affected with the disease termed gud-ap. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.)
gadN: see art. gdw.

hom.sense: gud-apN (IDrd, Ṣ, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gudadapN↓ (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ) [A ganglion; i. e.] any hard lump in the tendinous parts; (L, Ḳ;) [a lump of] flesh arising from disease, between the skin and the flesh, which may be made to move about: (Mṣb:) and any small nodous lump (Euqodap) in the body (IDrd, O, L, Ḳ) of a man, (IDrd, O, L,) surrounded by fat: (IDrd, O, L, Ḳ:) pl. gudadN [properly pl. of gud-apN, and also a coll. gen. n. of which gudadapN is the n. un.]: (Ṣ, O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) gud-apN [is applied in the present day to a ganglion: and a bubo: and a wen: and all these may be meant by its being said that it] also signifies a [swelling such as is termed] siloEap, (L, Ḳ,) overspread by fat. (L.)

And gud-apN signifies likewise The plague, or pestilence, (TaAEuwn,) in camels; (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ;) as also gadadN↓: (Ḳ:) or the same in camels as the TAEwn in man: (Mṣb:) it attacks them in the groins, and seldom do they recover from it: (L:) or it is only in the belly; (Ḳ, TA;) and when it extends to the camel's naHor [or part where he is stabbed, or stuck, when he is slaughtered], and to his groin, or arm-pit, the epithet daAbirN [so in the TA, but in the O daAriYN, which I believe to be the right reading,] is applied to him: so says IAạr: (TA:) or it is also in the fat parts; (Lth, O, L;) and between the flesh and the skin. (L.)
And What is between the fat and the hump [of the camel]. (Ḳ.)

Another signification of gud-apN is A part, or portion, of property; (L, Ḳ;) as in the saying, Ealayohi gud-apN mino maAlK [He owes a part, or portion, of some property]: (L:) pl. gadaAYidu, (L, Ḳ,) and, in some of the copies of the Ḳ, gidaAdN. (TA.) And [these two pls.] gadaAYidu and gidaAdN signify also Lots, portions, or shares: (L, Ḳ:) thus, accord. to Fr, the former of them means in a verse of Lebeed cited and expl. voce EadiydapN; but the reading better known is EadaAYidu: accord. to Az, gadaAYidu in this instance signifies redundances. (L.)

entry.sense: gadadN: see the next preceding paragraph.
gudadapN: see gud-apN.
[The pl.] gadadaAtN is expl. by AHeyth as signifying Redundances of fatness: and redundances of goodly [fur, such as is termed] wabar. (L.)
gaAd-N: see mugid-N, in two places.
mugad-N: see the paragraph here following.

mugid-N A camel having the disease termed gud-apN; (Aṣ, Az, Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ;) as also mugad-N↓ (L) and magoduwdN↓, (Az, L, Ḳ,) or this is not said, (Aṣ, O, Ḳ,) but it was heard by Az from the Arabs, (O, L,) and mugad-adN↓ (Az, L) and gaAd-N↓: (O, L, Ḳ:) mugid-N, without p, is also applied to a she-camel: and its pl. is magaAd-u: (L:) the pl. of gaAd-N↓ is gidaAcN. (O, L, Ḳ.*)

[Hence,] ‡ An angry man: (Aṣ, Ṣ, L:) or swollen by reason of anger, (A, L,) as though he were a camel having the disease termed gud-ap. (A.) One says, raOayotu fulaAnFA mugid-FA and musomagid-FA↓ ‡ I saw such a one swollen with anger. (L.)
mugad-adN: see the next preceding paragraph.
migodaAdN † A man, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) and a woman, (O, L, Ḳ,) much, or often, in anger: (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ:) or always angry: (O, Ḳ:) or angry in disposition or nature. (O, L.)
magoduwdN: see mugid-N.
musomagid-N: see mugid-N.

hom.sense: 1. gadarahu, (Ḳ,) and [more commonly] gadara bihi, aor. _i {yagodiru} (Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _u {yagoduru}; (M, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ;) and gadira, aor. _a {yagodaru}, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) but ISd doubts the correctness of this last; (TA;) inf. n. gadorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of gadara; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and gadarN (TA, and so in the CK in the place of gador,) and gadaraAnN, (Ḳ, TA,) which are both of gadira; (TA;) He acted perfidiously, unfaithfully, faithlessly, or treacherously, to him; (M, Ḳ;) he broke his compact, contract, covenant, or the like, with him; (Mṣb;) he neglected the performance, or fulfilment, of his compact,, &c., with him: (Ṣ:) gadorN is the contr. of wafaMCN, (Ḳ,) or of wafaMCN biEahodK: (M:) or it signifies the being remiss in a thing, and neglecting it. (B.)

gadara, aor. _i {yagodiru}, (T, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. gadorN, (T, O,) He drank the water of the gadiyr [q. v.]: (T, O, Ḳ:) and, accord. to the Ḳ, gadira, he drank the water of the sky; but this is a sheer mistake, occasioned by a misunderstanding of a saying in the T; here following: (TA:) Az says that gadara meaning as expl. above should accord. to analogy be gadira, like kariEa meaning “he drank the karaE,” i. e. the water of the sky: (O, TA:) moreover, a distinction is strangely made in the Ḳ between the water of the gadiyr and the water of the sky. (TA.)
gadarato waladahaA, said of a woman, is like dagaratohu [q. v.]. (TA.)

gadira, [aor. _a {yagodaru}, inf. n. gadarN,] He remained, or lagged, behind; as also tgd-r↓, accord. to Aṣ, who cites the following verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys:
EaXiy-apa jaAwazonaA HamaApa wasayorunaA
Oaxuw Aljahodi laA nalowiI EalaI mino tagod-araA
[In the evening when we passed beyond Hamáh, and our journeying was laborious, we not waiting for such as lagged behind]: but accord. to one relation it is taEac-ara, which means [the same, or] “held back, or withheld himself, for a cause rendering him excused.” (TA.) You say gadira Eano OaSoHaAbihi He remained, or lagged, behind his companions. (TA.) And gadirati Aln-aAqapu Eani AlUibili, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AlX-aApu Eani Alganami, (Ṣ,) The she-camel remained, or lagged, behind the other camels, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) not coming up to them, (TA,) and so the sheep, or goat, behind the other sheep, or goats. (Ṣ.) And gadara fulaAnN baEoda Uixowatihi Such a one remained after the death of his brothers. (TA. [But gadara, here, is app. a mistake for gadira, unless both forms be allowable.])
gadira All-ayolu; (Ḳ;) or gadirati All-ayolapu, aor. _a {yagodaru}, inf. n. gadarN; and Oagodarat↓; (Ṣ;) The night became dark: (Ḳ:) or became intensely dark. (Ṣ.)
gadirati Alganamu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gadarN, (TA,) The sheep, or goats, became satiated in the place of pasture in the first of the growth thereof. (Ḳ.)
gadirati AlOaroDu The land abounded with gadar [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. gAdrhu, inf. n. mugaAdarapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gidaArN; (Ḳ;) and Agdrhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He left him, or it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he left him, or it, remaining. (Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur xviii. 47, laA yugaAdiru SagiyrapF walaA kabiyrapF It will not leave, or omit, or it will not fall short of, (TA,) a small sin nor a great sin. (Jel.) And in a trad., yaA layotaniI guwdirotu maEa OaSoHaAbi nuHoSi Aljabali Would that I had [been left behind, and had] suffered martyrdom with the people of the foot of the mountain of Ohud, who were slain there, and the other martyrs: said by Moḥammad. (AʼObeyd.) [See also a verse of 'Antarah cited voce mutarad-amN; and another, of Kutheiyir, voce EasobN.] Agdr also signifies He left behind. (TA.) You say Agdr↓ Aln-aAqapa, and AlX-aApa, He (the pastor) left the she-camel behind the other camels, and the sheep, or goat, behind the other sheep, or goats. (Ṣ.) And lahu celika fiI qalobiI mawad-apF i. e. [Such a one aided me, and that] left remaining [in my heart a love for him]. (Lḥ, TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 3, in four places:
and see also 1:
and 2.

entry.sense: 5: see gadira.
10. Astgdr It (a place) had in it pools of water left by a torrent or torrents. (Ḳ.)
And Aisotagodarato hunaAka gudurN Pools of water left by a torrent or torrents became formed there. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: [Hence,] one says, Oaloqati Aln-aAqapu gadarahaA The she-camel cast forth what her womb had left remaining in it of blood and foul matter [after her bringing forth]. (TA.) And Oaloqati AlX-aApu guduwrahaA The ewe, or she-goat, cast forth the water and blood and other remains in her womb after bringing forth. (TA.)
And fiI Aln-ahori gadarN In the river, or rivulet, is slime remaining when the water has sunk into the earth. (TA.)

gadarN signifies also A place such as is termed Zalif [app. as meaning hard, and that does not show a footmark, or rugged and hard], abounding with stones: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or a place abounding with stones, difficult to traverse: (TA:) or any difficult place, through which the beast can hardly, or in nowise, pass: (Ḳ:) or soft ground, in which are [trenches, or channels, such as are termed] laxaAqiyq: (TA:) or burrows, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and banks, or ridges, worn and undermined by water, (Lḥ, TA,) and uneven laxaAqiyq in the ground: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [and the like is also said in the TA on the authority of Aṣ:]) and stones (Ḳ, TA) with trees; thus accord. to AZ and IḲṭṭ: (TA:) and anything that conceals one, and obstructs his sight: pl. OagodaArN. (TA.)

[Hence,] one says, maA Oavobata gadarahu, meaning maA Oavobatahu fiI Algadari [How firm is he in traversing the rugged and hard and stony place!, &c.]: this is said of the horse: and also † of the man when his tongue is firm in the place of slipping and of contention or litigation: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to Lḥ, it means † how firm, or valid, is his argument, or plea, and how seldom does harm in consequence of slipping and stumbling befall him! or, accord. to Ks, how firm is what remains of his intellect or understanding! but ISd says that this explanation did not please him. (TA.) And farasN vabotu Algadari A horse firm, or steady, in the place of slipping. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) And rajulN vabotu Algadari ‡ A man firm, or steadfast, in fight, or conflict, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or in altercation or disputation, or in speech, (Ṣ accord. to different copies,) or and in altercation or disputation, (Ḳ, TA,) and in speech; (TA;) and also in everything that he commences. (Ḳ, TA.) And accord. to Ibn-Buzurj one says, Uin-ahu lavabotu Algadari, meaning † Verily he is strong in talking or discoursing, with men, and in contending, or disputing, with them. (L.) [See also vabotN.]
gadirN [part. n. of gadira].
See gaAdirN, last sentence but one.
And see also gaduwrN.

You say also layolapN gadirapN and mugodirapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) meaning A dark night; (Ḳ;) as also gadoraMCu↓: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) or an intensely-dark night, (Ṣ,) in which the darkness confines men in their places of alighting or abode, and their shelter, so that they remain behind: or, as some say, such a night is termed mugodirapN↓ because it casts him who goes forth therein into the gdr [i. e. gadar]. (L, TA.)
gudaru and gudarN: see gaAdirN, in six places:
and for gudarN, see also gadiyrN.

entry.sense: gadorapN [an inf. n. un., signifying An act of perfidy. unfaithfulness, faithlessness, or treachery]: see two exs. voce gaAdirN.

gudorapN and gidorapN↓, (Ḳ,) or gidarapN↓, (ISk, Az, TA,) and gadarapN↓ and gadarN↓, (Lḥ, TA,) and gudaArapN↓, with damm, (Ḳ,) or gidaArapN↓, (as written in the L,) A portion that is left, or left remaining, of a thing; (Ḳ,* TA;) a remain, remainder, remnant, relic, or residue: (Lḥ, ISk, Az, L:) the pl. of gudoArapN is gudoraAtN (Ḳ) [and accord. to analogy gudaraAtN and guduraAtN] and app. gudarN; (TA;) and that of gidarapN↓ [or gidorapN↓] is gidarN and gidaraAtN; (ISk, Az;) and that of gadarN↓ is guduwrN. (TA.) You say, EalaI fulaAnK gidarN↓ mina AlS-adaqapi Such a one owes arrears of the poor-rate. (ISk.) And EalaI baniI fulaAnK gadarapN↓ mina AlS-adaqapi and gadarN↓ The sons of such a one owe an arrear of the poor-rate. (Lḥ, L.) And bihi gaAdirN↓ mino maraDK In him is a relic of disease; like gaAbirN. (TA.)
gadarapN: see gudorapN, in two places. gidarapN, and the pl. gidarN: see gudorapN, in three places.

hom.sense: gadoraMCu Darkness. (Ḳ.)
See also gadirN.
OaroDN gadoraMCu Land abounding with places of the kind termed gadar. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

entry.sense: gadaAri: see gaAdirN.

hom.sense: gaduwrN: see gaAdirN, in two places.

Also A she-camel that remains, or lags, behind the other camels: (Ḳ, TA:) in some of the copies of the Ḳ gaduwrapN, with p; but the former is the right. (TA.) And naAqapN gadirapN↓ gabirapN gamorapN A she-camel that remains, or lags, behind the other camels, in being driven. (Lḥ.)

entry.sense: gadiyrN A pool of water left by a torrent: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEilN, from gaAdarhu, or mufoEalN, from Oagodarahu; or, as some say, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN; (Ṣ;) because it is unfaithful to those who come to it to water, failing when much wanted: (Ṣ,* TA:) but it is a subst.; [not an epithet; or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, and only used as a subst.:] you do not say hecaA maMCN gadiyrN: (Lḥ:) or a place in which rain-water stagnates, whether small or large, not remaining until the summer: (Lth:) or a river: (Mṣb:) [but this is extr.:] pl. [of pauc. OagodirapN, (occurring in a verse cited voce Uil-aA, &c.,) and of mult.] gudoraAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and gudurN (Ṣ, Nh, L, TA,) which last is sometimes contracted into gudorN: (TA:) in the Ḳ, the last pl. is said to be of the measure of SuradN; [i. e. gudarN↓;] but this is inconsistent with what is said in other lexicons, as shown above: and it is also said in the Ḳ that gudarN signifies the same as gadiyrN, in the sense first given above; but it appears that this is a pl. of gudorapN; and that, in the Ḳ, we should read, for kaAlgadiyri, waAlgadiyru, and place this before, instead of after, its explanation. (TA.)
Hence, ‡ A piece of herbage; (TA;) as also gadiyrapN↓: pl. gudoraAnN: (Ḳ, TA;) this is the only pl. (TA.)
Hence also, (TA,) ‡ A sword; (Ḳ, TA;) like as it is called luj-N. (TA.)
And gadiyrapN↓ also signifies A she-camel left by the pastor (Ṣ, Ḳ) behind the other camels; and in like manner, a sheep, or goat. (Ṣ.)
gudaArapN or gidaArapN: see gudorapN.

hom.sense: gadiyrapN: see gadiyrN, last two sentences.

Also A portion, or lock, or plaited lock, of hair, hanging from the head; syn. cuWaAbapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, every EaqiySap is a gadiyrap; and the gadiyrataAni are the two portions, or locks, or plaited locks, of hair (caWaAbataAni) which fall upon the breast: (TA:) pl. gadaAYiru: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or gdAYr pertain to women, and are plaited; and DafaAYir, to men. (TA.)
gadiyrapu AlHaAYiki means The hollow, in the ground, in which the weaver puts his legs, or feet: also called Alwahodapu. (Mgh in art. whd.)

entry.sense: gad-aArN: see gaAdirN, in two places.
gad-iyrN: see gaAdirN.
gad-aArapN: see gaAdirN, in two places.

hom.sense: gaAdirN and gudarN↓ [respecting which see below] (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gaduwrN↓ and gad-aArN↓ and gid-iyrN↓ (Ḳ) are epithets applied to a man [and signifying, the first, Perfidious, unfaithful, faithless, or treacherous; or acting perfidiously,, &c.; and the rest, very perfidious,, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and gaduwrN↓ and gad-aArN↓ and gad-aArapN↓ are epithets applied to a woman [and signifying as above]: (Ḳ:) but gudar↓ is mostly used in calling to a man and reviling him: (Ṣ:) you say to a man, yaA gucaru [O very perfidious man]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in like manner, yaA magodaru↓, and yA magodiru↓, and yaA Qbona magodarK↓, and yA Abn magodirK↓, all determinate; (Ḳ, TA;) and to a woman, yA gadaAri↓, like qaTaAmi: (Ḳ:) [accord. to some, gudar↓ is only used in this manner, and is therefore without tenween; for] it is said that rajulN gudaru is not allowable, because gudaru is determinate: but Sh says rajulN gudarN, writing it, says Az, with tenween, contr. to what Lth says; and this is correct; a word of the measure fuEal being imperfectly decl. [only] when it is a determinate subst., like Eumaru and zufaru: and IAth says that gudaru is altered from its original form, which is gaAdirN, for the sake of intensiveness: (TA:) in the pl. [sense] you say yaAla gudara, (Ṣ,) or yaA lagudara, [for yaA Mla gudara, (see the letter l, and see MlN, in art. Awl,)] like yaA lafujara. (TA.) It is said in a trad., yaA gudaru↓ Oalasotu OasoEaI fiI gadoratika↓ [app. meaning, O thou very perfidious: am I not striving, or labouring, in respect of thine act of perfidy, to rectify it?]. (Ṣ: but in one copy, gudoratika.) And in another trad., relating to El-Hodeybiyeh, yaA gudaru↓ wahalo gasalota gadorataka↓ Uil-aA biQloOamosi [O thou very perfidious: and didst thou wash away thine act of perfidy save yesterday?]: said by 'Orweh Ibn-Mesʼood to El-Mugheereh. (TA.) And in another trad., Aijoliso gudaru↓ [Sit thou, O very perfidious]; for yaA gudaru: said by ʼÁïsheh to El-Kásim. (TA.)

[Hence,] sinuwna gad-aArapN↓ ‡ Years in which is much rain and little herbage; from [the inf. n.] Algadoru; i. e. that excite people's eager desire for abundance of herbage, by the rain, and then fail to fulfil their promise. (TA.)

[And gadirN↓ is app. syn. with gaAdirN; for] gadirapN occurs in a trad. applied to land (OaroD), as though meaning † Not producing herbage bountifully; or giving growth to herbage, and then soon becoming blighted, or blasted; wherefore it is likened to the gaAdir, who acts unfaithfully. (TA.)
See also gudorapN, last sentence.

entry.sense: magodar and magodir: see gaAdirN, each in two places.
layolapN mugodirapN: see gadirN, in two places.
1. gadafa lahu fiI AlEaTaMCi, (aor. _u {yagodufu}, inf. n. gadofN, TḲ,) He was profuse to him in giving. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

4. Agdft qinaAEahaA She (a woman, Ṣ) let down, or let fall, her [head-covering called] qnAE upon her face. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) 'Antarah says,
Uino tugodifiI duwniI AlqinaAEa faUin-aniI
Tab-N biOaxoci AlfaArisi AlmusotaloYimi , (Ṣ,) i. e. If, O my beloved, thou let down before me the head-covering, meaning if thou veil thyself from me, I am expert in capturing the mail-clad horseman: then how should I lack power to capture thee? (EM p. 236.)
[Hence,] Agdf All-ayolu ‡ The night let down its curtains [of darkness]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And AlX-abakapa EalaI AlS-ayodi He (a sportsman, or fowler, or the like,) let fall the net upon the object, or objects, to be captured. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., Uin-a qaloba AlmuWomini OaXad-u QrotikaADFA mina Alc-anobi yuSiybuhu mina AlEuSofuwri Hiyna yugodafu bihi (Ṣ, TA,) i. e. [Verily the heart of the believer is more vehemently agitated in consequence of the offence that he purposes than the sparrow] when the net is made to cover it, whereupon it struggles to escape: (TA:) or mina AlxaTiyoYapi [i. e. in consequence of the sin that he is tempted to commit]. (So in the O, instead of min Alcnb ySybh.)
Agdf bihaA † He compressed her, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) i. e., a woman: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O:) or, as in the A, he went in to her. (TA.)
Agdf said of the sea [app. from the same verb said of the night] ‡ It became confusedly agitated in its waves; expl. by the words AiEotakarato OamowaAjuhu. (TA.)
And † He slept. (AA, TA in art. sdf.)

And, accord. to Lḥ, (O,) Agdf said of the circumciser (O, Ḳ, TA) of a boy (O) means He cut off entirely the prepuce; (O, Ḳ, TA;) like OasoHata; (O, TA;) but ISd holds that the latter has this meaning, and the former means he left somewhat thereof: (TA:) one says to the circumciser, laA tugodifo walaA tusoHito, (O, TA,) but this means Leave not thou much of the skin, nor cut off entirely. (TA.)
8. Agtdf minohu He (a man, O) took from him (another man, O) much. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And Agtdf Alv-awoba He cut the garment, or piece of cloth. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
12. Aigodawodafa It (the night) came with its darkness. (TA.)

gadafN A state of ease, and plentifulness, or ampleness: so in the saying, Alqawomu fiI gadafK mino EayoXihimo (O, Ḳ *) or maEiyXatihimo (TA) [The people, or party, are in a state of ease,, &c., in respect of their means of subsistence]: thus in the O and TṢ: but in the L, fI gudAfK↓ mn mEyXthm. (TA.)
gudofapN A thing in the form of the [head-covering called] qinaAE, worn by the women of the Arabs of the desert. (TA.)
gidofapN The apparel of the king. (TA.)

hom.sense: gudaAfN The crow, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or, as some say, the large crow, (TA,) of the summer, or hot season: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to some, in an absolute sense, the crow: (TA:) or the large crow that is full in the wings: (JK:) or the black crow: (MA:) pl. gidofaAnN. (Ṣ, O.)
And A vulture having abundant plumage (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) is sometimes thus called: (Ṣ, O:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
And Long, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) abundant, (TA,) black hair. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
Also A black wing. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And Anything intensely black is termed gudaAfN, and Oasowadu gudaAfiI-N↓. (TA.)
See also gadafN.

entry.sense: gudaAfiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.

mgdf, [app. mugodifN, or perhaps taken from a mistranscription for mugodiqN,] as an epithet applied to means of subsistence (EayoXN), signifies Smooth and ample. (TA.) [Freytag mentions mugad-afN and mugad-aqN, each having the fem. with p {mugad-afapN and mugad-aqapN}, as signifying Copious, applied to rain: both from the “Fákihet el-Khulafà,” p. 141, l. 3; where the word is mgdqp, evidently mugodiqap, and rhyming with muTobiqap.]

1. gadiqati AlEayonu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yagodaqu}, inf. n. gadaqN, (Mṣb,) The spring, or source, abounded with water; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Agdqt↓, inf. n. UigodaAqN. (Mṣb.) And gadiqa AlmaTaru, inf. n. as above; (Mṣb;) and Agdq↓, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. OigodaAqN; (Mṣb;) and Aigodawodaqa↓; (Ḳ;) and gayodaqa↓; (Abu-l-ʼOmeythil, TA;) The rain was, or became, copious. (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) And gadiqato sanatunaA [Our year was, or became, rainy]. (O.) And gadiqa, aor. and inf. n. as above, There was abundance of rain, or dew, or moisture, or of water, in the place. (Zj, TA.)
gadaqN is also used in relation to herbs, or herbage, as meaning The being plentifully irrigated, or flourishing and fresh, juicy, or moist. (En-Naḍr, AḤn, TA.)
And you say, gadiqati AlOaroDu, and Agdqt↓, meaning The land abounded, or became abundant, with herbage, or with the produce of the earth. (TA.)
And gadaqati AlOaroDu, aor. _i {yagodiqu}, being of the class of Daraba, The land became moistened by abundant water. (Mṣb.)
4: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in three places.
12: see 1, second sentence.
Q. Q. 1. gayodaqa: see 1, second sentence.
Also ‡ He (a man, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O) had much saliva; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA;) or, accord. to the L, much slaver. (TA.)

gadaqN [an inf. n.: and used in the sense of the part. n. gadiqN↓, meaning] Abundant, or copious; applied to water; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) not restricted to rain; (TA;) as also mugodiqN↓ and mugodawodiqN↓, both applied to rain, and the latter [or both] applied to water [in general]; and gayodaAqN↓ likewise, applied to water, and, as AA says, to rain: or gadaqN is applied to rain as meaning abundant, or copious, [so as to be] general in its extent. (TA.)
It is said in the Ḳur [lxxii. 16], lawi QsotaqaAmuwA EalaI QlT-ariyqapi laOasoqayonaAhumo maMCF gadaqFA [If they should go on undeviatingly in the way which they are pursuing, we would water then with abundant water]; (O, TA;) to try them thereby; the Tryqp here being that of infidelity; so says Th, and in like manner Fr; but others say that it is that of the right direction: (TA:) 'Ásim Ibn-Abi-n-Najood read gadiqFA↓. (O, TA.) In the saying, in a trad., Aall-ehum-a QsoqinaA gadaqFA mugodiqFA↓, the last word is used as a corroborative [the meaning being O God, water us very abundantly]. (TA.)
See also gayodaAqN.

gadiqN: see gadaqN, in two places. You say also EayonN gadiqapN A spring, or source abounding with water. (Mṣb.) And OaroDN gadiqapN Land that is moist and irrigated in the utmost degree; abounding with water. (TA.) And EuXobN gadiqN Herbs, or herbage, plentifully irrigated, or flourishing and fresh, juicy, or moist. (En-Naḍr, AḤn, TA.)
EayonN gudayoqapN: see EayonN, near the end of the paragraph.
gayodaqN: see the next paragraph, in two places.
gayodaqaAnN: see the next paragraph, in two places.
gayodaAqN: see gadaqN.

[Hence,] EayoXN gayodaAqN A life ample in its means, or circumstances; plentiful; as also gayodaqN↓: and humo fiI gadaqK↓ mina AlEayoXi and gayodaAqK [They are in an ample, or a plentiful, state of life]. (TA.) And EaAmN gayodaAqN A year abounding in herbage, fruitful, or plentiful; and so sanapN gayodaAqN, without p [to the latter word]. (TA.)
And Uin-ahu lagayodaAqu AljaroIi and AlEadowi Verily he is wide-stepping in respect of running. (TA.)
And Xad-N gayodaAqN A vehement running. (TA.)
gayodaAqN applied to a horse signifies TawylN [app. meaning Long-bodied]. (O, Ḳ.)

And, applied to a man, (Ṣ, O, TA,) Generous; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) bountiful; large, or liberal, in disposition; munificent; (TA;) and so gayodaqaAnN↓; (Ḳ,* TA;) or this, some say, signifies abundant, ample, as applied to anything. (TA.)
And gayodaAqN signifies also The young one of the [lizard called] Dab-, (AZ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) after the state in which it is termed HisolN [q. v.]. (AZ, Ṣ, O.)
And [the pl.] gayaAdiyqu signifies Serpents. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.)
gayodaAqiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
mugodiqN: see gadaqN, in two places. [mugod-aqN mentioned by Freytag as signifying “copious,” applied to rain, is a mistake: see the last paragraph of art. gdf.]
mugodawodiqN: see gadaqN, first sentence.

1. gadaA, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yagoduw, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. Euduw-N (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gadowN (M, TA, and so accord. to the CK instead of guduw-N [which is the only inf. n. commonly known]) and gudowapN, (Ḳ,) He went, or went away, in the time called gudowap, (Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e. [the early part of the morning,] the period between the prayer of daybreak and sunrise: this is the primary signification: (Mṣb:) or i. q. bak-ara [he went forth early in the morning; in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise]; so in the phrase gadaA Ealayohi [he went forth early in the morning,, &c., to him, or it]; (Ḳ;) as also AgtdI↓: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) and gAdAhu↓ signifies the same as gadaA Ealayohi; (Ṣ;) or the same as baAkarahu [which is syn. with bak-ara Ealayohi as expl. above; and signifies also, like bak-ara Ealayohi, he hastened to it, or to do it, at any time, morning or evening]: (ISd, Ḳ, TA:) Alguduw-u is the contr of Alr-awaAHu [inf. n. of raAHa]. (Ṣ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [lxviii. 22], Oani QgoduwA EalaI Harovikumo [Saying, Go ye forth early,, &c., to your land's produce]: and the saying of a poet,
waqado OagotadiI↓ waAlT-ayoru fiI wukunaAtihaA
[And sometimes, or often, I go forth early,, &c., while the birds are in their nests]. (TA.)

Afterwards, by reason of frequency of use, it became employed as meaning He went, or went away, or departed, at any time. (Mgh,* Mṣb, TA.) Hence the saying, (Mgh, Mṣb,) of the Prophet, (Mṣb,) in a trad., (Mgh,) Augodu yaA Ounayosu, (Mgh, Mṣb,) meaning Depart then, O Uneys. (Mṣb.)
[Freytag bas erroneously assigned to it another meaning, i. e. “Nutrivit” misled by his finding tagoduwo put for tagocuw in art. TlI in the CK.]
gadiIa: see 5.
2. gad-ayotuhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagodiyapN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) I fed him with the meal called gadaMC [q. v.]. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.)
3: see 1, first sentence. One says, OanaA OugaAdiyhi waOuraAwiHuhu expl. in the first paragraph {1} of art. rwH.

5. tgd-I [He ate the meal called gadaMC, q. v.; properly,] he ate in the first part of the day; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also gadiIa↓, (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gadFA. (TḲ: but in the TA written gdAC.) When it is said to thee, tagad-a [Eat thou the gadaMC], thou sayest, maA biI mino tagad-K [I have no desire for eating the gadaMC]; and not maA biI gadaMCN, for [the] gadaMC is the meal itself. (Ṣ, Mṣb. See also 5 in art. EXw.) tagad-aI fiI ramaDaAna means tasaH-ara [i. e. He ate the meal, or drank the draught of milk, called saHuwr, q. v.]. (TA.)
And tagad-ati AlUibilu means The camels pastured in the first part of the day. (AḤn, TA.)
8: see 1, first and second sentences.
[10. AstgdI accord. to Freytag is syn. with tagad-aI; but for this I do not find any authority.]

gadN, meaning The morrow, the day next after the present day, (Mṣb,) is originally gadowN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the w being elided, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) without any substitution, (Ṣ,) and the d being made a letter of declinability. (Mṣb.) And one says gadFA meaning [I will do such a thing, &c.,] tomorrow: and baEoda gadK the day after to-morrow. (MA.) See also gadaApN.
And its signification has been extended so that it is applied to a remote time that is expected, (Mṣb, TA,) and to a near time. (Nh, TA.)

It is not used in its complete form except in poetry: (Nh, TA:) Lebeed, (Ṣ, TA,) or Dhu-r-Rummeh, (TA,) has thus used it in his saying,
wamaA Aln-aAsu Uil-aA kaAld-iyaAri waOaholuhaA
bihaA yawoma Hal-uwhaA wagadowFA↓ balaAqiEu
[And mankind are no other than the like of dwellings, the occupants thereof being in them daring the day in which they have alighted in them, and to-morrow they are vacant]: (Ṣ, TA:) or, accord. to the M, one says, hecaA Eaduka and hecaA gadowuka↓ [This is thy morrow]. (TA.)
It has no diminutive. (Sb, Ṣ, in art. Ams.)
gadowN: see the next preceding paragraph, in there places.

gadaApN: see gudowapN, in four places: though [properly] fem., and not heard as made masc., it may be made masc. if meant to be understood as signifying the “first part of the day:” (IAmb, Mṣb:) it is originally gadawapN, because its pl. is gadawaAtN. (IHsh, TA.) One says, Mtiyka gadaApa gadK↓ [I will come to thee in the early part of the morning,, &c., of to-morrow]. (Ṣ, TA.) biQlogadaApi waQloEaXiI-i in the Ḳur [vi. 52 and xviii. 27] means After the prayer of daybreak and [after] the prayer of [the period of the afternoon called] the EaSor: or, accord. to some, [it means in the morning and the evening, or rather in the forenoon and the afternoon, for they say that] it denotes constancy of religious service: Ibn-'Ámir and Aboo-ʼAbd-er-Rahmán Es-Sulamee read biQlogudowapi↓ waQloEaXiI-i; but the former is the common reading; and AʼObeyd says, we think that they read thus following the handwriting, for it is written in all the copies of the Ḳur-án with w like AlS-alawp and Alz-akawp, and this is not an indication of the reading [which they have adopted], as the w in AlSlwp and Alzkwp is not pronounced [otherwise than as an A of prolongation except that it requires the fet-ḥah that follows to be uttered with a somewhat broad sound]. (TA.)
huwa Qbonu gadaAtayoni means He is a son of two days [i. e. he is two days old]. (TA.)

The dim. is guday-apN↓: (TA:) or this is the dim. of gudowapN↓: (EM p. 56:)
one says, Oarokabu Uilayohi guday-apF [I will ride to him, or it, in a short period of an early part of a morning,, &c.]: and one says also, catayotuhu guday-aAnaAtK↓ [I came to him, or it, in short periods of early parts of mornings,, &c.]; an anomalous [pl.] dim. like EuXay-aAnaAt; both of which are mentioned by Sb. (TA.)
gadowapN A journey in the first part of the day: [an inf. n. un. of gadaA:] opposed to rawoHapN. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.
And see gadaMCN.

gudowapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and gadowapN↓, said by MF to be well known, and gidowapN↓, said by him to be rare, or disapproved, (TA,) The early part of the morning; the first part of the day; (Ḳ;) or the period between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also gadaApN↓, and gadiy-apN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) the last [in the CK gadoyapi, but correctly] a dial. var. of gudowapN, like DaHiy-apN a dial. var. of DaHowapN: (IAạr, TA:) or gadaApN↓ is syn. with DaHowapN [meaning the early part of the forenoon, after sunrise; accord. to some, when the sun is yet low; or, accord. to others, when the sun is somewhat high]: (Mṣb:) [it may therefore be generally rendered morning, before, or after, sunrise:] the pls. are gudFI, which is pl. of gudowapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and gadawaAtN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) which is pl. of gadaApN↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and guduw-N↓, (Ḳ, TA,) which is a pl. of gudowapN, formed by rejecting the p [of the sing.], or, accord. to the M, an anomalous pl. of gadaApN↓, or, as J says, [in the Ṣ,] referring to the phrase biQlogaduw-i waQloMSaAli, in the Ḳur [vii. 204 and xiii. 16 and xxiv. 36], biAlguduw-i there means biAlgadawaAti, and is a verb [i. e. an inf. n.] used to denote the time, as [is TuluwE] in the saying TuluwEa AlX-amosi meaning fiI waqoti TuluwEi AlXms; (TA;) and gadiy-aAtN, (IAạr, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, gadayAtN,]) which is pl. of gadiy-apN↓; (TA;) and gadaAyaA, (Ḳ, TA,) which is likewise a pl. of gadiy-apN↓, accord. to IAạr, and, if so, regularly formed from gadaAyiwu, in the same manner as has already been expl. in the case of EaXaAyaA [pl. of EaXiy-apN, q. v. voce EaXiI-N]; by some said to be a pl. of gudowapN, but this has been controverted by IHsh in the Expos. of the “Kaabeeyeh” and by its commentator ['AbdEl-Kádir] El-Baghdádee; (TA;) or gadaAyaA is not used except in conjunction with EaXaAyaA; (Ḳ, TA;) one says, Uin-iI laMtiyhi biAlgadaAyaA waAlEaXaAyaA [Verily I come to him in the early parts of mornings and in the late parts of evenings], for the purpose of conformity. (Ṣ, TA.) Zj says that when gudowap means The bukorap [or early part of the morning,, &c.,] of the present day, or of a particular day, it is imperfectly decl.: and AḤei says that it is thus accord. to the opinion commonly obtaining, as is also bukorap, each as being a generic proper name, like OusaAmapu; and that when you mean to generalize, you say, gudowapN waqotu naXaATK [An early part of a morning is a time of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness]; and when you mean to particularize, laOasiyran-a All-ayolapa UilaI gudowapa [I will assuredly journey to-night until the early part of the morning]: (TA:) [in the latter case also] one says, Oatayotuhu gudowapa [I came to him in the early part of the morning of this, or of a particular, day]; gdwp being here imperfectly decl. because it is determinate, like saHara; but it is of those adv. ns. that may be used otherwise than as adv. ns.: you say, siyra EalaI farasika gudowapa and gudowapF [i. e. Journeying was performed on thy horse, or mare, in the gudowap of this, or of a particular, day, and in a gudowap,] and gudowapN and gudowapN [i. e. the journey of the gudowap of this, or of a particular, day, and the journey of a gudowap, was performed (lit. was journeyed) on thy horse, or mare, gudowapu and gudowapN being for. masiyrapu gudowapa and masiyrapu gudowapK, like as XahorN in the Ḳur xxxiv. 11 is for masiyrapu XahorK]; what is with tenween, of these, being indeterminate, and what is without tenween being determinate. (Ṣ. [In one of my copies of the Ṣ, siro is put in the place of siyra: that the latter is the right is shown by the addition of gudowapu and gudowapN; for each of these must be what is termed naAYibN Eano faAEilK i. e. a substitute for an agent.]) See also gadaApN, in two places.
gidowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
gadawiI-N: see gadiI-N.

Also Whatever [offspring] is in [any of] the bellies of pregnant animals (AO, Ḳ, TA) of camels and of sheep or goats: (AO, TA:) or peculiarly of sheep or goats; (Ḳ, TA;) thus in the dial. of the Prophet: (TA:) or it [virtually, in a trad. mentioned in what follows,] means the selling a camel, or other [animal], for what the stallion begets: or the selling a sheep for the offspring begotten by the ram: (Ḳ:) in all of which senses gaciI-N and gacawiI-N are [said to be] syn.: (Ḳ in art. gcw:) or gadawiI-N, (TA,) or gacawiI-N, or, as some relate a verse of El-Farezdaḳ in which it occurs, gadawiI-N, (Ṣ in art. gcw,) means the selling a thing for the offspring begotten by the ram [or, as appears from what follows, by the stallioncamel] in that year: gadawiI-N being a rel. n. from gadN: as though they rendered one desirous by saying, “Our camels will bring forth and we will give thee to-morrow (gadFA):” (Ṣ in art. gcw, and TA:) what is thus termed is forbidden in a trad.: a man used to buy, for a camel or a she-goat or money, what was in the bellies of pregnant animals; and this is a hazardous proceeding, and was therefore forbidden. (Nh, TA.) See also art. gcw.
And see Eadawiy-apN, in art. Edw.

gadoyaAnu Eating the meal called gadaMC: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) fem. gadoyaA, of the measure faEolaI, applied to a woman; (Ṣ;) or gadoyaMCu: (so in copies of the Ḳ:) they are originally with w [in the place of the I], on the ground of preference, as is said in the M: and gadoyaAnapN is mentioned by Z, as applied to a woman, coupled with EaXoyaAnapN. (TA.)

gadaMCN The morning-meal, that is eaten between daybreak and sunrise; i. e. the meal, or repast, of the gudowap; (Ḳ;) or of the gadaAp; (Mṣb;) the meal, or repast, that is the contr. of the EaXMC: (Ṣ:) [it may therefore be rendered breakfast: but it is now commonly applied to dinner, which is eaten soon after the prayer of noon, and which is a lighter repast than the EaXaMC, i. e. supper:] Algdwp [app. Algadowapu↓] as meaning AlgadaMCu is vulgar: (TA voce EaXowapN:) the pl. of gadaMCN is OagociyapN. (Ḳ.) And The [meal, or the draught of milk, called] saHuwr is thus termed; because it is to the person fasting the like of what it is to him who is not fasting. (TA.)
Also The pasture of camels in the first part of the day. (TA.)
gucuw-N: see gudowapN.
See also Eadawy-apN, in art. Edw.
gadiy-apN: see its syn. gudowapN, in three places.
guday-apN: and see gadaApN, last sentence.
guday-aAnaAtN: see gadaApN, last sentence.
AlgaAdiI The lion: (Ḳ, TA:) because he goes forth in the early part of the morning against the prey. (TA.)

gaAdiyapN A cloud that rises (Ṣ, Ḳ) in the SabaAH (Ṣ) or in the gudowap (Ḳ) [i. e. in the first part of the day]: or a rain of the [period of the morning called] gadaAp: (Ḳ, TA:) thus says Lḥ: the pl. is gawaAdK. (TA.) [See a verse in the Ḥam p. 429.]
magodFI and magodaApN↓ [A place to which people go, or to which they return, in the period of the morning called gudowap; opposed to maraAHN and maraAHapN].
[Hence] one says, maA taraka fulaAnN mino Oabiyhi magodFI walaA maraAHFA, and magodaApF↓ walaA maraAHapF, expl. in art. rwH. (Ṣ in art. rwH, and Ḳ in the present art.)
magodaApN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. gac-a, aor. _i {yagocicu}. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ, &c.) and _u, (Ḳ,) but the former aor. only is known, (MF,) inf. n. gad-N, (Ṣ, O, L,) It (a wound) flowed with what was in it; as also Agc-↓: (Ḳ:) or flowed with thick purulent matter; (Ṣ, O;) as also Agc-↓ [and gav-a] and Agv-: (O, L:) or flowed with purulent matter, thick or thin: (Az, O, L:) or became swollen: (Lth, L, Ḳ:) or this is a mistake; the true signification being that next preceding. (Az, O, L.) You say, tarakotu juroHahu yagic-u [I left his wound flowing with thick, or thin, purulent matter]. (Ṣ.)
Also It (a vein) flowed with blood without stopping; (O, L;) and so Agc-↓. (L.)
[And, accord. to Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd, He delayed, or loitered, and remained behind, in (fiI) a journey.]

And gad-ahu He diminished, or impaired, to him; or made him to lose; syn. naqaSahu; (O, Ḳ;) as also gacogaca↓ minohu. (O, Ḳ.) You say, maA gacacotuka XayoYFA i. e. maA naqaSotuka [I did not diminish to thee,, &c., or I have not diminished to thee,, &c., aught]. (O.)

entry.sense: 4. Agc-: see 1, in three places.
Agc- fiI Als-ayori, (Ṣ,* O,* L, Ḳ,) inf. n. UigocaAcN; (Ṣ, O, L;) and Agc- Als-ayora; (L, Ḳ;) He hastened in the pace or journeying; (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ;) and he hastened the pace or journeying. (L, Ḳ.)
And Abu-l-Ḥasan Ibn-Keysán thinks, from the use of the phrase sayorN mugic-N, that one says also, Agc- Als-ayoru, meaning The pace, or journeying, was quick. (L.)
R. Q. 1. gacogaca: see 1, last sentence but one.
R. Q. 2. tagacogada He leaped, sprang, or bounded. (O, Ḳ.)

gaciycapN Thick purulent matter (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ) of a wound; as also gaviyvapN. (Ṣ, O, L.) Yaạḳoob says that the c of the former is a substitute for the v of the latter; (L;) and so says Ibn-es-Seed. (TA.)

hom.sense: gaAc-N [act. part. n. of 1, q. v.:] as such signifying A vein incessantly bleeding. (L.)

Also A recrudescence (Earab [inf. n. of Eariba], so in the O, in copies of the Ḳ garab, and in the CK garob, [app. a mistranscription suggested by another explanation of gaAc-N which will be found in what follows,]) in any part of the body. (L, Ḳ.) AZ says, what we call AlEarabu, the Arabs term AlgaAc-u. (O.) One says of a camel that has had a gall on the back which has healed but is, or becomes, moist [or exuding], bihi gaAc-N [He has a gall which has healed but is moist, or constantly discharging, or exuding]. (Ṣ, O, L.)
And A vein, or duct, in the eye, [also called garobN,] which flows incessantly. (L, Ḳ.) In this sense, and in that immediately preceding, it is a subst. like kaAhilN and gaAribN. (L.)
And AlgaAc-u signifies AlHis-u: one says, qaTaEa Qll-ehu gaAc-a fulaAnK i. e. His-ahu [app. meaning May God cause to cease the sound of such a one]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O)

entry.sense: AlgaAcapu The part that is in a state of commotion, [or that pulses,] of the top of the head of a [young] child; as also AlgaAciyapu [which belongs to art. gcw]. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)
Oagac-u More, or most, or very, quick, and brisk, or sprightly. (L.)
sayorN mugic-N A quick pace or journeying: a phrase like layolN naAYimN. (L. [See also 4: and see an ex. voce muric-N, in art. rc.])
mugaAc-N A camel that loathes water. (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gacawotuhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) aor. Oagocuwhu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gacowN, (Ḳ,) I fed him, or nourished him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) [for instance,] a child, (Ṣ, TA,) with milk; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and gacayotuhu signifies the same, unknown by J, and therefore disallowed by him, (Ḳ and TA in art. gcI,) but known by ISd: (TA in that art.;) and so gac-ayotuhu↓, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. tagociyapN, (Ṣ, TA,) [but, accord. to SM.] in an intensive sense. (TA.) And gacaAhu AlT-aEaAmu, aor. and inf. n. as above, The food [nourished him, or] had an agreeable, a wholesome, or a beneficial, effect upon him, and sufficed him; namely, a child. (Mṣb.)
And [hence,] gucuw bilibaAni Alkarami ‡ [They were fed, or nourished, by sucking the milk of generosity; meaning they derived generosity from their parents]. (TA.)

gacaA bawolahu, and gacaA bihi, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a camel) interrupted his urine; (Ḳ, TA;) as also gc-Ahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. tagociyapN. (Ṣ, TA.) And gacaA Alkalobu bigacFI [or bigacFA] The dog emitted urine in repeated discharges. (TA.)
gacaA, said of urine, It became interrupted: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) the verb being intrans. as well as trans. (TA.)

And, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) aor. yagocuw, inf. n. gacowN and gacawaAnN, (M, TA,) It flowed; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) said of water, (Ṣ,) or, as some say, of anything, [or] of water or blood or sweat. (TA.) [Thus,] as IḲṭṭ says, the verb has two contr. significations. (TA.) It flowed with blood; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) aor. as above, inf. n. gacowN; (Ṣ;) said of a vein; as also gc-I↓, inf. n. tagociyapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And It flowed continually; aor. as above; said of a wound. (TA.)
And † He went quickly. or swiftly; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) aor. as above, inf. n. gacowN and gacawaAnN; said of a horse. (TA.)
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, first sentence.
[Hence,] Aln-aAru tugac-aI biAlHaTabi ‡ [The fire is fed with firewood]. (TA.)
And Alt-agociyapu signifies also Alt-arobiyapu [app. as meaning The rearing a child, &c. though it also means “the feeding, or nourishing”]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in an intensive sense. (TA.)
See, again, 1, in two places.

entry.sense: 5. tgc-I quasi-pass. of 2: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) see 8.
[Hence,] one says of a man, xayoruhu yatagac-aI kul-a yawomK ‡ His goodness increases every day. (TA.)

8. AgtcI He was, or became, fed, or nourished; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tgc-I↓. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, AgtcI bihi He was, or became, fed, or nourished, with it; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) namely, food, and beverage, (Ṣ,) or milk. (Mṣb.)
10. AstgcAhu He threw him down on the ground with vehemence. (Ḳ.)

gacFA or gacFI [accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the former agreeable with a general rule, though the latter is said in the TA to be the right,] The urine of the camel, (Ḳ, TA,) and of the dog. (TA. [See 1.])

gacawaAnN [an inf. n. of gacaA said of water, and of a horse, and hence, app.,] † Swift: (TA:) or brisk, lively, or sprightly, and swift; applied to a horse: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [see also gacawaAnN:]) or that interrupts his urine, or emits it in repeated discharges, (yagocuw bibawolihi,) when he runs. (TA.)

And (applied to a man, TA) † Long-tongued, or clamorous and foul-tongued; foul, unseemly, or obscene [in speech]: fem. with p {gacawaAnapN}: (Ḳ, TA:) the latter, applied to a woman, expl. by Fr as signifying faAHiXapN [i. e. foul,, &c., as above]. (TA.)
gacawiI-N: see gaciy-N, in four places:
and see also Eadawiy-apN, in art. Edw.

hom.sense: gicaMCN Aliment, or nutriment; consisting of food and of drink; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) the means of the growth, or increase, and of the sustenance, or support, of the body: (Ḳ:) pl. OagociyapN. (KL.) [One says rajulN Hasanu AlgicaMCi A man good in respect of food: i. e., who feeds on good food: and say-iYu AlgicaMCi bad in respect of food: who feeds: a bad food.]
It is also applied, by the poet Eiyoob Ibn-'Abáyeh. to † The water for irrigation of palm-trees. (TA.)
Also pl. of gaciI-N. (Ṣ, &c.)

entry.sense: gaciI-N A lamb, or kid; syn. saxolapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or, as some say, a lamb (Hamal); (Mṣb:) and the pl. is gicaMCN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and syn. with gadawiI-N in senses expl. in art. gdw: as also gacawiI-N: (Ḳ:) or gaciI-u AlmaAli and gacawiy-uhu↓ signify the younglings of cattle, such as lambs or kids and the like; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) accord. to Khalaf El-Aḥmar, (Ṣ,) or IF; so that they are of camels and of him and of sheep or goats: (Mṣb:) accord. to IAạr, gacawiI-N↓ is syn. with bhym [an evident mistranscription for bahom, q. v.]: and signifies such as is fed: (TA:) and he was told, he says, by an Arab of the desert, of Belhujeym, that the gacawiI-↓ is the lamb (Hamal), or the kid, that is not nourished with the milk of its mother, but with another's milk; accord. to which explanation it is different from the gaciy-; and so it is accord. to Az; but as IF says, some imagine AlgacawiI-u to be from AlgaciI-u, which signifies the saxolap [as expl. in the beginning of this paragraph]. (Mṣb, TA.) The dim. of gaciI-N is gucaI-N↓. (Ṣ.)
See also Eadawiy-apN, in art. Edw.
gucaI-N dim. of gaciI-N, q. v. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: gaAciI maAlK † A good manager or tender [of cattle]: (Ḳ, TA:) as though he fed them. or reared them. (TA.)
And AlgaAciI signifies also Teh wound that will not cease to bleed. (TA.)

entry.sense: AlgaAciyapu A certain vein; (Ḳ, TA;) so called because of its flowing with blood. (TA.)

And The part that is in a state of commotion, [or that pulses,] of the top of the head of a [young] child. as long as it continues soft; for when it becomes hard, and becomes bone, it is termed yaOofuwx: pl. AlgawaAciI: mentioned by AZ: (TA:) also called AlgaAc-apu. (IAạr, Ḳ in art. gc.)

AlgayocaA, of the measure fayoEalN [when indeterminate], from gacaA “it flowed,” occurring in a trad. as meaning The clouds, is said by Z to be the only word of this measure having the final radical letter infirm except AlkayohaA, [which I do not find in its proper art.,] meaning “the large, or bulky,” she-camel [like kahaApN and kayohaApN]. (TA.)
1. gacayotuhu: see 1 (first sentence) in art. gcw.

hom.sense: 1. gar-ahu, aor. yagur-u, inf. n. guruwrN (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gar-N, (Az, Ḳ,) which latter is preferable to the former, [though less common,] because the inf. n. of a trans. verb is scarcely ever of the measure fuEuwlN, (Az,) and gir-apN (Lḥ, Ḳ) and gararN, (IḲṭṭ, TA,) He (the devil, TA) deceived him; beguiled him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) made him to desire what was vain, or false. (Ḳ.) You say gar-atohu Ald-unoyaA The world deceived him, or beguiled him, by its finery, or show, or pomp. (Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [lxxxii. 6], maA gar-aka birab-ika What hath deceived thee, and led thee into error, so that thou hast neglected what was incumbent on thee to thy Lord? (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ:) or what hath deceived thee respecting thy Lord, and induced thee to disobey Him, and to feel secure from his punishment? (TA:) or what hath deceived thee, and emboldened thee to disobey thy Lord? (Bḍ. [But see bi as syn. with Eano.]) maA gar-aka bifulaAnK signifies [What hath deceived thee, and emboldened thee against such a one? or] how is it that thou art emboldened against such a one? (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) [See also 4.] And mano gar-aka bifulaAnK, (TA,) and mino fulaAnK, (Ṣ, TA,) Who hath made thee to pursue a course without being rightly directed, or a course not plain, (mano OawoTaOaka EuXowapF, Ṣ, TA,) with respect to such a one, (Ṣ,) or with respect to the case of such a one? (TA. [See again 4.]) [Also gur-a mino fulaAnK, i. e. gur-a guruwrFA SaAdirFA mino fulaAnK, He was deceived by such a one; he was deceived with deceit proceeding from such a one. See gariyrN, as syn. with magoruwrN.] And gar-a fulaAnN fulaAnFA Such a one exposed such a one to perdition or destruction [app. by deceiving him]. (TA. [See also 2, and 4.]) Also Such a one acted with such a one in a manner resembling the slaying with the edge of the sword. (TA. [See 3 in art. ETw.])

gar-a faroxahu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagoruru}, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. gar-N (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and giraArN, (O, Ḳ, [or the latter is inf. n. of gaAr-a only,]) It (a bird, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* or a pigeon, TA) fed its young one with its bill: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and gAr-↓ OunovaAhu, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. giraArN (Ṣ) or mugaAr-apN, (TA,) he (the [collared turtle-dove called] qumoriI-) fed his female with his bill. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Hence, in a trad., kaAna yagur-u Ealiy-FA (O, TA) biAlEilomi (TA) † He (the Prophet) used to nourish ʼAlee with knowledge like as the bird feeds its young one. (O, TA.*) And one says, gur-a fulaAnN mina AlEilomi maA lamo yugar-uhu gayoruhu † Such a one has been nourished, and instructed, with that wherewith other than he has not been nourished, and instructed, of knowledge. (TA.)

gar-a, aor. yagir-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) with kesr; (Ṣ;) or gar-a, see. pers. garirota, aor. yagar-u; (Ḳ, TA;) inf. n. garaArapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb, or a youth, or young man, Ḳ) was inexperienced in affairs; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he was ignorant of affairs; negligent, or heedless, of them. (Mṣb.) You say kaAna celika fiI garaAratiI waHadaAvatiI, i. e. fiI gir-atiI, That was in [the time of] my inexperience and youth. (Ṣ.) [See also 8.]

And gar-a, (Ḳ,) see. pers. garrota, (IAạr, T, TA,) aor. yagar-u, with fet-ḥ, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,) inf. n. garaArapN, (IAạr, T, TA,) He acted in a youthful or childish manner: (IAạr, T, TA:) or he so acted after having soundness of judgment, produced by experience. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) But this is at variance with what J cites from Fr, in art. Xd, that the aor. of an intrans. verb of this class of the measure faEala, should be of the measure yafoEilu, with kesr to the E. (TA.)

gar-a, (IAạr, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,) in one place written by IAạr garira, to show that it is of the measure faEila, and that the sec. pers. is garirota, (TA,) aor. yagar-u, (IAạr, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,) inf. n. gararN (IAạr, Ḳ) and gur-apN, (IAạr, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,) or the latter, as ISd thinks, is not an inf. n., but a subst., (TA,) and garAarapN, (Ḳ,) He (a horse, IAạr, IḲṭṭ, and a camel, IAạr) had what is termed a gur-ap upon his forehead: (IAạr, IḲṭṭ:) it (his face) had what is so termed: (Ḳ:) it (his face) became white. (IAạr, Ḳ.*)
gar-a, aor. yagar-u, He (a man) became eminent, or noble. (TA.)
And gur-apN signifies also A grape-vine's quickly becoming tall. (Ḳ.)
See also R. Q. 1.

gar-a Ealayohi AlmaMCa He poured upon him, or it, the water: like qar-a. (TA.) And gur-a fiI HawoDika Pour thou into thy watering-trough. (TA.) And gur-a fiI siqaAYika Fill thou thy skin by putting it into the water and throwing the water into it with thy hand, not abstaining until thou fillest it: thus as related by Az accord. to the usage of the desert-Arabs. (TA.)

2. gr-r binafosihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and bimaAlihi, (TA,) inf. n. tagoriyrN and tagir-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He exposed himself, (Ḳ, TA,) and his property, (TA,) to perdition, or destruction, or loss, (Ḳ, TA,) without knowing it: (TA:) he endangered, jeoparded, hazarded, or risked, himself, (Ṣ, TA,) [and his property,] and was negligent, or heedless, of the end, issue, or result, of an affair. (TA.) [See also 1.]

guz-ira He (a horse) was marked with a gur-ap [i. e. a star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face]: you say bima gur-ira farasuka With what kind of gur-ap is thy horse marked? and the owner answers, With a XAadixap, or with a watiyrap, &c. (Mubtekir El-Aạrábee, TA.)

gar-arato vaniy-ataA AlgulAamK The central incisors of the boy showed their points for the first time: (Ṣ:) or gr-r AlgulAamu the first of the teeth of the boy showed its point; as though the gur-ap, i. e. whiteness, of his teeth appeared: and gar-arato OasonaAnu AlS-abiI-i the teeth of the boy were disposed to grow, and came forth. (TA.)
And hence, (TA,) gar-arati AlT-ayoru The birds desired, or endeavoured, to fly, and raised their wings. (Ḳ, TA.)
gr-r Alqirobapa (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA) and Als-iqaMCa (TA) He filled the water-skin. (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.)

3. gAr-t Aln-aAqapu, (Aṣ, ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. tugaAr-u, inf. n. giraArN, (ISk, Ṣ,) The she-camel became scant of milk: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or deficient in milk: (TA:) or she took fright, and drew up her milk, (ISk, Ṣ,) after yielding milk freely: (ISk, TA:) or the she-camel, having yielded milk abundantly on her teats' being stroked, and not being promptly milked, drew up her milk, and would not yield it plentifully until it collected again in her udder in the interval before the next period of milking. (Az.) [This signification of the verb is said in the TA to be tropical: but I rather think it to be proper; as the next is derived from it.]
gAr-at Als-uwqu, aor. tugaAr-u, (AZ, Ṣ,) inf. n. giraArN, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) ‡ The market became stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) contr. of dar-at. (AZ, Ṣ.)
[See also giraArN, below.]
gAr- OunovaAhu, said of the qumoriI-: see 1.

entry.sense:
4. Agr-hu He, or it, emboldened him, or encouraged him; [by deceiving him;] syn. Oajosarahu: so says AHeyth; and he cites the following verse:
Oagar-a hiXaAmFA mino Oaxiyhi Qboni Oum-ihi
qawaAdimu SaOonK yas-arato warabiyEu
meaning [The teats of sheep that have yielded abundance of milk and of young, and spring herbage, i. e.] the abundance of his sheep and their milk, have emboldened Hishám against his brother, the son of his mother, [to pursue a wrong course towards him, and] to forsake him, thinking himself in dependent of him: the poet makes qwAdm to belong to sheep, whereas they properly belong to the udders of camels, using the word metaphorically. (TA.) [But I incline to think that the Oa in Oagar-a is the interrogative particle, and that its explanation is Oajas-ara, with the same particle; and the more so as I have not found any authority, if this be not one, for Oajosara in the sense of jas-ara: so that the meaning of the verse is, Have the teats,, &c.? and it shows that gar-ahu minohu, not Oagar-ahu, means jas-arahu Ealayohi, like gar-ahu bihi. See 1.]
Also He caused him to fall into peril, danger, jeopardy, hazard, or risk. (TA.) [But perhaps this meaning is also derived from a misunderstanding of the verse quoted above. See again 1.]

hom.sense: 8. Agtr- He became deceived, or beguiled; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) made to desire what was vain, or false; (Ḳ;) biXaIoCK by a thing. (Ṣ.) [See also 10.]
He was negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, heedless, or unprepared; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he thought himself secure, and therefore was not on his guard. (Mṣb.) [See again 10.]

Agtrahu He, or it, came to him when he was negligent, inadvertent, heedless, or unprepared; (T, Ṣ, TA;) as also Astgr-hu↓: (T, Ḳ, TA:) or he sought to avail himself of his negligence, inadvertence, heedlessness, or unpreparedness; as also Agtr-bihi. (TA.)
10. Astgr- i. q. Agtr- [which see in two places: but in what sense, is not said]: (Ḳ, TA:) said of a man. (TA.)
Astgr-hu: see Aigotar-ahu.

R. Q. 1. garogara, (IḲṭṭ,) inf. n. garogarapN, (Ḳ,) He gargled with water; (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ;) and in like manner with medicine; (IḲṭṭ;) made it to reciprocate in his throat, (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,) not ejecting it, nor suffering it to descend easily down his throat; (IḲṭṭ;) as also tagarogara↓. (Ḳ.)
garogarati Alqidoru The cooking-pot made a sound in boiling. (TA.) And grgr All-aHomu The flesh-meat made a sound in broiling. (Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a verse of El-Kumeyt cited voce maroDuwfapN.]
grgr He gave up his spirit, [app. with a rattling sound in the throat,] at death; (Ḳ;) as also gar-a↓. (TA.)
grgr biSuwotihi He (a pastor) reiterated his voice in his throat. (Ṣ.)
garogarahu He slaughtered him by cutting his throat with a knife. (Ḳ,* TA.)
He pierced him in his throat with a spear-head (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ.)
And garogarapN signifies also The breaking of the bone of the nose, and of the head of a flask or bottle. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tagarogara: see R. Q. 1.
tgrgr Sawotuhu fiI Haloqihi His (a pastor's) voice became reiterated in his throat. (Ṣ.)
tgrgrt Eayonuhu biAld-amoHi The water came and went repeatedly in his eye. (TA.)

hom.sense: gar-N, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ, O, TA, [in the CK erroneously said to be with damm,]) A crease, wrinkle, ply, plait, or fold, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) in skin, (O,* Ṣ,) accord. to Lth, from fatness, (TA,) or in a skin, (Ḳ,) and in a garment, or piece of cloth; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) syn. kasorN, (Ṣ, O,) or kasorN matavan-K, (Ḳ,) and makosirN: (Ṣ,* O:) pl. guruwrN. (Ṣ, TA.) [Hence,] guruwru Alfaxicayoni The furrows [or creases or depressed lines] between the muscles of the thighs. (TA.) And guruwru Alc-iraAEayoni The duplicatures [or creases] between the [sinew's called] HibAal [pl. of HabolN q. v.] of the fore arms. (TA.) And gar-u AlZ-ahori The duplicature [or crease] of the maton [or flesh and sinew next the backbone]: or, as ISk says, gar-u Almatoni signifies the line of the mtn. (TA.) And guruwru Alqadami The creases of the foot. (TA.) And one says, Tawayotu Alv-awoba EalaI gar-ihi I folded the garment, or piece of cloth, according to its first, or original, folding. (Ṣ, O, TA. [In the TA said to be tropical; but for this I see no reason.]) And hence Tawayotuhu EalaI gar-ihi meaning † I left him as he was, without making known his case: a saying proverbially used in relation to one who is made to rely upon his own opinion. (Ḥar p. 233. [In Freytag's Arab Prov., ii. 38, it is not well rendered nor well explained.]) Hence also the saying of ʼÁïsheh, respecting her father, mentioned in a trad., farad-a naXara AlUisolaAmi EalaI gar-ihi i. e. † And he reduced what was disordered of El-Islám to its [primitive] state [of order]: (O:) meaning that he considered the results of the apostacy [that had commenced], and counteracted the disease thereof with its [proper] remedy. (TA.)
Also A fissure, or cleft, in the earth or ground. (Ḳ.)
And A rivulet: (IAạr, TA:) or a narrow steam of water in land: (Ḳ, TA:) so called because it cleaves the earth: pl. guruwrN. (TA.)
guruwrN signifies also The streaks, or lines, of a road. (TA.)
And Algar-aAni signifies Two lines by the two sides of the lower part of the Eayor [or ridge in the middle of the iron head, or blade, of an arrow, &c.]. (AḤn, TA.)
See also giraArN, last sentence.
Also, the sing., The extremity of a tooth: pl. as above. (O.)
And The food wherewith a bird feeds its young one with its bill: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.)

Its pl. is used in a verse of 'Owf Ibn-Dhirweh in relation to the journeying of camels, in the phrase AiHotasaI guruwra Eiydiy-aAtihaA, meaning † He jaded their Eiydy-aAt [an appellation given to certain excellent she-camels]; as though he supped their guruwr. (TA.)

entry.sense: gir-N Inexperienced in affairs; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) ignorant of affairs; negligent, or heedless, of them; (Mṣb;) applied to a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or to a youth, or young man; (Ḳ;) as also gaAr-N↓ (Mṣb) and gariyrN↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and applied to a young woman; as also gir-apN and gariyrapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or these three epithets, applied to a girl, signify young, inexperienced in affairs, and not knowing what woman know of love: (AʼObeyd:) the pl. of gir-N is OagoraArN (Ṣ) and giraArN; (TA;) and of gariyrN↓, Oagor-aMCu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Oagir-apN [which is a pl. of pane.] (Ḳ.) [And gir-apN is also used as a pl.] Paradise says, yado xuloniI gir-apu Aln-aAsi The simple, of mankind, who prefer obscurity. and discard the affairs of the present world, and provide themselves for the world to come, enter me. (TA, from a trad.)
Also Youthful, or childish, in conduct: applied to a man, and to a girl, or young woman. (IAạr, T.)
And One who submits to be deceived. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: gur-apN Whiteness: clearness of colour or complexion. (L, TA.) So in the phrase Oagar-u↓ gur-apF [app. meaning More, or most. fair-complexioned]; occurring in a trad. applied to virgins: or the phrase is Oagar-u↓ gir-apF↓, meaning more, or most, remote from the knowledge of evil. (L.)

[A star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face of a horse;] a whiteness on the forehead of a horse, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) above the size of a diroham; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or of the size of a drhm; (Mgh;) as also gurogurapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it is a general term [for a star or blaze], including different kinds, as the quroHap and the XimoraAx and the like: or, if round, it is termed watiyrapN; and if long, XaAdixapN: or as, ISd thinks, the space itself, of the face, that is occupied by whiteness; not the whiteness: pl. gurarN. (TA.) [See also Oagar-u.]
In a dog, A white speck, or a small white spot, above each of the eyes: so in a trad., in which it is said that the black dog having two such marks is to be killed. (TA.)

Also ‡ The first, or commencement, of the month; (Mṣb;) the night, of the month, in which the new moon is first seen: (Ḳ:) so called as being likened to the gur-ap on the forehead of a horse: (AHeyth:) pl. gurarN: (AHeyth, Mṣb:) which is also applied to the first three nights of the month. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb.) One says katabotu gur-apa AlX-ahori kacaA I wrote on the first of the month thus. (TA.)
[And hence,] † The first, or commencement, of El-Islám; (TA;) and of anything. (Ṣ.)
The whiteness of the teeth; and the [first that appears] of them. (Ḳ.)
† The head [app. when first appearing] of a plant. (TA.)
† [The sight, or spectacle, or] whatever appears to one, of light, or daybreak: you say thereof, badato gur-atuhu [The sight, or spectacle, thereof appeared]. (Ḳ.)
† The aspect of the new moon: (Ḳ:) because of its whiteness: (TA:) or the phasis of the moon in the first night [of the month]. (TA in art. hl.)
† The face of a man: (Ḳ:) or his aspect; syn. TaloEap. (TA.)
† [And The forehead of a man. So used, as opposed to qafFA, in the Life of Teemoor, 170, ed. Mang., cited by Freytag; and so used in the present day; but whether in classical times I know not.]

taTowiylu Algur-api. in performing the ablution termed waDuwoC, means † The washing of the fore part of the head with the face, and the washing of the side of the neck: or, as some say the washing of somewhat of the fore arm and of the shank with the hand and the foot. (Mṣb)
And gur-ahN also signifies † A noble, or an eminent, man, (Ḳ,) or a chief, or lord, (Ṣ,) of a people (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. gurarN. (Ṣ.)

And ‡ The best. (Ḳ.) and chiefest, (TA,) of goods. or household furniture: (Ḳ:) pl. as above: (TA:) the best of anything: (Ṣ:) the best, (Mgh,) or most precious and excellent, (Aboo-Saʼeed,) of property; as, for instance, a horse, and an excellent camel, (Aboo-Saʼeed, Mgh.) and camels, (TA.) and a male slave. (Aboo-Saʼeed. Ṣ. Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) and a female slave, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or a clever female slave: (Aboo-Saʼeed, Mgh:) its application to a slave, male or female, [among articles of property,] is most common. (TA.) It has this last signification (a male or female slave) in a trad. in which it relates to the compensation for the destroying of a child in the womb: (TA:) as though this term were applied, by a synecdoche, to the whole person; (Ṣ;) the word properly signifying the “face;” in like manner as the terms raqabapN and raOosN are employed: (Mgh:) Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-Alà is related to have said that it there means a white male slave or a white female slave: but this is not a condition accord. to the doctors of practical law; for they hold the term to mean a male or female slave whose price amounts to the tenth part of the whole price of blood: (IAth:) or to the twentieth part thereof: (Ḳ, T:) or it means a slave of the best sort. (Mgh.) The Rájiz says,
kul-u qatiylK fiI kulayobK gur-aho
Hat-aI yanaAla Alqatolu Mla mur-aho
Every one slain in retaliation for Kuleyb is as a slave, until the slaying reach the family of Murrah. (TA.)

Also † Goodness, and righteous conduct: so in the saying, Uiy-aAkumo waAlmuXAar-apa faUin-ahaA tadofinu Algur-apa watuZohiru AlEur-apa [Avoid ye contention, or disputation, for it hides goodness,, &c., and manifests what is disgraceful]. (TA.)
[It is also an inf. n.: see 1, latter part.]

gir-apN Negligence; inattention; inadvertence, or inadvertency; inconsiderateness; heedlessness; or unpreparedness: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [pl. gir-aAtN and girarN: see an ex. of the former in a verse cited voce XafaEa, and exs. of both in a verse cited voce daraI.] It is said in a prov., Algir-apu tajolibu Ald-ir-apa Inadvertence brings the means of subsistence: (TA:) or paucity of milk causes to come abundance thereof: applied to him who gives little and from whom much is hoped for afterwards. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 179: and see also girAarN.]) [Hence,] EalaI gir-apK [On an occasion of negligence,, &c.; unexpectedly]. (Ḳ in art. ErD;, &c.) [And Eano gir-apK In consequence of inadvertence: see an ex. in a verse cited voce zalaqN.] Also Inexperience in affairs. (Ṣ.) gir-apN and garaArapN signify the same. (AʼObeyd.) [The latter is an inf. n.: see 1.] See also gur-apN, second sentence.
gir-apN biQll-ehi means Boldness against God. (Mgh.)
[See also gir-N.]

entry.sense: gur-aI: see Oagar-u, near the end.

hom.sense: gararN Peril; danger; jeopardy; hazard; or risk. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., nahaI Eano bayoEi Algarari He (Moḥammad) forbade the sale of hazard, or risk; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) of which it is unknown whether the thing will be or not; (Mgh;) such as the sale of fish in the water, and of birds in the air: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or, accord. to ʼAlee, in which one is not secure from being deceived: (Mgh:) or of which the outward semblance deceives the buyer, and the intrinsic reality is unknown: (TA:) or that is without any written statement (Euhodap), and without confidence. (Aṣ, Mgh.)
HabolN gararN means gayoru mawovuwqK bihi [i. e., app., A bond, or compact, in which trust, or confidence, is not placed]. (TA.)
See also gariyrN.

entry.sense: giraArN Paucity of milk of a camel: (Ḳ:) or deficiency thereof. (Ṣ.) [See 3.] It is said in a prov., respecting the hastening a thing before its time, sabaqa dir-atuhu giraArahu [lit., His abundant flow of milk preceded his paucity thereof]: (Aṣ:) or sabaqa dir-atahu giraAruhu [lit., his paucity of milk preceded his abundance thereof; agreeably with an explanation of Z, who says that it is applied to him who does evil before he does good: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 613: and see also gir-apN]. (So in my copies of the Ṣ.)
Hence, † Paucity of sleep. (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ.)

[Hence also,] in prayer, ‡ A deficiency in, (Ḳ,) or an imperfect performance of, (Ṣ,) the bowing of the body, and the prostration, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the purification. (Ḳ.) And in salutation, The saying (in reply to Als-alaAmu Ealayokumo) waEalayokumo, not waEalayokumu Als-alaAmu: (T, TA:) or the saying salaAmN Ealayokumo (Ḳ) or salaAmN Ealayoka (M) [without Al prefixed to slAm: as though it were a deficient form; but it is the form specially sanctioned by the Ḳur-án]: or the replying by saying Ealayoka, not Ealyokumo. (Ḳ.) This is said in explanation of a trad., lAa giraAra fiI SalaApK walaA tasoliymK [There shall be no deficiency in prayer, nor in salutation]: but accord. to one relation, it is lA grAr fI SlAp wlA tasoliyma, meaning, that the person praying shall not salute nor be saluted: in the former case, tslym is an adjunct to SlAp: in the latter, it is an adjunct to grAr, so that the meaning is, There shall be no deficiency nor salutation in prayer. (TA.)
Also ‡ Little sleep (Ṣ, Ḳ), &c. (Ḳ.) El-Farezdaḳ uses the expression nawomuhun-a girAarN Their sleep is little. (TA.)
And particularly † Littleness of consideration; denoting haste. (TA.) You say, OataAnaA EalaI girAarK † He came to us in haste. (Ṣ.) And laqiytuhu giraArFA † I met him in haste. (TA.)

And maA Oaqamotu Einodahu Uil-aA giraArFA † [I remained not at his abode save] a little while. (TA.) And labiva giraAra XahorK He (a man, Ṣ) tarried the space of a month. (Ṣ, O, TA.) And layota Alyawoma giraAru Xahori i. e. [Would that the day were] of the length of a month. (So in some copies of the Ṣ, and in the O: in other copies of the Ṣ, labiva Alqawomu giraAra XahorK [like the phrase immediately preceding].)

And, accord. to Aṣ, giraArN signifies A way, course, mode, or manner. (Ṣ, O, TA.) One says, ramayotu valaAvapa OasohumK EalaI giraArK waAHidK [I shot three arrows] in one course. (Ṣ, O, TA.) And waladato fulaAnapu valaAvapa baniyna EalaI giraArK, (Ṣ,) or EalaI giraArK waAHidK, (TA,) i. e. [Such a woman brought forth three sons,] one after another, (Ṣ, TA,) without any girl among them. (TA.) And banaI Alqawomu buyuwtahumo EalaI giraArK waAHidK [app. The people, or party, reared their tents, or, perhaps, their houses, in one line, or according to one manner]. (Ṣ, O.)

Also The model, or pattern, according to which iron heads (Ṣ, Ḳ) of arrows (Ṣ) are fashioned, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in order to their being made right. (Ḳ.) One says, Daraba niSaAlahu EalaI giraArK waAHidK (Ṣ, TA) i. e. [He fashioned his arrow-heads according to] one model, or pattern. (TA.)

And The Had- [app. meaning point, or perhaps the edge of the iron head or of the blade,] of a spear and of an arrow and of a sword: [see also cubaAbN:] and gar-N↓ also signifies the Had- of a sword: (Ḳ, TA:) or AlgiraAraAni signifies the two sides of the [arrow-head called] miEobalap: (AḤn, TA:) or the two edges of the sword: [see, again, cubaAbN:] and giraArN, the Had- of anything that has a Had-: (Ṣ, O:) and the pl. is Oagir-apN. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: garuwrN Very deceitful; applied in this sense as an epithet to the present world; (Mṣb;) or what deceives one; (Ḳ;) such as a man, and a devil, or other thing; (Aṣ, TA;) or such as property or wealth, and rank or station, and desire, and a devil: (B, TA:) and guruwrN↓ signifies a thing by which one is deceived, of worldly goods or advantages: (Ṣ:) or the former signifies the devil, specially; (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ;) because he deceives men by false promises and by inspiring hopes; or because he urges a man to do those things which are causes of his being loved but which are followed by that which grieves him: (TA:) and this last sense it has, accord. to ISk, in the Ḳur xxxi. 33 and xxxv. 5: (Ṣ:) also the present world; (Ḳ;) as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: and this sense is assigned to it by some as used in the passages of the Ḳur-án to which reference has just been made. (TA.) [It is masc. and fem., agreeably with analogy.]
Also A medicine with which one gargles: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a word similar to laduwdN and laEuwqN and saEuwTN (Ṣ) and safuwfN. (TA.)

entry.sense: guruwrN False, or vain, things; vanities: (Zj, Ḳ:) as though pl. of gar-N, inf. n. of gar-ahu: (Zj:) or pl. of gaAr-N↓; (Zj, Ḳ;) like as XuhuwdN is pl. of XaAhidN, and quEuwdN of qaAEidN: (Zj:) or what is false, or vain; a deception; a thing by which one is deceived. (AZ.) See also garuwrN.

gariyrN Deceived; beguiled; made to desire what is vain, or false; (AʼObeyd, Ḳ;) and so magoruwrN↓. (Ḳ.) And you say likewise, OanaA gararN↓ minoka, in the sense of magoruwrN [I am deceived by thee]. (TA.) And magoruwrN↓ signifies also A man who marries to a woman in the belief that she is free, and finds her to be a slave. (TA.)
See also gir-N, in three places.

It is said in a prov., OanaA gariyruka mino hecaA AlOamori, meaning I am one possessing knowledge in this affair so that when thou askest me of it I will inform thee respecting it without being prepared for it and without consideration: so says AZ: and Z says the like; i. e. I [am one who] will answer thee if thou ask me unexpectedly respecting this affair by reason of the soundness of my knowledge of the true state of the case: or [it means I am a deceived informant of thee respecting this affair; for] as Aṣ says, the meaning is, thou art not deceived by me, but I am the person deceived; the case being this, that false information came to me, and I acquainted thee with it, and it was not as I told thee; I having only related what I had heard. (TA.) And one says, OanaA gariyruka minohu i. e. I caution thee [or I am thy cautioner] against him; (Ḳ, TA:) [i. e.,] mino fulaAnK [against such a one]; (Ṣ, O;) meaning, as Aboo-Naṣr says in the “Kitáb el-Ajnás,” [that] there shall not happen to thee, from him, that whereby thou shalt be deceived; (Ṣ, O, TA;) as though he said, I am thy surety, or sponsor, for that. (AM, TA.)
[Hence, app., it is said that] gariyrN signifies also A surety, sponsor, or guarantee. (Ḳ, TA.)
And EayoXN gariyrN ‡ A life in which one is not made to be in fear: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) like EayoXN Oabolahu: (TA:) pl. gur-aAnN. (Ḳ.)

Hence, perhaps; or from Algir-apu [app. as meaning “inexperience”], which is sometimes approved; (Ḥar p. 607;) or because it [sometimes] deceives; (TA;) gariyrN also signifies ‡ Good disposition or nature. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
One says of a man when he has become old, and evil in disposition, Oadobara gariyruhu waOaqobala hariyruhu ‡ His good disposition has regressed, or departed, and his evil disposition has advanced, or come: (Ṣ, Meyd, O, TA:) or what deceived and pleased has gone from him, and what is disliked on his part, of evilness of disposition, &c., has come. (Meyd.)

giraArapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) not garaArapN, (Ḳ,) for the latter is vulgar, (TA,) A sack, syn. juwaAliqN, (Ḳ,) for straw, &c., (Ṣ,) resembling what is called EidolN: (Mṣb:) [J says,] I think it is an arabicized word: (Ṣ:) pl. garAaYiru. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: gaAr-N Deceiving; beguiling; causing to desire what is vain, or false; a deceiver. (TA.)
See also guruwrN.
And Negligent; inattentive; inadvertent; inconsiderate; heedless; unprepared. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also gir-N.

entry.sense: garogarapN A sound with which is a roughness, (Ḳ,) like that which is made by one gargling with water. (TA.)
The sound of a cooking-pot when it boils. (Ḳ.)
The reciprocation of the spirit in the throat. (Ṣ.)
A word imitative of the cry of the pastor (Ḳ, TA.) and the like. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1.]
gurogurapN: see gur-apN:
and see Oagar-u.

hom.sense: Oagar-u More, or most, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, heedless, or unprepared. (Mgh.) See also gur-apN, second sentence.

And White; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to anything: (Ḳ:) pl. gur-N (TA) and gur-aAnN (Ṣ) [and perhaps gurarN, as in an ex. voce cirowapN: but see what is said of this pl. in a later part of this paragraph]. You say rajulN Oagar-u Alwajohi A man white of countenance. (TA.) And qawomN gur-aAnN, (Ṣ,) and gur-N, (TA,) White people. (Ṣ.) And AimoraOapN gar-aMCu A woman [white of countenance: or] beautiful in the front teeth. (TA voce far-aMCu.) See, again, gur-apN, second sentence. And AlOay-aAmu Algur-u The days of which the nights are white by reason of the moon; which are the 13th and 14th and 15th; also called AlbiyDu. (TA.) And yawomN Oagar-u muHaj-alN: see art. Hjl. And All-ayolapu Algar-aMCu † The night of [i. e. preceding the day called] Friday. (O.)

Also A horse having a gur-ap [i. e. a star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or having a gur-ap larger than a diroham, in the middle of his forehead, not reaching to either of the eyes, nor inclining upon either of the cheeks, nor extending downwards; it is more spreading than the quroHap, which is of the size of a drhm, or less: or having a gur-ap of any kind, such as the quroHap or the XimoraAx or the like: (L, TA:) and in like manner a camel having a gur-ap: (IAạr:) fem. gar-aMCu. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See an ex. in a prov. cited voce bahiymN: and another (from a trad.) voce muHaj-alN.]

[Hence] Algar-aMCu † A certain bird, (Ḳ, TA,) black, (TA,) white-headed: applied to the male and the female: pl. gur-N; (Ḳ, TA;) which is also expl. in the Ḳ as signifying certain aquatic birds. (TA.)
And Oagar-u, (Ḳ, TA,) applied to a man, (TA,) † One whose beard occupies the whole of his face, except a little: (Ḳ, TA:) as though it [his face] were a [horse's] gur-ap. (TA.)
