Algisoliynu (in the Ḳur [lxix. 36], TA) What is washed off of the flesh and the blood of the inmates of the fire [of Hell]; (Akh, Ṣ, O;) [for] what comes forth from any wound, or sore, when it is washed, is termed gisoliyn: (TA:) what is washed off from the bodies of the unbelievers, in the fire: (Mṣb:) or what flows from the skins of the inmates of the fire, (Ḳ, TA,) such as thick purulent matter, &c.; thus expl. by Fr and Seer; (TA;) as though it were washed from them: (Sb, TA:) accord. to Mujáhid, a certain food of the inmates of the fire; and El-Kelbee says that it is what the fire has cooked, of their flesh, and has fallen off, and is eaten by them: (TA:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to Eḍ-Ḍaḥḥák, (O, TA,) a species of trees in the fire; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and so he says of AlD-ariyEu: (O, TA:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) what is intensely hot: (O, Ḳ, TA:) the I and n are augmentative. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.)

gasuwlN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and gas-uwlN↓ (O, Ḳ) and gusolN↓ (Mgh, Ḳ) and gisolN↓ and gisolapN↓ (IAth, Ḳ) Water with which one washes himself; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ;) as also mugotasalN↓, occurring [in this sense] in the Ḳur xxxviii. 41: (Ṣ:) or the words preceding this signify water little in quantity, with which one washes himself: (TA:) and xiTomiI- [or marsh-mallows], (Ḳ, TA,) and OuXonaAn [or potash (see also gaAsuwlN)], and the like thereof, and certain of the [plants termed] HamoD: (TA:) or gasuwlN signifies a thing [or substance] with which the hand is washed, such as OuXonaAn &c.: (Ḥar p. 86:) or, accord. to the M, anything with which one washes a head or a garment and the like. (TA.) [See also the pl. gasuwlaAtN voce daluwkN.]

gasiylN i. q. magosuwlN↓ [i. e. Washed]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a thing, (Ṣ, O,) and to a dead body; (Lḥ, Mṣb, TA;) and the former is also applied as an epithet to a fem. n., as is also gasiylapN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or this last is used after the manner of substs., like naTiyHapN and cabiyHapN; not as is said in the Ṣ [and O] after the manner of epithets: (IB, TA:) the pl. of gasiylN is gasoliI and gusalaMCu; (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA;) and the pl. of gasiylapN [and app. of gasiylN used a fem. epithet] is gasaAlaI or gusaAlaI. (Ḳ accord. to different copies.) Han- dhaleh Ibn-er-Ráhib was called gasiylu AlmalaAYikapi [The washed of the angels], because he died a martyr on the day of Ohod, and the angels washed him, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) accord. to the Prophet, who said that he saw them washing him. (O.)
See also gusalapN.
[It is now used as meaning Clothes, or the like, put together to be washed.]

AlgusaAlapu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or gusaAlapu AlX-aIoCi, (Ḳ,) That with which one has washed the thing: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) or the water with which the thing is washed. (Ḳ.) [Hence the latter often signifies The infusion of the thing; i. e. the liquid in which the thing has been steeped, and which is impregnated with its virtues.]
Also, the latter, What is extracted from the thing by washing. (Ḳ.)
And AlgusaAlapu also signifies What is washed from the garment and the like; and so Algisoliynu↓. (Ḳ.)
gasowiylN A certain plant, growing in places that exude water and produce salt: (O, Ḳ:) said by IDrd to be a species of trees. (O.)
gas-aAlN [A washer of clothes, and also of the dead: fem. with p {gas-aAlapN}]. (TA.) [See also gaAsilN.]
gas-uwlN: see gasuwlN.
gis-iylN: see gusalapN.

hom.sense: gaAsilN A washer of the dead. (Mṣb.) [See also gas-aAlN.]
And A species of trees. (TA.)

entry.sense: gaAsuwlN i. q. OuXonaAnN [i. e. Potash: and the plant from which it is prepared; kali, or glasswort; or mesembryanthemum nodiflorum (Forskål, Flora Ægypt. Arab. pp. lxvii. and 98), a species of glasswort]. (TA.) [See also gasuwlN.]

magosilN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and magosalN [which is anomalous] (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and mugotasalN↓ (Ḳ) A place in which the dead are washed: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) pl. of the first (Ṣ, Mṣb) and second (Ṣ) magaAsilu: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and one says also magosilu AlmawotaI. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.*)

hom.sense: migosalN A thing [i. e. vessel] in which (so in the M, in the Ḳ with which,) a thing is washed. (TA.)
See also gusalapN.

entry.sense: magosuwlN: see gasiylN.

Hence one says, kalaAmuhu magosuwlN, meaning † His speech, or language, is devoid of nice, or subtile, expressions or allusions; as though it were washed from such; or deserving to be washed and obliterated: or it may mean ‡ trimmed, or pruned. (TA.)
mugotasalN A place in which one washes himself: (O, Mṣb, TA:*) dim. mugayosilN↓: and pl. magaAsiylu [which, if correct, is anomalous]. (TA.)
And it is said to signify also what is called in Pers. HwD masiyn [or HawoD misiyn app. meaning A tank, or the like, of copper]. (Mgh.)
See also magosilN.
And see gasuwlN.
mugayosilN: see the next preceding paragraph.
1. gasama It (the night) was, or became, dark; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Agsm↓, (JK, Ḳ,) like OagosaI. (JK.)
4: see what precedes {1}.

gasamN The darkness (Ṣ, ISd, TA) of night; (ISd, TA;) like gasaqN: (Ṣ, TA:) or blackness: (Kr, Ḳ:) and (Ḳ) accord. to En-Naḍr, (Ṣ,) the confusedness, or blending, of the darkness: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the first rising of the dawn. (JK.)
And Dust, or dust rising, or spreading, like smoke; syn. habowapN and gabarapN (Ḳ) or guborapN [which sometimes signifies the same as gabarahN]. (CK.)
gusamN; see OagosaAmN.
layolN gaAsimN Dark night. (TA.)
fiI Als-amaMCi OagosaAmN and gusamN↓ In the sky are portions of clouds. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4: see what precedes {1}.
AgsI also signifies He (a man) entered upon the time of, or a little after, sunset. (TA.)
And Oagosi mina All-ayoli Journey thou not in the first part of the night, until its darkness depart. (TA.)
And AgsAhu All-ayolu The night enveloped him in its darkness. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

1. gaX-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagoXuXu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gaX-N, (Mṣb, TA,) or giX-N, with kesr, (Ṣ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He acted towards him, or advised or counselled him, dishonestly, or insincerely: (A. Mṣb, Ḳ:) and he dressed up to him an affair [in false colours]: (Mṣb:) or he acted towards him with dissimulation: pretended to him the contrary of what he conceived in his mind: (A, Ḳ:) but this is a needless addition, for it is the same as the first explanation (TA:) as also gX-Xhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tagoXiyXN: (TA) or this latter has an intensive signification: it is said to be derived from gaXaXN, signifying “a turbid drinking-place,” (TA:) It is said in the story of Umm-Zarạ, accord. to one relation, laA tamolaOu bayotanaA tagoXiyXFA↓, said by some to be from AlgiX-u, and by others to be from [a usage of] AltgXyX as signifying Aln-amiymapu [app. here meaning the embellishing speech with falsehood]: but accord. to the approved relation, it is [tagoXiyXFA] with the unpointed letter. (IAth.) [See art. EX.]

[Also He made it to seem what it was not; falsified it; counterfeited it; adulterated it: so as used often by post-classical authors; and so, probably, in classical times also; see its pass. part n., below.]
gaX-a Sadoruhu,, aor. _i {yagoXiXu}, [inf. n., probably. giX-N, q. v.,] His bosom concealed enmity and violent hatred; or bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, (TA,)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.

4. AgX-hu, inf. n. UigoXaAXN, He made him to fall into dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel; into dissimulation; or the pretending the contrary of what he conceived in his mind. (TA.)
And OagoXaXotuhu Eano HaAjatihi I prevented him from obtaining the object of his want; syn. OaEojalotuhu. (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ.)
8: see the next paragraph {10}, in two places.

10. AstgX-hu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AgtX-hu↓ (Ḳ, TA) He reckoned him, or deemed him, dishonest, or insincere, in action, or advice or counsel; contr. of AisotanoSaHahu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AinotaSaHahu; (Ḳ;) or, [which means the same,] i. q. Ead-ahu gaAX-FA: (TA:) or he imagined in him dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel; dissimulation; or the pretending the contrary of what he conceived in his mind. (Ḳ.) A poet says,
OayaA rub-a mano tagotaX-uhu↓ laka naASiHN
wamusotanoSaHK biAlogayobi gayoru Oamiyni
[O man, many a one whom thou reckonest dishonest in action, or advice, is honest therein to thee; and (many a) one who is reckoned honest in action, or advice, in that which is beyond the reach of perception, is not faithful]. (TA)

gaX-N, (Ḳ, TA,) of the measure faEolN, or it may be originally of the measure faEilN, (TA,) applied to a man, (Ḳ, TA,) i. q. EaZiymu AlX-arahi [i. e. Very greedy]; not EZym Als-ur-api, as in some copies of the Ḳ; nor EZym AlX-ir-api, as in other copies: a rájiz says,
layosa bigaX-K ham-uhu fiymaA Oakalo
[He is not one who is very greedy; whose care, or solicitude, is in respect of what he has eaten]. (TA)

giX-N Dishonest, or insincere, conduct, or advice or counsel: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) and the embellishment of an affair [with false colours]: (Mṣb:) or dissimulation; pretence of the contrary of what one conceives in his mind. (Ḳ.) [See also 1.]
And Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (Ḳ.)
[Also Adulterating alloy in coin (See HumolaAnN.)]
[And Adulterated, or counterfeit, coin. (See zagalN.)]

gaXaXN A turbid drinking-place: (Az, IAmb, Ṣgh, TA:) Alkadiru AlmaXuwbu in the Ḳ is a mistake: the right explanation of AlgaXaXu being AlmaXorabu Alkadiru, which is that given by Az and IAmb and Ṣgh. (TA.)
gaXaAXN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: giXaAXN, applied to a drinking (XurobN), Little in quantity, (Ḳ, TA,) because of turbidness: (TA: [in which it is said to be applied in like manner to a day, ywm; but I think that this is a mistranscription for nawomN, i. e. sleep:]) or hasty. or not wholesome; (Ḳ, TA;) because the water is not clear. (TA.)
And The beginning of the darkness: and the end thereof. (Ḳ.)

naqiytuhu giXaAXFA, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and gaXaAXFA↓, (Ḳ,) I met, or found, him, or it, in haste; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so ElI gXAX: (T, TA:) or at sunset; (Lth, Ḳ;) but Az disallows this: (TA:) or in the night; (Ḳ;) which is nearly the same as what Lth says. (TA.)

entry.sense: gaAX-N Acting, or advising or counselling, dishonestly, or insincerely; or acting with dissimulation; pretending the contrary of what one conceives in his mind: [see its verb;] pl. giXaXapN and [quasi-pl. n., like as SaHaAbapN is of SaAHibN,] gaXaAXapN (TA.)

XaIoCN magoXuwXN [A thing made to seem what it is not; falsified; counterfeited; adulterated]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a thing that is not pure; not genuine; or not unadulterated. (Ḳ.) You say, TaEaAmu fulaAnK magoXuwXN OaEolaAhu yaAbisN waOasofaluhu maroXuwXN [The wheat of such a one is made to seem what it is not: it upper part is dry, and its lower part is sprinkled]. (A.) And labanN magoXuwXN Milk mixed with water. (Mgh, Mṣb.) And fiD-apN magoXuwXapN Silver mixed with copper or brass. (TA.)

1. gaXomN signifies The acting, or treating, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the taking another's property wrongfully,, &c., or by force: and the taking a course, in journeying [&c.], at random, without direction and without knowledge. (JK.) One says of a governor, gaXama Alr-aEiy-apa, aor. _i {yagoXimu}, [accord. to the TḲ, the aor. of the verb in the sense here following is _u, but this I think a mistake,] inf. n. gaXomN, He struck, or beat, with vehemence, the people under his government, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, and took [from them] what he could. (TA.) And gaXama Aln-aAsa He asked whom he could of the people. (Z, TA.) And gaXama AlOumuwra He performed affairs, or the affairs, [in a random manner,] confusedly, without discrimination. (Ḥam p. 37: by implication.)

And gaXamahu, aor. _i {yagoXimu}, He smeared him [i. e. a camel] with tar so that he left nothing [or no part of him] without tar, pouring it upon what was sound thereof and what was diseased thereof: and gaXamN↓ [perhaps as an inf. n., but accord. to the TḲ it is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is gaXomN,] signifies the act of so smearing. (Ḳ.)
And gaXama ‡ He collected firewood by night, cutting whatever he could get, without consideration, (Ḳ, TA,) or, as in the A, without discrimination. (TA.)

hom.sense: gaXamN: see the preceding paragraph.
Also Blackness [of night: app. a dial. var. of gasamN; or, perhaps, a mistranscription]. (Ḥam p. 163.)

entry.sense: gaXuwmN A man who strikes, or beats, people vehemently, [and wrongfully, (see 1,)] and takes [from them] everything that he can get; as also gaX-aAmN↓ and gaAXimN↓ [except that the first and second are app. intensive epithets and the last is a simple part. n.]: and it is likewise applied to a fem., as, for ex., to a hand (yadN): and to a striking, or beating, (DarobN,) [app. as meaning wrongful,] as is also gaXamoXamN↓. (TA.) [One says,] AlHarobu gaXuwmN [War is wrongful], because it reaches other than the committer of a crime, or an offence deserving punishment. (Ṣ.)
Also A she-camel that will not be turned back from her course, or way. (R, TA.)
gaXiymN, meaning [Ignorant of affairs,] not knowing anything, is a word of the vulgar. (TA.)
guXuwmiy-ahN, meaning Ignorance of affairs, is a word of the vulgar, like that next preceding. (TA.)
gaX-aAmN: see gaXuwmN.
gaAXimN: see gaXuwmN.
gaXamoXamN: see migoXamN. Accord. to some, it signifies One who acts with much wrongfulness, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny. (Ḥam p. 104.)

naAqapN gaXamoXamapN A she-camel strong, resisting, or indomitable, in spirit. (IJ, TA.) And gaXamoXamN is applied to a he-camel as meaning haAYijN [i. e. Excited by lust]. (Meyd in explanation of the prov. here following.)

gaXamoXamN yugaX-iI AlX-ajara, i. e. This, or it or he, is a torrent [wild in its course,] that overwhelms the trees, so that it crushes them and uproots them, sayolN preceded by hecaA or huwa being meant to be supplied, is a prov. applied to a man who cares not what wrong he does. (Meyd.)
See also gaXuwmN.
Uin-ahu lacuw gaXamoXamapK and gaXamoXamiy-apK Verily he is one who possesses boldness, or daringness, and penetrative energy. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OagoXamu [More, and most, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical:, &c.: see 1]. OagoXamu mina Als-ayoli [More wild in course than the torrent] is a proverb. (Meyd.)
IAar cites a verse in which it is applied to a plant as meaning Dry and old; but accord. to one relation of that verse, the word is OaEoXam. (TA.)

entry.sense: migoXamN One who goes at random, heedlessly, or in a headlong manner, without consideration, whom nothing will turn from that which he desires, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of his courage; (Ṣ;) as also gaXamoXamN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, one who performs affairs [in a random manner,] confusedly, without discrimination: or, as some say, one who, when the road is unapparent to him, goes at random, without direction and without knowledge. (Ḥam p. 37.)

hom.sense: 1. gaXiyahu, aor. yagoXaI, inf. n. gaXaAwapN, It covered, or concealed, him, or it; (TA;) as also tgX-Ahu↓. (MA.) And one says, gaXaAniI All-ayolu, i. e. gaXiyaniI [The night covered me, or concealed me: or the meaning may be that which next follows]. (JK.)

gaXiyahu, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) is said of an event (OamorN), [and of heat, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. dgm,) and of cold, (Ḳ in that art.,) and of an affection of the mind or body, and of various things, sometimes in like manner of a man, and of a company of men,] in a similar sense; and so tgX-Ahu↓; (Ḳ, TA;) both signifying It came upon, [or invaded, so as to surprise, and so as to over-whelm, properly meaning] as a thing that covered, him, or it. (Ḳ,* TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [liii. 16], Uico yagoXaI Qlsi-dorapa maA yagoXaI [When there was coming upon the lote-tree so as to cover it, or overspread it, what was so coming]. (TA.) And in the same [xx. 81], fagaXiyahumo mina Qloyam-i maA gaXiyahumo [And there came upon them so as to overwhelm them, of the sea, what so came upon them]. (TA.) And in the same [viii. 11], Uico yagoXaAkumu [followed by QAln-uEaAsu, i. e. When it (drowsiness) was coming upon you, or overcoming you]; accord. to one reading; other readings being yugoXiykumu and yugaX-iykumu [followed by Qln-uEaAsa]. (TA.) See also gaAXiyapN, in three places.
[A somewhat similar signification of gaXiyahu will be found below.]
[And gaXiyahu, and gaXiIa baSarahu and gX-Ahu↓, signify It, i. e. light (DawoCN), came upon him, and upon his eye, with an overpowering effect, so as to obscure, or dazzle, his sight.]

gaXiyahu also signifies jaMCahu (Ṣ) or OataAhu (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) [which have two meanings, i. e. He came to him, and he did it; both, perhaps, here meant, for both are well-known meanings of gaXiyahu]; and, thus used, the aor. is as above, (TA,) and the inf. n. is gaXayaAnN, (Ṣ, TA,) or giXoyaAnN, (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) or the subst. is giXoyaAnN↓, (Mṣb,) with kesr, (Mgh, Mṣb,) syn. with UitoyaAnN. (Mgh.) You say, gaXiIa fulaAnFA He came to such a one; syn. OataAhu; as also gaXaAhu, aor. yagoXuwhu. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] gaXiyahaA, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gaXayaAnN or giXoyaAnN, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) or the latter and gaXoIN, (MA,) or giXoyaAnN↓ is the subst. in this case also, (Mṣb,) and syn. with UitoyaAnN, metonymically used in the sense of jimaAEN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) ‡ He compressed her; (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a woman; (MA, Ḳ;) as also tgX-AhA↓. (MA, Mṣb, TA.)

And gaXiIa Uilayohi maHojarFA He did to him (OataI Uilayohi) a forbidden action. (TA in art. Hjr.) [Hence,] giXoyaAnu↓ AlmaHaArimi [The doing of forbidden things]. (Mgh and Mṣb and Ḳ in art. rhq.) And gaXiIa AlX-aIoCa He occupied himself with the thing, engaged in it, or personally managed or conducted it; syn. laAbasahu and baAXarahu. (JM.) [And tgX-I↓ has a similar meaning; for it is said that] Alt-agaX-iI and AlgaXoIu primarily signify AlUitoyaAnu and AlmulaAbasapu: and they took an extended range in using the former, so that one said, tagaX-aAhumo↓ biAlEadoli or biAlojawori [app. meaning He ruled them with equity or with injustice]. (Ḥam p. 27.) [And one says, yagoXaI AlHuruwba (see Ḥam p. 27), meaning He plunges into wars, or battles: see mugaAmisN, and its verb.]

One says also, gaXiyahu biAls-awoTi, (Ḳ, in which it is said to be like raDiyahu, and so accord. to some copies of the Ṣ, the phrase in these being gaXiyatu Alr-ajula biAls-awoTi,) or gaX-aAhu↓ bihi, (accord. to other copies of the Ṣ, the verb in these being written gaX-ayotu, and thus accord. to an explanation of qan-aEa raOosahu biAls-awoTi in art. qnE in the Ḳ,) He struck him (i. e. a man, Ṣ) with the whip; he flogged him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

guXiIa Ealayohi, (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gaXoIN, (Ṣ, Mgh,* Ḳ,) or guXoIN, (MA,) or both, (Mṣb,) and gaXayaAnN, (Ḳ, TA, and so in some copies of the Ṣ,) or giXoyaAnN, (so in other copies of the Ṣ,) and gaXoyapN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or this last is an inf. n. of un., (Mṣb,) or it is the subst., (Ḳ,) He swooned, i. e. became senseless: (MA, PṢ:) or i. q. OugomiIa Ealayohi [q. v.]: (Ḳ, TA:)
or AlgaXoIu, or AlguXoIu, is a state of inertness (taEaT-ul, Mgh, Mṣb) of the motive and sensitive faculties, (Mgh,) or of the motive faculties and of the sensitive will, (Mṣb,) on account of the weakness of the heart, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and the soul's becoming drawn together thereto by a cause that suppresses it (yuxofiyhi) within so that it finds not a place of passage, and of the causes thereof is a strangling [or stifling], or hurtful, cold repletion, or vehement hunger, (Mgh,) or vehement pain, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or cold, or excessive hunger, (Mṣb,) or an evil affection in some associate, or participating, organ, such as the heart and the stomach: (Mgh:) some say that it is the same as AlUigomaMCu [for which see its proper art.]; (Mgh, Mṣb;) thus say the scholastic theologians: (Mgh:) others (the physicians and the lawyers, Mgh) make a difference between these two terms. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2. gaX-ayotu AlXaIoCa, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. tagoXiyapN, (Ṣ,) I covered the thing; put a cover, or covering, upon it, or over it. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) One says, gaX-aI Qll-ehu EalaI baSarihi, inf. n. as above; and AgXI↓; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. God put a covering upon, or over, his eyes. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) it is said in the Ḳur [xxxvi. 8], faOagoXayonaAhumo↓ fahumo laA yuboSiruwna And we have put a covering over them [so that they shall not see]. (Ṣ, TA.)
[See a usage of the inf. n. voce XiynN.]
gX-Ahu said of light; see 1, former half.
See also 4.
gX-Ahu biAls-awoTi: see 1, latter half.

One says also, gaX-ayotuhu sayofFA, or sawoTFA, [in my original gXyth, without any syll. sign, but app. as I have written, for I do not find any instance of gaXiIa as doubly trans., meaning I equipped him with a sword, or a whip,] like the saying kasawotuhu sayofFA, or Eam-amotuhu. (TA.)
4. AgXAhu Uiy-aAhu and gX-Ahu↓ He made it to cover it; or to be a cover, or covering, upon it, or over it. (MA,* TḲ, and Bḍ * and Jel * in vii. 52, &c.)

And [hence,] both signify He made it, i. e. an event (Oamor), to come upon, [or invade, so as to surprise, or so as to overwhelm, properly meaning] as a thing that covered, him, or it. (Ḳ,* TA,) Both of these verbs are used in this sense in the Ḳur-án accord. to different readings in vii. 52 and xiii. 3, and likewise (as mentioned in the first paragraph of this art., q. v.,) in viii. 11. (TA.)
Also, the former, He made him, or it, to come to him. (Ṣ, MA, TA.)
See also 2, in two places.
[Hence,] AgXI All-ayolu: see 1, former half.
and see also 1, first and third sentences:
and again {1}, near the middle, in three places.

10. AstgXI vawobahu, (T, Ḳ, [agreeably with phrases in the Ḳur xi. 6 and lxxi. 6,]) and (Ḳ) bivawobihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and tgX-I↓ bihi, (Ṣ,) [see an ex. of the latter verb in a verse of El-Khansà cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. rEI, where it is trans. without a preposition,] He covered himself with his garment (Ṣ, Ḳ) in order that he might not see nor hear: (Ḳ: [in the CK, yusomaEa and yuraI are put for yasomaEa and yaraI:]) accord. to Er-Rághib, AisotagoXawoA viyaAbahumo means they put their garments as a covering over their ears; and is a phrase denoting the refusing to hearken; or, as some say, an allusion to running, like the phrase Xam-ara cayolFA, and OaloqaI vawobahu. (TA.)
gaXFA The whiteness of the head [or face], of a horse and of other animals, denoted by the epithet OagoXaI [q. v.]. (Ṣ.)
gaXowN The nabiq [generally meaning the fruit of the lote-tree called sidor; but sometimes the tree thus called itself]: (Ḳ:) accord to the M, [the n. un.] gaXowapN signifies a sidorap. (TA.)
gaXowapN and giXowapN and guXowapN: see giXaAwapN.
gaXoyapN an inf. n. of the verb in the phrase guXiIa Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or the subst, thereof, (Ḳ,) or the inf. n. un. thereof [signifying A swoon]. (Mṣb.) See 1, last sentence.
gaXoyapu Almawoti is The clouding (lit. covering) of the understanding that befalls a man on the occasion of death. (TA.)
And gaXoyapu Hum-aI signifies A touch, or slight attack, of fever. (TA.)
guXoyapN: see giXaAwapN.
giXoyaAnN: see 1, near the middle, in three places.

giXaMCN A cover, or covering; syn. giTaMCN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or it differs from the giTaMC in being of clothing or the like: (TA in art. gTw) and giXaAwapN [q. v.] signifies the same: (Mṣb;) [the pl. of the former is OagoXiyapN and OagoXaMCN; the former regular; and the latter, (which occurs in this art. in the TA in an explanation of gawaAXK, pl. of gaAXiyapN.) like MdaAmN as pl. of UidaAmN.] The giXaMC of the heart is The cover, or covering, thereof; (Ḳ, TA;) the qamiyS thereof, likewise mentioned in the Ḳ as being called the gaAXiyap↓; a covering of skin, [i. e. the pericardium,] the removal of which therefrom causes death; and also called the giXaAwap↓, this being expl. as meaning the skin of the heart: (TA:) and so of the horse's saddle; (Ḳ, TA;) which is a covering of skin or other material: (TA:) [see also gaAXiyapN:] and so of the sword; (Ḳ, TA.) which is its gilaAf [a term applied to its scabbard, and also to a case, or covering, enclosing the scabbard, or enclosing the scabbard with its appertenances] (TA;) and so of other things. (Ḳ.)

giXaAwapN (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ) and gaXaAwapN and guXaAwapN (ISd, Ḳ) and gaXowapN↓ and giXowapN and guXowapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gaAXiyapN↓ and guXoyapN↓ and guXaAyapN↓ and giXaAyapN (Ḳ) signify A covering upon the eyes (Ṣ, Ḳ) and upon the heart: (Ḳ:) you say, EalaI baSarihi giXaAwapN, &c. [Upon his eyes is a covering, or film, app. used only in a tropical sense], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and EalaI qalobihi [upon his heart], (Ḳ:) thus the first of these words signifies. in relation to the eyes, in the Ḳur [ii. 6 and] xlv. 22, in relation to the heart, Az says that it is a [sort of] covering of rust (mino TabaEK [also termed rayon]). (TA.) See also giXaMCN, in two places.
guXaAyapN and giXaAyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
gaAXiyapN: see giXaMCN and gawaAXK giXaAwapN is its pl. (TA:) occurring in the Ḳur vii. 39, meaning OagomaMCN, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. OagoXaMCN [or Coverings, a pl. of giXaMCN]. (TA.)
It is also [The covering, like giXaMCN, q. v.], of the horse's saddle. (Ṣ.)
And (Ṣ,) of the [camel's saddle called] raHol, (Ḳ,) it is The iron that is above the muWax-arap or [hinder part], (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) also called the daAmigap [q. v.]. (Az TA.)

Also The skin with which the jafon [or scabbard] of a sword is covered, from the lower part of its XaArib [q. v.] to its naEol [or shoe of iron, or silver, at the lower end of the scabbard]: or the covering that is put upon the hilt, consisting of [the skins called] OasofaAn [pl. of safanN, q. v.]: (Ḳ. [for OasofaAn, which is the reading in the M, some copies of the Ḳ have OasofaAr:]) or the first part, of the sword, of what is next to thee [when holding the hilt]: and sometimes it signifies its gimod [or scabbard], also. (Ḥam p. 22.)

AlgaAXiyapu (in the Ḳur lxxxviii. I, TA) means The resurrection; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) because it will overwhelm (tagoXaI↓) with its terrors; (Ṣ, TA;) or because it will come upon mankind as a thing covering them, (tagoXaI↓ Alxaloqa,) so as to include them universally: (TA:) and, (Ḳ, TA,) some say, (TA,) the fire [of Hell]; (Ḳ, TA;) because it will cover, or overspread, (tagoXaI↓,) the faces of the unbelievers. (TA.) [In like manner also,] gaAXiyapN mina AlEacaAbi means Punishment that is general, or universal, in its extent. (TA.)
And gaAXiyapN signifies also A calamity, or misfortune. (TA.)
And A certain disease that attacks in the jawof [i. e. belly, or chest]. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, ramaAhu Qll-ehu bigaAXiyapK [May God smite him, or afflict him, with a gaAXiyap]. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)

Also Petitioners that come to one (Ḳ, TA) seeking, or demanding, or asking, gifts: (TA:) and visiters, and friends, that come to one time after time; (Ḳ, TA;) and that resort to one (TA:) a man's resorters; such as guests; and hangers-on, or seekers of favours; servants [or dependants]; and others. (Ḥar pp. 95 and 467.)

OagoXaI, applied to a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to other than a horse, (Ṣ,) Whose whole head, as distinct from his body, is white; like Oaroxamu: (Ṣ:) or whose face is covered by whiteness: (Ḳ:) or having a blaze covering his face, and wide: (M, TA;) fem. gaXowaMCu, applied to a goat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
magoXiI-N Ealayohi Swooning; i. e. senseless; (MA, PṢ;) having the affection denoted by the phrase guXiIa Ealayohi [q. v.]. (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

1. gaS-a, (Mṣb, MF,) sec. pers. gaSiSota, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and gaSaSota, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter extr., (TA, [see 1 in art. ED,])
aor. yagaS-u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) when the sec. pers. of the pret. is gaSiSota, (Mṣb,) and yaguS-u, (Mṣb, TA,) when the sec. pers. of the pret. is of the other form mentioned above, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gaSaSN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or gaS-N, (Mṣb,) or the former when the aor. is yagaS-u, and the latter when the aor. is yaguS-u, (TA,) His throat, or fauces, became choked, or obstructed, (Ṣ, Ḳ, MF,) by food: (Ṣ, Mṣb, MF:) [as also, app., AigotaS-a↓:] accord. to some of those skilled in the science of lexicology, you say gaS-a when it is by food, and Xariqa when it is by beverage, [or by the spittle, and water, and the like, (see art. Xrq,)] and XajiIa when it is by a bone, and jariDa when it is with spittle; but every one of these is sometimes used in the place of any other: (MF:) and [thus] you say also, gaS-a biAlmaMCi, meaning, his throat, or fauces, became choked, or obstructed, by the water; or the water stopped therein, and he was hardly able to swallow it. (TA.)
[Hence,] gaS-a biriyqihi [lit., His throat, or fauces, became choked by his spittle;] meaning, ‡ he died. (TA.)
Hence, also, gaS-a biAlgayoZi ‡ [He was, or became, choked with wrath, or rage]. (Mṣb.)
[And gaS-a, alone, seems to signify † He became grieved, or disquieted in mind; like as does XajiIa (q. v.): and it seems to be indicated in the CK that AgtS-↓ signifies the same: see guS-apN.]

[Hence also,] gaS-ato binaA AlOaroDu † The land became straitened [as though it were choked] by us. (TA.) And gaS-a Almajolisu biOaholihi † [The sitting-place became straitened, or choked, or choked up, by its people]; as also AgtS-↓. (TA.)

4. AgS-hu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. UigoSaASN, (TA,) He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb) caused his throat, or fauces, to be choked, or obstructed, (Ṣ,) by food; (Mṣb;) syn. OaXojaAhu [which has the above-mentioned meaning and also another to he found below]. (TA.) [And It (food, &c.) choked him.]
Hence, AgS-hu biAlgayoZi ‡ [He (a man) caused him to become choked with wrath, or rage]. (Mṣb.)

[Hence also,] AgS-hu biriyqihi [lit., He caused his throat, or fauces, to become choked by his spittle;] meaning, † He caused him to become grieved, or disquieted in mind; (A, TA;) [like OaXojaAhu: and it seems to be indicated in the CK that AgS-hu without any addition signifies the same: see guS-apN.]
[Hence also,] AgS- EalayonaA AlOaroDa † He made strait to us the land. (Ḳ, TA.)
8: see 1, in three places.

guS-apN A thing lying across in the throat, or fauces, so as to cause a choking, or an obstruction, thereof; (IDrd, A,* Ḳ;) a thing by which one has his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed; (TA;) food by which one has his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed; (Mṣb;) i. q. XajFA; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [which has another meaning that will be found below; and both these meanings may be intended by it in the Ṣ; but in the Ḳ, the latter only seems to be intended; for there, between it and the explanation which is here first given, we find intervening the pl., and also, in the CK, the words waqado AagoSaSotuhu fAgotaS-a;] a thing by which one is choked (XajFA yugaS-u bihi, Lth, JK, TA) in the Haroqadap [meaning the head of the windpipe], (Lth, TA,) or in the throat, or fauces: (JK:) pl. guSaSN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur [lxxiii. 13], waTaEaAmFA caA guS-apK (TA) And food that sticks fast, (Bḍ,) or by which one is choked, (Jel,) in the throat, or fauces. (Bḍ, Jel.)
And hence, ‡ Choking wrath or rage. (Mṣb.)
[And † Grief, or disquietude of mind; a signification often occurring; and app. intended by the explanation XajFA in the Ḳ. See what is said on this point above.]
Hence also, guSaSu Almawoti [The chokings, or strangulations, of death: the deathrattles: or † the agonies of death]. (TA.)
gaS-aAn: see what next follows.

gaAS-N A man having his throat, or fauces, choked, or obstructed, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) by food; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also gaS-aAn↓. (Ṣ [in two copies of which it is written gaS-aAnu], Ḳ [in two copies of which it is written gaS-aAnN], Mṣb [in my copy of which, as well as in the TA, it is without any final syll. sign].)
mugotaS-N: see what next precedes.

1. gaSabahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagoSibu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gaSobN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) and AgtSbhu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He took it wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) or by force; (Mgh, Mṣb;) minohu and Ealayohi [i. e. from him], both meaning the same. (Ṣ.) AlgaSobu repeatedly occurs in the traditions, signifying The taking another's property wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or by violence. (L.) But as employed in law, it means The taking property that has a price and is forbidden, without the permission of its owner, without stealthiness: therefore it does not rightly apply in the case of an animal that has died a natural death or not been slaughtered according to the law, because it is not property; nor in the case of the free person, in like manner; nor in the case of the wine of the Muslim, because it has not a price; nor in the case of the property of him with whom one is at war, because it is not forbidden; the saying “without the permission of the owner” precludes the trust, or deposit; and the saying “without stealthiness” excludes theft. (KT.)
One says also, gaSabotuhu maAlFA and gaSabotu minohu maAlFA I took property from him [wrongfully,, &c., or] by force. (Mṣb.)
And gaSabahaA nafosahaA (Mṣb, TA) and AgtSbhA↓ nfshA (Mṣb) ‡ He violated her; forced her; had connection with her against her will; (TA;) or constuprated her by force. (Mṣb.)
And gaSaba fulaAnFA EalaI AlX-aIoCi (Ḳ, TA) and AgtSbh↓ (TA) He compelled such a one by force to do the thing. (Ḳ, TA.)

And gaSaba Aljiloda, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) † He removed from the skin its hair and its fur by plucking and peeling, without subjecting it to the process termed EaTonN, in the tan, and without UigomaAl [i. e. burying it] in moist earth, (Ḳ, TA,) or [soaking it in] urine [to loosen the hair and fur], and without folding it up: so Az heard it expl. by the Arabs. (TA.)
[3. gASbhu Uiy-aAhu, accord. to Freytag, signifies He took it from him by violence: but for this he has not named any authority.]
8: see 1, in three places.
One says also, of a woman, AugotuSibato nafosahaA, meaning ‡ She was constuprated by force; (A, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also AugotuSibato EalaI nafosihaA. (Mṣb.)
gaSobN and magoSuwbN↓ A thing taken wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or by force: (Mgh, Mṣb:) the former originally an inf. n. (Mṣb.)
gaASibN One taking, or who takes, a thing wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, (TA,) or by force: pl. guS-aAbN. (Mṣb.)
magoSuwbN: see gaSobN.
magoSuwbN lahu and minohu A man from whom a thing has been taken [wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or] by force. (Mṣb.)
1. gaSanahu, aor. _i {yagoSinu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gaSonN, (TA,) He drew it to him, or towards him; namely, a guSon [or branch]: (Ḳ, TA:) from El-Kanánee. (TA.)
And He took it; namely, a thing: (Ḳ, TA:) or he cut it off: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it signifies also he cut it off, namely, a guSon, and took it. (TA.)

And gaSana fulaAnFA Eano HaAjatihi, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yagoSinu} and _u {yagoSunu}, (TA,) He turned, or turned away, and withheld, such a one from the object of his want: (Ḳ, TA:) Az says that it was thus read to him by El-Mundhiree in the “Nawádir” of IAạr; but that, accord. to Sh, it is [gaDana, i. e.] with D; and this is correct: (TA:) the former is a mistake. (TA in art. gDn.)
2: see the next paragraph {4}.
4. AgSn AlX-ajaru, (A in art. frX,) inf. n. UigoSaAnN, The trees put forth branches. (KL.)

And AgSn, and gS-n↓, said of a bunch of grapes (Eunoquwd), It was, or became, large (kabura, thus in some of the copies of the Ḳ, in other copies kavura, but the former is the right, TA) in its berries: (Ḳ:) or somewhat large therein. (TA.)

guSonN A branch from the stem [or from another branch] of a tree; of the slender thereof as well as of the thick: (Ḳ:) [sometimes signifying a twig, or shoot:] pl. [of pauc.] OagoSaAnN and [of mult.] guSuwnN and giSanapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
guSonapN [A branchlet; and a small twig or shoot;] a small guSon. (Ḳ.)
OagoSanu A bull having a whiteness in his tail. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gaD-a Tarofahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaguD-u, (Mṣb,* TA,) [and yagoDuDo may be used, in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, instead of its contracted form yaguD-a,] imp. guD-a, (Ṣ, A,) in the dial. of Nejd, (Ṣ,) and AugoDuDo, in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, (Ṣ,) inf. n. gaD-N (Mṣb, Ḳ) and giDaADN, with kesr, (A, Ḳ,) and gaDaADN and gaDaADapN, with fet-ḥ, (Ḳ,) He lowered his eye, or eyes; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also gaD-a mino Tarofihi; (Mṣb;) [the mn being redundant, accord. to some; but see what is said on this point below:] and he contracted his eye, or eyes; syn. kasarahu; [so as to wrinkle the lids;] or he blinked; i. e. he contracted his eyelids, or drew them near together, and looked: [this signification is very common:] and he contracted (kasara) his eye, or eyes, and looked towards the ground, not opening his eye [or eyes]: and sometimes it indicates a state of abasement. (TA.) Also gaD-a alone, inf. n. gaDaADapN, He contracted his eyelids; like OagoDaI: he looked languishingly. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxiv. 30], qulo lilomuWominiyna yaguD-uwA mino OaboSaArihimo, in which some of the grammarians hold mn to be redundant; but the meaning is obvious, i. e. [Say thou to the believers] that they shall abridge their look, or view, from what is prohibited to them: (Ṣgh:) or that they shall restrain somewhat of their look, or view. (TA.)
[And hence,] † He bore with forgiveness and silence what was disagreeable, or hateful, or evil. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

gaD-a Sawotahu, (Mṣb,) or mino Sawotihi, (Ṣ, TA,) or both, (Mṣb,) in like manner signifies He lowered his voice. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) It is said in the Ḳur [xxxi. 18], waQgoDuDo mino Sawotika, (Ṣ, A,) i. e. And lower thy voice: or diminish the loudness of thy voice. (TA.)
gaD-a mino lijaAmi farasihi He lowered the rein of his horse, in order to lessen his sharpness of temper. (A, TA.*)

Also gaD-ahu, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. gaD-N, (TA,) He lessened it, diminished it, or made it defective or deficient; (Ḳ, TA;) and so gaDogaDahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gaSogaDapN. (TA.) You say gaDaDotu Als-iqaMCa I lessened, diminished, or made defective or deficient, [the contents of] the skin. (Mṣb.) And gaDogaDotu↓ AlmaMCa I lessened,, &c., the water. (Ṣ.) And fulaAnN baHorN laA yugaDogaDu↓ Such a one is a sea, or great river, that will not be lessened,, &c.: (Ṣ:) or that will not become exhausted. (Ḥar p. 418.) [See also R. Q. 1 below, and R. Q. 2.] And [you make the former verb doubly trans., saying,] maA gaDaDotuka XayoYFA I have not abridged thee, deprived thee, or defrauded thee, of anything. (TA.) And laA OaguD-uka dirohamFA I will not abridge thee, deprive thee, or defraud thee, of a dirhem. (TA.) You also say, gaD-a mina AlX-aEari He shortened the hair. (M in art. qSr.) And [in like manner] one says, gaD-a mino raOosihi, i. q. Tam-a raOosahu. (Ḳ voce Tam-a, q. v.)
Also He broke it (i. e. a branch, or stick, or the like,) but did not break it thoroughly; (L, Ḳ, TA;) and so gD-Dhu↓. (L, TA.)

And gaDaDotuhu also signifies I withheld, restrained, or prevented, it; whatever it were. (Ṣ.) [Hence the phrase in the Ḳur xxiv, 30, accord. to an explanation given above.] You say gaD-a AlEacola, or AlmalaAmapa, aor. as above, inf. n. gaS-N, He withheld blame. (Lth.) And you say to a rider, in asking him to stop a little where you are, guD-a saAEapF, (TA,) and AugoDuDo liI saAEapF, (A, TA,) i. e. Restrain for me thy beast, and stop, or pause, where I am, a while. (A, TA.)

gaD-a, [first pers. gaDaDotu,] aor. yagiD-u; (Mṣb;) or the first pers. is gaDiDotu and gaDaDotu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the aor. of each is yagaD-u; (Ḳ;) or, accord. to the T, some say gaDiDota, aor. tagaD-u, and some say gaDaDota, aor. tagaD-u: (IB, TA;) but the latter of these requires consideration; (TA;) inf. n. guDuwDapN (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ) and gaDaADapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or the former only, accord to Alee Ibn-Hamzeh; but the saying baDaADapN and buDuwDapN, to denote the quality of that which is termed baD-N, strengthens what J says [in the Ṣ] with respect to gaDaADapN; (IB;) It (a thing) was, or became, fresh, juicy, sappy, moist, not flaccid. (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or flourishing and fresh; or luxuriant: (IAạr:) or beautiful and bright: (Ḳ:) and gaD-ato, aor. tagiD-u and tagaD-u, inf. n. gaDaADapN and guDuwDapN, said of a woman, ‡ she was, or became, fine-skinned, or thin-skinned, so that the blood appeared [through the skin]. (Lḥ, TA.)
2. gD-D: see 1, latter half.

Also, inf. n. tagoDiyDN, He ate what is termed gaD-, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. the TaloE [or spadix of a palm-tree]: (TA:) or he became thin-skinned, and plump, and soft, or tender: (O, Ḳ:) or he became affected with languor and abasement; (Ḳ, TA;) or, as in the Tekmileh, with softness, or tenderness. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AngD- AlT-arofu i. q. AnogamaDa: (Ṣ, TA:) [or the former more probably signifies The eye, or eyes, became contracted: and the latter, the eye, or eyes, became closed.]
8: see 1, near the middle.

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. gaDogaDahu, inf. n. gaDogaDapN: see 1, near the middle, in three places.
EaDogaDa [inf. n. as above] is also intrans. (TA.) See R. Q. 2.

It likewise signifies It (for instance a sea, or a large river, TA) became scanty, or little in quantity, and sank into the earth, or disappeared in the earth; or became scanty, or little in quantity; or decreased: (Ḳ, TA:) or went away. (TA.) In the TṢ, the inf. n. is expl. by gayoZ, which is an abominable mistake for gayoD. (TA.)
And gaDogaDapN also signifies A man's speaking indistinctly. (TA.)
And The boiling of a cooking-pot. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tgaDogaDa It (water, and a sea, or great river, Ṣ) decreased, diminished, lessened, or became defective, or deficient; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gaDogaDa↓, (TA,) inf. n. gaDogaDapN. (Mṣb.) You say, maAta fulaAnN bibiTonatihi lamo yatagaDogaDo minohaA XaIoCN Such a one died with his property abundant, (Ṣ,) or complete; nothing thereof having been given away by him; a prov. relating to the death of the niggard. (AʼObeyd.) And ʼAmr Ibn-El-'As said, alluding to the death of Ibn-'Owf. xarajota mina Ald-unoyaA bibiTonatika walamo tatagaDogaDo minohaA XayoYFA, meaning Thou hast died with thy religion unimpaired: (AʼObeyd:) i. e. he had not been occupied with any office of authority or administration where by his recompense might be diminished. (Az.) You say also maTarN laA yatagaDogaDu Rain that will not cease (TA.)

gaD-N Fresh; juicy; sappy: moist; not flaccid; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) applied to a thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) whatever it be; (TA;) as also gaDiyDF↓. (Ṣ. Ḳ,) Hence the trad. mano sar-ahu Oano yaqoraOu AlquroMna gaD-FA kamaA nazala faloyaqoraOo qiraMCapa Qboni Oam-i EabodK [He who is rejoiced or pleased, to read the Kur-an freshly, who as it descended, let him read according to the reading of Ibn-Umm-ʼAbd]. (TA.)
A calf recently born: pl. giDaADN. (Ḳ.)

Anything (Ṣ) beautiful and bright; (Ṣ, Ḳ;,) as † youth, and the like: (Ṣ;) or gaD-N applied to youth, and gaD-apN applied to a woman, ‡ i. q. baD-N and baD-apN thinskinned, or fine-skinned, and plump:, &c. j: (A:) or the latter, applied to a woman, ‡ thin-shinned, or fine-skinned, so that the blood appears [though the skin]; (Lḥ:) and gaDiyDapN↓ also is thus applied like gaD-apN. (TA.) You say also, XaIoCN baD-N gaD-N, and baAD-N gaAD-N↓ A thing fresh,, &c., and beautiful and bright; [in a flourishing condition;] not changed, or altered [for the worse]. (TA.) And nabotu gaD-N A [fresh and flourishing and] tender plant. (TA.) And Zil-N gaD-N † Shade which the sun has not reached; like a plant which the sun has not reached. (TA.)

The spadix of a palm-tree; syn. TaloEN; as also gaDiyDN↓: (IAạr:) or both signify a tender TaloE: (Ḳ:) or a tender TaloE when it appears: (TA:) or the latter, a TaloE when it appears: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or the same, fruit when it first comes forth. (TA.)

hom.sense: guD-apN: see gaDaADapN.
Also A sufficiency of the means of subsistence; like gub-apN. (TA in art. gb.)

gaDiyDN, applied to an eye, or eyes, (Tarof,) Lowered: (A, TA:) contracted: having the lids contracted, or drawn near together, and so looking: contracted, and looking towards the ground: (TA:) languishing: (Ḳ, TA:) and so magoDuwDN↓, in all these senses: (TA:) and the former, so applied, [and app. the latter also,] having the eyelids relaxed, or flaccid. (TA.)
You say, ZaboIN gaDiyDu AlT-arofi A gazelle having languishing eyes. (Ṣ.) And Uin-aka lgaDiyDu AlT-arofi naqiI-u AlZrofi, meaning † [Verily] thou art faithful, not treacherous; by AlZ-arof being meant wiEaAWuhu. (TA.)

[Lowered and lessened in estimation, dignity, or rank: (see gaD-a minohu:)] defective or deficient [in good qualities]; (Ḳ;) and, in consequence thereof, (TA,) low, mean, or vile: (A, Ḳ:) pl. OagiD-apN (Ḳ) and OagiD-aMCu. (TA.)
Lessened; diminished; made defective or deficient. (TA.)
See also gaD-N, in three places.

entry.sense: gaDaADapN, [an inf. n., of which the verb is not mentioned in senses agreeing with those here following,] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and gaDiyDapN↓ and magaD-apN↓ (IAạr, Ḳ) and guD-apN↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) A defect, an imperfection, a fault, a vice, or the like: and lowness, meanness, or vileness: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) and the first, [or all,] languor, or want of power. (TA.) You say, layosa Ealayoka fiI hecaA AlOamori gaDaADapN There is not, or will not be, charged against thee, in, or with respect to, this affair, lowness,, &c.; or any defect,, &c.; (Ṣ, TA;) or languor, or want of power. (TA.) And maA Oaradotu bidelika gaDiyDapa↓ fulaAnK, and magaD-atahu↓, I desired not, or meant not, thereby, to attribute any defect, imperfection, fault, vice, or the like, to such a one. (IAạr.)
gaDiyDapN: see gaDaADapN, in two places.
gaAD-N: see gaD-N.
magaD-apN: see gaDaADapN, in two places.
magoDuwDN: see gaDiyDN.

hom.sense: 1. gaDiba Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [aor. _a {yagoDabu},] inf. n. gaDabN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and magoDabapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) He was angry with him; (MA, Ḳ,* PṢ, &c.;) and tgD-b↓ Elyh signifies the same. (Mṣb.) [See AlgaDabu below.] And gaDiba mino laAXaIoCK i. e. [He was angry] for nothing; meaning, for no cause. (Mṣb. [lAXIC, in a case of this kind, is regarded as one word, and is therefore as above, not laA XaIoCi: see p. 1626, third col.])

gaDiba lahu (meaning He was angry with another person for his sake, or on his account, TA) is said when the person [on whose account the anger is excited] is living: and gaDiba bihi, when he is dead: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so says El-Umawee, and El-Aḥmar says the like. (Ṣ.)
[And you say, gaDiba fiI Qll-ehi He was angry for the sake of God.]

And gaDibati Alfarasu EalaI All-ijaAmi ‡ The mare champed upon the bit. (TA.) Abu-n-Nejm says,
tagoDabu OaHoyaAnFA EalayA ll-ijaAmi
kagaDabi Aln-aAri EalaI AlD-iraAmi
‡ [She champs, sometimes, upon the bit, like the fierce burning of the fire upon the quickly-kindling fragments of firewood]. (A, TA.) [See also 5, last sentence.]
guDiba, like EuniIa [pass. in form]; and gaDiba; (Ḳ, TA;) the former of which is the more usual; (TA;) He had the disease termed giDaAb [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.)

And gDbt Eayonuhu, with fet-ḥ and kesr [i. e., app., gaDibato; or “with fet-ḥ and kesr” may be a mistranscription for “with damm and kesr,” so that the verb may be guDibato; His eye had in it what are termed giDaAb]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. gaADabotuhu I made him angry, he also making me angry. (Ḳ.)

And I broke off from him, or quitted him, in anger, or enmity. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) cahaba mugaADibFA, in the Ḳur [xxi. 87], means He went away, breaking off from his people, or quitting them, in anger, or enmity. (Ṣ.)
4. AgDbhu He angered him, or made him angry. (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ.)
5. tgD-b He became angered or angry: (Ṣ:) or he was angry somewhat after [having been so] somewhat. (Ḥam p. 522.) See also 1, first sentence.
And tgD-bt Alqidoru ‡ The cooking-pot boiled fiercely EalaI All-aHomi [upon the flesh-meat]. (TA.)

hom.sense: gaDobN (Ṣ, Ḳ) Red (Ṣ) intense in redness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) you say OaHomaru gaDobN: so says ISk: (Ṣ:) or gaDobN signifies OaHomaru gaDobN (Ḳ) i. e. red that is dense, or deep: (TḲ:) or OaHomaru [i. e. red], applied to anything: and galiyZN [i. e. thick,, &c.]. (TA.)
Also, and gaDobapN↓, A hard rock (Ḳ, TA) set, or fixed, in a mountain, and differing therefrom: (TA:) or the latter signifies thus: or a hard, round, rock. (O.)
And AlgaDobu signifies The lion: and the bull: as also [in the latter sense, or perhaps in both senses,] AlgaDuwbu↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: gaDabN an inf. n. of gaDiba [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) AlgaDabu is The contr. of Alr-iDaI: (Ḳ, TA:) it is variously defined: some say that it is a state of excitement of the blood of the heart for the purpose of revenge: some say that pain on account of anything reparable is gaDab; and for anything irreparable, Oasaf: some say that it [is a passion which] includes all that is evil; wherefore the Prophet, to a man who asked of him a precept, said, laA tagoDabo: and some say that AlgaDab is [a passion] accompanied by an eagerness to obtain revenge; and Algam- is accompanied by despair of obtaining it: (TA: [see also gayoZN:]) there is a gaDab that is commended, and a gaDab that is discommended; the former being that which is for the sake of religion and truth, or right; and the latter being that which is in a wrong case: and the gaDab of God is his disapproving of the conduct of him who disobeys Him, and whom He will therefore punish. (Ibn-ʼArafeh, TA.)
gaDibN: see gaDobaAnu.

hom.sense: gaDobapN A single fit of gaDab [or anger]. (O.)
See also gaDobN.
Also An [eminence of the kind termed] Oakamap. (L, TA.)

And A baxaSap (Ḳ, TA, in the CK baxoSap), or protuberance [of flesh], above, or beneath, the eyes, in the form of a flatulent tumour, (TA,) or in the upper eyelid, produced by nature: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the M. (TA.)
And A thing resembling a daraqap, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. a shield, (TA,) of the hide of the camel, (Ḳ, TA,) one part of which is folded over another. (TA.)
And A [garment of the kind called] jub-ap made of the hides of camels, and worn for fighting. (O.)
Also The skin of a mountain-goat advanced in age. (Ḳ.) The skin of a fish. (Ḳ.) The skin of the head. (Ḳ.) And The skin of the part between the horns of a bull. (Ḳ.)
And A patch of the small-pox: so in the saying, OaSobaHa waAHidapF mina AljudariI-i jiloduhu gaDobapF [His skin became one patch of the small-pox]: (O:) like gaDonapN. (Ṣ in art. gDn.)

entry.sense: guDabapN: see gaDobaAnu.

hom.sense: gaDobaI fem. of gaDobaAnu [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and pl. thereof. (Ṣ.) [See also gaDuwbN.]

It is also said by J, (Ḳ, TA,) and [before him] by Ez-Zejjájee, and also [after him] by ISd, (TA,) to be a name for A hundred camels, and not to have tenween, nor the article Al: but this is a mistake for gaDoyaA. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: Alquw-apu AlgaDabiy-apu [The irascible faculty]. (KT, in explanation of Alt-ahaw-uru.)

gaDobaAnu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [and, in the dial. of BenooAsad, as is implied by the fem. in that dial. mentioned in what follows, gaDobaAnN,] and gaDibN↓ and gaDuwbN↓ [which is both masc. and fem.] and guDub-N↓ (Ḳ) and guDub-apN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gaDub-apN↓ and gaDab-apN↓, (Ḳ,) or the last, accord. to MF, is guDabapN↓, (TA,) are epithets applied to an angry man: (Ḳ:) [the first seems often to signify simply Angry, like gaDibN; but accord. to SM,] all these epithets signify quickly, or soon, angry [as guDub-apN is said in the Ṣ to signify, on the authority of Aṣ]: (TA:) the fem. of the first word is gaDobaI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and (in the dial. of Benoo-Asad, Ṣ) gaDobaAnapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is seldom used; (Ḳ;) and gaDuwbN is also used as a fem. epithet [as stated above], (Ḳ,) and has an intensive signification: (TA:) pl. (of the first word, Mṣb) giDaAbN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and (likewise of the first) gaDobaI (Ṣ) and guDaAbaI (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gaDaAbaI. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
guDub-N: see the next preceding paragraph.
guDub-apN and gaDub-apN and gaDab-apN: see gaDobaAnu.
giDaAbN and guDaAbN Motes (qacFI) in the eye: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as in one copy of the Ḳ, [and in the O,] in the eyes. (TA.)
And A certain disease; (Ḳ, TA;) or so the latter word; (O;) an eruption in the skin; but not small-pox: (TA:) or (so accord. to the TA, but in the CK “and”) small-pox. (Ḳ, TA.)
gaDuwbN: see gaDobaAnu.

Also Stern, or austere, in look, or countenance; applied to a woman: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and in like manner applied to a she-camel: (O, Ḳ:) or thus applied to a she-camel: and also signifying a company of women. (TA.)
And A malignant serpent. (O, Ḳ.)
See also gaDobN.
guDaAbiI-N A man (TA) perturbed (kadirN) in social intercourse and in comportment. (Ḳ. [For waAlmuxaAlafapi in some copies of the Ḳ, I read waAlmuxaAlaqapi, as in other copies.])
AlOagoDabu The part between the penis and the thing. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: magoDuwbN Ealayohi [An object of anger]. By AlmagoDuwbi Ealayohimo in the Ḳur [ch. i. last verse], are meant The Jews. (O, TA.)
magoDuwbN also signifies Having [the disease called giDaAb, i. e.] the smallpox. (O, TA.)
1. gaDura, aor. _u {yagoDuru}, inf. n. gaDaArapN, It (anything) was, or became, soft, or tender. (TA. [See also the inf. n. below; and see the part. n., gaDiyrN; and gaDirN.])

And gaDira, aor. _a {yagoDaru}, inf. n. gaDarN, He (a man) became rich, wealthy, or abounding in property. (Mṣb.) You say, gaDira biAlmaAli, (Ḳ. TA,) and in like manner, biAls-aEapi waAlOaholi, aor. _a {yagoDaru}, inf. n. gaDarN and gaDaArapN: (TA;) as also guDira, like EuniIa; (IḲṭṭ, TA;) He (a man, TA) had abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (Ḳ, TA;) [or he was, or became, rich in wealth and family;] after having been poor. (Ḳ, TA.)

gaDarahu Qll-ehu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagoDuru}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. gaDorN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) God made him to be rich, wealthy, or abounding in property: (Mṣb:) to enjoy a pleasant life: (Ṣ:) or to have abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (Ḳ, TA.)
gaDira, with kesr, said of a place, It had in it red clay or earth: so says Az. (O.)

gaDara Eanohu, aor. _i {yagoDiru}, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gaDorN [and magoDarN↓ likewise, accord. to a verse of Ibn-Aḥmar as cited in the O and TA, but accord. to the reading of that verse in my copies of the Ṣ, it is magoDirN↓, app., if correct, a n. of place]; as also gaDira; (TA;) He turned aside or away, or deviated, from it, or him; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) and so tgD-r↓. (O, Ḳ.) One says, maA gaDarotu Eano SawobiI I did not deviate from my course. (TA.)
gaDara Ealayohi, (Ḳ. TA,) aor. _i {yagoDiru}, inf. n. gaDorN, (TA,) i. q. EaTafa (Ḳ, TA) [app. as meaning He turned against him, for it is added] and maAla. (TA.)
And maAgaDara Eano XatomiIa He did not hold back, or refrain, from reviling me. (TA.)

And gaDarahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yagoDiru}, inf. n. gaDorN, (TA,) It, or he, withheld, or prevented, him. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) One says, Oaradotu Oano Mtiyaka fagaDaraniI OamorN [I desired to come to thee, and] an affair withheld, or prevented, me. (TA.)
And gaDara AlX-aIoCa He cut off the thing, (Ḳ, TA,) lahu [for him]. (TA.) You say, gaDara lahu mino maAlihi He cut off a portion for him from his property. (Ḳ.)
And gaDara Aljiloda He tanned well the skin. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Hamala famaA gaD-ara He charged, and was not cowardly, and did not fall short of what was requisite. (TA.)
5: see the first paragraph {1}.
8. AugotuDira He died being a youth, or young man, in a sound state: (Ḳ, TA:) like AuxotuDira. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. grD.]
Q. Q. 1. gaDowara He (a man, TA) was angry. (O, Ḳ.)
maA naAma liguDorK is expl. as meaning He hardly, or scarcely, slept; but is said to be with E and S, and has been thus mentioned before [in art. ESr]. (TA.)

hom.sense: gaDirN: see gaDiyrN.
One says also EayoXN gaDirN maDirN An easy and a plentiful life: (Ḳ,* TA:) mDr being here an imitative sequent to EDr. (TA.)
And gaDiru Aln-aASiyapi applied to a man, (O, Ḳ,) and gaDirapu Aln-aASiyapi applied to a beast (d-aAb-ap), (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Blest, fortunate, or abounding in good or advantage or utility. (O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
See also gaDoraMCu, in two places.

entry.sense: gaDorapN A certain plant. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence the prov. yaOokulu gaDorapF wayarobiDu HajorapF [He eats ghadrah, and lies down aside]. (TA. [See also HajorapN.])

hom.sense: gaDoraMCu: see gaDaArapN, in six places.

Also Earth, or land, (OaroDN, Ḳ,) or a piece, or portion, of clay or earth, (TiynapN, Ṣ, Mṣb,) good, or fertile. (Tay-ibapN, Ḳ,) green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour: (xaDoraMCu EalikapN: Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and land in which is clay, or soil, of a good kind, without sand, or without salt earth; (Ḳ, TA;) as also gaDiyrapN↓ or gaDirapN↓, accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the latter accord. to the L. (TA:) or, accord. to IAạr, gaDirN↓ [in the TA gaDoraMCu, which is a mistranscription,] signifies a place having in it red clay or earth. (O.) One says, OanobaTa fulaAnN biYorahu fiI gaDoraMCa(Ṣ, TA) i. e. Such a one produced the water of his well by digging in land of soft and good earth of which the water was sweet. (TA.)
And Land in which palm-trees will not grow until it is dug, (Ḳ, TA,) the upper part thereof consisting of white [soft stones, like dry pieces of clay, such as are termed] kac-aAn. (TA.)

entry.sense: gaDaArN Clay that is cohesive, and OaxoDar [i. e. green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour], (Ḳ,) or (O) of a good kind, without sand, or without salt earth; (O, Ḳ;) and so gaDaArapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter signifies such clay itself: (Sh, O:) and the former signifies baked clay (Sh, O, Ḳ, TA) made of gaDaArap, (Sh, O,) green, or of a dark or an ashy dust-colour, (OaxoDaru, O, TA,) which is suspended upon a human being as a preservative from the [evil] eye. (O, Ḳ,* TA.*)

hom.sense: gaDowarN Sticky clay, (Ḳ, TA,) that adheres to the foot, which will hardly, or in nowise, go into it [app. by reason of its compactness]. (TA.)

And A species of trees [or plants], (Ḳ, TA,) dustcoloured, that grow large: n. un. with p {gaDowarapN}, (TA.) And (TA) A certain plant, (Ṣ, O, TA,) resembling the vumaAm [or panic grass], (TA,) or of the species of Oasal [or rushes], not beneficial, nor causing increase in the cattle; (AḤn, O;) it is said that the cattle pasturing upon it do not form fat thereby, (O, TA,*) and that it does not dissolve in their stomachs: (O:) n. un. with p {gaDowarapN}. (AḤn, O.)

gaDiyrN Soft, or tender; (TA;) applied to a plant, or herbage; as also gaDirN↓, and gaADirN↓; (O, TA;) all in this sense: (TA:) or so the first, applied to anything: (O, Ḳ, TA) or this signifies moist, juicy, or fresh: (AA, O:) and i. q. xaDiyrN [syn. with OaxoDaru i. e. green]. (Ḳ.)
See also gaDoraMCu.

gaDaArapN an inf. n., of gaDura and of gaDira. (TA.) [Used as a simple subst.,] Ease, comfort, and affluence; easiness of life: ampleness of the conveniences of life, or of the means of subsistence; plenty; (Ḳ,* TA;) prosperity; (TA;) plenty and prosperity; (Ṣ;) a plentiful and pleasant and easy state of life: (TA:) and gaDoraMCu↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ.) One says, Uin-ahumo lafiI gaDaArapK mina AlEayoXi and fI gaDoraMCi↓ mn AlEyX, Verily they are in a plentiful and prosperous condition [of life]. (Ṣ.) Accord. to Aṣ, one should not say OabaAda Qll-ehu xaDoraMCahumo, but AbAd Qll-eh gaDoraMCahumo↓, meaning May God put an end to their prosperity, and their plentiful condition: (Ṣ:) but Aḥmad Ibn-ʼObeyd says that both of these phrases mean may God destroy the collective body of them: and another says, their clay of which they were created. (TA. [See also xaDoraMCu, voce OaxoDaru.]) One says also, Uin-ahu lafiI gaDoraka↓ EayoXK and xaDoraMCi EayoXK i. e. Verily he is in a plentiful condition of life. (TA.) And Uin-ahu lafiI gaDoraMCa↓ mino xayorK [Verily he is in an ample state of prosperity]. (TA.)

And, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, (O,) AlgaDaArapu is an appellation of The qaTaAp [or sand-grouse]; (O, Ḳ;) but Aṣ disapproved this: (O:) [or] the qaTaAp is called AlgaDoraMCu↓; and the pl. is AlgaDaAriI-u. (Mṣb.)
See also gaDaArN.

Of gaDaArapN meaning A certain utensil, IDrd says, I do not think it to be genuine Arabic: (O, TA:) it signifies a large [bowl such as is termed] qaSoEap: [app. from the Pers. gadaAraho:] pl. gaDaAYiru. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: gaDaAriI-N A species of locust; also called the jaraAd mubaArak: a word of uncertain derivation. (Mṣb.)
Also pl. of gaDoraMCu mentioned near the end of the next preceding paragraph. (Mṣb.)
AlgaDaw-ara The lion. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: gaADirN: see gaDiyrN.
Also Withholding, or preventing. (TA.)
And A skin well tanned. (AḤn, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And One who occupies himself early in the morning in the accomplishment of the objects of his want, or in his needful affairs. (AA, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: magoDarN and magoDirN: see the first paragraph {1}.
mugoDirN: see the following paragraph.

magoDuwrN A man enjoying a pleasant life: (Ṣ:) blest; fortunate; abounding in good, or advantage, or utility: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or in a state of ease, comfort, and affluence; or of plenty, or prosperity; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and of happiness: (TA:) as also mugoDirN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. of the former magaADiyrN, as well as magoDuwruwna. (TA.)
guDoruwfN is syn. with guroDuwfN, (Ṣ and Ḳ, &c. in art. grDf, q. v.,) in [all of] its meanings: (Ḳ:) pl. gaDaAriyfu. (O and TA in art. grDf.)

hom.sense: 1. gaDafahu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagoDifu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gaDofN, (TA,) He broke it, namely, a branch, or stick, or the like, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and a thing, (TA,) but not thoroughly. (Ṣ, O, TA.) [See also 2.]

And gaDafa Oucunaha, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, O,) He (a dog) relaxed his ear, and folded, or creased, it: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) [see, again, 2:] or gaDafa Oucunaha, inf. n. gaDofaAnN and gaDafaAnN, he (a dog) twisted his ear: and in like manner one says of the wind, [gaDafatohaA,] i. e. it twisted it. (TA.) And gDaf AlwisaAdapa He folded the pillow [so as to make creases in it]. (Ḥam p. 785. [But perhaps this is correctly gD-f↓: comp. its quasi-pass., 5.])

gaDafato said of [wild] she-asses, (O,) or of a she-ass, (Ḳ,) aor. as above, (O, TA,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) signifies Oaxacati AljaroIa OaxocFA [as though meaning They, or she, restrained the running, i. e. their, or her, running; agreeably with what here follows]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) gaDafa, [for gaDafa mina AljaroIi,] said of a horse, &c., means he lessened, lit. took from, the rate of the running, (Oaxaca mina AljaroIi,) without reckoning: (L, TA:) Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee- 'Áïdh El-Hudhalee says,
yaguD-u wayagoDifona mino ray-iqK , (O, TA) meaning He (the ass) withholds somewhat of his running, (yakuf-u baEoDa jaroyihi,) and they (the she-asses) lessen, lit. take from, the [or rather a] first, or former, rate of their running, (yaOoxucona OaxocFA mino Oaw-ali jaroyihin-a,) without reckoning: (Skr: see Kosegarten's “Carmina Hudsailitarum,” p. 189:) Skr says, in explanation of the citation above from Umeiyeh, that gaDofN signifies the act of taking and lading out [with the hand] (OaxocN and garofN); and on one occasion he says, the taking easily; [adding,] one says, gaDafa fulaAnN mino TaEaAmK lay-inK [Such a one took, or laded out with his hand, from soft food]. (TA.)
gaDafa AlEayoXu, inf. n. guDuwfN, The life was soft, or easy, and plentiful. (TA.)

gaDifa, [aor. _a {yagoDafu}, inf. n. gaDafN,] He (a dog, Ṣ) was, or became, relaxed, or flabby, in the ear. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And gaDifati AlOucunu, inf. n. gaDafN, is said to mean The ear was, or became, long and relaxed or flabby: or it advanced upon the face: or it retired towards the head: or its extremities folded upon the inner part thereof: or, in a dog, it turned towards the back of the neck: or it became folded, or creased, naturally. (TA.) [See also gaDafN, below: and see 7.]
gaDifa All-ayolu: see 4.

entry.sense: 2. gD-fhu, inf. n. tagoDiyfN, He broke it. (TA.) [See also 1, first signification.]
tagoDiyfN signifies also The making [a thing] to hang down. (O, Ḳ.)
See also 1, third signification.
4. AgDf All-ayolu The night became dark and black; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also gaDifa↓, inf. n. gaDafN. (Ṣ.)
AgDft Als-amaMCu The sky became clouded, and prepared to rain. (O,* Ḳ,* TA.)
AgDft Aln-axolu The palm-trees had many branches, and bad fruit: (Ḳ, TA:) or became laden, or heavily laden, with fruit; or abounded therewith. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And AgDf AlEaTanu The usual abidingplace of camels, or cattle, or their place of lying down at, or around, the water or watering-trough, had many thereof. (Ḳ.)

And tagaD-ufN signifies The being, or becoming, creased, or wrinkled; (O, Ḳ, TA;) like tagay-ufN. (TA.) And tagaD-afa He, or it, inclined, and bent, and became folded, or creased, much, or in several places, syn. maAla, and tavan-aI, and takas-ara, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) Ealayohi upon him, or it. (Ṣ, O.) And tgD-ft AlHay-apu The serpent twisted, or coiled, itself. (O, Ḳ.)

ngD-ft AlbiYoru The sides of the well fell in ruins, or became demolished: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) the well collapsed, or broke down, EalaI fulaAnK upon such one, who had descended into it; (O;) as also AngDft↓. (O, Ḳ.)
tgD-f EalayonaA All-ayolu The night covered us. (O, Ḳ.)
tgD-ft EalayonaA Ald-unoyaA The world became abundant to us in its good things; and favourable to us. (O, Ḳ.)
7: see 5, in two places.
AngDft Oucunuhu His ear became folded, or creased, not naturally. (TA.) [See also 1, near the end.]
AngDf AlD-abaAbu The DbAb [or thin clouds, like smoke,] overlay one another. (TA.)
AngDfwA fiI AlgubaAri They entered into the dust, or raised and spreading dust. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
gaDofN: see gaDafN.
guDofN [written by Golius guDufN]: see gaDafapN.

hom.sense: gaDafN [inf. n. of gaDifa (q. v.): and, as a simple subst.,] Laxness, or flabbiness, in the ear: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, as in the T, a laxness, or flabbiness, of the upper part [of each] of the two ears, upon, or over, the concha thereof, by reason of its width and its largeness: (TA:) Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee says, after citing a verse of Abu-n-Nejm, describing a lion, that it signifies a twisting, in the ear, backwards: accord. to ISh, it is, in the lion, a laxness, or pendulousness, of the upper eyelids, upon the eyes; arising from anger and pride: (O:) and he says that, accord. to some, it is, in the lion, abundance of the fur, and a folding, or creasing, of the skin. (TA.) And one says, [app. in relation to the lion,] fiI OaXofaArihi gaDofN↓ and gaDafN [app. In the edges of his upper eyelids is a laxness, or pendulousness]; both meaning the same. (TA.)
Also Softness, or easiness, and plentifulness, of life: (Ṣ:) like gaTafN. (O in art. gTf.)

And A species of tree in India, exactly like the palm-tree, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) except that (Ḳ) its fruit-stones are divested of covering, without a liHaMC [or pulpy pericarp], and from its lowest to its uppermost part it has green saEaf [or branches like those of the palm-tree], (Lth, O, Ḳ,) covered [thereby]: (Lth, O:) AḤn says, it is a plant resembling the palm-tree exactly, (O, L, TA,) but not growing tall, (TA,) having many saEaf, and prickles, and [leaves such as are termed] xuwS, of the hardest sort, whereof are made large [receptacles of the kind called] jilaAl [pl. of jul-apN], that serve for sacks, goods being carried in them by land and by sea; (O, L, TA;) it produces from its head unripe dates of disagreeable flavour, not eaten; and, he says, of its xuwS are made mats like carpets, (L, TA,) called simaAm, pl. of sum-apN [q. v.], (L,) one of which may be spread for twenty years. (L, TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

gaDafapN A certain bird: or a qaTaAp [or sandgrouse]: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) or the qaTaAp termed juwniy-ap: pl. gaDafN↓ [or rather this, if correct, is a coll. gen. n.]: J says that AlgaDafu↓ [thus in the TA, but in my and other copies of the Ṣ AlguDofu↓, for which Golius appears to have found AlguDufu,] signifies AlqaTaA Aljuwnu; but IB says that it is correctly AlqTA AljuwniI-u. (TA. [See juwniI-N: and particularly what is said at the end of the paragraph thus headed.])

Also An [eminence of the kind called] Oakamap. (O, Ḳ, TA. [For Akmp, in this case, the TḲ has most strangely substituted Akmh, meaning Oakomahu, for it explains it as signifying “blind from the birth;” and this, though an obvious mistake, Freytag asserts to be the right reading and explanation.])

entry.sense: gaADifN: see OagoDafu, in two places.
Also [applied to a man] Soft, or easy, and plentiful, in his circumstances. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

OagoDafu, applied to a dog, Relaxed, or flabby, in the ear; pl. guDofN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) occurring in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, cited voce EacabN; (O, TA;) and the fem. gaDofaMCu is applied [to a bitch, and] to an ear: (TA:) or a dog having the upper part of his ear folded, or creased, backwards; and gaADifN↓ when it is forwards. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) And hence [the pl.] guDofN, as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, is used as an appellation for Dogs of the chase. (TA.)

Applied to a lion, Having the ear folded, or creased; (Hr, O, Ḳ;) denoting a quality that renders him more abominable: (Hr, O:) or relaxed, or pendulous, in the ears: (O, Ḳ:) or whose upper eyelids are lax, or pendulous, upon his eyes, by reason of anger or pride; (Ḳ, TA;) so says ISh. (TA.)
And accord. to Lth, A beast of prey whose upper part of his ear is folded, or creased, and the lower part thereof relaxed, or pendulous. (TA.) And the fem., gaDofaMCu, A she-goat whose extremities of her ears descend low, by reason of their length. (IA.)
Also Anything bending, folding, or creasing, and relaxed, flabby, or pendulous: fem. as above. (TA.) And mugoDifN↓ is like OagoDafu, (TA.)
And AlOagoDafu is one of the names of The lion (TA.)
sahomN OagoDafu An arrow of which the feathers are thick; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) contr. of OaSomaEu, (Ṣ, O.)
layolN OagoDafu A night that is dark (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and black; (Ṣ, O;) covering with its dark ness. (TA.)
mugoDifN: see OagoDafu, latter half.
Applied to palm-trees (naxolN), Having many branches, and bad fruit; (O, TA;) thus without p; (O;) and also with p {mugoDifapN}. (TA. [See also its verb.])

And vamarapN mugoDifapN A fruit that has become flaccid, but not completely ripe: (O:) or nearly, but not yet, ripe: (Sh, TA:) or whereof the goodness has not become apparent: or, accord. to AA, hanging upon its tree, flaccid. (TA.)
Q. 1. gaDofara He (a jade, or hackney, TA) was, or became, heavy, or sluggish. (Ḳ, TA.)
gaDofarN: see the next paragraph, in two places.
guDaAfirN: see the next paragraph.

gaDanofarN Big, thick, or rude, in body or person; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gaDofarN↓, which is the original form; the n in the former being augmentative: (Az, TA:) or simply, big, thick, or rude: applied to a man: (Lth, TA:) or rude, or coarse, [in disposition or in make,] and big, or thick: (TA:) as also ganaDofarN↓ and gaDofarN↓; (Ḳ;) applied to a man: (TA:) or big, or thick, (AA, TA.) in make, (TA,) and wrinkled; (AA, TA;) applied to a lion. (TA.) You say also OucunN gaDanofarapN, meaning, A big, or thick, fleshy, ear. (AO, L.)
[Hence,] AlgaDanofaru The lion; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AlguDaAfiru↓. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
gaDanofarN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. gaDanahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagoDinu} and _u {yagoDunu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gaDonN, (Ṣ,) He, or it, (a man, and a thing, Ṣ,) withheld, restrained, hindered, or diverted, him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, maA gaDanaka Ean-aA What withheld, hindered, or diverted, or has withheld,, &c., thee from us? (Ṣ.) In the “Nawádir” of IAạr, this verb, which is correctly thus, with D, is erroneously with S. (TA.)

gaDanato biwaladihaA, and gaD-nt↓, She (a camel) cast her young one, or fœtus, in an imperfect state, (Ḳ, TA.) before the hair had grown upon it and its make had become [perfectly] apparent. (TA. [See also xadajato.]) [This is what is meant in the Ṣ where, after the mention of a signification of Alt-agoDiyn↓ which will be found below, it is said that this word signifies also Alr-ijaAEu (an inf. n. of rajaEato, q. v.): hence, app., (though referring to the Ḳ as his authority,) Freytag has given to gD-nt, as said of a she-camel, besides the signification mentioned above, another, which is also assigned to rajaEato; i. e., she falsely indicated her being pregnant, by raising her tail,, &c.]
See also 5, in form places:

2. gaD-anotuhu, inf. n. tagoDiynN, I wrinkled, shrivelled, or puckered, it syn. of the inf. n. taXoniyjN. (Ṣ.) One says, daxalotu Ealayohi fagaD-ana liI mino jabohatih [I went in to him and be wrinkled to me a portion of his forehead]. (TA.)
and see 1 in two places
and 4.

entry.sense: 3. AlmagaADanapu signifies mukaAsarapu AlEayonyoni [The contracting of the eyes as to wrinkle the lids], (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) by reason of doubt, or suspicion. (TA.) One says, gaADana AlmaroOapa, meaning gaAzalahaA bimukaAsarapi AlEayonayoni [i. e. He talked, or acted, with the woman, in an amatory and enticing manner, with the contracting of the eyes so as to wrinkle the lids]. (A. TA.)

4. AgDnt Als-amaMCu The sky rained continually; (Ṣ, TA;) as also gDnt [perhaps gaDanat↓, but more probably, I think, gaD-anat↓] (TA.) And gDnt Als-aHaAbapu [The cloud rained continually]. (Ṣ and TA in explanation of ray-amat.)
And AgDn Ealayohi AlHum-aI The fever continued upon him persistently. (IAạr, TA.)
AgDn Ealayohi All-ayolu The night became dark upon him. (TA.)

5. tgD-n It was, or became, wrinkled, shrivelled, or puckered; syn. taXan-aja; (Ṣ, MA, TA;) as also gaDina↓, inf. n. gaDanN [and app. guDuwnN, like qubuwlN as an inf. n. of qabila. though this requires consideration, as will be shown by what follows]. said of the face as having this signification, or as signifying it was, or became, wrinkled and speckled; (MA;) [and so, perhaps, gD-n↓, for] AltgDyn [if not a mistranscription for Alt-agaD-unu], as also AlguDuwnu↓, is syn. with Alt-aXan-uju; and one says rajulN cuw guDuwnK↓ fiI jabohatihi meaning takas-urK [i. e. a man having a wrinkling in his forehead; but guDuwn may be here used as pl. of gaDonN, and thus meaning wrinkles]: and gaDanN↓ signifies a bending (tavan-K and talaw-K) of a branch or twig or the like. (TA.) One says also, tagaD-anati Ald-iroEu EalaI laAbisihaA The coat of mail became folded, [or it hung, or sat, with folds,] upon its wearer. (TA.)

hom.sense: gaDonN and gaDanN↓ A wrinkle, crease, fold, ply, plait. or pucker, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the skin, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and of anything, (Mṣb,) or in a garment, and in a skin, (Ḳ,) and in a coat of mail, (Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c. (Ṣ:) pl. guDuwnN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) occurring in a verse cited in art. XOb (TA.)
[Hence,] one says, kaAna celika fiI guDuwni kacaA [lit. That was within the folds, meaning in the midst, of such a thing, or such an affair or event]; like fiI OavonaMCi kcA (TA in art. vnI)
guDuwnu AlOucuni means The places of fold the case; syn. mavaAniyhaA. (Ḳ, TA. in the CK [erroneously] manAbituhA.)

Also (i. e. gaDonN and gaDanN↓. TA) Difficulty, distress, or trouble, and fatigue, or weariness. (Ḳ, TA.) The Arabs say to a man, in threatening him, laOuTiylan-a gaDonaka or gaDanaka↓ i. e. [I will assuredly make] thy difficulty, &c. [to be long]. (AZ, Az, TA.)

entry.sense: gaDanN an inf. n. of gaDinu. (MA [See 5, in two places.])
See also gaDonN, in three places,
gaDanu AlEayoni signifies The exterior, or apparent jilodap [app. meaning tunic i. e. the sclerotic tunic,] of the eye. (Ṣ, TA.)

gaDonahN [A patch of the smallpox] One says of a person whose skin has became covered, or wholly covered, (Oulobisa,) with the smallpox, OuSobaHa jiloduhu gaDonapF waAHidapF [His skin has became one patch of the smallpox]: and some say gaDobap (Ṣ,)
giDaAnN the subst from the verb in the phrase gaDanato biwaladihaA [i. e. a subst. signifying The act denoted by that phrase. q. v.]. (Ḳ.)
gaDiynN A she-camel's young one or fœtus, cast in an imperfect state, before the hair has grown upon it and its make has become [perfectly] apparent. (TA.)
OagoDanu Contracting his eye so as to wrinkle the lids, naturally, or by reason of enmity, or from pride. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gaDaA, aor. yagoDuw; and gaDaI, aor. yagoDaI: see 4; the former, in three places.

gaDaA, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. yagoDuw, thus in the M, (TA,) inf. n. guDuw-N. (Ḳ,* TḲ,) He, i. e. a man, [and app. it. i. e. a thing,] was, or became, such as is termed gaADK [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA. [In the TḲ it is mentioned only as said of a thing but the context in the Ḳ indicates that it is said of a man, and app. of a thing also.])
[See also guDuw-N below]
gaDiyati AlUibilu, inf. n. gaDFA, The camels had a complaint (M, Ḳ, TA) of their bellies (Ḳ, TA) from eating of the trees called gaDFA. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
And gaDiyati AlOaroDu The land abounded with the trees called gaDFA. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

4. AgDI, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UigoDaMCN, (Ṣ,) He contracted his eyelids; drew them near together; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like gaD-a; (TA in art. gD;) [and] so AgDI Eayonahu; said of a man: (Mṣb:)
or he closed his eyelids upon his iris; so in the M; as also gaDaA↓, a dial. var. of AgDI, likewise mentioned by ISd; and gaDaI↓, aor. yagoDaI, is also a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) or he made one of his eyelids to cleave to the other, that he might not see a thing, by reason of shame: (Ḥar p. 19:) or he put one of his eyelids upon the other from dislike of a thing. (Id. p. 492.) [See also 6.]

Hence it is used in relation to forbearance: so that one says, OagoDaI EalaI AlqacaI He held, or refrained, notwithstanding annoyance, spontaneously, without being asked, or without constraint: (Mṣb, TA:) or AgDI EalaI qacFI he bore annoyance patiently. (M, TA.) And AgDI Eanohu He feigned himself neglectful of it; [he closed his eyes from it;] he connived at it; as also AgmD Enh. (TA in art. gmD.) And [sometimes] AlUigoDaMCu means The abstaining from proceeding to extremities. (Mgh in art. jwz.)
Hence also, AgDI EalaI AlX-aIoCi He was silent respecting the thing; and so gaDaA↓, aor. yagoDuw. (Ḳ, TA.)
And AgDI Eanohu Tarofahu means He closed, or turned away, from him, or it, his eye, or eyes; syn. sad-ahu [in the CK Xad-ahu], or Sad-ahu: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the M. (TA.)
AgDI All-ayolu The night was, or became, dark; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and covered everything (Ḳ, TA) with its darkness; from ISd; (TA;) as also gaDaA↓, aor. yagoDuw. (Ḳ, TA. [See also guDuw-N.])

entry.sense: 6. tgADI He contracted, or put together, his eyelids, that he might not see an evil, or unseemly, thing. (Ḥar p. 473. [See also 4.])
And [hence,] tgADI Eanohu i. q. tagaAfala [i. e. He was, or he feigned himself, unmindful,, &c., of him, or it]: (Ḳ, TA:) like tagaAbaI Enh: mentioned by Az. (TA. [See, again, 4.])

gaDFA, said by Th to be written [thus] with A but ISd says, I know not why this is; (TA;) [the latter, it seems, holding its last letter to be originally I, not w;] A species of trees, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) the wood of which is of the hardest of wood, and therefore there is hardness in its charcoal; (Mṣb;) it is of the plants of the sands, and has [sprigs, or foliage, of the kind termed] hadab [q. v.], like that called OaroTFI; (TA;) and its fire is of long continuance: (Ḥar p. 60:) [see also rimovN: Mr. Palgrave (in his Travels, i. 38,) describes it as a shrub believed by him to be peculiar to the Arabian Peninsula, “of the genus Euphorbia, with a woody stem, often five or six feet in height, and innumerable round green twigs, very slender and flexible, forming a large feathery tuft, not ungraceful to the eye, while it affords some kind of shelter to the traveller, and food to his camels:”] the sing. [or rather n. un.] is gaDaApN: (Ḳ:) and AḤn says that sometimes gaDaAtN is a pl. [of the n. un.]. (TA.)

Hence, ciYobu gaDFA [A wolf of trees, or shrubs, called gaDFA]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or, as in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà ciYobu AlgaDaA; and such is the most abominable, or malignant, or noxious, of wolves; for he comes not into close proximity to men save when he desires to attack: or this means the wolf of the covert of trees: for
gaDFA signifies also A covert of trees: (TA:) and a gayoDap [i. e. thicket; or collection of tangled, or confused, or dense, trees;, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
Oaholu AlgaDaA is an appellation of the people of Nejd, (Ḳ, TA,) because of the abundance of [the trees called] gDA there. (TA.)
baEiyrN gaDK A camel having a complaint of his belly from eating of the trees called gaDFA: and UibilN gaDiyapN and gaDaAyaA [camels having such a complaint]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like ramivapN and ramaAvaI. (Ṣ.)
gaDoyaA: see gaDoyaMCu.

Also, (Ḳ, TA,) determinate, and imperfectly decl., like [its syn.] hunayodapu, (TA,) A hundred camels: (IAạr, Ḳ, TA:) held by ISk to be so called as being likened to a place producing [an abundance of] gaDFA [i. e. the trees thus called]: AA has mentioned it with the article Al, saying that AlgaDoyaA signifies a hundred. (TA.)
gaDoyaMCu A land (OaroDN) abounding with the trees called gaDFA. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And, as also gaDoyaA↓, A place in which is a collection of the trees called gaDFA; (Ḳ, TA;) a place where they grow. (TA.)
And the former, Rugged land or ground. (TA.)
