hom.sense: guDuw-N Intense darkness of the night. (IḲṭṭ, TA. [Perhaps in this sense an inf. n. of which the verb is gaDaA: see 4, last sentence.])
And The eating of the trees called gaDFA. (IḲṭṭ, TA. [App. in this sense an inf. n. of which the verb is gaDaA.])
And A state of muchness, abundance, copiousness, fulness, or completeness, or a thing. (Ḳ. [See also 1, second sentence.])

entry.sense: rajulN gaDiI-N Eani AlxanaA or Eani AlfaHoXaMCi [A man who refrains from taking notice of that which is foul, abominable, unseemly, or obscene,] may be from gaDaA; or it may be from OagoDaI, similar to OaliymN and wajiyEN; but the former derivation is the better. (TA.)
gaDawiI-N a rel. n. from AlgaDaA [the trees thus called], and applied to a camel [app. as meaning That is fond of, or wont to feed upon, the trees called gaDFA]. (Ṣ.)
gaDoyaAnapN A herd of camels of generous race: (Ḳ, TA:) mentioned by Az, from AA. (TA.)

hom.sense: And gaADiyapN signifies also Bright, or shining brightly; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a night, (thus in one of my copies of the Ṣ,) or to fire (naAr): (so in other copies of the Ṣ and in the TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Great; applied to a fire (nAr): a signification said by Az to be taken from the fire of the tree called gaDFA, which is of the best of firewood. (TA.)
baEiyrN gaADK A camel that eats the trees called gaDFA: and UibilN gaADiyapN and gawaADK [camels that eat those trees]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
XaIoCN gaADK A thing that is much in quantity, abundant, copious, full, or complete. (Ḳ.)
And rajulN gaADK A man having food and clothing; or having a good state, or condition, in respect of food, and having clothing; sufficed, or satisfied. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mugoDK: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. gaT-ahu fiI AlmaMCi, aor. _u {yagoTuTu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _i, (Ḳ,) [the latter contr. to analogy,] inf. n. gaT-N, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him, or it, in the water: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he made him to plunge, or dive, in, or into, the water: (Ṣ:) [Golius adds, as from Ibn-Maạroof, head-downwards; but it is not so in my copy of the KL:] and gat-ahu signifies the same. (TA in art. gt.)
And gaT-ahu, inf. n. gaT-N, He pressed, or squeezed, him, or it, (EaSarahu,) vehemently; and i. q. kabasahu [q. v.]. (TA.) [And gat-ahu, q. v., has a similar meaning.]

gaT-a,, aor. _i {yagoTiTu}, inf. n. gaTiyTN, said of a he-camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He brayed; syn. hadara: (Ḳ:) or he brayed, (hadara, AZ, Ṣ,) or made a sound, (Saw-ata, Mṣb,) in the XiqoXiqap [or bursa faucium]: when not in the XqXqp, it is termed hadiyrN: you say of the she-camel, tahodiru; not tagiT-u; (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb;) because she has no XqXqp: (AZ, Ṣ:) or, as some say, he brayed, but not in the XqXqp. (L.)

gaT-a, aor. as above, (Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and inf. n. as above (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and gaT-N, (TA,) said of a person sleeping, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of one strangled, or throttled, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of an animal slaughtered, (Ḳ,) He emitted a sound; (Ḳ;) in which sense it is also said of a lynx, and of a leopard, and of a bustard: (TA:) or snored, or snorted: (Ṣ, TA:) or sent back his breath up to his fauces so that it was heard by persons around him: (Mṣb:) or emitted a sound with his breath, reiterating his breath where he found not an easy passage [for it]. (TA.)
gaT-ati Alburomapu The stone cooking-pot boiled audibly. (TA.)
See also gat-a, near the end of the paragraph.

entry.sense: 3. gAT- HuwtFA He vied, or contended, with a fish in plunging, or diving. (JK in art. qms.)

6. tgAT- Alqawomu The people, or company of men, vied, or contended, one with another, in plunging, or diving, (tamaAqaluwA,) in the water. (Ṣ.) And AlS-iboyaAnu yatagaAT-uwna fiI AlbaHori The children vie, or contend, one with another, in plunging, or diving, (yataqaAmasuwna,) in the sea or great river. (A in art. qms.)
7. AngT- fiI AlmaMCi He (a man, TA) became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in the water; or he plunged, or dived, in the water. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

R. Q. 1. gaTogaTa AlbaHoru [inf. n. gaTogaTapN] The waves of the sea became high (Ealato), so in some copies of the Ḳ, or estuated (galato); so in other copies of the Ḳ, and in the L; (TA;) as also tagaTogaTa↓. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And gaTogaTati Alqidoru [The contents of the cooking-pot] made a sound: or boiled vehemently. (Ḳ.)
And gaTogaTa Ealayohi, said of sleep, It overcame him. (L, Ḳ, TA.)
R. Q. 2. tagaTogaTa: see the next preceding paragraph (R.Q.1).
Also It (a thing) became separated, or dispersed. (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: gaTaATN The [bird called the] qaTaA [i. e. the sandgrouse]: (M, Ḳ:) or a species thereof, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, as some say, a species of bird not of the qTA, (TA,) dust-coloured in the backs and the bellies (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and the bodies, (Ṣ, TA,) black in the inner sides of the wings, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) long in the legs and the necks, and slender, not collecting in flocks, two or three at most being found together: (Ṣ, TA:) n. un. with p {gaTaATapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is said that the qTA compose two species: the short in the legs, yellow in the necks, black in the primary feathers of the wings, of a white hue tinged with red (Suhob) in the tertials, are the kudoriy-ap and the juwniy-ap: and the long in the legs, white in the bellies, dust-coloured in the backs, wide in the eyes are the gTAT: AḤát says that in the OaxodaEaAni [by which is here meant, as in some other instances, the places of the two veins so called in the neck] of the gaTaATap are what resemble two decorations, two lines, black and white; and it is slender, [but] exceeding the muk-aMC: accord. to Skr, it is a bird resembling the qTA. (TA.)
See also the paragraph here following.

entry.sense: guTaATN The commencement of the dawn: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a remaining portion of the blackness of the night: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or the commingling of the darkness of the last part of the night with the light of the first part of the day: (TA:) and (Ḳ) the saHar [or period a little before daybreak;] as also gaTaATN↓. (Th, Ḳ, TA.)
gaTogaTapN a word imitative of The cry of the [bird called the] qaTaA: (Ṣ, Ḳ:)
and of The sound of the [vehemently-boiling] cooking-pot. (TA.)
qidorN mugaTogiTapN A cooking-pot vehemently boiling. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. gaTorafa He (i. e. God) made persons to be [gaTaAriyf i. e. chiefs,, &c., ( pl. of giToriyfN,) or] noble. (Ḥam p. 793.)
[And He treated violently, unjustly. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
See also the next paragraph.

entry.sense: Q. 2. tagaTorafa He sought chiefdom, or lordship; [&c.;] from giToriyfN meaning say-idN. (O.)

And He magnified himself, or was proud: (El-Aḥmar, O, Ḳ:) [and so, app., gaTorafa↓, for] gaTorafapN and tagaTorufN and tagatorufN signify takab-urN: (Ṣ:) [or] he was proud, haughty, or self-conceited, in walk (IAạr, O, Ḳ) especially. (IAạr, O)

gaTorafapN [app. an inf. n. of gaTorafa, q. v.; and, used as a simple subst., signifying Self-magnification, or pride: (see Q. 2:) or] pride, haughtiness, or self-conceit: and play, or sport; or such as is vain, or unprofitable. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
giToraAfN: see giToriyfN, in two places.
guToruwfN: see the following paragraph.
giTorawofN: see the following paragraph.

giToriyfN The hawk, or falcon; syn. baAzK: this is said to be the primary signification: (Ḥam p. 793:) or the young one thereof (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or the hawk, or falcon, (baAzK,) that has been taken from its nest: as also giToraAfN↓. (TA.)

And A say-id [i. e. chief, or lard,, &c.]: (Ṣ:) or a say-id that is high-horn, or noble, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) or generous: said to be so called as being likened to the hawk, or falcon: (Ḥam ubi suprà:) and liberal, bountiful, generous, noble, and youthful: (ISk, O, Ḳ:) or a goodly, or comely, youth or young man. (TA:) and giToraAfN↓ signifies the same: (ISk, O, Ḳ:) pl. gaTaArifapN (O, Ḳ, TA) and gaTaAriyfu and gaTaArifu. (TA.) Also Goodly, or beautiful; and so guToruwfN↓ and giTorawofN↓: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O. Ḳ:) or the last of these signifies a youth, or young man, such as is Zariyf [i. e. excel-lent, or elegant in mind, manners, and address, or speech, and in person., &c.]. (AA, O, Ḳ.)
Also The common fly: syn. cubaAbN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ)
And EunuqN giToriyfN A wide neck. (O, TA.:) as also xiToriyfN (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gaTasahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagoTisu}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. gaTosN; (Ṣ;) or gT-shu↓, (Mṣb,) inf. n. tagoTiysN; (TA;) or both: (A. TA;) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, in water. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb * Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence,] gaT-asaniI↓ fiI baHori QnoEumihi † [He overwhelmed me in the sea of his benefits, or favours]. (A.)

gaTasa, aor. _i {yagoTisu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gaTosN, (Mṣb,) He, or it, became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in water or he immersed, or immerged himself, plunged, or dived, in water (Mṣb,* Ḳ)
gaTasa fiI AlUinaMCi He put his mouth into the vessel and so drank. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
gaTasato bihi All-ujamu Death took him away: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) a dial. var. of EaTasato [q. v.]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.

hom.sense: 6. tgATsA They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, (A, Ḳ,) in water; (Ḳ;) syn. tamaAqalaA (A, Ḳ) and tagaAT-aA (A) and tagaAmasaA. (TA.) And tgATswA They vied, or contended, one with another, in plunging, or diving, in water; syn. tagaAT-uwA. (TA.)

tgATs He feigned himself negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless, not being really so; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) and tgATX is a dial. var. of the same: both are from Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer (TA.) You say, tgATs Eanohu He feigned himself negligent of it,, &c.; (Aboo-Saʼeed, TA in art. gTX;) and [app. in like manner] tgATshu. (IAạr, TA in art. EmX.)

entry.sense: gaT-aAsN One who dives to the bottom of water to fetch the shells that contain pearls, &c. (TA.)
layolN gaATisN Dark night: as also gaATiXN. (IDrd.)
magoTisN A place in which one plunges, or dives. (TA.)
magonaTiysN and its variations, here mentioned in the Ṣ and L and Ḳ, see in art. mgnTs.

hom.sense: 1. gaTaXa, aor. _i {yagoTiXu}, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. gaToXN, (TḲ,) [or perhaps gaTaXN, q. v.,] It (the night) became dark; (A, Ḳ;) as also OagoTaXa↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or gaTaXN is syn. with sadafN; and hence AgTX↓ All-ayolu [app. meaning the night became dark, or black]. (Aṣ, A, TA.) [See gaTaXN, below.]

gaTiXa, (Ṣ, TA.) [aor. _a {yagoTaXu},] inf. n. gaTaXN, (TA,) He had an affection resembling weakness of the sight, with a shedding of tears at most times. (Ṣ, TA.) And gaTiXa AlbaSaru [The eye, or sight, became weak, and affected with a shedding of tears at most times] and so AgTAX-↓, like AHmAr- [in measure] (TA:) and tgT-Xt↓ Eayonuhu His eye became dark, or dim, (IDrd, Ḳ,) and weak-sighted. (IDrd.)
4. AgTX: see 1, in two places.
AgTXwA They entered into, or upon, the darkness [of night]. (TA.)
AgTX Qll-ehu All-ayola God made the night dark, (Fr. Ṣ, A,* Ḳ)

entry.sense: 5: see 1. last sentence.

6. tgATX Eanohu He feigned himself negligent, or heedless, of it; (Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer, Ḳ;) namely, a thing, or an affair; as also tgATs; (Aboo-Saʼeed;) and [app. in like manner] tgATXhu: (IAạr, TA in art. EmX:) or he feigned himself blind to it; either in the eyes or intellectually; syn. tEAmI. (TA.) You say also, mararotu bihi fatagaATaXa [I passed by him and he feigned himself heedless, or blind]. (A.)
11: see 1, last sentence.

gaTaXN i. q. sadafN [app. meaning The darkness, or blackness, of night]: (Aṣ, A, TA:) Aboo-Turáb, (L,) or AZ, (TA,) makes it to be after the gabaX: (L, TA:) and guTaAXN↓ also signifies the darkness and confusedness of night. (TA.)
Also Weakness of sight, with a shedding of tears at most times: (Ḳ:) or an affection resembling this. (Ṣ, TA.)
gaTiXN: see OagoTaXu, in two places.

falaApN gaToXaI, (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Kr, Ṣ, A,) or gaToXaMCu, (O, Ḳ,) if from gaTaXa All-ayolu, originally [and properly] like EamoyaMCu, but by poetic license it is made perfectly decl., [with tenween,] but if gaToXaAnu occurred, as meaning “dark,” it would be a fem., written [gaToXaI,] with I (O, TA,) or both forms, without and with medd, (TA,) A desert, or waterless desert, that is dark: (Kr:) or of which the ways through it are obscure; (Aṣ, AʼObeyd,. A, TA;) where one cannot find the right way. (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
You say, rakibonaA falaApF gaToXaI wanaHonu karimaAlihaA EaToXaI [We travelled upon a desert, or waterless desert, of which the ways through it were obscure, and we were like its sands thirsty]. (A.)
guTaAXN: see gaTaXN.
gaATiXN: see what next follows.
OagoTaXu Dark; applied to night; as also gaATiXN↓ and gaTiXN↓: [fem. gaToXaMCu: see gaToXaI:] and tagoTiyXN↓, an inf. n. [of gaT-aXa] used as an epithet, signifies the same, applied to sight. (TA.)
Also A man having the affection of the eyes termed gaTaXN; (Ṣ, TA;) as also gaTiXN↓: (TA:) fem. of the former gaToXaMCu. (Ṣ, TA.)
tagoTiyXN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mutagaATiXN Feigning blindness to a thing. (Ṣ.) [See 6.]

hom.sense: gaTafN Ampleness of the means, or circumstances, of life: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) like gaDafN. (O.)

And Length, and a folding, (O, Ḳ,) in the edges of the eyelids, (O,) or of the edges of the eyelids: (Ḳ:) or length, and then a bending [app. upwards] of the eyelashes: occurring in a trad., and, as some relate it, with E; but Er-Riyáshee knew not this, and thought it to be gaTaf: (TA:) or abundance of the hair of the eyebrow: (Ḳ:) said by ISh to be syn. with waTafN: (TA:) but by IDrd said to be the contr. of waTaf, and signifying paucity of the hair of the eyebrows: (O, TA:) and it is said to be sometimes used as meaning paucity of the eyelashes. (TA.) [See also gaDafN.]

entry.sense: [gTfAn, in a note to “Abulf. Ann.” i. 194, thought by Reiske to be the name of a bird, is app. a mistake for some word relating to the cry of the bird called gaTaAT.]
gaATuwfN A miSoyadap [or snare, trap, gin, or net]: a dial. var. of EaATuwfN [q. v.]. (TA.)

hom.sense: OagoTafu A life (EayoXN) ample in its means, or circumstances: like OagoDafu. (Ṣ, O.)
And syn. with OawoTafu in relation to the edges of the eyelids [Having what is termed gaTafN as meaning waTafN]. (TA.)

1. gaTalati Als-amaMCu (JK, O, Ḳ) yawomanaA hecaA, (JK, O,) and OagoTalat↓, (JK, O, Ḳ,) The sky has [by its becoming overcast] concealed the light of the sun [in this our day]: (JK:) or its dajon [or shade of the clouds in a rainy day, or its abundant rain, or its covering of clouds full of moisture, and dark, but containing no rain,] has overspread. (O, Ḳ.)
And gaTila All-ayolu, aor. _a {yagoTalu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gaTalN, (TA,) The darkness of the night became confused. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see the preceding paragraph {1}.

hom.sense: Q. Q. 1. gaToyala, (O, Ḳ, TA,) with the T before the I, (Ḳ,* TA,) He was, or became, abundant in his property, or cattle, and his dependents, or relations and household, or servants, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and his weal. (O, TA.)

And gayoTala, (O, TA,) thus correctly in the following senses, accord. to the Ḳ gaToyala, but this is a mistake, (TA,) He made his traffic to be in beasts of the bovine kind, bulls or cows, (O, Ḳ, TA,) which are termed gayoTalN. (TA.)

And gayoTala Alqawomu fiI AlHadiyvi The people, or party, pushed on, pressed on, or were copious or profuse, in discourse; or entered into it; and their voices became high: (Ḳ,* TA:) on the authority of El-Hejeree. (TA.) [Accord. to the Ḳ gaToyala, which is said in the TA to be a mistake.]

entry.sense: Q. Q. 4. AigoTaOal-a It became heaped up, or it mounted, one part upon another: (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ, TA:) and so AigoZaOal-a, mentioned by IḲṭṭ: (TA:) the former verb occurs in a verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit, said of the sea. (O, TA.)
And, said of the heat, It rose, or became raised. (R, TA.)

hom.sense: gayoTalN is pl. of gayoTalapN↓, [or rather a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.,] signifying Numerous dense or tangled trees: (Ṣ, O:) or the latter word signifies thus: (Ḳ:) or it (the latter) signifies also dense, or tangled, trees: (Ṣ, O:) or both signify thus: and also anything confused, or mixed: (Ḥam p. 213:) or the latter has this last meaning: and signifies also a collection of trees and of herbs; (AḤn, TA;) and a collection of [the common tamarisks, called] TarofaMC; (Ḳ, TA;) as AḤn says on one occasion. (TA.)
And [the former, or perhaps both words,] The light of the dawn when mingling with the darkness of the night. (Ḥam p. 213 [q. v.].)

And gayoTalu AlD-uHaI signifies Hayovu takuwnu AlX-amosu mino maXoriqihaA kahayoYatihaA mino magoribihaA waqota AlZ-uhori, (JK, O, and so in copies of the Ḳ,) or baEoda AlZ-uhori, (accord. to the text of the Ḳ in the TA,) or waqota AlEaSori: (so in some copies of the Ḳ, as mentioned in the TḲ:) [the last is evidently the right reading; and the meaning, The period of the earlier part of the forenoon, after sunrise, when the sun is distant from its place of rising like as it is from its place of setting at the time of the EaSor (q. v.): AlZhr is probably an old mistranscription.]
Also Beasts of the bovine kind, bulls or cows. (TA.) [See also gayoTalapN, last explanation.]
And The cat: (Ḳ, TA:) as also xayoTalN: on the authority of Kr. (TA.)

entry.sense: gayoTalapN: see gayoTalN.
Also A company, or collection, (Th, Ḳ, TA,) of men: (Ḳ, TA:) or the assembling of men, and their becoming in a dense, or confused, state. (IAạr, TA.)

And Darkness; as also gayoTuwlN↓; (Ḳ;) or the latter signifies confusedness of darkness; (IDrd, O;) or signifies also dense (lit. accumulated) darkness. (Ḳ. [The Arabs describe thick darkness as “darknesses one above another:” see Ḳur xxiv. 40.]) And The intricate and confused blackness of night: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or gayoTalapu All-ayoli signifies the confusedness and denseness of the darkness [of night]: and the pl. is gayaATilu. (TA.)

Also A confusion, or mixture, of cries or shouts or noises; (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ;) and so gayoTuwlN↓: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) gayoTalaAtN, pl. of the former, signifies clamours of men: and the sing., the numerous cries or shouts or noises, and the dust, of war, or battle. (TA.)

And The overpowering influence of drowsiness: (O, Ḳ:) [or so gayoTalapu nuEaAsK: pl. gayaATilu:] one says, ray-avatohu gayaATilu Aln-uEaAsi meaning gawaAlibuhu [i. e. The overpowering influences of drowsiness retarded him, or made him late]. (A, TA.)

And The means of happiness of the present world or state of existence: (Ḳ:) or gayaATilu Ald-unoyaA means those means of happiness: (O:) or this latter phrase means the consecutive means of happiness of the present world. (TA.) And The eating and drinking and rejoicing, with security. (Fr, O, Ḳ.)

And AlgayoTalapu (accord. to Fr, as is said in the O and TA,) signifies AlmaAlu AlmuTogiI [as though most probably meaning Property that causes extravagance]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) [but from what SM remarks respecting it, I can only infer that he holds AlmuTogiI to be an epithet applied to the cow as signifying “having a youngling,” which is termed TagoyaA or TugoyaA, (like AlmuEojilu signifying “having a calf,” which is termed EijolN, and several other epithets of the same form,) and in like manner applied to a collective number of cows, though I do not find it mentioned in this sense; i. e., that he understands; and would explain, AlmaAlu AlmuTogiI as signifying The cattle, meaning cows, having younglings: but his derivation of it seems to be far-fetched; and perhaps he may have been led to assign this meaning to it by another explanation of gayoTalapN with which it is agreeable, and which will be found in the next sentence:] it is not [he says] from TagaA, aor. yaToguw, signifying Oasorafa fiI AlZ-ulomi, as it seems to be at first sight; but from Tagato said of the baqarap waHoXiy-ap, signifying SaAHato, the like of which is also said of the vawor. (TA.)

gayoTalapN signifies also Such as has milk, of gazelles, or antelopes, and of beasts of the bovine kind [perhaps meaning of the wild species, i. e. bovine antelopes]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) pl. gayaATilu: (Ṣ, O:) accord. to AO, the baqarap waHoXiy-ap [or bovine antelope]: (Ṣ, O:) Th says that it signifies the baqarap [or beast of the bovine kind, bull or cow], not particularizing the wild species. (TA.) [See also gayoTalN, last explanation but one.]
gayoTuwlN: see gayoTalapN, first quarter, in two places.
guwTaAlapN i. q. rawoDapN [generally meaning A meadow]. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
XajarN mugoTaYil-N Dense, or tangled, trees. (JK. [See also gayoTalN.]) And guSuwnN Soft, or tender, branches, (O, TA,) having dense leaves. (TA.)

giTam-N A great sea, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) abundant in water; (Ṣ, TA;) and giToyam-N↓, (Ḳ, TA,) like qiroXab-u, (TA,) [in the CK gaTiyom,] signifies the same; as also gaTamoTamN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) one says baHorN giTam-N. (Ṣ.)
And † A man large (Ṣ, Ḳ) in disposition (Ṣ) or dispositions; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] liberal, or bountiful: (TA:) one says rajulN giTam-N. (Ṣ.)
And A numerous company, or collective body: (Ḳ, TA:) one says jamoEN giTam-N. (Ṣ, TA.) And EadadN giToyam-N↓, like qiroXab-N, A large number. (TA.) [See also guTaAmiTN, in art. gTmT.]
giToyam-N: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
gaTamuTamN: see the first paragraph (giTam-N).
gayoTam-N Thick milk. (Ḳ, TA.)
And The sea's being great in the waves, and abundant in the water; as also giTomaATN; each an inf. n. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA: but omitted in the CK.)
And The sounding of a torrent in a valley. (Ḳ.)
Q. 2. tagaTomaTa, and its inf. n.: see the preceding paragraph, in four places.
The inf. n. signifies also The making, or sending forth, a sound (Ṣ, Ḳ) with which, (Ṣ,) or in which, (Ḳ,) is a roughness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
giTomaATN (originally an inf. n., mentioned above: TA:) Waves (mawojN) dashing together. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: guTaAmiTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gaTomaTiyTN↓ (IDrd, Ḳ) The sound of the sea when the waves are great and the water is abundant: (so accord. to copies of the Ḳ:) or the sound of the boiling of the sea; (so [the former] in a copy of the Ṣ; TA;) or of the boiling of the cooking-pot, and of the waves of the sea: (so in other copies of the Ṣ: TA:) and ↓the latter word, also, the sound of water. (IDrd, TA.)

And baHorN guTaAmiTN and gaTawomaTN↓ and gaTomaTiyTN↓ A sea great in the waves, and abundant in the water. (Ḳ.) guTaAmiT is applied in a verse of Ru-beh to a number of men [app. as meaning † Multitudinous]. (TA voce giToyam-N, by which it is followed.)

entry.sense: gaTawomaTN: see the next preceding paragraph (guTaAmiTN).
gaTomaTiyTN: see guTaAmiTN, in three places.

dictScrap.note: [Accord. to J, the m in the words of this article is augmentative.]

entry.sense: 1. gaTaA AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ, TA,) first pers. gaTawotu, aor. _u, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gaTowN; (TA;) and gaTaI AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ, TA,) first pers. gaTayotu, aor. _i, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gaToIN; (Ṣ, TA;) and gaTaI Ealayohi; (Ḳ;) and gT-Ahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagoTiyapN; (Ṣ;) or this has an intensive signification; (Mṣb;) [but it is very often used in the sense of gaTaAhu without teshdeed;] and AgTAhu↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) He, or it, covered, or concealed, the thing; (Ḳ and TA in explanation of all;) and came, or became, upon it, or over it. (Ḳ and TA in explanation of all except the first.) gaT-aI↓ Ealayohi AlmiXomalapa, a phrase used by Lḥ, is thought by ISd to mean He covered [or enveloped] him with the [garment called] mXmlp, i. e. gaT-aAhu bihaA. (TA in art. Xml.)

gaTaIa All-ayolu fulaAnFA means The night clad [or covered] such a one with its darkness; as also gT-I↓ (Ḳ.) [And the former is also said of the night as though intrans.; an objective complement being app. understood: thus,] gaTaI All-ayolu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i; (Ṣ, TA;) as also gaTaA, aor. _u, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gaTowN and guTuw-N; (Ḳ, TA;) signifies The night was, or became, dark: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) [and Freytag states that AgTI↓ is used in this sense in the Deewán of Jereer; like AgDI;] or covered, or concealed, everything with its darkness: (Mṣb:) or as some say, rose, and covered, and clad, everything. (TA.)
Aall-ehum-a QgoTi EalaI qalobihi is a saying of the Arabs, meaning OagoXi [i. e. O God, put Thou a covering upon, or over, his heart]. (TA.)

And one says, gaTaAhu AlX-abaAbu. inf. n. gaToIN and guTiI-N, [but the latter I think doubtful, for it is of a measure extr. as that of an inf. n. of a trans. v.,] meaning Oalobasahu [i. e. Youthfulness, or young manhood, clad him, or invested him as with clothes]; as also gT-Ahu↓. (TA.) And [using the former v. as intrans., one says,] gaTaI AlX-abaAbu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AlX-Ab-u,]) aor. _i, inf. n. gaToIN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and guTiI-N, thus in the Ṣ and accord. to ISd and IḲṭṭ and Ṣgh, but accord. to the Ḳ guToIN, (TA,) meaning AimotalaOa [i. e. The sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood became full, or mantled, in a person]. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.)
And gaTati AlX-ajarapu The tree had long branches, spreading over the ground, (Ḳ, TA,) so that it covered what was around it; (TA; mentioned in art. gTI;) like OagoTat↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

And gaTaA AlmaMCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and gaTaI, (TA,) The water rose, or rose high, (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.) and became abundant. (TA.) And gaTaA EalaI AlX-aIoCi is said of anything as meaning It rose, and became high, upon, or over, the thing. (Ṣ, TA.) And gaTayaAnu AlbaHori signifies The overflowing of the sea, or great river. (TA.)
And gaTati Aln-aAqapu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gaToIN, (TA,) The she-camel proceeded in her course, (Ḳ, TA,) and stretched forth. (TA.)

And faEala bihi maA gaTaAhu is mentioned in the M as meaning saMCahu [i. e. He did to him that which occasioned evil to him; or that which displeased, grieved, or vexed, him]: but this may be a mistranscription, for EaZaAhu, which is mentioned in the Ḳ in this sense: or the two verbs may be dial. vars. (TA. [See also a similar explanation of gaTaAhu in the first paragraph of art. XrI.])
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in four places.
4: see 1, in three places.
AgTI Alkaromu The grape-vine had the sap running in it, (Ḳ, TA,) and increased. (TA.)
5. tgT-I bihi (Ṣ, MA) He was, or became, covered with it; [or he covered himself with it;] namely, his garment [&c.]; (MA;) [and so AgtTI↓; for] AgtTI signifies the same as tgT-I. (Ḳ.)
8: see what next precedes {5}.
Uin-ahu lacuw gaTawaAnK Verily he is one possessing might, and power of resistance, in his people, or party; and possessing abundance [of defenders, or of the means of defence, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

giTaMCN A cover, or covering; i. e. a thing by which, or with which, a thing or person is covered, or concealed: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or a thing by which or with which, thou art covered, or coverest thyself: (Ṣ:) or a thing by which, or with which, thou art covered or another thing is covered: so in the M: accord. to Er-Rághib, a thing that is put upon, or over, a thing, such as a Tabaq [meaning cover, or lid,] and the like thereof, like as the giXaMC is of clothing and the like thereof; (TA:) or the cover, or lid. of a cooking-pot or the like: (MA:) pl. OugoTiyapN: (Mṣb, TA;) it is [said to be] from the phrase gaTaIi All-ayolu. (Mṣb.)

And it is metaphorically applied to denote ‡ Ignorance: whence [accord. to some] the saying in the Ḳur [l. 21], fakaXafonaA Eanoka giTaMCaka fabaSaruka Qloyawoma HadiydN ‡ [But we have removed from thee thine ignorance; and thy sight, or thy mental perception, to-day, is sharp, or piercing: see HadiydN]. (TA.)

giTaAyapN A thing, of the stuffing of clothes, with which a woman has covered herself, (Ḳ, TA,) beneath her clothes, (TA,) such as the gilaAlap [q. v.] and the like: (Ḳ, TA:) [it is said that] the I therein is substituted for w. (TA.)
gaATK [act. part. n. of 1, Covering, or concealing,, &c.]
[And hence,] layolN gaATK Dark night: or night rising, and covering, and clothing, everything. (TA.)
And XajarapN gaATiyapN A tree having long branches, spreading over the ground, so that it covers what is around it. (TA.)
And maMCN gaATK Abundant water. (TA.)

gaATiyapN [as a subst.] A grape-vine covering the ground: (IB in art. Ejb:) occurring in a verse cited in that art.: so called because of its high growth and its spreading: (TA in the present art.:) or a grape-vine having many nawaAmK, i. e. branches. (T and TA in art. nmI.)
magoTiI-N A thing covered, or concealed,, &c. (TA.)
[Hence] one says, huwa magoTiI-N AlqinaAEi, meaning † He is obscure in respect of reputation. (TA.)
mugaT-aApN i. q. mugab-aApN [meaning A pitfall covered over with earth]. (TA in art. gbI, q. v.)
5. tgf-fhu He took the guf-ap [i. e. what was sufficient for his subsistence] thereof. (TA.)
See also what next follows {8}.

hom.sense: 8. Agtf-t Alfarasu, (Ṣ,) or Ald-aAb-apu, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. AigotifaAfN, (Ṣ,) The mare, or the beast, obtained what was sufficient for its subsistence of the [herbage called] rbiyE; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also tgf-ft↓: (TA:) or [in the Ḳ “and”] acquired somewhat of fatness: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) each of these meanings is mentioned as on the authority of Ks: (Ṣ:) AZ mentions the phrase Agtf-t AlmaAlu, (Ṣ,) or Agtf- AlmAl, (O,) and says that the meaning is [the cattle obtained] middling pasture, and middling fatness. (Ṣ, O.) And AigotifaAfN signifies also The taking [with the mouth] fodder, or provender. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. gv.]
Aigotafafotuhu I gave him somewhat, little in quantity. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: gaf-N Such as has become dry of the leaves of ruTob [or juicy herbage (in the CK raTob)]: (O, Ḳ:) as also qaf-N. (TA.)
guf-apN A sufficiency of the means of subsistence: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) like guv-apN and gub-apN. (O in art. gv.) See an ex. in a verse cited voce TabaEN.
And A thing [or portion of pasture or fodder] that a camel takes with his mouth in haste. (Sh, O, Ḳ.)
And Old, and wasted or withered, such as is the worst, of pasture or herbage. (TA.)
And A portion remaining of the contents of a vessel and of an udder. (TA.)
And The mouse; because it is sufficient food for the cat. (IDrd,* O,* Ḳ.)
gafiyfapN Such as is beautiful and bright, in full maturity and in blossom, of herbs, or leguminous plants. (Ḳ.)
jaMCa EalaI gif-aAnihi He came at the time thereof: (O, Ḳ:) so says Ibn-ʼAbbád: (O:) or (Ḳ) it is correctly Eif-aAnihi, with the unpointed E (O, Ḳ,) originally Uif-aAnihi. (O.)

hom.sense: 1. gafarahu, aor. _i {yagofiru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gaforN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He covered, veiled, concealed, or hid, it; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., anything. (TA.) This is the primary signification. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
[Hence] gafar AlX-ayoba biAlxiDaAbi He covered, or concealed, the white, or hoary, hair with dye; (Ḳ;) as also Oagofarahu↓. (TA.)
And gafara AlmataAEa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) fiI AlwiEaMCi, (Ḳ,) He put the goods, or utensils, into the bag, or receptacle, and concealed them; (Ḳ;) as also Agfrhu↓. (Ḳ.)

[Hence also] gafara lahu canobahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagofiru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. magofaripN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and guforaAnN and gaforN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gufuwrN (Lḥ, Ḳ) and gafiyrN and gafiyrpN, (Ḳ,) He (God) covered, his sin, crime, or offence; (Ḳ;) forgave it; pardoned it; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Agtfr↓ canobahu, (Ṣ,) or Agtfr lahu maA SanaEa he forgave him what he had done: (Mṣb:) or guforaAnN and magofirapN, on the part of God, signify the preserving a man from being touched by punishment: and sometimes gafara lahu signifies [he forgave him, or pardoned him: and also] he forgave him, or pardoned him, apparently, but not really; and thus it is used in the Ḳur xlv. 13, accord. to the B. (TA.) As an ex. of the last of the inf. ns. mentioned above on the authority of the Ḳ, the following saying, of a certain Arab, is cited: OasoOaluka Algafiyraho waAln-aAqapa Algazyiraho waAlEiz-a fiI AlEaXiyraho faUin-ahaA Ealayoka yasiyraho [I beg of Thee (O God) forgiveness, and a she-camel abounding in milk, and might among the kinsfolk, or in the tribe, for they are to Thee things easy]. (TA.) [See also the paragraph commencing with gafiyrapN.]

In the following saying of Zuheyr, the verb is used tropically:
OaDaAEato falamo tugofaro lahaA gafalaAtuhaA
meaning [She lost her young one, and] her acts of negligence with respect to her young one were not forgiven her, by the wild beasts, so they ate it. (TA.)

gafara AlOamora biguforatihi↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) and bigafiyratihi↓, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagofiru}, (Ṣ,) [lit. He covered the affair with its cover,] means † he rectified the affair with that wherewith it was requisite that it should be rectified. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And Agtfrhu↓ perhaps signifies the same: see murotaOabN, in art. rOb.]

gafara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagofiru}, inf. n. gaforN, (Ṣ,) It (a wound) became recrudescent; or reverted to a bad, or corrupt, state; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gafira, [of which see another meaning in what follows,] aor. _a {yagofaru}, inf. n. gafarN. (Ṣ.) And in like manner the former is said of a sick person: (Ṣ:) [i. e.] gafara signifies likewise He (a sick person) relapsed into disease, after convalescence; as also gufira: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner one says of a wounded person. (TA.) And [hence, app.,] it is also said of an excessive lover, meaning He experienced a return of his desire, (Ḳ, TA,) after consolation. (TA.)
gafira said of a wound signifies also It healed: thus having two contr. meanings. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

gafara Aljalabu Als-uwqa, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. _i {yagofiru}, inf. n. gaforN, (TA,) means rax-aSahaA [more correctly OaroxaSahaA i. e. The beasts, or other things, brought thither for sale, made the market cheap]. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. gf-rhu He said gafara Qll-ehu lahu [May God cover his sins,, &c.; may God forgive him, or pardon him]. (TA, from a trad.)

hom.sense: 4. Agfr: see 1, in two places.
Oagofarato It (land) produced somewhat of gafar, meaning small herbage: (TA:) [i. e.] it produced herbage like the nap of cloth. (O, L, TA.*)

And It (land) produced its magaAfiyr [pl. of mugofuwrN, q. v.]. (IAth, O, L, TA.) And Agfr It (the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov, Ṣ, and the EurofuT, [&c.,] TA) exuded, or produced, its magaAfiyr. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also, i. e. Agfrt, [from guforN, q. v.,] She (a mountaingoat) had a young one, or young ones. (O, TA.)
And Agfr Aln-axolu The palm-tress had, upon their unripe dates, what resembled bark, or crust; (O, Ḳ, TA;) which the people of El-Medeeneh term AlgafaA [or AlgafaI]. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tgf-r and tamagofara↓ He gathered what is called migofar and mugofuwr [see the latter of these two words]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) He who says mugofuwr says xarajonaA natamagofaru↓, and he who says migofar says xrjnA natagaf-aru, We went forth to gather mgfwr, or mgfr, from its trees. (Ṣ.)
6. tgAfrA They two prayed for the covering of sins,, &c., or for forgiveness, or pardon, each for the other. (TA.)
8: see the first paragraph {1}, in two places.

10. Astgfr Qll-eha, (Mṣb,) and Astgfr Qll-eh mino canobihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and licanobihi, (Ṣ,) and canobahu, (Ḳ,) He begged of God forgiveness, or pardon; (Mṣb;) he sought of God the covering, or forgiveness, or pardon, of his sin, crime, or offence, (Ḳ, TA,) by word and by deed; for so God requires one to do; not with the tongue only. (TA.)
11: see the first paragraph {1}.
Q. Q. 2. tamagofara: see 5, in two places.

hom.sense: gaforN: see gafarN, in two places.
See also guforN.
Also The belly. (Ḳ.)
And A certain thing like the [sack called] juwaAliq. (Ḳ.)

And Algaforu is the name of The star [λ] in the left foot of Virgo: (Ḳzw in his Descr. of Virgo:) or three obscure stars, (Ḳzw in his Descr. of the Mansions of the Moon,) or three small stars, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [most probably, I think, (not φ and ι and κ, as supposed by Freytag, who refers to Ideler's “Untersuch.” pp. 169 and 288, but) ι and κ and λ of Virgo, though said to be] belonging to Libra: (Ṣ:) one of the Mansions of the Moon, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) namely, the Fifteenth. (Ḳzw in his Descr. of the Mansions.)

entry.sense: guforN The young of the mountain-goat; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gaforN↓; but the former is the more common; (Ḳ;) the latter, rare: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OagofaArN and [of mult.] gifarapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gufuwrN: (Kr, Ḳ:) the female is termed guforapN: and it is said that guforN is an appellation of one and of a pl. number: the phrase guforN kaviyrN is mentioned [as meaning many young ones of the mountain-goat]. (TA.)
giforN The young of the cow [probably meaning of the bovine antelope called the wild cow]. (El-Hejeree, Ḳ.)
And A certain duwayob-ap [by which may be meant a small beast or creeping thing, or an insect]: (IDrd, O, Ḳ:) so, says IDrd, they assert. (O.)

gafarN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and gaforN↓ (Ṣ, TA) and gufaArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) Hair like down, such as is upon the shank of a woman, and upon the forehead, and the like thereof: (Ṣ, TA:) or the hair of the neck, and of the jaws, and of the back of the neck; (Ḳ, TA;) as also gafiyrN↓ accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, but accord. to the L and other lexicons gaforN: and the small, short, hairs of the body. (TA.)
And gafarN signifies also The growth of hair in the place of the mane of a horse or similar beast. (TA.)

And The nap, or villous substance, upon the surface of a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and the like thereof; (TA;) and gaforN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ, TA:) n. un. gaforapN [and app. gafarapN]: and gafarN is also expl. as signifying the hudob [app. here meaning likewise nap, or pile, or perhaps the unwoven end,] of a garment, or piece of cloth, and [particularly] of the thin and soft sorts of what are termed xamaAYiS and quTuf [pls. of xamiySapN and qaTiyfapN]; but not the extremities of Oarodiyap and malaAHif [pls. of ridaMCN and miloHafapN]. (TA.)

And Small herbage; (Ḳ:) [or] a sort of small, sprouting herbage, of the [season called] rabiyE, growing in plain, or soft, land, and upon the [eminences termed] MkAm [pl. of OakamapN]; when green, resembling green passerine birds standing; and when it has dried up, resembling such as are red, not standing. (L, TA.*)
huwagafiru AlqafaA means He is one who has [hair such as is termed] gafar upon the back of his neck: and hiIa gafirapu Alwajohi, she is one who has gafar upon her face. (AḤn, Ḳ,* TA.)
guforapN A cover; a thing with which another thing is covered. (Ṣ.) [Hence] one says, gafara AlOamora biguforatihi (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bigafiyratihi↓ (Ḳ) expl. above: see 1.
giforapN HasanapN A good manner of covering, forgiving, or pardoning, sins, &c. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
gufaArN: see gafarN, first sentence.
gifaArN A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon the cheek [app. of a camel]. (TA.)
gafuwrN: see gaAfirN, in three places.

hom.sense: jam-aMCu gafiyrN A helmet that encloses and embraces the whole head. (Ḳ.) AO says, in his “Book on the Coat of Mail and the Helmet,” that bayoDapN is a general name for a helmet, which has plates like the bones of the skull, fastened together, edge to edge, by nails. (TA.)

jaAWuwA jam-aMCa gafiyrFA, and Aljam-aMCa Algafiyra, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jam-aMCa Algafiyri, and jam-FA gafiyrFA, and Aljam-a Algafiyra, and jam-a Algafiyri, and jam-aMCa AlgafiyraI↓, and jam-aMCa gafiyrapF↓, and Algafiyrapa↓ Aljam-aMCa, and jam-aMCa Algafiyrapi↓, and jam-a Algafiyrapi↓, and bijam-aMCi Algafiyri, and bijam-aMCi Algafiyrapi↓, (Ḳ,) are phrases meaning They came all together, high and low, none of them remaining behind, and they being many: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to Sb, (Ḳ,) it (Aljm-MC Algfyr, Ṣ, which is the only form that he mentions, TA, [or rather the former of these two words,]) is a subst., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) put in the place of an inf. n., (Ḳ,) i. e. put in the accus. case like an inf. n. of the same meaning, (TA,) i. e., [as when you say] mararotu bihimo jumuwmFA kaviyrFA [I passed by them they being very many]: (Ḳ:) it is not a verb, [by which is here meant, as in many other instances, an inf. n.,] but is put in the accus. case like an inf. n. of the same meaning, as when you say jaAWuwniI jamiyEFA, and qaATibapF, and Tur-FA, and kaAf-apF, [They came to me all together,] and the article Al is prefixed like as it is prefixed in the saying OaworadahaA AlEiraAka, meaning OaworadahaA EiraAkFA [He brought them (the camels) to the water all together]: (Ṣ:) Sb says that it is one of those denotatives of state which have the art. Al prefixed, and is extr.; and that Algfyr is an epithet inseparable from Aljm-MC; meaning that you do not say Aljm-MC and then be silent: (TA:) others hold it to be an inf. n.: IAmb allows it to be in the nom. case, on the condition that hum is understood [before it; i. e., the complete phrase being jaAWuwA humu Aljam-aMCu Algafiyru]: and Ks says that the Arabs put Aljm-AC Algfyr in the accus. case fiI Alt-amaAmi [i. e. in the case of its occurring after a proposition rendered complete by the mention of the agent. as when you say jaMCa Alqawomu Aljam-aMCa Algafiyra], and in the nom. case fiI Aln-uqoSaAni [i. e. in the case of its occurring when what precedes it is not a complete proposition, and is only rendered complete by it as the agent, as when you say jaMCa Aljam-aMCu Algafyiru]. (Ḳ.)

It is said in a trad., that Moḥammad, being asked by Aboo-Dharr, what was the number of the apostles, answered valevumiAYapK waxamosapa EaXara jam-a Algafiyri, meaning, Three hundred and fifteen: a great number. (Nh, TA.)
See also gafarN, first sentence.

entry.sense: gifaArapN: see migofarN, in three places.

Also A piece of rag worn beneath the miqonaEap [q. v.], by which a woman preserves it from the oil or grease [on her head]: (Ṣ: [accord to one of my copies of the Ṣ, “preserves her head:”]) or a piece of rag by which a woman preserves her ximaAr [q. v.] from the oil or grease: (Ḳ:) or a piece of rag with which a woman covers the fore part and the hind part (but not the middle) of her head. (TA.)
[And A cloth that is spread upon the camel-litter. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
And A patch (ruqoEap) that is put upon the notch, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a piece of skin which is upon the head, (TA,) upon which runs the string, of the bow. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And A cloud (Ṣ, Ḳ) that is as though it were (Ṣ) above another cloud. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And The head of a mountain. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: gafiyrapN: see guforapN, and 1.

maA fiyhimo gafiyrapN [There is not in them any disposition to forgive;] means they do not forgive any one a sin, a crime, or an offence. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And maAEinodahumo EaciyrapN walaA gafiyrapN [They have not a disposition to excuse nor a disposition to forgive;] means they do not excuse nor do they forgive a sin, a crime, or an offence, of any one. (TA.) The rájiz (Sakhr-el-Ghei, L) said, (on seeing his companions, with whom he was journeying, fly from the Benu-l-Mustalik, whom they chanced to meet, L,)
yaA qawomi layosato fiyhimu gafiyraho
faQmoXuwA kamaA tamoXiI jimaAlu AlHiyraho
[O my people, there is not in them any disposition to forgive: therefore march ye as march the camels of El-Heereh]: (Ṣ, L:) he mentioned particularly the camels of El-Heereh because they carry burdens; and meant, march ye heavily, and defend yourselves, and do not fly. (L.)
Also Abundance, and increase, in family and cattle or other property. (TA, from a trad.)
See also gafiyrN, in five places.

entry.sense: gafiyraI: see gafiyrN.
gaf-aArN: see the next paragraph.

gaAfirN (TA) and gafuwrN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and gaf-aArN↓ (Ḳ, TA) are epithets applied to God. (Ḳ, TA,) the second and third of which are intensive; (TA;) meaning, [the first,] Covering and forgiving the sins, crimes, and offences, of his servants; [or simply forgiving; and the second and third, covering and forgiving much the sins,, &c., of his servants; or very forgiving.] (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA) The pl. of gafuwrN↓ is gufurN. (Ṣ.) And gafuwrN↓ is also applied to a woman, without p. (TA.)

gawofarN The autumnal biT-iyx [i. e. melon or water-melon]: (Ḳ:) or a species thereof (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA) It is said that the biT-iyx and the gawofar are of those things in the cases of which the giving of the tithe is not incumbent. (Mgh.)

Oagofaru [Having the quality of covering, or the like, in a greater, or in the greatest, degree]. One says AuSobugo vawobaka bAls-awaAdi faUin-ahu Oagofaru liwasaxihi Dye thou thy garment, or piece of cloth, with black; for it has the quality of bearing and concealing its dirt in the greatest degree. (Ṣ,* TA.)
mugofurN: see mugofuwrN, in two places.
mugofirN, (O, TA,) or mugofirapN, (Ṣ,) or the latter also, (O, TA,) A she-goat of the mountain having a young one or young ones: (Ṣ,* O,* TA:) pl. mugofiraAtN. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense:
migofarN What is worn beneath the helmet: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or a piece of mail, (zaradN, Ṣ Ḳ,) woven (Ṣ) from the diroE [or coat of mail], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) according to the size of the head, (Ṣ,) worn beneath the [kind of cap called] qalanosuwap; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also migofarapN↓ and gifaArapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the raforaf [or pendent appertenance] of the helmet: (TA:)
or a piece of mail, (HalaqN, or HilaqN, as in different copies of the Ḳ,) which an armed man, (Ḳ,) or a man, accord. to some lexicons, (TA,) wears in the manner of a qinaAE (yataqan-aEu bihaA); as also migofarapN↓ and gifaArapN↓: (Ḳ:) accord. to ISh, the migofar is a piece of mail (HalaqN) which a man puts beneath the helmet, hanging down upon the neck: and sometimes, he says, it is like the qalanosuwap, except that it is more ample; a man throws it upon his head, and it reaches to the coat of mail; then the helmet is put on over it; and this mgfr hangs down upon the shoulders: sometimes, also, the mgfr is [a covering for the head] made of diybaAj [i. e. silk brocade], and of [the cloth called] xaz- [q. v.], beneath the helmet: accord. to “the Book of the Coat of Mail and the Helmet,” by AO, migofarN and gifaArapN↓ are names applied to a portion of mail [forming a headcovering], which is also called tasobigapN [q. v.]; and sometimes the rings are exposed to view; and sometimes they line them within, and cover them externally, with diybaAj or xaz- or [the kind of silk stuff called] bizoyawon; and they stuff it with something (HX-whA bmA kAn); and sometimes they make above it a qawonas [or tapering top] of silver, &c.: (TA:) the term migofar is also applied to the helmet itself. (Mgh.)
See also mugofuwrN, in three places.

entry.sense: migofarapN: see migofarN, in two places.
migofaArN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

mugofuwrN (AA, T, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and migofarN↓ (Ks, T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and mugofarN↓ and migofaArN↓ and migofyrN↓ (Ḳ) i. q. mugovuwrN; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) [A kind of manna;] a produce of the [species of tree, or shrub, called] rimov and sometimes of the EuXar and the EurofuT and the vumaAm and the salam and the TaloH &c.; (Ṣ;) the gum of the rmv and ErfT; (T;) the gum that is found upon the rmv, which is sweet, and is eaten; (AA;) a thing that flows, or exudes, from the ends of the twigs of the rmv, resembling dibos in its colour; (ISh, in explanation of the pl. magaAfiyru;) a gum that flows, or exudes, from the ErfT, not of pleasant odour; (IAth;) a gum resembling [the kind of sweetmeat called] naATif, exuded by the ErfT, which is put into a piece of cloth, then sprinkled with water, and drunk: accord. to Lth, migofaArN↓ is applied to the gum of the Uij-aASap: and some say that migofarN↓ is applied to gum of a round shape; SuEoruwrN to that which is in shape like a finger; and cawobN to that which flows upon the ground: and migofarN↓ is also applied to a twig of a gum-tree, from which [for bihi (with which), in the TA, I read minohu,] is wiped a white fluid, whereof is made a sweet beverage: (TA:) pl. [of mugofuwrN and migofaArN and migofiyrN] magaAfiyru, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and [of migofarN and mugofurN] magaAfiru: (Ḳ:) it is also said that magaAfiyru is applied to a kind of sweet honey, like rub-, except that it is white. (TA.) [Hence the saying,]
hecaA AljanaI laA Oano yukad-a Almugofuru↓
[This is gathering, not the scraping off mgfr]: a prov. alluding to the preference of a thing; said to him who obtains much good. (Ḳ.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 874.]
migofiyrN: see the next preceding paragraph.
OaroDN magofuwraMCu Land containing [trees producing] magaAfiyr. (IDrd, Ḳ.) [See mugofuwrN.]
3. gAfShu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. mugaAfaSapN and gifaASN, (TA,) He came upon him suddenly, or unexpectedly; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he took him at unawares, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and did an evil action to him. (TA.)
Hence the saying, (Mṣb,) Oaxacotuhu mugaAfaSapF (A, Mṣb, TA) I took it (a thing, Mṣb) striving to overcome. (Mṣb, TA.)

gaAfiSapN A sudden, or an unexpected, calamity, of time, or fortune: (Ṣgh,* Ḳ,* TḲ:) pl. gawaAfiSu. (A.) You say, waqaAka Qll-ehu gawaAfiSa Ald-ahori [May God preserve thee from the sudden, or unexpected, calamities of time, or fortune]. (A.)

1. gafala Eanohu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagofulu}, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. gufuwlN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gafolapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Ḳ,) or it is a simple subst. as well as an inf. n., and so may be gufolaAnN, said in the Ḳ to be a simple subst.; and MF says that gafila, aor. _a {yagofalu}, of which gafalN, mentioned in the Ḳ as a subst. syn. with gafolapN, may be the inf. n., has been mentioned by some as a dial. var. of gafala, but had not been found by him in any of the lexicological works notwithstanding much research, so that its correctness requires consideration; (TA;) He was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it; (Mṣb;) namely, a thing: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) or he neglected it; and was, or became, unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it: (Ḳ:) and sometimes it is used as meaning he neglected it [intentionally], leaving it, and turning away: (Mṣb:) and Agflhu↓ signifies the same as gafala Eanohu: or gafala signifies SaAragaAfilFA [he became unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent]: and gafala Eanohu and Agflhu↓ signify waS-ala gafolatahu Uilayohi [which is app. said merely for the purpose of showing that the former verb is made trans. only by means of Eano, and the latter is trans. without any prep.; for waS-ala AlfiEola UilaI mafoEuwilhi and OawoSalahu Uilayohi, which latter phrase is the more usual, mean “he made the verb transitive”]: (Ḳ:) or Agflhu↓ signifies he neglected it (i. e. a thing) though remembering it. (ʼEyn, Sb, Ṣ, O, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., mani Qt-abaEa AlS-ayoda gafala i. e. He who pursues the object of the chase has his mind busied and possessed by it so that he becomes unmindful [&c. of other things]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. gf-lhu, inf. n. tagofiylN, He made him to become unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent. (Mṣb.)
See also 4.

Alt-agofiylu signifies [also] The sufficing one's companion [in respect of an affair] when he who is the object thereof is unmindful, unoccupied [in mind, or actually,] by anything. (ISk, Ḳ, TA.) [You say, gf-l SaAHibahu meaning He sufficed his companion in respect of an affair when he (the latter) was unmindful,, &c.]
And gf-lhu, (Mgh, O, Ḳ, but in my copy of the Mgh written without teshdeed,) inf. n. as above, (O, Ḳ,) He concealed it, (Mgh, O, Ḳ,) namely, a thing. (Mgh, O.)

entry.sense: 3. gAflhu [app. He acted with him in the manner of him who is unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent]. (TA voce saAhaAhu, q. v., in art. shw.)
4. Agflhu: see 1, in three places.

[Hence,] one says, maA Oagofalahu Eanoka XayoYFA [app. lit. signifying How unmindful of thee is he as to anything! and therefore virtually] meaning dismiss doubt [from thee respecting him as to anything]. (TA. [See further explanations of it voce XaIoCN.])

And Agflhu Eanohu He made him to be unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, or heedless, of it, or inadvertent to it; (Ṣ,* O, TA;) namely, a thing. (Ṣ.) [Or] Agflhu signifies He, or it, smote him, or lighted on him, he (the latter) being gaAfil [i. e. unmindful,, &c.]: or he made him to be gaAfil: or he called him, or named him, gaAfil: and in like manner gf-lhu↓, inf. n. tagofiylN: (TA:) or tagofiylN signifies the calling [one] unmindful,, &c.: and the rendering [one] stupid, or foolish. (KL.)
And Agflhu signifies also He asked him [for, or respecting, a thing] in the time of his occupation, not waiting for the time of his freedom therefrom. (TA.)
And Agfl Ald-aAb-apa He left the beast unbranded; did not brand it. (Ṣ, O.)

hom.sense: 5. tgf-l as intrans.: see 6, in two places.

tgf-lhu He watched for his unmindfulness, forgetfulness, negligence, heedlessness, or inadvertence; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb;) as also tgAfl↓ Eanohu, (Ṣ, O,) and Astgflhu↓: (TA:) tgAfl [as trans.] in this sense [without a prep.] is a mistake. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: 6. tgAfl He feigned himself unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent; not being so really. (Mṣb.) [And] He was intentionally, or purposely, unmindful, forgetful,, &c.; as also tgf-l↓: (Ḳ:) or the former has this meaning: but tgf-l↓ signifies he was deceived, or circumvented, in a state of unmindfulness, forgetfulness,, &c. (TA.) tgAfl Eanohu: see 5. It means [also] He was unmindful,, &c., of him, or it: or he feigned himself unmindful,, &c., of him, or it. (MA.)
10. Astgflhu: see 5.

gufolN Land without cultivation: (Ḳ:) or without any way-mark: (Mṣb:) or without any waymark and without cultivation: (Ṣ, O:) or not rained upon: (Ks, Ṣ, O:) or unknown; in which is no known trace; or vestige:
and, accord. to the M, a desert, or waterless desert, that causes one to lose his way, wherein is no sign, or mark: (TA:) pl. OagofaAlN, (Ṣ, TA,) syn. with mawaAtN [q. v.]; (Ṣ:) and Lḥ mentions the phrase OaroDN OagofaAlN, as though they made every portion thereof to be what is termed gufolN: and bilaAdN OagofaAlN, meaning [tracts of country] wherein are no way-marks by which to be directed. (TA.)
Also A road, or way, &c., in which is no sign, or mark, whereby it may be known. (Ḳ.)

And A gaming-arrow (qidoHN) upon which is no mark [or notch to distinguish it]; (Ḳ;) such as has no portion assigned to it, and no fine: (O, Ḳ:) [or,] accord. to Lḥ, one says qidaAHN gufolN, using the sing. form [of the epithet] meaning [gaming arrows] in which are no notches, and to which is assigned no portion and no fine: they used to be added to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play], i. e. to increase the number: and they were four; the first [called] AlmuSad-aru; the next, AlmuDaE-afu; the next, AlmaniyHu; and the next, Als-afiyHu. (TA.)

And A beast (daAb-apN) having no brand upon it: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and a she-camel that is not branded, in order that the poor-rate may not be [considered as] incumbent for her: and gufulN↓ is a dial. var. thereof, or is used by poetic license: the pl. is OagofaAlN. (TA.) The pl. (OagofaAlN) is also applied to Camels, or cattle, (naEamN,) that yield no milk. (TA.)
And A muSoHaf [or copy of the Ḳur-án] bare of the [signs called] EawaAXir [pl. of EaAXirapN q. v.] and the like of these. (TA.)

And A book, or writing, [that is anonymous,] of which the author is not named. (TA.) And Poetry of which the author is unknown. (Ḳ.) And A poet unknown (Ḳ, TA) and unnamed [or anonymous]: pl. OagofaAlN. (TA.)

Also A man inexperienced in affairs. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA.) One whose beneficence is not hoped for, nor his evilness feared; (Ḳ, TA;) he being like the shackled that is neglected: pl. as above. (TA.) And One having no grounds of pretension to respect or honour: (Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, of whom one knows not what he possesses. (TA.)
And The fur (lit. furs, or soft portions of hair, OawobaAr, [perhaps because long left unshorn,]) of camels. (AḤn, Ḳ, TA.)
gafalN: see gafolapN.

Also [Such as is] abundant and high [in estimation, app. of the means of subsistence]; syn. kaviyrN rafiyEN: (O, Ḳ: [or the latter word is correctly rafiygN, (so in the TḲ,) i. e. ample, and pleasant or good, as applied to the means of subsistence:]) and a state of ampleness of the means of subsistence: (O, Ḳ:) thus in the saying, huwa fiI gafalK mino EayoXihi [He is in a state of ampleness in respect of his means of subsistence: app. thus termed as being a cause of unmindfulness, or heedlessness]. (O.)
gufulN: see gufolN, latter half.

gafolapN the subst. from gafala, (ISd, Ḳ,) or it is an inf. n. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA) and also a simple subst., (TA,) or the subst. is gafalapN↓, with fet-ḥ to the f to distinguish it from the inf. n.; (Mṣb;) as also gafalN↓, (ISd, Ḳ,) or this may be the inf. n. of gafila, mentioned above as a dial. var. outweighed in authority; (TA;) and gufolaAnN↓, (Ḳ,) or this may be an inf. n. like kuforaAnN, and it may be a simple subst.; (TA;) Unmindfulness, forgetfulness, neglectfulness, heedlessness, or inadvertence; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) [the state in which is] absence of a thing from the mind of a man; and unmindfulness, or forgetfulness: and sometimes, intentional neglect: (Mṣb;) or gafolapN signifies the forgetting, neglecting, or being unmindful, of a thing: (Abu-l-Baḳà, TA:) or the want of requisite knowledge or cognizance of a thing: (El-Harállee, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Raghib, negligence occurring from littleness of consideration and of vigilance; or, as some say, the following the soul in that which it desires, (TA.) [fiI gafolapK In a state of unmindfulness, &c., and Eano gafolapK in consequence of unmindfulness, &c., may often be rendered at unawares.]
gafalapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
gafolaAnN, or gafolaAnu: see gaAfilN.
gufolaAnN: see gafolapN.
gafuwlN A she-camel that does not take fright and flee, (Ḳ, TA,) nor hold back from a young one that she suckles, nor care who milks her. (TA.)
gaAfilN and [gafolaAnN↓, or gafolaAnu, Unmindful, forgetful, neglectful, heedless, or inadvertent: and the former, sometimes, intentionally neglecting: pl. of the former gufuwlN and guf-alN]. (Ḳ.)
mugofilN Possessing camels not branded. (TA.)

magofalapN The Eanofaqap [or tuft of hair beneath the lower lip]; (O, Ḳ, TA;) so says Th, (O,) or Ez-Zejjájee: (TA:) not the two sides thereof as it is said to signify by J: (Ḳ:) so called because many men neglect [the washing of] it. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Ealayoka biQlomagofalapi [Keep thou to the washing of the tuft of hair beneath the lower lip]: meaning that one should use heedfulness in washing it, in the performance of the ablution termed wuDuwC. (TA.)
mugaf-alN [lit. Made unmindful,, &c.; see its verb: and hence, a simpleton; or] devoid of intelligence, sagacity, skill, or natural understanding. (IDrd, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gafaA, and gafiIa: see 4.
gafaA, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gafowN and gufuw-N, (TA,) also signifies It (a thing, TA) floated upon the water (Ḳ, TA.)

gafaI AlT-aEaAma, aor. _i, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gafoIN, (TA,) He cleared the wheat of what is termed gafFI, i. e. a thing such as [the noxious weed called] zuWaAn [q. v.], (Ḳ, TA,) and other refuse; (TA;) or the straw; as also AgfI↓. (Ḳ, TA,)

4. AgfI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UigofaMCN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and gafaA↓, (Ḳ,) first pers. gafawotu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gafowN and gufuw-N; (Ḳ;) the latter verb said by ISd to occur in the trads., (TA,) but disallowed by ISk (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and by others, (Mṣb,) and said by Az to be rare; (Mṣb, TA;) He slept: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he slept a light sleep: (Mṣb, TA;) or he was, or became, drowsy, or heavy with sleepiness; as also gafiIa↓, aor. _a, inf. n. gafoyapN. (Ḳ.)
And AgfI He (a man, TA) slept upon what is termed gafFI, i. e. the straw, in the place in which the grain thereof was trodden out: (Ḳ:) mentioned as from IAạr by Az, and by Ṣgh as from AA. (TA.)
And AgfI AlT-aEaAmu The wheat was abundant in its nuxaAlap, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, but more properly its nufaAyap [i. e. refuse]. (TA.)
See also 1.
AgfI AlX-ajaru The trees hung down their branches. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

entry.sense: 7. AngfI. It (a thing, TA) became broken. (Ḳ, TA.)

gafowN and gafowapN↓ and gafoyapN↓ (Ḳ, TA) and gufoyapN↓ and gifoyapN↓ (Ṣgh, TA) A zuboyap [or hollow dug in the ground], (Ḳ, TA,) in which a sportsman lurks: the first and second mentioned by Lḥ. (TA.)

gafFI The refuse that is taken forth from wheat, and thrown away, (Fr, Ṣ, TA,) such as [the noxious weed called] zuWaAn [q. v.]; (Ṣ;) a thing that is in wheat, such as zWAn, (Ḳ, TA,) and other refuse: (TA:) or the straw [thereof]; (Ḳ, TA;) accord. to IAạr, the bad, that is thrown away, of wheat; as also gafaMCN↓. (Az, TA.)

Also, (thus accord. to ISd in all the senses here following in this paragraph that are found in the Ḳ, as is said in the TA, and thus in some copies of the Ḳ,) or gufaMCN↓, (thus in the copies of the Ḳ followed in the TA,) i. q. guvaMCN [i. e. The rubbish, or small rubbish, or particles of things, or refuse, and scum, and rotten leaves mixed with the scum, of a torrent]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And Fragments, or broken portions, of wheat: (Ḳ, TA;) or the stalks thereof. (TA.)

And A blight incident to palm-trees, like dust falling upon the unripe dates, preventing their becoming ripe, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and rendering them tasteless. (Ṣ [in which the word thus expl. is gafFI] and TA.) And A thick crust that comes upon unripe dates: [see 4 in art. gfr:] or, as some say, bad dates, that become [app. in the skin] thick, or coarse, and like the wings of locusts. (TA.)
And A disease incident to straw, rendering it bad. (TA.)
Also Such as they drive away, or expel, of their camels. (Ḳ, TA.)
And gafFI signifies also The bad of anything. (TA.)
And The low, vile, mean, or sordid; or the lower, viler,, &c.; or the refuse, or rabble; of mankind. (TA.)

hom.sense: gafowapN A light sleep: occurring in the traditions. (TA.)
See also gafowN.

entry.sense: gafoyapN and gufoyapN and gifoyapN: see gafowN.

gafiyapN, like fariHapN [in measure], in the phrase xTp gfyp, [in which, app., the former word is xuT-apN, and the meaning of the phrase An affair, or a case, or a dubious, or momentous, and difficult affair, in which is something evil, or to be rejected,] is a possessive epithet, signifying fiyhaA gafFI. (TA: immediately after gafFI expl. as meaning the “bad” of anything.)
gafaMCN and gufaMCN: see gafFI, first and second sentences.
AlgufaMCapu [in the CK AlgufApu] The whiteness upon the Hadaqap [or iris of the eye], (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., that covers the Hdqp. (TA.)
UigofaMCapu AlS-uboHi The sleep of daybreak, or the first part of the day. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gal-ahu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yagolulu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. gal-N, (Ḳ,) He made it, or caused it, to enter, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* [in the CK Audoxila is erroneously put for Oadoxala,]) fiI XaIoCK into a thing; (O, Ḳ;) as also galogalahu↓, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. galogalapN; or this last word signifies the making, or causing, a thing to enter a thing so as to become confused with, and a part of, that into which it enters: (TA:)

and gal-a, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ṣ) and so the inf. n., (TḲ,) signifies also It entered [into a thing]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) being intrans. as well as trans.; (Ṣ, O;) and so does Ainogal-a↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and tgl-l↓, and tagalogala↓; (Ḳ, TA;) said of [what are termed by logicians] substances and of [what are termed by them] accidents. (TA.)

yagul-u said of a ram means Penem suum inserit (yudoxilu qaDiybahu) non sublatâ caudâ. (Ṣ, O,* TA.) And gal-a signifies also Inivit (HaXaOa, in some copies of the Ḳ without the hemzeh,) feminam: (Ḳ, TA; in which latter is added wlA ykwn Al-A mn DaxomK [app. meaning that this is not said of any but such as is big, or bulky]:) mentioned by IAạr. (TA.)
gal-a Ald-uhona fiI raOosihi He made the oil to enter amid the roots of the hair of his head. (Ḳ.) And gal-a XaEarahu biAlT-iybi He made the perfume to enter amid his hair. (TA.)
And gal-ahu lahu He made it to be unapparent to him (das-ahu lahu), he [the latter] having no knowledge of it. (TA: in which the pronoun affixed to the verb relates to a dagger, and to a spear-head.)
gal-a AlmafaAwiza He (a man) entered into the midst of the deserts, or waterless deserts. (Ṣ, O.)

gal-a AlmaMCu bayona AlOaXojaAri, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yagolulu}, (Ṣ, O,) The water ran amid the trees. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And tagalogala↓ AlmaMCu fiI AlX-ajari The water entered amid the breaks, or interspaces, of the trees. (Ṣ.)

gal-a AlgilaAlapa He clad himself with, or wore, the glAlp [q. v.] (Ḳ, TA) beneath the [other] garments; because he who does so enters into it. (TA.) And Aigotalalotu↓ Alv-awoba [in like manner] signifies I clad myself with, or wore, the garment beneath the [other] garments. (Ḳ.)

gal-a fulaAnFA, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put upon the neck, or the hand, of such a one, the gul- [i. e. ring, or collar, of iron, for the neck, or pinion or manacle for the hand]. (Ḳ, TA.) And gul-a He had the gul- put upon him. (Ṣ,* TA.) And galalotu yadahu UiliI Eunuqihi [I confined his hand to his neck with the gul-]. (Ṣ, O.) And gal-a OasiyrFA bigul-K mino qid-K waEalayohi XaEarN [He confined a captive with a gul- of thongs upon which was hair]. (TA.) One says, maA lahu Oul-a wagul-a, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA, [in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ, which have misled Golius and Freytag, mAlh Oul-N wagul-N,]) a form of imprecation, (Ḳ, TA,) meaning [What ails him?] may he be thrust, or pushed, in the back of his neck, and become possessed, or insane, (IB, TA in the present art. and in art. Al,) and therefore have the gul- put upon him. (TA in the present art.) And gul-ato yaduhu UilaI Eunuqihi [sometimes] means † His hand was withheld from expenditure. (TA.)

gul-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yugal-u, inf. n. galalN, said of a man, (Ṣ,) He was, or became, thirsty; or vehemently thirsty; (Ḳ, TA;) or affected with burning of thirst, (Ṣ, TA,) little or much; (TA;) or with burning of the inside, (Ḳ, TA,) from thirst, and from anger and vexation. (TA.)

gal-a Sadoruhu, aor. yagil-N, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, yagal-u,]) with kesr, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. gil-N, with kesr, (O,) His bosom was, or became, affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and with dishonesty, or insincerity. (Ṣ, O.) [See also gil-N, below.] It is said in a trad., valaAvN laA yagil-u Ealayohin-a qalobu AlmuWomini i. e. [There are three habits, (xiSaAl being understood, these, as is said in the O, being “the acting sincerely towards God,” and “giving honest counsel to those in command,” and “keeping to the community” of the Muslims,)] while conforming to which the heart of the believer will not be invaded by rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, causing it to swerve from that which is right; (Ṣ,* O;) a saying of the Prophet; thus related by some: accord. to others, yugil-u↓, (Ṣ, O,) with damm to the I, (O,) which is from the meaning expl. in the next sentence here following. (Ṣ,* O.)

gal-a, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yagul-u, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. guluwlN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He acted unfaithfully; as also Agl-↓: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or thus the latter, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to ISk (Ṣ, Mṣb) and AʼObeyd, (Ṣ,) in a general sense; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and he became unfaithful: (TA:) but the former verb is used only in relation to spoil, or booty; (Ṣ, Mgh, O,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) you say, gal-a mina Almagonami meaning xaAna [i. e. He acted unfaithfully in taking from the spoil, or booty]; (Ṣ, O;) or meaning he acted unfaithfully in relation to the spoil, or booty: (Mgh:) or gal-a, (IAth, Mgh, TA,) aor. as above, (Mgh,) inf. n. guluwlN, (IAth, TA,) or gal-N, (Mgh, [thus in my copy, accord. to which it is trans., as will be shown by what follows,]) signifies also he stole; and was unfaithful in respect of a thing privily; and such conduct is termed guluwlN because, in the case thereof, the hands, or arms, have the gul- [q. v.] put upon them: (IAth, TA:) or it signifies also he took a thing and hid it amid his goods; and it occurs in a trad. as meaning he took a Xamolap privily. (Mgh.) It is said in the Ḳur [iii. 155], wamaA kaAna linabiI-K Oano yagul-a and Oano yugal-a↓, accord. to different readers; the former meaning [And it is not attributable to a prophet] that he would act unfaithfully; and An yugal-a↓ meaning, [agreeably with an explanation of Oagal-a fulaAnFA in the Ḳ,] that unfaithful conduct should be imputed to him; or that there should be taken from his [share of the] spoil, or booty; (Ṣ, O, TA;) [or this may mean, that he should be found to be acting unfaithfully; for, accord. to the TA, Agl- Alr-ajula means wajadahu gaAl-FA;] but IB says that a pass. aor. is seldom found in the language of the Arabs in a phrase of this kind. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. laA UigolaAla↓ walaA UisolaAla i. e. There shall be no acting unfaithfully nor stealing: or there shall be no act of bribery [nor stealing]: (Ṣ, O:) or, as some say, there shall be no aiding another to act unfaithfully [&c.]. (TA.)
galalotu liln-aAqapi I fed the she-camel with galiyl i. e. date-stones mixed with [the species of trefoil called] qit-. (Ṣ,* O, TA.)
gal-a AlUihaAba: see Oagal-a fiI AlUihaAbi.

entry.sense: 2. gl-lhu, (Ḳ,) or gl-l liHoyatahu, (Ṣ, O,) biAlgaAliyapi, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagoliylN, (Ḳ,) He perfumed him, (Ḳ,) or daubed, or smeared, his beard, much, (O,) the teshdeed denoting muchness, (Ṣ, O,) with gaAliyap: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and tgl-l↓ bAlgAlyp and Agtl-↓ and tagalogala↓ He perfumed himself with gAlyp: (Ḳ:) Lḥ mentions tagal-aI biAlgaAliyapi, which is either from the word gaAliyap or originally tagal-ala, in the latter case being like taZan-ayotu for taZan-anotu, but the former is the more agreeable with analogy: accord. to Fr, one says, tagal-alotu↓ bAlgAlyp, and not tagal-ayotu: (TA:) Aṣ held tagal-alotu↓ from AlgAlyp to be allowable if meaning I introduced the gAlyp into my beard or my mustache; (Ṣ, O;) and the like is the case with respect to gal-alotu bihaA liHoyatiI: (Ṣ:) accord. to Lth, one says, from AlgAlyp, gal-alotu and gal-afotu and gal-ayotu. (TA. [See also 1 in art. glI.])

hom.sense: 4. Agl- Uibilahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UigolaAlN, (TA,) He watered his camels ill, so that they did not satisfy their thirst: (Ḳ, TA:) or he brought, or sent, them back from the water without satisfying their thirst: (O, TA:) thus expl. by Az, who says that it is incorrectly mentioned by AʼObeyd, on the authority of AZ, [in this sense,] with the unpointed E. (TA. [But see 4 in art. El.])
And Agl- signifies also Agtl-t ganamuhu (O, Ḳ) [accord. to the TA as meaning His sheep, or goats, thirsted: but this I think doubtful: see 8].
Agl- and its aor. and inf. n. as relating to unfaithfulness, see in the latter half of the first paragraph, in five places.

Agl-t AlD-ayoEahu, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in the CK gal-at,]) and AlD-iyaAEu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) from Algal-apu, (Ṣ, O,) [The estate, and estates, consisting of land,, &c.,] became in the condition of having gal-ap [or proceeds, revenue, or income, accruing from the produce,, &c.]: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or yielded gal-ap: (Ḳ, TA:) i. e. yielded somewhat, the source thereof remaining. (TA.)

And Agl- Alqawomu meaning balagato gal-atuhumo [i. e. The gal-ap of the people, or party, arrived; as expl. in the PṢ and TA; or the people, or party, had their gl-p brought to them]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And The people, or party, became in [or entered upon] the time of the gal-ap. (TA.)
And fulaAnN yugil-u EalaI EiyaAlihi Such a one brings the gal-ap to his family, or household. (Ṣ, O.)
Agl- AlwaAdiI The valley gave growth to what are termed gul-aAn, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) pl. of gaAl-N. (TA.)

Agl- fiI AlUihaAbi, (Ṣ, O,) He (a butcher) left some of the flesh sticking in the hide, in stripping it off: (Ṣ, O:) or he took some of the flesh and of the fat [in the hide] in the skinning: (Ḳ:) and gl-↓ AlUihaAba he left somewhat [of the flesh, or of the flesh and of the fat,] remaining in the hide on the occasion of the skinning: a dial. var. of Oagal-a. (TA.)

And accord. to AA, AlUigolaAlu signifies The milking of the she-camel when milk remains [app. afterwards] in her udder. (O.) [Perhaps the meaning is The leaving some remaining in the udder on the occasion of milking.]
Agl- AlxaTiybu The orator, or preacher, said, or spoke, what was not right, or correct. (TA.)
Agl- baSarahu, (Ṣ, O,) or AlbaSara, (Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ, O) looked intensely, or intently. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence.
UigolaAlN signifies also The making an overt, or open, hostile, or predatory, incursion. (TA.)
And The clothing oneself with, or wearing, a coat of mail. (TA.)
5: see 1, first sentence:
and see also 2, in three places.

entry.sense: 7: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: 8. Aigotalalotu Alv-awoba: see 1, former half.
Aigotalalotu AlX-araAba I drank the beverage. (Ḳ.)
lahu OurayoDapN yagotal-uhaA: see 10.
Agtl- said of a camel, and Aigotal-ato said of sheep or goats: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. (See also the next sentence but one.)
Agtl- biAlgaAliyapi: see 2.
Aigotal-ato said of sheep or goats, They became affected with the disease termed galal [q. v.]. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10. AisotigolaAlN signifies The desiring, or demanding, or [tasking a person,] to bring gal-ap [i. e. proceeds, revenue, or income, accruing from the produce, or yield, of land,, &c.]. (PṢ.) One says, Astgl- Eabodahu, meaning He tasked his slave to bring gal-ap to him. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [In the explanation in the CK, yagul-a is erroneously put for yugil-a.])

And The taking, or receiving, [or obtaining,] of gal-ap: (PṢ:) or the bringing of gal-ap from a place [or an estate]. (KL.) One says, Astgl- Almusotagal-aAti↓ He took the gal-ap of the mstgl-At [i. e. of the lands, or estates, from which gl-p is obtained]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) And lahu OurayoDapN yagotal-uhaA↓ like yasotagil-uhaA [i. e. To him belongs a small portion of land of which he takes, or receives, or obtains, the gal-ap]. (TA.)
And [hence] one says of a hard man, laA yusotagal-u minohu XaIoCN † [Nothing, meaning no profit or advantage, is reaped, or obtained, from him]. (L and TA in art. mrs: see 5 in that art.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. galogala, inf. n. galogalapN: see 1, first sentence.
galogala risaAlapN UilaI SaAHibihaA [He conveyed a message, or letter, to the person to whom it pertained: see the pass. part. n., below]. (Ḥam p. 500.)
And galogalapN signifies also A breaking [of the bone of the nose, and of the head of a flask or bottle], like garogarapN. (TA.)

[See mugalogilapN.I do not find any instance of the usage of galogala otherwise than as trans.: but in the TḲ, and hence by Freytag, galogalapN in a sense in which it is expl. below is regarded as an inf. n., and consequently the verb is said to signify He went quickly; which is a meaning of R. Q. 2.]

R. Q. 2. tagalogala: see 1, first quarter, in two places. qado tagalogalota yaA Eaduw-a Qll-ehi, said to the muxan-av Heet, when he described a woman, as is related in a trad., is expl. as meaning Thou hast reached, in thy looking, of the beauties of this woman, a point which no looker, nor any one having close communion, nor any describer, has reached [beside thee, O enemy of God]. (TA.)
Also He went quickly: (Ḳ,* TA:) one says, tagalogaluwA famaDawoA [They went quickly, and passed, or passed away]. (TA.)
tglgl biAlgaAliyapi: see 2.

gul-N A ring, or collar, of iron, which is put upon the neck: (Mṣb:) a shackle for the neck or for the hand: [i. e. a ring, or collar, for the neck, or a pinion or manacle for the hand:] (MA:) or a [shackle of the kind called] jaAmiEap, (TA, and so in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. jmE,) of iron, (TA,) collecting together the two hands to the neck: (Ṣ in art. jmE; and Jel * in xxxvi. 7:) [sometimes, a shackle for the neck and hands, consisting of two rings, one for the neck and the other for the hands, connected by a bar of iron: (see zam-aArapN:)] and a shackle with which the Arabs used to confine a captive when they took him, made of thongs, upon which was hair, so that sometimes, when it dried, it became infested with lice upon his neck: (TA:) the pl. is OagolaAlN: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) which repeatedly occurs in the Ḳur-án and the Sunneh as meaning † difficult tasks and fatiguing works [as being likened to shackles upon the necks]. (TA.)

[Hence] the Arabs apply it metonymically to denote ‡ A wife. (TA.) And gul-N qamilN [lit. A lousy shackle for the neck, &c.] is an appellation of † a woman of evil disposition; originating from the fact that the gul- used to be of thongs, upon which was hair, so that it became infested with lice. (Ṣ.)

Also, and gul-apN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and galalN↓, (Ḳ,) or this is the inf. n. of gul-a, (Ṣ,) [and accord. to analogy of gal-a as originally galila,] and galiylN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) Thirst: or vehement thirst: (Ḳ, TA:) or the burning of thirst; (Ṣ, O, TA;) little or much: (TA:) or burning of the inside, (Ḳ, TA,) from thirst, and from anger and vexation (TA.)

entry.sense: gil-N and galiylN↓ Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or latent rancour, &c.: (JK in explanation of the former:) and envy; so each signifies; (TA;) [and so the former in the Ḳur vii. 41 and xv. 47:] and enmity: (TA in explanation of the latter:) and the former signifies also dishonesty, or insincerity. (Ṣ, O.)

gal-apN Proceeds, revenue, or income, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, Ald-axalapu is put for Ald-axolu,]) of any kind, (Mgh, Mṣb,) accruing from the produce, or yield, of land, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or from the rent thereof, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) [in which sense magal-N↓ is also used, as a subst., pl. mugal-aAtN,] or from seed-produce, and from fruits, and from milk, and from hire, and from the increase of cattle, and the like, (TA,) and from the rent of a house, (Ḳ, TA,) and from the hire of a slave, (Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) and the like; (Mgh, Mṣb;) [generally meaning corn, or grain; i.e.] wheat and barley and rice and the like; (KL;) the gal-ap of the slave is the payment imposed by the master, and made to him: (TA voce DariybapN:) pl. gal-aAtN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA) and gilaAlN. (Mṣb, TA.)

Also Dirhems [or pieces of money] that are clipped (muqaT-aEap), in a single piece thereof [the quantity clipped being] a qiyraAT or a Tas-uwj or a grain; of which it is said in the “Eedáh,” that one's lending gal-ap in order to have such as are free from defect returned to him is disapproved: (Mgh:) or dirhems [or pieces of money] that are rejected by the treasury of the state, but taken by the merchants. (KT. [Freytag has given this latter explanation, but has erroneously assigned it to gul-apN.])

hom.sense: gul-apN A thing in which one hides himself. (IAạr, TA.)
See also gilaAlapN, in two places:
and galalN.
And see gul-N, last sentence.

galalN Water amid trees: pl. OagolaAlN. (Ṣ, O. [See an ex. voce EacobN.]) And Water having no current, only appearing a little upon the surface of the earth, disappearing at one time and appearing at another: (AA, Ṣ, O:) or, accord. to AḤn, a feeble flow of water from the bottom of a valley or water-course, amid trees. (TA.) Aboo-Saʼeed says,
laA yacohabu kalaAmunaA galalaA
[Our speech shall not pass away as a feeble flow of water]: meaning that it ought not to be concealed from men, but should be made public. (TA.)

Also A strainer, or clarifier: occurring in a verse of Lebeed, cited voce raAziqiI-N: where it means the fidaAm (Ṣ, O, TA) on the heads of the OabaAriyq, (Ṣ,) or on the head of the Uiboriyq: (O, TA:) or, as some relate the verse, the word is gulalN, pl. of gul-apN↓; (Ṣ, O, TA;) which signifies [the same, i. e.] a piece of rag bound on the head of the Abryq [to act as a strainer]. (IAạr, TA.)
And The flesh that is left upon the thumb when one skins [a beast]. (TA.)
See also gul-N, last sentence.

Also, (O, Ḳ,) and galaAlapN↓, (O, and so in copies of the Ḳ,) or gulaAlapN↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ, and accord. to the TA,) A certain disease that attacks sheep, or goats, (O, Ḳ, TA,) in the orifice of the teat, occasioned by the milker's not exhausting the udder, but leaving in it some milk, which becomes blood, or coagulates and is mixed with a yellow fluid. (TA.)

entry.sense: galuwlu AlX-ayoxi The food of the old man, which he ingests into his belly [or stomach]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and likewise the beverage drunk by him. (TA.) One says, niEoma galuwlu AlX-ayoxi hecaA [Excellent, or most excellent, is this food of the old man, &c.!]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: galiylN: see gul-N, last sentence.
[Hence,] sometimes, (TA,) † The burning of love, and of grief. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also gil-N.
And see magoluwlN.
Also Date-stones mixed with [the species of trefoil called] qat-, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and in like manner with dough, (TA,) for a she-camel, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) which is fed therewith. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
See. also gaAl-N.

entry.sense: galaAlapN, or gulaAlapN: see galalN, last sentence.
