gilaAlapN A garment that is worn next the body, beneath the other garment, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and likewise beneath the coat of mail; (Ṣ, O;) also called gul-apN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. [of the former] galaAYilu and [of the latter] gulalN. (TA.)

And A piece of cloth with which a woman makes her posteriors [to appear] large, (O,* Ḳ,* TA,) binding it upon her hinder part, beneath her waist-wrapper; (TA;) as also gul-apN↓, of which the pl. is gulalN. (IB, TA.)

And The pin that connects the two heads of the ring [of a coat of mail]: (O, Ḳ:) pl. galaAYilu. (TA.) And galaAYilu signifies Coats of mail: or the pins thereof that connect the heads of the rings: or linings, or inner coverings, that are worn beneath them, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. beneath the coats of mail: and [it is said that] the sing. thereof is galiylapN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
galiylapN: see what next precedes.

gal-aAnN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and gaAl-N↓, (Ḳ,) applied to a camel, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) Thirsty: (Ḳ:*) or vehemently thirsty: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) or affected with burning of the inside: (Ḳ:*) and gaAl-apN↓, and its pl. gawaAl-u, camels not having fully satisfied their thirst. (TA.)

hom.sense: Also Low, or depressed, ground, in which are trees, and places of growth of [the trees called] salam and TaloH: one says gaAl-N mino salamK, like as one says EiyoSN mino sidorK and qaSiymapN mino gaDFA: (AḤn, Ṣ, O:) or, as also galiylN↓, a place of growth of [the trees called] TaloH: or a low, or depressed, valley or torrent-bed in the ground, (Ḳ, TA,) in which are trees: (TA:) pl. gul-aAnN. (Ḳ.)
And A certain plant, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) [said to be] well known: (Ḳ: [but I have not found it to be now known:]) pl. gul-aAnN. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: gaAl-apN [as a subst.] A part broken off from the shore of the sea and become collected together in a place. (TA.) [Expl. by Freytag as signifying “Pars maris, quæ in litore abrupta est:” and as being a word of the dial. of El-Yemen: on the authority of IDrd.]
glgl, [thus in my original,] applied to the root (Eiroq) of a tree, Extending far into the earth: pl. galaAgilu. (TA.)
galogalapN A quick rate of going. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA.) [App. a simple subst.; but perhaps an inf. n., of which the verb is galogala, q. v.]
gulogulapN Clamour and confusion of voices. (TA.) [Like the Pers. gulogul and gulogulah.]

hom.sense: mugil-N A man cleaving to rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)

An unfaithful man; one who acts unfaithfully. (Ṣ,* Mgh, O,* TA.) Hence the saying of Shureyh, layosa EalaI AlmusotaEiyri gayoriAlmugil-i DamaAnN, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, TA,) walaAEalaI AlmusotawodaEi, (TA,) i. e. [There is no guaranteeship to be imposed upon the asker of a loan, except the unfaithful, nor upon him who is asked to take charge of a deposit, meaning], except in the case of him who has been unfaithful in respect of the loan and the deposit: or, as some say, by the mugil- is here meant the musotagil-↓ [i. e. the person employed to bring the gal-ap]: but IAth says that the former is the right explanation. (TA.)

mugil-apN, applied to a garden (jan-ap), as in a verse cited voce Harada, (Ṣ, O,) or to an estate (DayoEap), (Mgh, TA,) Having, (Mgh,) or yielding, (TA,) gal-ap [q. v.; fruitful, or productive]. (Mgh, TA.)

magoluwlN, applied to a man, Having the [shackle called] gul- put upon him. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [v. 69], waqaAlati Qloyahuwdu yadN Qll-ehi magoluwlapN [And the Jews said, The hand of God is shackled], meaning, withheld from dispensing. (O.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a man, (Ṣ,) and galiylN↓, and mugotal-N↓, (Ḳ,) Thirsty; or vehemently thirsty; (Ḳ, TA;) or affected with burning of thirst, (Ṣ, TA,) little or much; (TA;) or with burning of the inside, (Ḳ, TA,) from thirst, or from anger and vexation. (TA.)

entry.sense: mugotal-N: see what next precedes.
[Hence,] OanaA mugotal-N Uilayohi ‡ I am yearning, or longing, for him, or it. (Ḳ, TA.)
risaAlapN mugalogalapN A message, or letter, conveyed from town to town, or from country to country. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
mugalogilapN, with kesr to the second g, Hastening; syn. musoriEapN [which is trans. and intrans.; but generally the latter, like sariyEN]. (TA.)
musotagal-N A place [or land or an estate] from which gal-ap is obtained: (KL:) [thus used, as a subst., it has for its pl. musotagal-aAtN:] see 10.
musotagil-N: see mugil-N.

hom.sense: 1. galabahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [and galaba Ealayohi,] aor. _i {yagolibu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. galabN and galobN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) or the latter is an inf. n. and the former is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and galabapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) [the most common form,] or this is a simple subst. like galabN, (Mṣb,) which is perhaps formed from it by the elision of the p, (Fr, Ṣ,) and magolabN and magolabapN, (Ḳ, TA,) which last is rare, (TA,) and galaAbiyapN and [in an intensive sense] gulub-aI and gilib-aI (Ḳ, TA) and gulub-apN (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA, said in the Ṣ to be syn. with galabapN) and galub-apN, with fet-ḥ to the g, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK glab-ap,) and gilib-aMCu, (Kr, TA,) He, or it, overcame, conquered, subdued, overpowered, mastered, or surpassed, him, or it; gained ascendency or the mastery, prevailed, or predominated, over him, or it; or was, or became, superior in power or force or influence, to him, or it. (A, MA, Ḳ, PṢ, TḲ, &c.) [See also 5.]

One says, galabotuhu Ealayohi meaning [I overcame him in contending for it; i. e.] I took it, or obtained it, from him [by superior power or force]. (A.) And guliba fulaAnN EalaI AlX-aIoCi Such a one had the thing taken from him by superior power or force. (Mgh.) Hence the saying, laA tugolabuwA EalaI SalaApK qabola TuluwEi AlX-amosi waqabola guruwbihaA Be not ye overcome and anticipated by others in performing prayer before the rising of the sun and before its setting, so that the opportunity for your doing so escape you. (Mgh.)
And galabahu EalaI nafosihi He forced him, or constrained him against his will. (A, TA.)
[And galabahu AlOamoru The affair overcame, defeated, or baffled, him.]
And galabahu biAlxawofi He exceeded him in fear. (Ṣ in art. xwf.)
And galaba EalaI fulaAnK Alkaramu Generosity was, or became, the predominant quality of such a one. (TA.)
And galaba Oano yuxoTama [He refused to have the xiTaAm (or leading-rope) put upon him]; said of a camel. (TA in art. xTm.)
And Oayugolabu OaHadukumo Oano yuSaAHiba Aln-aAsa maEoruwfFA meaning OayaEojizu [i. e. Is any one of you unable to associate with men kindly?]. (A.)

galiba, aor. _a {yagolabu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. galabN, (Ṣ,* TA,) He was, or became, thick-necked: (Ḳ, TA:) or thick and short in the neck: or thick and inclining in the neck: from disease or other cause. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. gal-abotuhu Ealayohi, inf. n. tagoliybN, [I made him to overcome, conquer, subdue, overpower, master, or surpass, him, or it;, &c.: see 1: and] I made him to gain the mastery over it, or to obtain possession of it, (namely, a town, or country,) by [superior power or] force. (Ṣ.)
And gul-iba EalaI SaAHibihi He (a poet) was judged to have overcome his fellow. (TA.) [See mugal-abN.]

[gal-aba lafoZFA EalaI lafoZK Mxara, a conventional phrase of the lexicologists, means He made a word to predominate over another word; as in AlqamaraAni for AlX-amosu waAlqamaru; and sironaA EaXorFA for sironaA EaXora layaAlK biOay-aAmihaA: of the former instance you say, fiyhi tagoliybu Alqamari EalaI AlX-amosi In it is the attribution of predominance to the moon over the sun; and in the latter, fyh tagoliybu All-ayoli EalaI Aln-ahaAri In it is the attribution of predominance to the night over the day. See more in Kull p. 115.]

3. gAlbhu [He vied, contended, or strove, with him, to overcome, conquer, subdue, overpower, master, or surpass,, &c., (see 1,) or for victory, or superiority], inf. n. mugaAlabapN and gilaAbN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) You say, gaAlabotuhu fagalabotuhu [I vied, contended, or strove, with him, to overcome,, &c., and I overcame him., &c.]. (O.) And Kaab Ibn-Málik says,
ham-ato saxiynapu Oano tugaAliba rab-ahaA
walayugolaban-a mugaAlibu Algal-aAbi
[Sakheeneh (a by-name of the tribe of Kureysh) proposed to themselves to contend for victory with their Lord: but he who contends for victory with the very victorious will assuredly be overcome]. (TA.)
5. tgl-b EalaI baladi kacaA He gained the mastery over such a town, or country, or obtained possession of it, by [superior power or] force. (Ṣ, Ḳ,*)
6. tgAlbwA EalaI Albaladi [They vied, contended, or strove, one with another, against the town, or country, to take it]. (A.)
10. Astglb Ealayhi AlD-aHiku Laughter became vehement in its effect upon him. (TA.)
12. Aglwlb AlEuXobu The fresh, or green, herbage attained to maturity, and became tangled and luxuriant, or abundant and dense: (Ṣ:) or became compact and dense. (TA.)

hom.sense: galabapN an inf. n. of galaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or a simple subst. (Mṣb.) [It is much used as a subst., signifying The act of overcoming, conquering, subduing,, &c.; (see 1;) victory, conquest, ascendency, mastery, prevalence, predominance, superiority. or superior power or force or influence; success in a contest; or the act of taking, or obtaining, by superior power or force.]
And pl. of gaAlibN. (TA.)

entry.sense: gulabapN: see what next follows.
gulub-apN and galub-apN and galab-apN: see what next follows.
gulub-aI and gilib-aI: see what next follows.

gal-aAbN (Ṣ, O) and gulabapN↓ (O) and gulub-apN↓ and galub-apN↓ (O, TA) and galab-apN↓ (O) and gulub-aI↓ and gilib-aI↓, (Fr, O,) [all of which except the first and second, and app. the fifth, are originally inf. ns.,] A man who overcomes, conquers, subdues, overpowers, masters, or surpasses, much, or often, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and quickly; (O;) [very, or speedily, or very and speedily, victorious:] or the third, accord to Aṣ, signifies a man who overcomes, or conquers,, &c., quickly: (Ṣ:) pl. of the first gal-aAbuwna. (TA.)
rajulN gaAlibN A man who overcomes, conquers, subdues, overpowers, masters, or surpasses; or overcoming,, &c.: pl. galabapN. (TA.)

AisomN gaAlibN A noun [used predominantly in one of its senses,] such as daAb-apN applied to “a horse,” and maAlN applied to “camels.” (TA in art. snh.) And SifapN gaAlibapN [i. e. gaAlibapN Qsomiy-atuhaA, or galabato EalayohaA AlAisomiy-apu,] An epithet [in which the quality of a substantive is predominant,] such as HaAjibN applied to “a doorkeeper.” (TA in art. Hjb.)

[And AlgaAlibu signifies also The most, or the most part; and the generality: whence, gaAlibFA and fiI AlgaAlibi meaning Mostly, or for the most part: in which sense fI AlOgolabi↓ is sometimes used: and generally.]
[And What is most probable: whence, gaAlibFA and fiI AlgaAlibi meaning Most probably.]

hom.sense: Oagolabu [More, and most, overcoming or conquering, &c.: fem. galobaMCu: and pl. gulobN]. One says qabiylapN galobaMCu A [most overcoming or] mighty, resistive, tribe. (Ḳ.) And Eiz-apN galobaMCu [Most overpowering might]. (Ṣ.)
See also gaAlibN.

Also Thick-necked, (Ṣ, TA,) applied to a man: (Ṣ:) [or thick and short in the neck: or thick and inclining in the neck: (see 1, last sentence:)] fem. galobaMCu, applied to a she-camel: and pl. gulobN. (TA.) And Thick, applied to a neck. (Lḥ, TA.)

[Hence,] HadiyqapN galobaMCu ‡ [A garden, or walled garden,, &c.,] of tangled and luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees: (Ṣ:) or of compact and dense trees; as also mugolawolibapN↓. (Ḳ, TA.) In the phrase HadaAYiqa gulobFA in the Ḳur [lxxx. 30], the epithet is expl by Bḍ as meaning ‡ Large. (TA.) And the fem. is applied to a [mountain, or hill, such as is termed] haDobap, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning ‡ Lofty and great. (TA.)
And AlOagolabu means The lion [app. because of the thickness of his neck]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: [magolabapN A place where one is overcome, or conquered. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

mugal-abN Overcome, conquered,, &c., repeatedly, several times, or many times; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a poet: (A:) and (so applied, Ṣ, A, TA) judged to have overcome (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ, TA) his fellow, (Ṣ, TA,) much, or often: (A:) thus having two contr. significations: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an epithet of praise as well as of dispraise: (O:) or, when the Arabs say of a poet that he is mugal-ab, the meaning is that he is overcome; but if they say, gul-iba fulaAnN, the meaning is, such a one has [been judged to have] overcome: thus they say, gul-ibato layolaI AlOaxoyaliy-apu EalaI naAbigapi baniI jaEodapa, for she overcame him, and he ([En-Nábighah] El-Jaadee) was mugal-ab. (Moḥammad Ibn-Selám, TA.)
magoluwbN [pass. part. of galaba, Overcome, conquered, subdued,, &c.]

[And] part. n. of guliba in the phrase guliba fulaAnN EalaI AlX-aIoCi expl. above: [see 1:] (Mgh: [and the like is said in the A:]) a poet says,
fakunotu kamagoluwbK EalaI naSoli sayofihi
[And I was like one whose blade of his sword has been taken from him by superior power or force; or who has had his blade of his sword taken from him, &c.]. (Mgh.)

mugolanobK One who overcomes, conquers, or subdues, another; who gains ascendency, or the mastery, over him: (Ḳ, TA:) it is quasi coordinate to [muHoranojimN, part. n. of] AiHoranojama [which is from Harojama]. (TA.)
HadiyqapN mugolawolibapN: see Oagolabu.

hom.sense: 1. galata, aor. _u {yagolutu}, (TḲ,) inf. n. galotN, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) He rescinded, or annulled, a purchase or sale. (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TḲ.)

galita, [aor. _u {yagolutu},] (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) inf. n. galatN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) i. q. galiTa [He made a mistake, or committed an error,, &c.]: (Aṣ, IAạr, Ṣ, O:) or the former means in reckoning, or computation; and the latter, in speech, (AA, T, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. he said a thing by mistake meaning to say another thing; (AA, Ṣ, O;) or the latter means in reckoning and in speech. (Lb, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA galata fiI AlUisolaAmi [There shall he no galat in El-Islám], meaning, [for instance,] a man's saying “I bought of thee this garment, or piece of cloth, for a hundred deenárs” and thy then finding that he bought it for less. (O.)

entry.sense: 5. tgl-thu He took him in a state of inadvertence, or heedlessness; (Ḳ, TA;) the doing of which (i. e. Alt-agal-utu) is said in a trad. to be not allowable; (TA:) as also Agtlthu↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
8: see what next precedes {5}.
Q. Q. 3. AigolanotaI Ealayohi He set upon him, or assailed him, or overcame him, with reviling and beating and violence: (AZ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) like AigoranodaI (AZ, Ṣ, O.) [See AisoranodaI.]
Algalotapu, (Ḳ,) or galotapu All-ayoli, (O,) The beginning, or first part, of the night. (O, Ḳ.)
gulotapN a subst. from [the inf. n.] galatu [meaning A mistake, or an error,, &c.], (O, Ḳ.)
galuwtN One who makes mistakes, or commits errors, much, or often, whether in reckoning, or computation, or in speech. (O,* TA.)

hom.sense: 1. galava, aor. _i {yagolivu}, inf. n. galovN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) which is like EalovN in its meanings, (Ḳ, TA,) for the most part, (TA,) He mixed one thing with another; as wheat with barley. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.)
galava Als-iqaMCa: see Ealava, with the unpointed E.

galiva, [aor. _a {yagolavu},] (Ṣ,) inf. n. galavN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [like Ealiva,] He fought vehemently. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And galiva bihi He kept, or clave, to him, fighting him. (Ṣ, O.) [And perhaps, as may be inferred from an explanation of mugaAlivN, one says in like manner gaAlavahu↓, or gAlv bihi; to which latter, Golius assigns a meaning similar to this, or to that which here next follows, as on the authority of J; but I do not find it in the Ṣ.] And galiva Alc-iYobu biAlganami [like Ealiva] The wolf kept to the sheep, or goats, seizing them, and breaking their necks. (Ṣ, O.)
And galiva, aor. _i {yagolivu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. galavN, (TA,) said of a zanod, It failed to produce fire; as also Agtlv↓. (Ḳ.) [See also 1 in art. Elv.]
And galiva said of a bird, It vomited from its crop something which it had swallowed. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Uin-iI laOajidu fiI nafosiI tagoliyvFA means Verily I find, or experience, in myself, disorder, or disturbance. (O.) [See also mugal-ivN: and see 2 in art. Elv.]
3: see the first paragraph above {1}.
5. fulaAnN yatagal-avu biI Such a one devotes himself to me, or clings to me with devotion. (L.) [See also tEl-v, with E.]

hom.sense: 8: see 1.

Agtlv zanodFA He chose a znd from a tree without knowing whether it would produce fire or not; (TA;) i. q. AEtlvhu [q. v.]. (Ḳ, TA.) And fulaAnN yagotalivu Alz-inaAda signifies the same as yaEotalivuhaA xpl. in art. Elv. (TA in that art.)
Agtlv Alqawoma gulovapF↓ He told the people, or party, a lie, or falsehood, whereby he effected his escape, or safety. (TA.)

entry.sense: Q. Q. 3. AigolanovaI Ealayohimo [like AigolanotaI] He set upon them, or assailed them, or overcame them, with beating and reviling (O, Ḳ) and violence. (O.) [See AisoranodaI.]
galovu AlHulomi A thing that one sees in sleep, that is not a true dream. (TA.)

galavN What is mixed: as wheat mixed with barley. (Mṣb.) [In the present day, it is used as signifying What is mixed with wheat, &c., of those things that are taken forth and thrown away; like EalavN. See also galiyvN.]

[And its pl.] OagolaAvN is mentioned by Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilá- bee as a term applied to Several sorts of plants, (O, TA,) not baqol nor HamoD nor EiDaAh, (O,) among which are the EikoriX and HalofaMC and HaAj and yanobuwt and laSaf and EiXoriq and sanaA and Oasal and barodiI- and HanoZal and tan-uwm and xirowaE (O, TA), &c. (O.) [See also EalavN.]
galivN and mugaAlivN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and gaAlivN↓ (TA) A man who fights vehemently, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) cleaving to him whom he pursues [for bloodrevenge or the like: see EalivN]. (TA.)
And the first, Possessed, or insane. (O, Ḳ.)
And One in whom is an odour arising from food and wine or beverage, and an inclining of the body from side to side, and a languor, or languidness, from drowsiness. (O, Ḳ.)
gulovapN: see 8.
galovaI A certain bitter tree, (Ḳ, TA,) with which one tans; mentioned by Kr: (TA:) or, accord. to Az, a certain tree, the fruit of which, if given to beasts of prey, or to vultures, kills them. (O.)
See also the next paragraph.
galiyvN and magoluwvN↓ Mixed. (Ṣ, O.) Wheat (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) mixed, (Ṣ, O,) or adulterated, (Ḳ,) with barley; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also EaliyvN. (AZ, TA in art. Elv.)
Also, the first, (Mṣb,) and second, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) Wheat mixed with pieces of dry clay and with [the weed called] zuWaAn [q. v.]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.)
And the first, [as also EaliyvN,] Bread made of barley and wheat. (Ṣ, O.)
And Food having poison mixed with it, by which vultures are killed; (O, Ḳ, TA;) as also galovaI↓, (O and TA in art. Elv,) and EalovaI; (TA in that art.;) and so lagiyvN. (O.)
gaAlivN: see galivN.
mugal-ivN A moderate pain, that does not cause the patient to lie on his side, and of which the source is not known. (L.) [See also 2 in this art. and 2 in art. Elv.]
magoluwvN: see galiyvN.
Also A [skin such as is termed] siqaMC tanned with dried dates (tamor), or with [unripe dates in the state in which they are termed] busor. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [But see Ealava Als-iqaMCa, in art. Elv.]
mugaAlivN: see galivN.

2. gl-s, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagoliysN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He, or it, (a company of men, Mṣb, Ḳ,) journeyed in the galas, or darkness of the last part of the night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or went forth in the galas. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

gl-swA, (Ḳ,) or gl-swA AlmaMCa, (Ṣ,) They came to the water in the galas, or darkness of the last part of the night, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or beginning of daybreak: and in like manner you say of birds of the kind called qaTFA, and of [wild] asses. (TA.)
gl-s biAlS-alaApi He performed the prayer [of daybreak] in the galas. (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb.)
4. Agls He, or it, (a company of men, Ḳ,) entered upon the galas, or darkness of the last part of the night. (A, Ḳ.)

galasN The darkness of the last part of the night, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) when it becomes mixed with the light of the dawn: (TA:) or the beginning of the dawn, until it spreads in the tracts of the horizon: as also gabasN: both signify blackness mixed with whiteness and redness; like the dawn. (Az, TA.) bigalasK In a period of the darkness so called. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also gabaXN.]
galiysN, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) or gulayosN, (JK,) a proper name for An ass; [meaning a wild ass;] (JK, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) because he is Oagolas in colour. (JK.)
Oagolasu [Of the colour termed galasN; i. e., black mixed with whiteness and redness: see galiysN]. (JK.)

waqaEa fiI tugul-isa, (TA, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or fiI waAdiI tugul-isa, (Ḳ, TA, and so in another copy of the Ṣ,) and tugal-isa, (TA,) imperfectly decl., like tuxuy-iba (Ṣ, Ḳ) and tuhul-ika, (Ḳ,) He fell into calamity, (AZ, Ṣ, TA,) or into an abominable calamity, (Ḳ, TA,) and that which was vain, unreal, nought, or the like: (AZ, Ṣ, TA:) originating from the fact that gaAraAt [or hostile, or predatory, incursions] (Ḳ, TA) generally (TA) took place early, bigalasK. (Ḳ, TA.)
Q. 1. galoSamahu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. galoSamapN, (Ḳ, TA,) He cut, or severed, his galoSamap [here app. meaning larynx, or upper part of the windpipe: compare Haloqamahu]. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)
And He took hold of, or laid hold upon, or seized, his galoSamap [here, likewise, app. meaning as expl. above: see the pass. part. n., below]. (Ḳ, TA.)
galoSamN: see the next paragraph.

AlgaloSamapu [The epiglottis: and also, app. by extension of the primary signification, the larynx, or upper part of the windpipe:] the thing that rises up in the uppermost part of the throat, and is said to throw the meat and drink into the œsophagus, or gullet: (Zj, in his “Khalk-el-Insán:”) the piece of flesh [or cartilage] that is between the head and the neck: or the Eujorap [or projecting thing] that is upon the place where the uvula and gullet meet: (Ḳ:) or [by an extended application] the head of the Huloquwm [or windpipe], (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with its [ducts called] XawaArib [q. v. voce XaAribN] and its Haroqadap [app. meaning pomum Adami]; (Ḳ;) i. e. the projecting place [or part] in the Haloq [here app. meaning, as it does in many cases, throat]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or the root, or base, of the tongue: (Ḳ:) or the place where the Huloquwm [or windpipe, i. e. the head thereof,] becomes in conjunction with the Haloq [or fauces] when the eater swallows a mouthful and it descends from [over] the Huloquwm: (TA:) pl. galaASimu. (Mṣb.)

Also † The chiefs, lords, nobles, or men of distinction: and the congregated or collective body [of a people], or the mass [thereof]; syn. AljamaAEapu: (Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.) And [hence] one says, huwa fiI galoSamapK mino qawomihi i. e. fiI XarafK waEadadK [meaning † He is among (such as are distinguished by) nobility and number, of his people], (ISk, Ḳ, TA,) [or] meaning, accord. to Aṣ, he is among the chief portion of his people, and the nobility thereof: (TA:)
[and in the same sense galoSam↓ is used, without p, but perhaps only by poetic license:] Abu-n-Nejm says,
OabiI lujayomN waQsomuhu miloCu Alfami
fiI galoSami AlhaAmi wahaAmi galoSami
[† My father is, or was, Lujeym, and his fame (a tropical rendering) is what fills the mouth; one among the chief portion and the nobility of the headmen, and among headmen of a chief portion and of nobility]. (TA.)
mugaloSamN pass. part. n. of Q. 1.

mugaloSamaAtN means Women having the necks bound. (Ḳ, TA.) A poet says,
gadaApa Eahidotuhun-a mugaloSamaAtK
lahun-a bikul-i maHoniyapK laHiymu
[In the morning when I met with them having their necks bound, (app. as captives,) they having in every bend of a valley or the like some one slain]. (TA.)

1. galiTa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yagolaTu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. galaTN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OugoluwTapN, (JK,) He made a mistake; committed an error; or missed, or erred from, the right way or mode or manner: (Mṣb:) or he was unable to find the right way, (JK, M, Ḳ,) and knew it not: (M, Ḳ:) in an affair; (Ṣ;) in anything; (JK;) in reckoning, or computation,, &c.: (Ḳ:) or in his speech, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in particular; (Ḳ;) and galita in reckoning, or computation: (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ:) but some of the Arabs make these two verbs to be syn. dial. variants. (Ṣ.)
2. gl-Thu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. tagoliyTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He said to him galiTota [Thou hast made a mistake,, &c.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he attributed or imputed to him the having made a mistake. (Mṣb.)
See also 4.

3. gAlThu, inf. n. mugaAlaTapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gilaATN, (Ḳ,) [He vied, or contended, with him, each endeavouring to cause the other to make a mistake: a signification well known, indicated in the TA, and agreeable with modern usage.]
4. AglThu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. UigolaATN, (TA,) He caused him to fall into the making of a mistake; (Ṣ,* TA;) as also gl-Thu↓, inf. n. tagoliyTN. (TA.)

galaTN [an inf. n. used as a simple subst., Mistake; error; in speech; or in that and also in reckoning, or computation, &c.;] has for its pl. OagolaATN; and ISd says, “I see that IJ has made gilaATN its pl.; but I know not the reason of that.” (TA.) magolaTapN↓ also signifies the same in the saying, waqaEa fulaAnN fiI AlmagolaTapi [Such a one fell into mistake, or error]. (TA.)
See also magoluwTN.
[galoTapN A single mistake, or error, in speech, or in speech, &c.: pl. galaTaAtN.]
rajulN galoTaAnu [A man making a mistake, or committing an error, in speech, or in speech, &c.]. (TA.)
galuwTN: see migolaATN:
and see also OugoluwTapN.
galuwTapN: see OugoluwTapN.
gal-aATN: see migolaATN.

OugoluwTapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and galuwTapN↓ and magolaTapN↓ (Ḳ) A question by which one causes to fall into the making of a mistake: (Ṣ:) or kalaAmN yugolaTu fiyhi [which may be rendered both language in which one makes a mistake, and language in which one is caused to fall into a mistake]: (Ḳ:) and all, (Ḳ.) or the first and second, (TA,) also signify a question by which a person. (Ḳ,* TA,) a man of learning, (TA,) is vied, or contended, with, in the endeavour to cause him to make a mistake, (Ḳ, TA,) in order that he may become lowered: and by which his judgment, or opinion, is sought to be made erroneous: (TA:) you say, masoOalapN galuwTN↓; but when you make the latter word a subst., you add the p: (El-Khaṭṭábee:) the pl. of OugoluwTapN is OugoluwTaAtN and OagaAliyTu (Ṣ) and galuwTaAtN, which is formed from the first of these pls. by the suppression of the hemzeh, and is not, as some have said, pl. of galuwTapN. (Hr.) Moḥammad forbade OugoluwTaAt, (Ṣ, TA,) or galuwTaAt, (TA.) because they are unprofitable with respect to religion, and there is scarely, or never, in them aught save what is unprofitable. (El-'Otbee, TA.)
magolaTapN [properly, or originally, A cause of falling into mistake: similar to maboxalapN and majobanapN, &c.]: see OugoluwTapN:
and galaTN.
magolaTaAniI-N One who vies, or contends, with others, endeavouring to cause them to make mistakes in their reckoning, or computation. (TA.)
mugal-aTN: see magoluwTN.
migolaATN One who makes mistakes, or commits errors, much, or frequently; expl. by kaviyru AlgalaTi; (Ḳ;) as also gl-aATN↓ (TA) and galuwTN↓. (O in art. glt.)
magoluwTN A book, or writing, having a mistake, or mistakes, made in it; and in like manner, a reckoning, or computation, as also galaTN↓ and mugal-aTN↓. (TA.)

1. galuZa, aor. _u {yagoluZu}; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and galaZa, aor. _i {yagoliZu}; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) inf. n. [of the former] gilaZN (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gilaAZapN↓ and giloZapN↓ (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ,* TḲ) and guloZapN↓ and galoZapN↓, (O, Ḳ,* TḲ,) all are inf. ns. of galuZa, (O,) or the last three, the second and third of which are mentioned in the Bári', on the authority of IAạr, are simple substs.; (Mṣb;) and perhaps galoZN may be an inf. n. [of the latter verb]; (ISd, TA;) It (a thing, Mṣb) was, or became, thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) it (a thing) became gl-iyZ; as also AstglZ↓. (Ṣ.) You say, galuZa jisomuhu His body was, or became, thick,, &c. (Mgh.) And AstglZ↓ Alz-aroEu i. q. galuZa, (Jel in xlviii. 29,) The seed-produce became thick: (Bḍ:) or strong: (Mṣb:) or well grown and thick: and in like manner one says of any plant or tree: (TA:) and galuZati Als-unobulapu, and AstglZt↓, the ear of corn produced grain. (Ḳ.) [And galoZa Alv-awobu The garment, or piece of cloth, was thick, or coarse.] And galuZati AlOaroDu, inf. n. gilaZN, and perhaps galoZN may be also an inf. n. [of this verb, or, more probably, of galaZat], The land was, or became, rough, or rugged. (ISd. TA.) [In this sense, also, galuZa is used in relation to various things.]
[Said of a colour, It was dense, or deep: see galiyZN.]

Also ‡ He was, or became, characterized by giloZap, the contr. of riq-ap, in manners, disposition, action or conduct, speech, life, and the like; (TA;) i. e., rough; coarse; rude; unkind; hard; churlish; uncivil; surly; hard to deal with; incompliant; unobsequious; evil in disposition; illnatured; or the like (Ṣ, by its explanation of giloZapN and gilaAZapN; and Mṣb:*) and in like manner, [as meaning it was, or became, hard, or difficult, and the like, (see galiyZN,)] it is said of an affair: (TA:) and tgl-Z↓ is said of a crime; meaning it was gross, or great; but this is accord. to analogy only; not on the authority of hearsay. (Mgh.) It is said in the Ḳur [ix. 74, and lxvi. 9], wQgoluZo Ealayohimo And use thou roughness towards them: (Bḍ in lxvi. 9:) and some read waQgoliZo, with kesr to the l. (TA.) [See also giloZapN, below.]
2. gl-Z AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. tagoliyZN, He made, or rendered, the thing galiyZ [in the proper sense, i. e., thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse;, &c.:]

[and also, and more commonly, in a tropical sense, i. e., ‡ hard, or difficult, and the like]: (TA:) and gl-Z Ealayohi AlX-aIoCa, inf. n. as abuse, ‡ [he made the thing hard, or difficult, or the like, to him;] and hence diyapN magal-aZapN, which see below. (Ṣ, TA,) [Hence also,] gal-aZotu Alyamiyna, inf. n. as above, † I made the oath strong, or forcible; I confirmed, or ratified, it: (Mṣb;) [and so OagolaZotuhaA↓; for you say,] Halafa biUigolaAZi Alyamiyni ‡ [He swore, making the oath strong,, &c.]. (TA.) And gal-aZotu Ealayohi fiI Alyamiyni, inf. n. as above, † I was hard, rigorous, or severe, to him in the oath. (Mṣb.)
tagoliyZN in pronunciation: see tafoxiymN.

3. mugaAlaZapN is similar to muEaAraDapN † [The act of mutually opposing, and app. with roughness, coarseness, or the like]: (TA:) and signifies a state of mutual enmity or hostility. (IDrd, Ḳ.) See giloZapN, below, last sentence.

hom.sense: 4. AglZ Alv-awoba He found the garment, or piece of cloth, to be thick, or coarse: (Ḳ:) or he bought it thick, or coarse: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former is the more correct: (O:) or the former only is correct. (TṢ.)
AglZt Alyamiyna: see 2.
AglZ [is also intrans., and signifies] He (a man, Ibn-ʼAbbád) alighted, or alighted and abode, in a rough, or rugged, tract of land. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
AglZ lahu fiI Alqawoli (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) ‡ He was, or became, rough, harsh, coarse, rude, uncivil, or ungentle, to him in speech: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) one should not say gl-Z. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, near the end.

hom.sense: AstglZ: see 1, in three places.

AstglZhu He saw it to be, regarded it as, or esteemed it, thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse. (Mṣb.) He abstained from purchasing it (namely a garment, or piece of cloth, Ṣ) because of its thickness, or coarseness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: galoZN Rough, or rugged, land or ground; (ISd, Ḳ;) mentioned on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád; and by AḤn, on the authority of En-Naḍr; but it has been repudiated: and is said to be correctly gilaZN↓: ISd says, of the former word, “I know not whether it be [properly] syn. with galiyZN, or whether it be an inf. n. used as an epithet:” accord. to Kr, it signifies hard land without stones: Ks says that galoZN is syn. with gilaZN↓. (TA.)
gilaZN: [see 1:]
[and] see galoZN, in two places.
galoZapN: see what next follows.
guloZapN: see what next follows.

giloZapN and guloZapN↓ and galoZapN↓: see 1: these three forms are mentioned by Zj, (TA,) and in the Bári', (Mṣb, TA,) on the authority of IAạr, (Mṣb,) and by Ṣgh; but the first of them [only] is commonly known: (TA:) they are substs. from galuZa; and signify Thickness, grossness, bigness, bulkiness, or coarseness. (Mṣb.) [And Roughness, or ruggedness.]

Also ‡ Contr. of riq-apN, in manners, disposition, action or conduct, speech, life, and the like; (TA;) i. e. roughness, coarseness, rudeness, unkindness, hardness, churlishness, incivility, surliness, roughness in manners, hardness to deal with, incompliance, unobsequiousness, evilness of disposition, illnature, or the like: (Ṣ, Mṣb:*) and in like manner, hardness, or difficulty, of an affair. (TA, as shown by an explanation of galiyZN.) You say, rajulN fiyhi giloZapN ‡ A man in whom is roughness, coarseness, rudeness,, &c.; (Ṣ, Mṣb;*) as also gilaAZapN↓. (Ṣ.) And it is said in the Ḳur [ix. 124], waloyajiduwA fiykumo giloZapN, in which the last word is pronounced in the three different ways shown above, accord. to different readers; meaning ‡ [And let them find in you] hardness, or strength, or vehemence, and superiority in fight: (TA:) or hardness, or strength, or vehemence, and patient endurance of fight: (Bḍ:) or hardness, or strength, or vehemence, in enmity and in fight and in making captives. (Mgh.) And you say, bayonahumaA giloZapN ‡ Between them two is enmity, or hostility; as also mugaAlaZapN↓. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
gulaAZN: see what next follows.

galiyZN (Ṣ, &c.) Thick, gross, big, bulky, or coarse; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also gulaAZN↓: (Ḳ:) fem. of the former with p {galiyZapN}: (TA:) and pl. gilaAZN. (Mṣb, TA.) Applied [to a body, &c.; and, as meaning Thick, or coarse,] to a garment, or piece of cloth. (Mgh, Ḳ.) You say also, OaroDN galiyZapN Rough, or rugged, land. (ISd, TA.) [And in this sense, of rough, or rugged, galiyZN is used in relation to various things.]
Applied to a colour [Dense, or deep: see gaDobN]. (Ḳ in art. gDb.)

Also, applied to a man, ‡ Characterized by giloZap, the contr. of riq-ap, in manners, disposition, action or conduct, speech, life, and the like; rough, coarse, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, surly, rough in manners, hard to deal with, incompliant, unobsequious, evil in disposition, illnatured, or the like: (Mṣb,* TA:) and so galiyZu AljaAnibi; [contr. of lay-inu AljaAnibi:] (O and Ḳ in art. fZ:) and galiyZu Alqalobi hard-hearted; (Bḍ in iii. 153;) evil in disposition, or illnatured. (TA.) Applied also to an affair, meaning ‡ Hard, or difficult. (TA.) And to punishment, [in the Ḳur xi. 61, &c.,] meaning ‡ Vehement, or severe; (Mgh;) intensely painful. (Mṣb.) And [in like manner] to slaying and wounding. (TA.) And to a compact, or covenant, [in the Ḳur iv. 25, &c.,] meaning ‡ Strong, confirmed, or ratified. (Mgh, TA.) And to water, meaning ‡ Bitter. (TA.)
OagolaZu comparative and superlative of galiyZN [in all its senses]. (IJ.)

diyapN mugal-aZapN † [A bloodwit, or fine for bloodshed, made hard, rigorous, or severe;] one which is incumbent for what is like an intentional homicide; (Ṣ;) or for a homicide purely intentional, and for that which is intentional but committed in mistake, and for that which is committed in the sacred territory, and for the slaughter of a kinsman; (EshSháfi'ee;) consisting of thirty camels of the description termed Hiq-ap, and thirty of that termed jacaEap, and forty between the vaniy-ap and the baAzil, all pregnant. (Esh-Sháfiʼee, Ḳ.) And yamiynN mugal-aZapN † [An oath made strong or forcible, or confirmed, or ratified.] (Ṣ.)
AlEaworapu Almugal-aZapu: see EaworapN.
musotagolaZu [The thick part of the fore arm]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. galafa, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagolifu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. galofN, (O, Mṣb, TA,) He put a bottle, or flask, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or a knife, (Mṣb,), &c., (TA,) into a gilaAf [q. v.]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also Aglf↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. UigolaAfN; (Mṣb;) or gl-f↓, inf. n. tagoliyfN: (Ḳ, TA:) or ↓the second signifies, (Mṣb,) or signifies also, (Ṣ,) he furnished it with a gilaAf; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or gl-f↓ signifies thus: (TA:) Oagolafotu↓ AlqaAruwrapa is said by Lth to be from AlgilaAfu; and so gal-afotuhaA↓, inf. n. tagoliyfN. (O.)

And accord. to Lth, (O,) one says, galafa liHoyatahu biAlgaAliyapi, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yagolifu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. galofN, (Ṣ,) meaning He daubed, or smeared, his beard with [the perfume called] gaAliyap [q. v.], (Mgh, TA,) and likewise with other perfume, and with Hin-aMC; (TA;) and gal-afahaA↓: (Mgh, TA:) but accord. to IDrd, the vulgar say so: (O, Mṣb, TA:) he says that the correct phrase is gal-aAhaA (Mgh, O, Mṣb, TA) bAlgAlyp, (O,) and gal-alahaA: (Mgh, O, Mṣb:) in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, however, kunotu Ougal-ifu↓ liHoyapa rasuwli Qll-ehi occurs as meaning I used to daub, or smear, the beard of the Apostle of God with gAlyp, doing so abundantly: (TA:) and one says, of a man, tgl-f↓ (Lth, Th, Ṣ, O, TA) biAlgaAliyapi (Th, Ṣ, TA) wasaAYiri AlT-iybi (Th, TA) [i. e. He daubed, or smeared, himself, or his beard, with gAlyp and the other sorts of perfume]; and [in like manner,] Agtlf↓ (Lth, O, TA) mina AlgaAliyapi (Lth, O) or mina AlT-iybi: (TA:) but accord. to the saying of IDrd [mentioned above], these are wrong, and should be only tagal-aI and tagal-ala, and AigotalaI and Aigotal-a: (O:) or, accord. to Ibn-El-Faraj, one says tgl-f↓ bAlgAlyp when it is external; and tgl-l bihaA when it is internal, at the roots of the hair. (O, TA. [See also 2 in art. gl.])
galifa, aor. _a {yagolafu}, inf. n. galafN, He was uncircumcised. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence, in three places. You say also, gal-afotu Als-aroja [I put a gilaAf upon, or to, the horse's saddle] and Alr-aHola [the camel's saddle: see also its pass. part. n., below]. (O.)
And AlHin-aMCu yugal-ifu Alr-aOosa The Hn-MC [q. v.] covers the head. (Mgh.) See also 1, second sentence, in two places.
4: see 1, first sentence, in three places.

5. tgl-f, said of a raHol [or camel's saddle, (in some copies of the Ḳ erroneously rajul,) and in like manner of other things], It had a gilaAf [q. v.], (Ḳ, TA,) of leather or the like; (TA;) as also Agtlf↓. (Ḳ, TA. [See 2, of which the former is quasi-pass.])
See also 1, latter half, in two places.
8: see 5:
and see also 1, last quarter.

galofN A species of trees, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) with which one tans, (TA,) like [accord. to some meaning the same as] the garof [q. v.]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) some say that one does not tan therewith unless together with the garof. (TA.)
galafN inf. n. of galifa [q. v.]: (Mṣb:) [as a simple subst.,] The state of being uncircumcised. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
[Also, of the heart, † The state of being Oagolaf: so, app., accord. to the TA: in the L written galafap.]
And † Ample abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (TA.)
galifN A certain plant, which is eaten, peculiarly, by the apes, or monkeys: mentioned by AḤn. (TA.)
gulofapN i. q. qulofapN (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gurolapN; (Mṣb;) i. e. [The prepuce;] the little piece of skin which the circumciser cuts off from the gilaAf [or sheath] of the head of the penis. (Mgh.)
And AlgulofataAni signifies The two extremities of the two halves of the mustache, next to the SimaAgaAni [or two sides of the mouth which are the places where the lips conjoin]. (TA.)

gilaAfN A thing well known; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. a receptacle used as a repository; and a covering, or an envelope, of a thing: (TA:) it is of a sword [i. e. the scabbard, or sheath; and also a case, or covering, enclosing the scabbard, or enclosing the scabbard with its appertenances]; (Ṣ, O;) and of a knife and the like [i. e. the sheath]; (Mṣb;) and of a flask or bottle [i. e. the case thereof]; (Ṣ, O;) and [likewise] of a bow; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and of a camel's saddle (Ḳ, TA) and of a horse's saddle, [i. e. a covering] of leather and the like; (TA;) and is such as the enclosing membrane (qamiyS) of the heart; [gilaAfu Alqalobi signifying the pericardium;] and the pellicle (giroqiY) of the egg; and the calyx of a flower; and the [imaginary] saAhuwr [q. v.] of the moon: (TA:) pl. gulufN (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gulofN (Ḳ) and gul-afN. (O,* Ḳ.) In the phrase in the Ḳur [ii. 82], waqaAluwA quluwbunaA gulufN, as some read it, and, accord. to one reading gul-afN, the last word means † receptacles for knowledge: (O, TA:) but others read gulofN, which is pl. of Oagolafu↓; (Ṣ,* O,* TA;) meaning † covered from hearing and accepting the truth; (TA;) or † as though they were covered from that to which thou invitest us. (O.)
Oagolafu [Enclosed] in a gilaAf [q. v.]; applied in this sense to a sword, as also [the fem.] galofaMCu to a bow; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and likewise to anything. (Ṣ, O. [See also mugal-afN.])
And A man having upon him a sort of garment from beneath which he has not put forth his fore arms. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, L, TA.)
And, applied to a man, i. q. Oaqolafu; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ;) i. e. (Mgh) Uncircumcised: (Mgh, Mṣb:) fem. galofaMCu [see baZorN]: and pl. gulofN. (Mṣb.)

Applied also to a heart, meaning † As thought it were covered with a gilaAf, so that it does not learn; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) or covered from hearing and accepting the truth. (TA.) See also gilaAfN. [And see mugal-afN.]

OaroDN galofaMCu † A land that has not been depastured, so that there is in it every sort of small and large herbage. (Sh, O, Ḳ.) And sanapN galofaMCu † A year in which is abundance of herbage; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) and so EaAmN Oagolafu. (TA.) And EayoXN Oagolafu † Life that is ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, and easy, or pleasant. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
mugal-afN, applied to a horse's saddle and to a camel's saddle, Having upon it a gilaAf [or covering] of leather or the like. (TA.)
And applied also to a heart as meaning [As though it were] covered. (TA.) [See also Oagolafu.]

hom.sense: 1. galaqa as syn. with Oagolaqa: see the latter.
Also, inf. n. galoqN, He went away. (TA.)
And galaqa fiI AlOaroDi, aor. _i {yagoliqu}, inf. n. galoqN, He went far into the land; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,* TA;) as also falaqa, aor. _i {yagoliqu}, inf. n. faloqN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA.)
galiqa said of a door: see 7.

[Hence,] galiqa Alr-ahonu, aor. _a {yagolaqu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. galaqN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or guluwqN, (IAạr, TA,) or both, (Sb, TA,) ‡ The pledge was, or became, a rightful possession [i. e. a forfeit] to the receiver of it (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) when not redeemed within the time stipulated; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) or so galiqa Alr-ahonu fiI yadi Almurotahini: (Sb, TA:) or galiqa Alr-ahonu means the pledge remained in the hand [or possession] of the receiver of it, the pledger being unable to redeem it; (IAạr, TA;) accord. to the Bári', it is when a man pledges a commodity and says, “If I do not pay thee within such a time, the pledge shall be thine for the debt.” (Mṣb.) This is forbidden in a trad. (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, &c.) It is said in a trad. of the Prophet on this subject, laA yagolaqu bimaA fiyhi laka gunomuhu wuEalayoka guromuhu [meaning It shall not become a forfeit to the receiver with what is involved in it: (or, accord. to an explanation of the first clause in the Mṣb, it shall not become a rightful possession to the receiver for the debt for which it was pledged:) to thee shall pertain the regaining of it, and its increase, and growth, and excess in value, if such there be, and upon thee shall be the obligation of the debt belonging to it, and the bearing of any unavoidable damage that it may have sustained]: (O:) or lahu gunomuhu waEalayohi guromuhu i. e., accord. to AʼObeyd, to him (the owner) it shall return, and to him shall pertain its increase [if there be any], and if it have become defective, or have perished, [unavoidably,] he shall be responsible for it and shall pay the debt to him to whom it is owed without being compensated by [the remission of] aught of the debt: (Mṣb:) or laka gunomuhu waEalayohi guromuhu, which means to thee (the pledger) shall pertain the increase of it (the pledge), and its growth, and its excess in value, [if it have any,] and upon him (the receiver of it) shall be the responsibility [to make compensation] for it if it perish [through his fault, in his possession], (O. [There are other, somewhat different, readings and explanations of this trad. in the Mgh, &c.; but what I have here given, from the O and Mṣb, appear to me to be the most approvable. See also gunomN: and see art. rhn.]) Zuheyr says,
wafaAraqatoka birahonK laA fakaAka lahu
yawoma AlwadaAEi faOamosaI Alr-ahonu qado galiqaA
† [And she separated herself from thee with a pledge for which there is nothing wherewith it may be redeemed, on the day of valediction, so the pledge has become a forfeit to its receiver]: (Ṣ, Mgh, O, TA:) he means that she received his heart as a pledge, and went away with it. (Mgh, TA.) The saying of Ows Ibn-Hajar
Oabuw galaqK fiI layolatayoni muWaj-ali
means † The owner of a pledge that has become a rightful possession [or forfeit] to its receiver, the period for the release of which is two nights: to this he likens a captivated heart. (TA.)

One says also, of a slave who has received permission to traffic, galiqato raqabatuhu biAld-ayoni † His raqabap [meaning person] has become a rightful possession [or a forfeit to his creditor or creditors] by reason of debt, when he is unable to free it. (Mgh.)
And galiqa signifies also † He was unransomed, or unredeemed; said of a captive, and of a criminal. (TA.)

And ‡ He, or it, stuck fast: (Ṣ, O, TA:) thus in the saying, galiqa qalobuhu fiI yadi fulaAnapa [His heart stuck fast in the possession of such a woman or girl]: (TA:) and AiHotad-a fagaliqa fiI Hid-atihi [He became excited by sharpness of temper, and stuck fast in his sharpness of temper]: (Ṣ, O. TA:) and galiqa is said of anything that sticks fast in a thing, and cleaves to it: thus one says, galiqa fiI AlbaATili [He stuck fast in that which was vain, or false]: and the saying of El-Farezdaḳ
walawo kaAnuwA OuwliI galaqK sigaAbaA
means Had they been persons who had stack fast in poverty and hunger, cleaving thereto. (Sh, TA.)

Also, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. galaqN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) † He was, or became, disquieted, (Mgh,) or disquieted by grief; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or angry, (Mṣb, TA.) and excited by sharpness of temper. (TA.) Hence yamiynu Algalaqi † The oath of anger; said by some of the lawyers to be so called because he who swears it closes thereby against himself a door preventing him from advancing or drawing back. (Mṣb.) And hence Uiy-aAka waAlgalaqa † Beware thou of, or avoid thou, the being disquieted, or disquieted by grief [or anger]: or, as some say, the meaning is, laA yugolaqu↓ Alt-aToliyqaAtu Hat-aI laA yaboqaI minohaA XaIoCN † [i. e. The sentences of divorce shall not be closed, or concluded, at once, by one's saying “Thou art trebly divorced,” so that there shall not remain of them aught]; for one should divorce agreeably with the sun-ap: (Mgh:) [or, accord. to the TA, Uiy-aAka waAlgalaqa app. means beware thou of, or avoid thou, the state of straitness:] and Algalaqu signifies also the being in a state of perdition: (TA:) and contractedness of the mind or bosom, (Mbr, JK, TA,) and paucity of patience. (Mbr, TA.)

One says also, galiqati Aln-axolapu, (O. Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. galaqN, (TA,): The palm-tree had worms in the bases of its branches and was thereby stopped from bearing fruit; (O, Ḳ, TA;) and so Ougoliqato↓ Eani AlUivomaAri. (TA.)

And galiqa Zahoru AlbaEiyri, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. galaqN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) ‡ The back of the camel became galled with galls not to be cured; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) the whole of his back being seen to be two portions of cicatrized skin, the results of galls that had become in a healing state, and the two sides thereof glistening: ISh says that in the case of the worst galls of the camel, the furniture, or saddle and saddle-cloth, cannot be [partially] raised from contact with him [so as to be bearable by him]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4, former half, in three places.

3. mugaAlaqapN signifies † The contending for a bet, or wager; syn. muraAhanapN; (O, Ḳ;) originally, in the game called Almayosir: whence, in a trad., the phrase AirotabaTa farasFA liyugaAliqa EalayohaA † [He tied up a mare in order that he should contend upon her in a race for a stake or stakes]. (O.)

4. Aglq AlbaAba, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UigolaAqN, (Mgh, Ḳ, &c.,) He made the door fast with a galaq, so that it could not be opened unless with a key; (Mṣb;) [i. e.] he locked the door; or bolted it: or he closed, or shut, it: (MA:) contr. of fataHahu: (O, Ḳ:*) and galaqahu↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagoliqu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. galoqN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) signifies the same; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) mentioned by IDrd, on the authority of AZ; but rare; (Mṣb;) or a mispronunciation; (Ḳ;) or bad, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and rejected; (Ṣ;) and galoqN is [said to be] the subst. from Oagolaqa; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) whence the saying of a poet,
wabaAbK UicaA maA maAla lilogaloqi yaSorifu
[And a door that, when it turns to be locked, or closed, creaks]: (Ṣ, O, Mgh:*) and one says, gal-aqotu↓ AlOabowaAba [I locked, or closed, the doors]; the verb being with teshdeed to denote multiplicity [of the objects]; (Sb, Ṣ, TA;) [and] it is so to denote muchness [of the action] or intensiveness, (O,) [for] one says also, gl-q↓ AlbaAba, a chaste phrase; El-Iṣbahánee says that gal-aqotu↓ signifies I locked, or closed, (Oagolaqotu,) many doors, or a door several times, or a door well or thoroughly; (TA;) and one says also Oagolaqotu AlOabowaAba; (Ṣ, O, TA;) said by Sb to be a good Arabic phrase; (TA;) but this is rare; (O;) El-Farezdaḳ says,
maA zilotu OafotaHu OabowaAbFA waOugoliquhaA
Hat-aI Oatayotu OabaA Eamoriw bona Eam-aAri
[I ceased not to open doors and to close them until I came to Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-'Ammár], meaning, as AḤát says, Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
[Hence] one says, Ougoliqa Ealayohi AlOamoru † The affair was [as though it were closed against him; i. e., was made] strait to him. (TA. [See also 10.])

And [hence] UigolaAqN signifies † The act of constraining: (Mgh, O, TA:) whence the saying in a trad., laA TalaAqa walaA EataAqa fiI UigolaAqK † [There is no divorcement of a wife, nor liberation of a slave, in a case of constraint]; (Mgh,* O, TA;) for the agent is straitened in his affair, (Mgh, TA,) as though the door were locked, or closed, against him, and he were imprisoned. (TA.) One says, Oagolaqahu EalaI XaIoCK † He constrained him to do a thing. (IAạr, Mgh, TA.)
See also 1, last quarter, in two places.

One says also, Aglq Alr-ahona ‡ He made, or declared, the pledge to be due [or a forfeit to its receiver]. (IAạr, TA.) And in like manner one says of the arrows termed magaAliq, [pl. of migolaqN,] tugoliqu AlxaTara i. e. ‡ They make the stake, or wager, or thing playedfor, to be due [or a forfeit] to the player (O, TA) who wins, or is successful. (TA.)

And Aglq AlqaAtila † He delivered, or surrendered, the slayer to the heir, or next of kin, of the slain, that he might decide respecting his blood as he pleased. (O, TA.) And Ougoliqa fulaAnN bijariyratihi † [Such a one was delivered, or surrendered, to be punished for his crime]. (TA.) And El-Farezdaḳ says,
OasaAraI HadiydK Ougoliqato bidimaMYihaA
† [Captives in bonds of iron, delivered, or surrendered, to be punished for their bloods that they had shed]. (TA.)
And Ougoliqa fulaAnN † Such a one was angered. (TA.)

And AlUigolaAqu [or rather UigolaAqu Zahori AlbaEiyri] signifies † The galling of the back of the camel by heavy loads: (Ḳ, TA:) whence the phrase mano Oagolaqa Zahorahu [meaning † Such as has heavily burdened his back with sins], applied, in a trad., to one of those for whom the Prophet will intercede; the sins that have burdened the back of the man being likened to the weight of the load of the camel: [but] it is also said that AlUigolaAqu was a practice of the Time of Ignorance; that when the camels of any one of them amounted to a hundred, OagolaquwA baEiyrFA, i. e. † They displaced the sanaAsin [pl. of sinosinN, q. v.] of one of the vertebræ of a camel, and wounded his hump, in order that he might not be ridden, and that no use might be made of his back; and that camel was termed muEan-FI [q. v. in art. Enw]. (TA.)
[6. tgAlqwA They contended, one with another, for bets, or wagers. See 3.]

7. Anglq; (MA, TA;) and galiqa↓, (TA,) inf. n. galaqN; (KL;) and Astglq↓; (KL, TA;) said of a door, (MA, KL, TA,) It was, or became, locked, or bolted; or closed, or shut; (MA, KL;) or difficult to be opened: (TA:) Anglq is the contr. of AnftH. (Mṣb.)
See a verse cited voce rawiyoYapN, in art. rwO. [And see also 10.]
[Hence] one says, Aisotagolaqato raHimu Aln-aAqapi falamo taqobala AlmaMCa † [The she-camel's womb became closed so that it did not admit the seminal fluid]. (Lth, Ḳ in art. rbE.)

And Astglq Ealayohi AlkalaAmu ‡ Speech was as though it were closed against him, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) so that he [was tongue-tied, or] spoke not: accord. to the A, it is said of one who is straitened, and required against his will to speak. (TA.)
And Astglq AlOamoru † i. q. OaEoDala, q. v. (Ṣ and O in art. EDl.)
And Astglq Alxabaru † i. q. Aisotabohama, q. v. (Mṣb in art. bhm.)
And AisotagolaqaniI fiI bayoEiI, (ISh, O,) or fI bayoEatihi, (Ḳ,) ‡ He made me to be without the option of returning [in the selling to me, or in his sale]: (ISh, O, Ḳ, TA:)
and Aisotagolaqato EalaI-a bayoEatuhu (ISh, O, Ḳ) ‡ His sale was to me without the option of returning. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: galoqN is [said to be] the inf. n. of galaqa as syn. with Oagolaqa: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) and (Ṣ, Ḳ) the subst. from the latter verb [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ.)

As an epithet, (O, Ḳ,) applied to a man, or to a camel, (Ḳ,) or to each of these, (O,) Old, or advanced in age, and lean, meagre, or emaciated: (O, Ḳ, TA:) accord. to the “Nawádir,” it is applied to an old man [app. as meaning lean, meagre, or emaciated]: (TA:) or red; (Ḳ;) or in this sense applied to a man, and to a skin for water or milk, and to leather: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O:) or, accord. to AA, applied to a skin for water or milk, vitiated, or rendered unsound, in the tanning. (O.)

entry.sense: maAlN giloqN † Unlawful property: (JK:) or property to which there is no access; (TA voce ritojN;) i. q. maAlN ritojN. (Ḳ and TA ibid.) One says HalaAlN TaloqN: [see art. Tlq:] and [in the contr. sense] HarAamN giloqN † [Unlawful, inaccessible]. (TA.)

galaqN [A lock;] a thing by means of which a door is made fast, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) not to be opened save with a key; (Ṣ and Ḳ voce mizolaAjN;) a thing that is closed and opened with a key; (Mgh;) pl. OagolaAqN, (Sb, Mṣb, TA,) its only pl.: (Sb, TA:) and migolaAqN↓ is syn. therewith; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) pl. magaAliyqu: (Mṣb:) so too is migolaqN↓: (Mṣb, TA:) and so mugoluwqN↓: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and so galaAqN↓. (TA.) El-Farezdaḳ has used its pl. metaphorically, [in a sense sufficiently obvious,] saying,
fabitona bijaAnibaI-a muSar-aEaAtK
wabit-u OafuD-u OagolaAqa AlxitaAmi
meaning xitaAma AlOagolaAqi, the phrase being inverted by him. (TA.)
Also i. q. ritaAjN, meaning A great door: whence the phrase mafaAtiyHu OagolaAqihaA, by which are meant [the keys of] the [great] doors thereof. (Mgh.)
galiqN [part. n. of galiqa primarily signifying Being, or becoming, locked, or bolted; or closed, or shut.]
[And hence,] ‡ A pledge being, or becoming, a rightful possession [i. e. a forfeit] to the receiver of it, not having been redeemed within the time stipulated. (TA. [See also the verb.])
And † A captive, and a criminal, unransomed, or unredeemed. (TA.)
† A narrow, or strait, place. (TA.)
† A man evil in disposition: or much, or often, in anger; thus expl. by Aboo-Bekr: or narrow in disposition, difficult to be pleased. (TA.)
And ‡ Speech, or language, [difficult to be understood,] dubious, or confused. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And naxolapN galiqapN ‡ A palm-tree having worms in the bases of its branches and thereby stopped from bearing fruit. (TA.)
And galiqN applied to the back of a camel, ‡ Having incurable galls; the whole of it being seen to be two portions of cicatrized skin, and the two sides thereof glistening. (TA.)
guluqN, applied to a door, [Locked; or bolted: or closed, or shut:] i. q. mugolaqN↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) of which magoluwqN↓ is a dial. var., but bad, (Ṣ, O,) and rejected. (Ṣ, TA.)

galoqapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) thus as heard by AḤn from El-Bekree and others, (O,) and giloqapN↓ (O, Ḳ) as heard by him from one of the Desert-Arabs of Rabee'ah, the former the more common, (O,) and galoqaI↓, (Ḳ,) A certain tree [or plant] with which the people of Et-Táïf prepare hides for tanning by the treatment termed EaTonN: (ISk, Ṣ, TA: [see EaTana Aljiloda:]) accord. to information given to AḤn by an Arab of the desert, (O,) a certain small tree, [or plant,] (O, Ḳ, TA,) resembling the EiZolim [q. v.], (O, TA,) bitter (O, Ḳ, TA) in an intense degree, not eaten by anything: it is dried, then bruised, and beaten, with water, and skins are macerated in it, in consequence of which there remains not upon them a hair nor a particle of fur nor a bit of flesh; this being done when they desire to throw the skins into the tan, whether they be of oxen or of sheep or goats or of other animals; and it is bruised, and carried into the various districts or towns for this purpose: (O, TA:) it is found in El-Ḥijáz and Tihámeh: (Ḳ, TA:) AḤn says, it is a tree [or plant] not to be endured for pungency; the gatherer of it fears for his eyes from its exhalation or its juice: (TA:) it is of the utmost efficiency for tanning: (Ḳ, TA:) Lth says, (O, TA,) it is a bitter tree [or plant]; (O;) and it is a poison; a mixture being made with its leaves for wolves and dogs, which kills them; and it is used also for tanning therewith: (O, TA:) and AḤn says, (TA,) the Abyssinians poison weapons with it, (Ḳ, TA,) cooking it, and then smearing with it the weapons, (TA,) and it kills him whom it smiles. (Ḳ, TA.) [Accord. to Forskål, (Flora Ægypt. Arab. p. lxvi.,) the names of “Harmal Hrml, and Ghalget ed dib glqt Aldyb,” by which he means Haromal and galoqap Alc-iYob, are now applied to Peganum harmala.]
giloqapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
galoqaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: galaAqN: see galaqN.

It is also a subst. from the verb in the phrase Ougoliqa fulaAnN bijariyratihi [q. v.]: 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd says,
wataquwlu AlEudaApu OawodaI EadiI-N
wabanuwhu qado OayoqanuwA biAlgalaAqi
[And the enemies say, “'Adee has perished, and his sons have made sure of being surrendered”]. (TA.)

entry.sense: UigoliyqN [like UiqoliydN, which is more common,] A key; pl. OagaAliyqu. (TA.) [OagaAliyqu may also signify Locks, as a pl. pl., i. e. as pl. of OagolaAqN, which is pl. of galaqN.]
mugolaqN: see guluqN.
migolaqN: see galaqN.

Also, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and migolaAqN↓ is a dial. var. thereof in this sense, (TA,) An arrow, (Ḳ,) i. e. any arrow, (Ṣ, O,) used in the game called Almayosir: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, (O,) Almigolaqu signifies Als-ahomu Als-AbiEu fiI muDaE-afi Almayosiri [i. e. the seventh arrow, app. belonging to the class, of the arrows of the game of Almysr, to which manifold portions are assigned; for AlmuDaE-afu as used in relation to the game called Almysr I do not find expl. otherwise than as an appellation of “the second of the arrows termed Algufol, to which are assigned no portion;” (see art. DEf, and see also safiyHN;) and this cannot be here meant, as the seventh arrow (which is commonly called AlmuEal-aI) has seven portions assigned to it: therefore it seems that muDaE-af is here used, if not mistakenly, in a sense which, though admissible, is unusual in a case of this kind]: (O, Ḳ:) pl. magaAliqu: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: in the CK [erroneously] magaAliyqu:) or AlmugaAliqu is one of the epithets applied to the winning arrows, and is not one of their [particular] names; (O, Ḳ;) they being those that make what is played-for to be a forfeit to the player (tugoliqu AlxaTara liloqaAmiri): so accord. to Az, who says that Lth has made a mistake in his explanation. (O.)
migolaAqN: see galaqN. [Hence] one says, fulaAnN mifotaAHN liloxayori migolaAqN lilX-ar-i † [Such a one is a key to that which is good, a lock to that which is evil]. (TA.)

And i. q. mirotaAjN [A thing with which a door is closed, or made fast, (app. a kind of latch,) affixed behind the door, in the part next to the lock]. (TA. [See art. rtj: and see miEolaAqN, which seems to have the same, or a similar, meaning.])

And rajulN migolaAqN. (Mṣb,) and qawomN magaAliyqu, (TA,) † A man, and a company of men, by means of whom (EalaI yadayohi, Mṣb, and EalaI Oayodiyhimo, TA,) the pledge is made a forfeit (yugonaqu). (Mṣb, TA.) And cuw migolaAqK means Aal-aciI tugolaqu EalaI yadihi qidaAHu Almayosiri † [app. One by means of whom the arrows in the game called Almysr are withheld from the rest of the players; i. e. by his winning]: or, accord. to Z, yugoliqu AlHuj-apa EalaI AlxaSomi † [app. one who closes the argument against the adversary in a dispute]. (TA in art. Elq.)
See also migolaqN.

hom.sense: magoluwqN: see guluqN.
Also A hide in which [the plant called] galoqap [q. v.] is put, when it is prepared for tanning by the treatment termed EaTonN: (ISk, Ṣ, TA:) or a hide tanned with galoqap. (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mugoluwqN: see galaqN.

1. galima, aor. _a {yagolamu}, inf. n. galamN (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and gulomapN; (Ḳ, TA;) and Agtlm↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) only the latter of which, accord. to Aṣ, is said of other than man, though sometimes said of a man; (Mṣb;) He was, or became, excited by lust, or appetence: (TA:) or overcome thereby: (M, Ḳ, TA:) said of a man; and in like manner one says of a girl, or young woman: (TA:) or he was, or became, vehemently affected with lust, or carnal desire. (Mṣb.) And Agtlm↓ said of a camel; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and [accord. to some, contr. to an assertion mentioned above,] galima, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. gulomapN; (Ṣ;) He was, or became, excited (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) by lust, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or by vehement lust, (Mgh, Mṣb,) to cover. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. Aglmhu It (a thing) excited his lust, or appetence. (Ḳ,* TA.) And Aglm said of a beverage, It strengthened in the venereal faculty. (TA in art. Awl.)
See also 8, in two places.

entry.sense: 8. Agtlm: see 1, in two places.
Also He (a boy) attained to the limit of what is termed Alguluwmap [app. meaning the seventeenth year]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
Said of a beverage, or wine, ‡ It was, or became, strong in its influence upon the head. (Mgh, TA.*)
Said of the sea, † It became stirred up, in a state of commotion, or tumultuous; its waves dashing together: as also Oagolama↓. (TA.)
And AlAigotilaAmu and AlUigolaAmu↓ signify † The exceeding the prescribed limit, of good or of evil. (TA.)

galimN, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and gil-iymN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) but this has an intensive signification, (Ṣ, TA,) and migoliymN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) [but this also has an intensive signification,] Excited by lust, or appetence: (TA:) or overcome thereby: (Ḳ, TA:) or vehemently affected with lust, or carnal desire (Mṣb:) [or the first may generally be better rendered in a state of excitement, or of vehement excitement, by lust and the second and third, lustful, or vehemently lustful:] the epithets applied to a female are galimapN and mugotalimapN↓ and gil-iymapN↓ and gil-iymN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) this last being applied to a male and to a female, (Az, TA,) and [particularly] applied to a he-camel, (TA,) and mgolymapN↓ and migoliymN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) the last [which is ommitted in the CḲ] being, like gil-iymN, applied to a male and to a female: (Az, TA:) and gayolamN↓ likewise is applied to a girl, or young woman. in the sense of mugotalimapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., xayoruAln-isaMCi Algalimapu EalaI zawojihaA [The best of women is the appetent to her husband]. (TA.)
gulumN, with two dammehs, [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] is expl. by IAạr as signifying maHobuwsuwna [Persons confined, restricted, imprisoned,, &c.]. (TA.)

gulomapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA, &c.,) written by some gilomapN, [like a pl. of gulaAmN,] is expl. by a number of authors as signifying Lust, appetence, or carnal desire: and the desire, or eager desire, of [i. e. experienced by] gilomaAn [meaning young men]: (TA:) or it signifies vehement lust or appetence: (Mṣb:) it is also of women, (Ḳ and TA in art. trj,) meaning their lust, or appetence: (TA ibid.:) [and] it is used [also] in relation to a camel, signifying his lust to cover. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [See also 1, where it is mentioned as an inf. n. In the Ḳ, voce qaEirapN, it is used as meaning The gratification of venereal lust.]

gulaAmN [A young man, youth, boy, or male child:] one whose mustache is growing forth or has grown forth: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or one from the time of his birth until he attains to the period termed XabaAb [meaning young manhood (see guluwmapN)]: (Ḳ:) or i. q. AibonN SagiyrN [meaning a son that has not attained to puberty]: (Mṣb:) and also applied to ‡ such as is termed kahol [i. e. one of middle age, or between that age and the period when his hair has become intermixed with hoariness]: (IAạr, Mṣb, Ḳ:) Az states his having heard the Arabs call thus the new-born child and also the kahol: (Mṣb:) the female is [sometimes] termed gulaAmapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e.] gulaAmapN occurs in poetry, applied to a jaAriyap: (Mṣb:) the pl. of gulaAmN is gilomapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a pl. of pauc., (Mṣb,) and OagolimapN, (Ḳ,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] or of these two pls. they used only the former, (Ṣ, IAth, TA,) or some of them did so, (M, TA,) and gilomaAnN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) [a pl. of mult.,] or this is pl. of gilomapN: (Mṣb:) the dim. of gulaAmN is gulay-imN↓; (TA;) and that of gilomapN is OugayolimapN↓, as if it were the dim. of OagolimapN though [it has been said that] they did not use this last word; but some of them said gulayomapN↓, agreeably with analogy. (Ṣ, TA.)
It is also used as meaning ‡ A male slave; like as jaAriyapN is used as meaning “a female slave:”
and as meaning ‡ A hireling [or servant]. (Mgh.)

guluwmapN and guluwmiy-apN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gulaAmiy-apN↓ (Ḳ) The state, or condition, of such as is termed gulaAm: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) the second is expl. by Moḥammad Ibn-Ḥabeeb as meaning the period from birth to the seventeenth year. (TA voce XabaAbN.)
gulayomapN dim. of gilomapN pl. of gulaAmN, q. v. (Ṣ, TA.)
gulaAmiy-apN: see guluwmapN.
guluwmiy-apN: see guluwmapN.
gulay-imN dim. of gulaAmN, q. v. (TA.)

hom.sense: gayolamN: see galimN.
Also A beautiful woman. (TA.)
And A youth, or young man, broad, (Ḳ, TA,) in the M large, (TA,) in the place of the parting of the hair of the head, having much hair; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also gayolamiI-N↓. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.)
maA biAld-aAri gayolamN means [There is not in the house] any one. (Ḳ.)
Also The tortoise: (TA:) or the male tortoise. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA. [In the Mṣb said to be, in this sense, galiym, like zabiyb.])
And The frog. (Ḳ.) [Or so EayolamN.]
And The place whence issues the water in wells. (Ḳ. [See also EayolamN.])

The word signifying “a comb,” and “a [thing with which the head is scratched, called] midorFI,” is fayolam, with f, but has been mistranscribed [gayolam], (Ḳ, TA,) by Lth, as has been notified by Az. (TA.)

entry.sense: gayolamiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oagolamu [More, and most, exciting to lust]. It is said that Oagolamu AlOalobaAni labanu Alxaliqapi [The most exciting to lust, of milks, is the milk of the pregnant camel, or such as has completed a year after bringing forth and has then been covered and has conceived]; i. e., to him who drinks it. (TA.)
OugayolimapN a dim. of gilomapN pl. of gulaAmN, q. v. (Ṣ, TA.)
magolamapN A cause [of lusting, or] of vehemence of lusting: such is said to be the drinking of the milk of the Oay-il [or Uiy-al i. e. mountain-goat]. (TA.)
migoliymN, and with p {migoliymapN}: see galimN, in three places.
mugotalimN: see its fem. voce galimN.
siqaMCN mugotalimN, (Mgh, TA,) and xaAbiyapN mugotalimapN, (TA,) ‡ [A skin, and a jar,] of which the beverage, or wine, is strong in its influence upon the head. (Mgh, TA.*)
The xaArijiI- is called maAriqN mugotalimN † [A deviater from the true religion,] an exceeder of the prescribed limit. (TA.)

1. galaA, aor. yagoluw, primarily signifies He, or it, exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit; was excessive, immoderate, or beyond measure; but the inf. n. differs in different cases, as will be shown in what follows: (Er-Rághib, TA:) it is said of anything as meaning it exceeded, or was excessive. (Mṣb.)

You say, galaA fiI AlOamori, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. guluw-N (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and galaAniyapN; as also tgAlI↓ bihi; (Ḳ * and TA in art. glI; [but belonging to the present art., as is said in the TA;]) He exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit, in the affair; was excessive, or immoderate, therein. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And galaA fiI Ald-iyni, aor. as above, inf. n. guluw-N, He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, or strictness, or rigour, in religion, so that he exceeded the proper, due, or common, limit: whence the usage of the verb in the Ḳur iv. 169 and v. 81: (Mṣb, TA:) accord. to IAth, Alguluw-u fiI Ald-iyni is the investigating of the intrinsic states, or circumstances, of things, [in religion,] and [applying oneself to] the discovery of their causes, and of the abstrusities relating to the rites and ceremonies thereof. (TA.) [See also 3.]

And galaA biAls-ahomi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. galowN (Ṣ, Er-Rághib, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and guluw-N; (Ḳ;) and gAlI↓ bihi, (Mgh, Ḳ,) and gAlAhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gilaMCN (Mgh, Ḳ) and mugaAlaApN; (Ḳ;) He shot the arrow to the furthest distance (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) that he was able to attain: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or he raised his arms with the arrow, desiring [to attain with it] the furthest limit. (Ḳ,* TA.) And galaA Als-ahomu The arrow rose in its course, and exceeded the [usual] limit; (Ḳ, TA;) and in like manner, AlHajaru the stone. (TA.)

And galaA Als-iEoru, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. as above, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. galaMCN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) The price, or rate, at which a thing was to be sold, was, or became, high; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) or exceeded the usual limit; (Er-Rághib, TA;) contr. of raxuSa. (Ḳ.)

And galaA bihaA EZm [i. e. EiZamN, lit. Bigness exceeded the usual limit in her;] meaning she became plump, or fat: (TA:) one says, glA biAljaAriyapi EZm, and biAlgulaAmi, [the girl, or young woman, became plump, or fat, and the boy, or young man,] in the case of their quickly attaining to young womanhood and young manhood. (TA in another part of this art.)

And galaA is said of anything as meaning AirotafaEa [i. e. It rose in degree; as is shown by the following ex.]: Dhur-Rummeh says,
famaA zaAla yagoluw Hub-u may-apa EinodanaA
wayazodaAdu Hat-aI lamo najido maA naziyduhaA
[And the love of Meiyeh ceased not to rise in degree with us, and to increase, so that we found not what more we might give to her]. (TA.)
See also 8.
And see 6.
2: see art. glI.

3. gAlI fiI Oamorihi, inf. n. mugaAlaApN, signifies [the same, or nearly the same, as galaA fiyhi; i. e.] He exceeded the usual, or proper, bounds, or degree, in his affair; acted immoderately therein; or strove or laboured, or exerted himself or his power or efforts, or the like, therein; syn. baAlaga [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)
See also 1, near the middle, in two places.

gaAlaI bihi, and gAlAhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which latter is used by a poet for gAlI bh, (Ṣ,) He bought it at a high, or an excessive, price, namely, flesh-meat; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also AglI↓ bihi; (Ṣ;) and AglAhu↓, i. e. water, and flesh-meat [&c.]: (IḲṭṭ, TA: [see an ex. in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn:]) or he exceeded what was usual in purchasing it, or in offering it for sale, and mentioning the price. (M, Ḳ, TA.) A poet says,
nugaAliI All-aHoma liloOaDoyaAfi niyoYFA
wanuroxiSuhu UicaA naDija Alquduwru
[We purchase at a high price flesh-meat, for the guests, raw; and we make it to be low-priced when the contents of the cooking-pots are thoroughly cooked]: he has suppressed the b [after ngAlI], meaning it [to be understood]. (Ṣ, TA.)

And gAlI fiI AlS-idaAqi He made the dowry, or the gift to, or for, a bride, high, or excessive, in amount; [he was excessive, or exorbitant, therein;] whence the saying of ʼOmar, laA tugaAluwA fiI SaduqaAti Aln-isaMCi [Be not ye excessive, or exorbitant, in respect of the dowries of women]. (TA. [See also 6.])
And gAlAhu, inf. n. mugaAlaApN, signifies also He contended with him for superiority in tallness or in beneficence; syn. TaAwalahu. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 3, in two places.
AglAhu also signifies He (God) made it to be high, or excessive, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) namely, the price, or rate, at which a thing was to be sold; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA;*) contr. of OaroxaSahu. (TA.)

And He lightened, or thinned, somewhat, its
leaves, (Ḳ, TA,) namely, those of a grape-vine, in order that it might grow high, and become [more productive, or] in good condition. (TA.)
See also 6.

entry.sense: 5: see art. glI.
6: see 1, second sentence.

tgAlwA fiI AlS-adaAqi They were excessive, or exorbitant, one towards another, in respect of the dowry, or the gift to, or for, a bride; contr. of tasaAhaluwA and tayaAsaruwA. (TA in art. ysr. [See also 3, last sentence but one.])

tgAlI said of a plant, or herbage, It grew high; (M, Ḳ, TA;) it became tall. (M, TA.) And, said of the same, It became tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and large; as also galaA↓, and AglI↓, and AigolawolaI↓; (Ḳ;) or this last is said of a grape-vine, signifying its leaves became tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and its branches, or its shoots upon which were the bunches of grapes, or the buds of its leaves and berries, (nawaAmiyhi,) became abundant, and it became tall. (TA.)

Also, said of the flesh of a beast, It rose, or went away, (AirotafaEa,) and became upon the heads of the bones: and it fell away on the occasion of preparing for racing, or the like, by scanty feeding, &c.: (T, TA:) or, said of the flesh of a she-camel, it went away; syn. cahaba; (Ḳ;) or AirotafaEa and cahaba. (Ṣ.)

8. AgtlI He was, or became, quick, or swift; he sped, or went quickly; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) said of a camel: (Ḳ, TA:) and he rose [in the degree of celerity] (AirotafaEa) so as to exceed goodness of rate, or pace; and in like manner one says [Agtlt] of any beast (daAb-ap); as also galat↓, inf. n. glw [app. guluw-N]. (TA.)
12. AglwlI: see 6.

galowapN The limit, or utmost extent, of a shot or throw; (Ṣ, Mgh;*) [i. e.] any maromaAp: (Ḳ:) [generally, a bow-shot; i. e.] the measure, space, or extent, of a single shooting of an arrow: (Ḥar p. 234:) [or the utmost measure of a bow-shot; i. e.] a shot of an arrow to the utmost possible distance; also termed gaAyapN: (Mṣb:) said to be from three hundred to four hundred cubits: (Mgh, Mṣb:) the twenty-fifth part of a complete farosax [q. v.]: (ISd, Z, Mgh, TA:) or it is reckoned by some as four hundred cubits, and by others as two hundred cubits: (Mṣb voce miylN [q. v.]:) pl. galawaAtN (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and gilaMCN. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.) Hence, (TA,) it is said in a prov., jaroIu Almucak-iyaAti gilaMCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or, as some relate it, gilaAbN. (TA. See art. ckw.) [Thus] galowapN is sometimes used in relation to horse-racing. (TA.)
galowaI i. q. gaAliyapN. (Ḳ.) See the latter in art. glI.

gulawaMCu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gulowaMCu, (Ḳ,) the latter mentioned by AZ, and app. a contraction of the former, (TA,) [and Freytag adds guluwaMC, for which I find no authority,] Excess, or exorbitance; (TA;) syn. with [the inf. n.] guluw-N. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) One says, xaf-ifo Eano gulawaAYika [Alleviate thine excess, or exorbitance]. (TA.)

And The quickness, or haste, or hastiness, and the first stage or state, of youth, or young manhood; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gulowaAnN↓. (ISd, Ḳ, TA.) One says, faEalahu fiI gulawaMCi XabaAbihi and gulowaAni↓ XabaAbihi [He did it in the quickness, or haste,, &c., of his youth, or young manhood]. (TA.)
And gulawaMCu signifies also The rising, or rising high, and increasing, of a plant, or of herbage. (Mz 40th nwE.)
gulowaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: Also, [i. e.] like samaMCN [in measure], (Ḳ,) but in the copies of the M gal-aMCN↓, with teshdeed, (TA,) A man who shoots the arrow far. (Ḳ.)
And A certain small, or short, fish, (Ḳ, accord. to different copies,) about a span [in length]: (TA:) pl. OagoliyapN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: galiI-N: see gaAlK, in three places.
gal-aMCN: see galaMCN.

gaAlK [act. part. n. of galaA: and hence, Acting, or behaving, with forced hardness, or strictness, or rigour, in religion, so that he exceeds the proper, due, or common, limit: (see 1:) and particularly] an extravagant zealot of the class of innovators: pl. gulaApN. (TA in art. sbO.)
And Shooting, or one who shoots, the arrow to the furthest distance. (Mṣb.)

And High, or excessive, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) applied to a price, or rate, at which a thing is sold; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also galiI-N↓. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence one says, biEotuhu biAlgaAliI and biAlgaliI-i↓ I sold it, or bought it, at what was a high, or an excessive, price, or rate. (Ḳ, TA.) A poet says,
walawo Oan-aA nubaAEa kalaAma salomaI
laOaEoTayonaA bihi vamanFA galiy-aA↓
[And if we were sold the speech, or discourse, of Selmà, we would give for it a high, or an excessive, price]. (TA.)
Also Fat flesh-meat. (Ḳ.)
gaAliyapN: see art. glI.
OagolaI More, or most, high [or excessive] in price: hence the saying, OafoDalu Alr-iqaAbi OagolaAhaA vamanFA [The most excellent of slaves is the highest thereof in price]. (Mgh.)

migolFI [in the CK migolaAC] An arrow with which one raises the arm [in shooting] in order to exceed with it the usual limit, or nearly to do so: (Ḳ,* TA:) or, accord. to the M, that is used in striving to exceed the usual limit: also termed migolaApN↓: pl. magaAlK. (TA.)
migolaApN: see what next precedes.

naAqapN migolaApu Alwahaqi A she-camel that goes quickly when her feet of her fore legs and of her hind legs fall in one place: (Ṣ: [it is there expl. by tagotaliI followed by the words UicaA tawaAhaqato OaxofaAfuhaA which I have here rendered accord. to an explanation in art. whq in the O: but the phrase mglAp Alwhq is there mentioned as an ex. of Alwahaq as signifying “the lasso;” whence it appears that the phrase lit. means that exceeds the limit of the lasso; agreeably with the explanation of Golius, “rapide currens, et fugiens laqueum sibi injiciendum:”]) or [the meaning is a she-camel that steps far in vying, or keeping pace, with another; for], in explaining the phrase migolaApu Alwahaqi, IB says that AlmigolaApu applied to the she-camel signifies Aal-atiI tuboEidu AlxaTowa; and Alwahaqu signifies AlmubaAraApu and AlmusaAyarapu. (TA voce hirojaAbN.)
OaroDN mugolawoliyapN A land having abundant, and dense or luxuriant, herbage; and with E also; i. q. mugim-apN and migam-apN. (TA in art. gm.)

1. galati Alqidoru, aor. tagoliI, inf. n. galoIN and galayaAnN, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) The cooking-pot boiled; (MA, &c.;) and galiyat, aor. tagolaI, is an unusual dial. var. thereof, the former being the more chaste; (Mṣb;) or galiyat is not allowable. (Ṣ.)
[Hence galaI said of a liquor, It estuated: it effervesced: it fermented: see nabiycN]

[And hence] yagoliI damuhu [as though meaning † His blood is fit to be shed] is a phrase like raAba damuhu, [q. v.], said of one who has exposed himself to slaughter: his blood being likened to milk that has become thick, and fit to be churned. (A in art. rwb.)
And galiIa Alr-ajulu, like raDiIa in measure [but see what has been said of this form of the verb above], ‡ The man became vehemently angry. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

hom.sense: 2: see 4, in two places.

gl-I Alr-ajula, inf. n. tagoliyapN, He rubbed the man over, or perfumed him, with gaAliyap. (TA.) And gl-I liHoyatahu (Mgh, O, Mṣb, all in art. glf) biAlgaAliyapi (O, ibid.) He daubed, or smeared, his beard with gaAliyap; as also gal-alahaA. (Mgh, O, Mṣb, ibid. [See 1 in art. glf.])
And tagoliyapN signifies also The saluting from afar, and making a sign. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AglI Alqidora, (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ,) and gl-AhaA↓, (Ḳ,) He made the cooking-pot to boil. (Ṣ,* MA, Ḳ.*) IDrd mentions, among some of the sayings of the people of former ages, Oun-a maMCF wagal-ihi↓ [Pour thou out water, and make it to boil]. (TA.) And one says, Oagolayotu Alz-ayota wanaHowahu [I made the olive-oil and the like to boil], inf. n. UigolaMCN. (Mṣb.)
