5. tgl-I (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) biAlgaAliyapi (Ṣ, Mṣb) He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb) perfumed himself, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) or rubbed himself over, (Ḳ,) with gaAliyap; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AgtlI↓ signifies the same; (IDrd, O in art. glf;) as also tagal-ala, (Mṣb, and O in art. glf,) and Aigotal-a. (O in that art.)
6: in all its senses, belongs to art. glw, q. v.
8: see 5.
galaAniyapN, mentioned in the Ḳ in this art., belongs to art. glw, being an inf. n. of the verb in the phrase galaA fiI AlOamori. (TA.)
gal-aAyapN A vessel of copper [or brass], in which water is heated; thus called by the people of Syria; the same that is called miHam-N [q. v.] and qumoqumN and qumoqumapN. (Mṣb voce qumoqumN.)

gaAliyapN [Galia moschata,] a sort of perfume, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known; (Ḳ;) a certain compound of perfumes; (Mṣb;) musk mixed or boiled [with other perfumes]; (MA;) or a perfume composed of musk and ambergris and camphor and oil of ben: (KL:) it is said that the first who called it thus was Suleymán Ibn-ʼAbd-El-Melik; (Ṣ, TA;) and he did so because it is a compound boiled together upon the fire: or it was thus named by Mo'áwiyeh; the case being, that ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-Jaạfar went in to him, and the odour of perfume was diffusing itself from him; so he said, “What is thy perfume, O ʼAbd-Allah?” and he answered, “musk and ambergris combined with oil of ben;” whereupon Mo'áwiyeh said, gaAliyapN, meaning highpriced: (TA:) [hence some hold the word to belong to art. glw; and their opinion is strengthened by the fact that] galowaI signifies the same. (Ḳ in art. glw.)

hom.sense: 1. gam-ahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yagomumu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gam-N, (Mṣb, TA,) He covered it, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) veiled it, or concealed it; (TA;) namely, a thing: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) this is the primary meaning. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, gum-a AlhilaAlu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) EalaI Aln-aAsi, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. gam-N, (TA,) The new moon was veiled, or concealed, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) to the people, (Ṣ,) by clouds, or otherwise, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or was intercepted by thin clouds, (Ḳ, TA,) or otherwise, (TA,) so that it was not seen. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.) It is said in a trad., faUino gum-a Ealayokumo faOakomiluwA AlEid-apa, (Mgh,* Mṣb, TA,) i. e. And if it [the new moon] be veiled,, &c., to you, then complete ye the reckoning of Shaabán, thirty [days], in order that the entering upon the fast of Ramadán may be with [inferential] knowledge. (Mṣb.) Az says that gum-a and OugomiIa and gumiIa all signify the same: (TA:) and all three occur in the trad. above mentioned accord. to different relations thereof. (Mgh.) [See also 1 in art. gmI.]
And [hence] gam-a Alqamaru Aln-ujuwma The moon concealed the stars: or almost concealed the light of the stars. (TA.)

And gum-a Ealayohi Alxabaru The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, or vague, to him; such as to be difficult to be understood; or such as not to be understood; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like OugomiIa: (Ṣ:) or was obscure, or unapparent, to him. (Mṣb.)

And gam-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,)) aor. _u {yagomumu}, inf. n. gam-N, (TA,) It (i. e. ham- [here meaning “grief,” see gam-N below,]) covered [or was as though it covered] his heart: (Ḥar p. 637:) or [accord. to common acceptation] it, or he, grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; syn. OaHozanahu. (Ḳ, and Ḥar p. 422. [See also 4.])

gam-ahu, in which the pronoun relates to an ass, &c., (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _u {yagomumu}, inf. n. gam-N, (TA,) means He put [as a covering] to his mouth and his nostrils the gimaAmap↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) which is a thing like the kiEaAm [or muzzle], (so in the Ṣ and CK,) or a thing like the fidaAm [which seems to be here similar in meaning to kEAm]: (so in other copies of the Ḳ:) or he put [as a covering] to his mouth a nose-bag, or the like, to prevent his feeding; and this is termed a gimaAmap↓: (TA:) [the verb that I have rendered “put to” in these explanations is Oaloqama, of which I do not find in its proper place any signification that would be exactly apposite in this case:] or gimaAmapN↓ signifies a sort of bag for the mouth of a camel and the like, (Ḳ, TA,) his mouth being put into it: (TA:) pl. gamaAYimu: (Ṣ, TA:) and one says, gam-ahu biAlgimaAmapi [he covered his mouth with the gmAmp], aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.)

gam-a AlX-aIoCa, aor. _u {yagomumu}, also signifies EalaAhu [app. as meaning It rose upon, or above, the thing, as though forming a covering over it]: mentioned on the authority of IAạr, who cites [as an ex.] the saying of En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab, [app. describing a rawoDap, or meadow,]
OunufN yagum-u AlD-aAlu nabota biHaArihaA
[Not depastured, the trees called DAl rising upon, or above, the herbage of its fertile tracts, or its tracts near to water]. (TA.) See also 8.

[gam-a is also intrans.: one says,] gam-a yawomunaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gam-N and gumuwmN; (TA;) and Oagam-a↓; Our day was, or became, [sultry, or] intensely hot, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) so that it took away, (Ṣ,) or almost took away, (TA,) the breath: (Ṣ, TA:) or both verbs, said of a day, and of the sky, mean it brought gam- [or distress that affected the breath or respiration], arising from closeness of heat, or clouds. (Mṣb.)

gam-a AlX-axoSu, of the class of taEiba, [the first pers. being gamimotu,] inf. n. gamamN, The person's hair of his head flowed down so that his forehead and the back of his neck were narrowed. (Mṣb.) [See also gamamN below.]

entry.sense: 3. gaAmamotuhu signifies gamamotuhu wagam-aniI [I grieved him, or caused him to mourn or lament, &c., and he grieved me, or caused me to mourn or lament, &c.; or I grieved him, &c., being grieved, &c. by him]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. Agm-t Als-amaMCu The sky became clouded: (Ḳ, as indicated by the context:) or i. q. tagay-arat [i. e., became altered]: thus in the Ṣ; but some say that it is correctly tagay-amat [agreeably with the former of the explanations above]. (TA.) See also 1, near the end.
maA Oagam-aka liI and UilaI-a is [an expression of wonder, meaning How great grief, or sadness, dost thou occasion to me!] from Algam-u signifying AlHuzonu. (Ḳ, TA.)
[Accord. to the TḲ, Oagam-ahu signifies OaHozanahu; like gam-ahu: but this I think a mistake.]
[And Freytag explains Oagam-a as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees signifying “Demersit:” but in which of its senses he uses this word he does not specify.]

entry.sense: 6. tgAm- He made a show of gam- [or grief,, &c.,] without its being in the heart. (Ḥar p. 126.)
7. Angm- It (a thing, Ḳ) was, or became, covered, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) veiled, or concealed. (TA.)
See also what next follows {8}.
8. Agtm- He was, or became, grieved, or caused to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) as also Angm-↓: (Ḳ:) both mentioned by Sb. (TA.)

And, said of a plant, or herbage, It was, or became, tall, (Ḳ, TA,) and tangled, or luxuriant, (TA,) and abundant: (Ḳ, TA:) as also AEtm-. (TA.) [And in like manner gam-a↓ is expl. by Freytag as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, said of a plant, meaning It was tall and luxuriant.]
And, said of a man, He withheld himself from going out, or forth. (TA.)
R. Q. 1. gamogama, [inf. n. gamogamapN, He (a bull) uttered a cry, or cries, in fright; as also tagamogama↓: see gamagomapN below.]
[And] He (a courageous man) raised his voice conflict with his antagonist; (Ḥar p. 531;) [as also tagamogama↓: see, again, gamogamapN below.]

And He [a man] spoke while taking a thing into his fauces, so that the hearer, or listener, did not understand what he was saying; (Ḥar ubi suprà;) [or spoke indistinctly; agreeably with an explanation of gamogamapN below; as also tagamogama↓.]
[And, said of a bow, It produced a sound; agreeably with another explanation of gamogamapN below.]

Also, said of an infant, inf. n. gamogamapN, He wept over the breast, desiring the milk: [and the inf. n. is used as a simple subst., and therefore pluralized:] IAar cites as an ex.,
UicaA AlmuroDiEaAtu baEoda Oaw-ali hajoEapK
samiEota EalaI vudiy-ihin-a gamaAgimaA↓
[When the suckling women, after the first light sleep in the beginning of the night, are in such a condition that thou hearest cryings over their breasts]; meaning, as he says, that the milk of these women is little in quantity, so that the sucking child weeps over the breast when sucking it. (TA.)
R. Q. 2. tagamogama: see R. Q. 1, in three places: and see its inf. n. voce gamogamapN, below, in two places.

Said of one drowning (gariyq) beneath the water, it signifies He uttered a cry, or cries: or, as is said in the T, he was pressed upon by the waves above him: a poet uses it of Pharaoh when he was overwhelmed [in the sea]. (TA.)

gam-N [an inf. n. used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] Grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; syn. HuzonN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) so called because it covers happiness and forbearance; (Mṣb;) or gam- in the heart is thus called because it veils, or precludes, happiness: (Ḥam p. 21:) [it may therefore be rendered gloominess of mind:] or i. q. karobN, (Ḳ,) which signifies Huzon, (Ḳ in art. krb,) or gam-, (Ṣ, in that art.,) [that affects the breath or respiration, lit.] that takes away the breath; (Ṣ and Ḳ in that art.;) as also gam-aMCu↓ (Ḳ) and gum-apN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the last [expl. in the Ṣ as syn. with kurobapN, which is syn. with karobN, and] mentioned by Lḥ: (TA:) [see also SaqaEN:] it is karob [or grief,, &c.,] that befalls the heart because of what has happened; differing from ham-N, which is krb that befalls because of annoyance, or harm, that is expected to happen: or, as some say, both are one [in meaning]: the differing is asserted by ʼIyáḍ and [many] others: (TA:) [see also gaSabN:] the pl. of gam-N is gumuwmN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet in the phrase yawomN gam-N (Ṣ, TA) i. e. A day that is [sultry, or] intensely hot, so that it [almost] takes away the breath; and layolapN gam-N [such a night], i. e. gaAm-apN↓: (Ṣ:) or one says yawomN gam-N and gaAm-N↓ and migam-N↓, (Ḳ, TA,) the last with kesr to the m, (TA,) [in the CK mugim-N↓,] meaning a day of heat, (Ḳ,) or of intense heat: (TA:) or a day of gam- [i. e. grief,, &c.]: and [in a similar sense, as is implied by the context immediately preceding,] layolapN gam-N and gam-apN and gam-aI↓: (Ḳ:) [but] AʼObeyd mentions, on the authority of AZ, layolapN gam-aI↓ and layolapN gam-apN↓ as meaning a night in which there is over the sky [a covering of clouds, or] what is termed gamoIN [a word belonging to art. gmI, being in measure] like ramoIN; (Ṣ;) and [in the like sense] yawomN gam-N. (So in one of my copies of the Ṣ.)

And one says, kaAna EalaI Als-amaMCi gm [app. gam-N, but this, I think, requires confirmation, for which I have searched in vain,] and gmI [app. gam-aI↓, or perhaps gamoIN, a word mentioned above,] meaning There was over the sky a collection [or an expanse] of thin clouds, or a DabaAbap [i. e. mist, or the like], faHaAla duwna AlhilaAli [and it intercepted the new moon]: and hecihi layolapu gam-aI↓, and some say gum-aI↓, This is a night [of a covering of clouds, or] of a DabaAbap [or mist, or the like], intervening between the new moon and men; so that the new moon is not seen: (Mṣb:) and [hence] SumonaA lilogam-aI↓, and lilogum-aI↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) both mentioned by ISk on the authority of Fr, (Ṣ,) and lilogam-aMCi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and lilogum-iy-api↓, (Ḳ, TA, but omitted in the CK,) and lilogum-api↓, (TA,) [i. e. We fasted after, or from the time of, the covering of clouds, or the mist, or the like, that concealed the new moon; (the prep. li being here used in the sense of baEoda, or mino waqoti, as in the Ḳur xvii. 80;) virtually] meaning [we fasted] without a sight [of the new moon]: (Mṣb, TA:) a rájiz says,
layolapa gum-aI↓ TaAmisK hilaAluhaA
OawogalotuhaA wamukorapN UiyogaAluhaA
[In a night of a covering of clouds, or of a mist, or the like, having its new moon effaced: I journeyed quickly and far in it, (OawogalotuhaA being used, app. by poetic license, for Oawogalotu fiyhaA,) and disliked was the journeying so therein]: (Ṣ, TA:) and it is said that layolapu gm-I [i. e. gam-aI↓ and gum-aI↓] signifies also the last night of the [lunar] month; being so called because the case thereof is veiled to people so that it is not known whether it be of the coming [month] or of the past. (TA.)
gam-apN fem. of gam-N, q. v., used as an epithet.
gum-apN: see gam-N, first sentence:
and also in the latter half.

Also, † Perplexity, and dubiousness, or confusedness: pl. gumamN: one says, huwa fiI gum-apK † He is in a state of perplexity, and dubiousness, or confusedness: (Mṣb:) and huwa fiI gum-apK mino Oamorihi † He is in a state of perplexity and darkness [in respect of his case or affair]; from Algam-u signifying “the act of covering” [a thing]. (Ḥam p. 320.) [See also gim-apN and gam-aMCu.] And one says OamorN gum-apN † A dubious, confused, or vague, case or affair. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) [See also gum-aI.] It is said in the Ḳur [x. 72], vum-a laA yakuno Oamorukumo Ealayokumo gum-apF i. e. ‡ [Then let not your case be to you one of] darkness, and straitness, and anxiety: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, covered, veiled, or concealed. (TA.) And OaroDN gum-apN means † A strait, or narrow, land. (TA.)
gim-apN i. q. lbsp [app. lubosapN, meaning † Obscureness, confusedness, or dubiousness: see also gum-apN]. (TA.)

gamamN is the inf. n. of 1 in the last of the senses expl. above: (Mṣb:) or it signifies The flowing down of the hair so that the forehead, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or as in the M, the face, (TA,) and the back of the neck, are narrowed: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or the hair that veils, or conceals, the jabiyn [generally meaning the part above the temple, but sometimes it means the forehead,] and the back of the neck. (Ḥar p. 21.) Z says that they dislike what is thus termed, and like what is termed nazaEN [i. e. baldness of the two sides of the forehead]. (TA.)

gamaAmN Clouds: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or white clouds: (Ḳ:) or thin clouds: (Jel in ii. 54:) and gamaAmapN↓ signifies one thereof: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the former being pl. of the latter, as also is gamaAYimu: (Ḳ:) [or rather gamaAmN is a coll. gen. n., of which gamaAmapN is the n. un.:] they are so called because they veil the sky, or because they veil the light of the sun. (TA.)
[Hence,] Hab-u AlgamaAmi signifies Hailstones, or hail. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. An, p. 109.]
gumaAmN i. q. zukaAmN [A rheum, such as is termed coryza]. (Ḳ.)
gumuwmN [a pl. of which no sing. is mentioned,] Small stars, such as are faint, or indistinct. (Ḳ.)
gamiymN i. q. gamiysN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. Fresh herbage (kalaON) beneath such as is dried up; (Ṣ, TA;) or green herbage beneath such as is dry. (TA.)
And Milk heated until it thickens: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because it becomes covered over. (TA.)
gamaAmapN: see gamaAmN.

Also ‡ Herbage: so in the saying, OaHomaI fulaAnN gamaAmapa waAdiI kacaA i. e. ‡ [Such a one made to be prohibited to the public] the herbage that was the growth of such a valley: thus called [because produced by the water of the clouds,] in like manner as it is called samaMCN. (TA.)
gumaAmapN: see the next paragraph.
gimaAmapN: see 1, near the middle, in three places.

Also A thing with which the eyes of a she-camel are bound, or with which her muzzle is bound: (Ḳ:) or a piece of cloth with which the nose of a she-camel is stopped (yusad-u) [or bound (yuXad-u)] when she is made to incline to the young one of another: pl. gamaAYimu. (AʼObeyd, TA.) [See also darojapN: and SiqaAEN.]
gam-aI: see gam-N, in six places.
Also Dust; syn. gabarapN. (Ḳ.)
And Darkness. (Ḳ.)
And † Hardship, or difficulty, or distress, [as though] covering [or overwhelming] a party in war, or battle. (Ḳ.) See also the next paragraph.
gum-aI: see gam-N, latter half, in four places.

Also † A calamity, or misfortune; and so gam-aMCu↓; (Ḳ, TA;) and gum-aMCu↓, likewise, is said to be allowable. (TA. [But this last I think doubtful.]) And † A hard, or difficult, affair or case, in relation to which one knows not the right course to pursue; as also gam-aI↓, (Ḳ, TA,) and gam-aMCu↓. (TA.)
gam-aMCu [fem. of Oagam-N, q. v.:]
[and also used as a subst.]: see gam-N, first sentence:
and also in the latter half:
and see also gum-aI, in two places.

Uin-ahumo lafiI gam-aMCa mina AlOamori means [Verily they are in a state of dubiousness, or confusedness, in respect of the case, or affair; or] in a dubious, or confused, case or affair. (TA.) [See also gum-apN and gim-apN.]
gum-aMCu: see gum-aI.
gum-iy-apN: see gam-N, latter half.
gaAm-N, and its fem. gaAm-apN: see gam-N, former half.

gamogamapN [mentioned above as an inf. n. (see R. Q. 1), used as a simple subst.,] signifies The cries [or cry] of bulls [or wild bulls] in fright: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and of courageous men in conflict: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA:) and so tagamogumN↓: pl. of the former, in both senses, gamaAgimu. (TA.) See also an ex. of the pl. voce gamogama.

And Indistinct speech; (Ḳ;) as also tagamogumN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) gamogamapN is when one hears the voice but does not distinguish the articulation of the words; and when speech resembles that of the Eajam. (T, in TA, voce rut-apN.)
Also The sound of bows. (TA.)

rajulN Oagam-N, (Ṣ,) and Oagam-u Alwajohi waAlqafaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) A man whose hair flows down so that the face and the back of the neck are narrowed: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and in like manner [the fem.] gam-aMCu is applied to a woman. (Mṣb.)
gam-aMCu applied to the forelock (naASiyap) of a horse means Excessively abundant in the hair: and such is disliked. (Ṣ.)
And saHaAbN Oagam-N means ‡ Clouds in which is no gap, or interstice. (Ḳ, TA.)
mugim-N and migam-N: see gam-N, former half.
OaroDN mugim-apN (Ḳ, TA) and migam-apN (TA) A land having abundant (Ḳ, TA) and dense or luxuriant (TA) herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)

mugam-imN, applied to clouds (gayom), and to a sea, Abounding with water: (Ḳ:) and in like manner, without p, to a well (rakiy-ap), that fills everything, and submerges it: (IAạr, TA:) and to what is termed HisoIN [q. v.], (IAạr, Ṣ, TA,) meaning covering. (IAạr, TA.)
magomuwmN [pass. part. n. of gam-ahu, i. e. Covered,, &c.].
[Applied to unripe dates (accord. to the TA to ruTab, a mistranscription for busor), like magomuwlN,] Put into a jar, and covered over until they have become ripe. (TA.)
Applied to a new moon, Veiled, or concealed, by clouds, or otherwise, (Mṣb,) or intercepted by thin clouds, (Ḳ,) so as not to be seen. (Mṣb.)
Applied to a man, Grieved, or caused to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (TA.)
And Affected with the malady termed gumaAm. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gamatahu, aor. _i {yagomitu}, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. gamotN, (Ṣ, O,) It (i. e. food) was, or became, heavy upon his heart [or stomach], (Ks, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) he having eaten much thereof so that it caused him to suffer indigestion, (Ks, O,) and it rendered him like one intoxicated: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Sh, it (i. e. grease) rendered him like one intoxicated, (O, TA,) in consequence of indigestion. (TA.)
And He covered it; (O, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (Ḳ.)
And gamatahu fiI AlmaMCi i. q. gaT-ahu [i. e. He immersed, or plunged, him, or it, into the water; like gat-ahu]. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.)
And gamata nafasFA He made a sign, or motion, with' his head, (O,) or he raised his head, (Ḳ,) [for the purpose of taking breath,] in drinking. (O, Ḳ.)
gamita He became like one intoxicated, by grease [in his stomach]: (Sh, O:) or he suffered from the heaviness of food upon his heart [or stomach] so that he became like one intoxicated. (Ḳ.)

1. gamadahu, aor. _i {yagomidu} and _u {yagomudu}, inf. n. gumodN; and Agmdhu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UigomaAdN; (Mṣb;) mentioned by AO, (Ṣ,) or by AʼObeyd, (L, TA,) as two chaste forms; (Ṣ, L, TA;) He put it (i. e. a sword, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, or the like, Mṣb) into its gimod [i. e. scabbard, or sheath; he sheathed it]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he made for it, or furnished it with, a gimod. (Mṣb.)
Hence, gamadahu bikacaA ‡ He covered him, or it, with such a thing; as though he made the latter a gimod to the former. (A.)
See also 5, in two places.
gamada, inf. n. gumuwdN, said of a tree of the species called EurofuT, † It had its branches abounding with leaves so that one could not see its thorns; (L, Ḳ;) as though they were sheathed. (L.)
gamadati Alr-akiy-apu, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagomudu}, inf. n. gumuwdN, (L,) ‡ The well lost its water. (L, Ḳ.)
And gamidat, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yagomadu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gamadN, (L,) ‡ It (a well) had much water: (Aṣ, L, Ḳ:) or it had little water. (AO, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 5, in two places.
4: see 1.
[Hence,] Agmd AlOaXoyaMCa ‡ He put the things one within another. (Ḳ.)
And Agmd AlHilosa ‡ He put the [cloth called] Hilos beneath the camel's saddle, to preserve the animal's back from being galled by the saddle. (Akh, A,* L.)
5. tgm-d Alv-awoba ‡ He put the garment, or piece of cloth, beneath him, to conceal it from the eyes of others. (A.)
And tgm-dAlr-ajula, (JK, L,) and gm-dhu↓, (L,) † He took the man beneath him (taHotahu, thus in the JK, in the L bixatolK [by deceit, or guile]), to cover him over, or conceal him. (JK, L.)
And tgm-d fulaAnFA, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and gm-dhu↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ He concealed, as with a veil, what had proceeded from such a one, or what such a one had done. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

And tgm-dhu Qll-ehu biraHomatihi, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and gamadahu↓ bihaA and gamadahu↓ fiyhaA, (L,) ‡ God covered him with his mercy, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as with a veil; veiled him therewith; (AʼObeyd, A, L, Mṣb;) clad him, or invested him, therewith. (AʼObeyd, L.)
tgm-d AlOaEodaMCa † He threw himself upon the enemies; or came upon them, or over them; and overwhelmed them. (L.)
And tgm-dhu ‡ He filled it, (A, Ḳ,) namely, a measure of capacity, (A,) or a vessel. (Ḳ.)

8. Agtmd All-ayola ‡ He (a man, Ṣ, L) entered into [the darkness of] the night; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) as though it became as a gimod to him; like as one says Aid-araEa All-ayola: (Ṣ, L:) and simply Agtmd he ventured upon, encountered, or braved, the night, (rakibahu,) to seek food for his family. (Ṣ, L.)
10. Aisotagomadati Als-amaMCu fiI Als-aHaAbi Alkaviyri † [The sky became obscured amid the many clouds]. (TA in art. Tnfs.)

gimodN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and gumud-aAnN↓, (L, Ḳ,) but the latter is not of established authority, (IDrd,) of a sword, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the like, (Mṣb,) The scabbard, or sheath; [this is well known to be the correct meaning; it is shown to be so in the Ṣ, voce qiraAbN; and is the meaning obtaining in the present day;] syn. gilaAfN, (Ṣ, O,) or jafonN: (L, Ḳ:) [both of these words have the signification mentioned above; but not that only; for glAf has a wider application; and it is said in the Ṣ, voce qiraAbN, that the jfn of a sword is a case, or receptacle, in which is (put) the sword together with its gimod and suspensory belt or cord:] the pl. is OagomaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] (O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gumodaAnN, (O,) or gumuwdN. (Ḳ.)
gumud-aAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

rakiI-N gaAmidN, a phrase like EiyXapN raADiyapN, [gaAmidN meaning magomuwdN,] ‡ Wells having their water covered by earth, or dust; contr. of rakiI-N mubodK. (A.) And gaAmidapN ‡ A well (biYorN) filled up, or choked up, with earth, or dust. (Ḳ, TA.)
And gaAmidapN and gaAmidN † A ship (safiynapN) filled, or laden; (Ḳ, TA;) as also MmidapN (TA) and MmidN. (Ḳ, TA.)
mugomadN: see what here follows.
magomuwdN and mugomadN↓ A sword [or the like] put into its gimod [meaning scabbard, or sheath; i. e. sheathed]. (Ṣ, A.)

hom.sense: 1. gamura, as in some lexicons, or gamara, aor. _u {yagomuru}, accord. to all the copies of the Ḳ [consulted by SM], (TA,) or gamira, [aor. _a {yagomaru},] (as in the CK and my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) inf. n. gamaArapN and gumuwrapN, [agreeably with analogy if gamura be the form of the verb, which is therefore most probably correct,] (Ḳ,) It (water) was, or became, much in quantity, abundant, copious, [or deep,] (Ḳ, B, TA,) so that it concealed its bottom. (B, TA.) You say maA OaXad-a gumuwrapa hecaA Aln-ahori How great is the abundance of the water of this river! (Ṣ.)
[And ‡ He abounded in beneficence.] You say rajulN bay-inu Algumuwrapi ‡ A man bearing evidence of abounding in beneficence. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

gamarahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagomuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gamorN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) It (water, Ṣ, Ḳ, or the sea, Mṣb) [overflowed,] came over, or rose above, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or covered, (Ḳ,) and concealed, (TA,) him, or it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also Agtmrhu↓: (Ḳ:) and he (a man) veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, him, or it. (Mṣb.)
Hence, gamarahu Alqawomu † The people rose above him, or surpassed him, in eminence, (Ṣ, TA,) and in excel-lence. (TA.)
And raOayotuhu qado gamara AljamaAjima biTuwli qawaAmihi † [I saw him to have overtopped the heads of others by the tallness of his stature]. (TA.)

gamira Sadoruhu EalaI-a, aor. _a {yagomaru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) inf. n. gamarN (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Mṣb) and gimorN, (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] His bosom bore concealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against me. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
gamirato yaduhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yagomaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gamarN, (TA,) His hand was, or became, foul with the smell of flesh-meat, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and with the grease thereof adhering to it. (Ḳ.)

gamura, aor. _u {yagomuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gamaArapN, (Ṣ, [in my copy of the Mṣb written gamaAr, probably by a mistake of the copyist,]) He was inexperienced in affairs: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) Benoo-'Okeyl say gamira, aor. _a {yagomaru}. (Mṣb.) You say fiyhi gamaArapN and garaArapN [In him is a want of experience in affairs]. (TA.)
2. gm-rt wajohahaA, inf. n. tagomiyrN, She (a woman) smeared her face with gumorap [q. v.]; (Ṣ;) as also Agtmrt↓ biAlgumorapi, (Ḳ,) and tgm-rt↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
gum-ira, inf. n. tagomiyrN, He (a man) was deemed ignorant. (TA.)

gm-r farasahu, inf. n. as above, He gave his horse water to drink in a cup, (Ḳ,) in the small cup called gumar, (TA,) because of the scarcity of water. (Ḳ.) IAạr mentions the phrase gm-rhu OaSoHunFA He gave him to drink some bowls of water: making the verb doubly transitive. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. gAmr fiI AlqitaAli and gAms fiyhi signify the same [i. e. † He plunged, or threw himself, into the midst of fight, or conflict]. (TA in art. gms.) [See also mugaAmirN.]
And gAmrhu † He engaged with him in fight, or conflict, not caring for death. (Ṣ, O.)
And gAmr signifies also † He contended in an altercation, or a dispute. (O.)

hom.sense: 5. tgm-rt: see 2.

tgm-r He drank from a small cup such as is called gumar: (Ḳ:) he drank a small quantity of water: (TA:) he drank less than would satisfy his thirst: (Ṣ:) he drank the smallest draught, less than would satisfy his thirst: (TA:) he did not satisfy his thirst with water; (Ḳ,* TA;) said of a camel, (Ḳ,) and of an ass. (TA.)
And tgm-rt AlmaAXiyapu The cattle ate what is termed gamiyr [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 7. Angmr He immerged, dipped, or plunged, himself, or he became immerged, dipped, or plunged, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in water, (Ṣ, TA,) and in a thing; (TA;) as also Agtmr↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 8: see 1:
and 7:
and 2.

gamorN Much, abundant, copious, [or deep,] water; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gamiyrN↓: (Ḳ:) or much, abundant, copious, [or deep,] water, that drowns, or submerges: (ISd, TA:) or that covers over him who enters into it: (IAth, TA:) [also used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, meaning much, abundant, copious, or deep, water;] and gamorapN↓ signifies the same as gamorN [when thus used; or a submerging deep, a deep place, or an abyss, of water]: (TA:) pl. gimaArN and gumuwrN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say baHorN gamorN An abundant sea: and [in the pl.] biHaArN gimaArN, and gumuwrN. (Ṣ.) And of a thing that has become much, you say, hecaA kaviyrN gamiyrN↓ This is much. (AZ.) [See also Algamari.]
The main of the sea: (Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.)

‡ Liberal in disposition: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) and in like manner, gamoru Alxuluqi: (TA:) or this last, and gamoru Albadiyhapi, signify ‡ abounding in beneficence: pl. as above: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [see also ridaMCN:]) and gamoru Albadiyhapi ‡ a man who takes by surprise with large bounty. (TA.)
‡ A horse fleet, or swift, or excellent, in running. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.)
‡ A garment ample, or full. (Ḳ,* TA.)

† A mixed crowd of men, (Ḳ,) and their thronging, pressing, or pushing, and multitude; (TA;) as also gamarN↓ and gamorapN↓ and gumaArN↓ and gamaArN↓: (Ḳ: [in the TA, instead of the last two words, I find gumaArapN and gamaArapN, as from the Ḳ, and gumaArN and gamaArN are afterwards there added: but most probably these only (without p) are correct:]) and gamorapN↓ and gumaArN↓ and gamaArN↓ signify a crowding, or pressing, of men, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and of water: (Ṣ:) the pl. of gamorapN↓ is gimaArN. (Ṣ.) You say daxalotu fiI gumaAri↓ Aln-aAsi, and gamaArihimo↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and gamarihimo↓, (TA,) † I entered among the crowding, or pressing, of the people, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and their multitude: (Ṣ, TA;) as also fI xamarihimo [and xumaArihimo, &c.] (TA.) And Oakuwnu fiI gumaAri↓ Aln-aAsi, meaning I shall be among the dense congregation of the people, occurs in a trad. (TA.)
See also gumorN.
layolN gamorN means Intensely dark night. (TA.)

gumorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gumurN↓ (Ṣ, ISd) and gamorN↓ and gimorN↓, accord. to the Ḳ, but this last is unknown, (TA,) and gamarN↓ (Ḳ) and gamirN↓, (TA,) originally, A boy devoid of intelligence: and hence, (Mṣb,) a man (Ṣ, Mṣb) inexperienced in affairs: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) ignorant: (TA:) inexperienced in war and in counsel; not rendered firm, or sound, in judgment, by experience: (L:) one in whom is no profit nor judgment: (ISd, TA:) one in whom is no good nor profit with respect to intelligence or judgment or work: (AZ, Mṣb:) and mugam-arN↓ signifies the same as gumorN; (Ṣ, TA;) or deemed ignorant: (TA:) the fem. of gumorN is with p {gumorapN}; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and so is that of gamirN↓: (TA:) and the pl. of gumorN is OagomaArN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and this may also be pl. of gamarN↓, like as OasobaAbN is pl. of sababN. (TA.)
See also gumorapN.
gimorN Concealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also gamira.]

And † Thirst: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. OagomaArN. (Ṣ.) El-ʼAjjáj says,
Hat-aI UicaA maAbal-ati AlOagomaAraA
‡ [Until, when they damped their thirst]. (Ṣ.) bal-ati AlUibilu OagomaArahaA means ‡ The camels drank a little. (TA.)
See also gumorN.
gamarN A drowning; being drowned: so in the phrase mawotu Algamari Death by drowning. (TA.)
See also gamorN.

The foul smell of flesh-meat, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and its grease adhering to the hand: (Ḳ:) and the smell of fish. (Ṣ.) Hence, minodiylu Algamari (Ṣ, Mgh) The napkin, or rough napkin, with which the hand is cleansed therefrom. (L, TA.)
See also gumorN, in two places.
gamirN [part. n. of gamira]. You say yadN gamirapN A hand foul with the smell of flesh-meat, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and with the grease thereof adhering to it. (Ḳ.) [See also sahikN.]
See also gumorN, in two places.
gamirapN as an epithet applied to a she-camel, see voce gabirN.

entry.sense:
gumarN A small drinking-cup or bowl, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with which people divided the water among themselves in a journey when they had little of it; and this they [sometimes] did by putting a pebble into a vessel, and then pouring into it as much water as would cover the pebble, and giving it to each man among them: (TA:) or the smallest of drinking-cups or bowls: (Ḳ:) [see qaEobN; and tibonN:] accord. to ISh, it contains twice or thrice the quantity of the measure called kiylajap: [but this seems to be a large gmr, used for watering a horse; and the words which here immediately follow are app. not added by ISh, but relate to the gmr used by a man for himself or for another man:] the qaEob is larger than it, and satisfies the thirst of a man: the pl. is OagomaArN. (TA.) El-Aạshà of Báhileh says, in an elegy on his brother El-Munteshir Ibn-Wahb,
takofiyhi Huz-apu filocK Uino Oalom-a bihaA
mina AlX-iwaMCi wayurowiI Xurobahu Algumaru
[A slice of camel's liver, roasted, if he lighted upon it, used to suffice him; and the gumar used to satisfy his thirst]. (Ṣ, TA.) And Moḥammad is related, in a trad., to have said, laA tajoEaluwniI kagumari Alr-aAkibi Sal-uwA EalaI Oaw-ala Ald-uEaMCi waOawosaTahu waMxirahu Make ye me not like the gumar of the rider: salute me in the beginning of prayer and in the middle thereof and in the end thereof: meaning that they should not make the salutation of him to be a thing of no great importance, and to be postponed: for the rider puts on his camel his saddle and his travel-ling-provisions, and last of all hangs upon his saddle his drinking-cup. (IAth, TA.)
gumurN: see gumorN.
gamorapN Water that rises above the stature of a man. (Bḍ in xxiii. 56.) See also gamorN, first sentence.

Hence, (Bḍ,) facarohumo fiI gamoratihimo, in the Ḳur xxiii. 56, ‡ Therefore leave thou them in [the submerging gulf, or flood, of] their ignorance; (Fr, Bḍ;) or in their error: (Jel:) or in their error and obstinacy and perplexity: (Zj, in explanation of another reading, fI gamaraAtihimo:) and in like manner, fiI gamorapN, in the same chap., verse 65, signifies in overwhelming heedlessness: (Bḍ:) or in ignorance: (Jel:) and in the Ḳur li. 11, in overwhelming ignorance: (Bḍ, Jel:) or gamorapN signifies [here] a state of obstinate perseverance in vain or false affairs: (Lth, Mṣb, TA:) and gamaraAtN is the pl. (Mṣb.) You say huwa fiI gamorapK mino lahowK, and XabiybapK, and sukorK, ‡ [He is in a submerging gulf, or flood, of frivolous diversion, and of youthful folly, and of intoxication]. (TA.)
And gamaraAtu jahan-ama signifies [The fiery depths of Hell; or] the places, of Hell, that abound with fire. (TA.)

[Hence] gamorapu AlxuSuwmapi † The main part of the contention. (TA.) [And gamorapu AlHarobi † The main part, i. e. the thick, or thickest, of the fight or battle. (See also gamaraAtu AlHarobi in what follows.)]

Hence likewise, gamorapN signifies also ‡ Difficulty, trouble, distress, or rigour, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and pressure, of a thing: (Ḳ:) pl. gamaraAtN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gimaArN (Ḳ) and gumarN. (Ṣ.) Hence, (Mṣb,) gamaraAtu Almawoti ‡ The rigours, or pangs, (XadaAYidu,) of death: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or gamorapu Almawoti signifies the agony, i. e. the vehemence of the troubles or disquietudes, of death: (TA:) and gamaraAtu AlHarobi, and gimaAruhaA, † the rigours of war. (TA.)
See also gamorN again, latter half, in three places.

gumorapN A kind of liniment, made from [the plant called] waros, (Ṣ, TA,) used by a bride, for her person: (TA:) or [the plant] wrs [itself]: (TA:) or saffron; as also gumorN↓: (Ḳ:) or kurokumN [which also means saffron and bastard saffron]: or gypsum; syn. jiS-N: or, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed, a mixture of dates and milk, with which the face of a woman is smeared, to render her skin fine: and the pl. is gumarN. (TA.) [See also xumorapN.]
gmrp, [thus in the TA, app. gumarapN, of the class of SuraEapN, &c.,] as an epithet applied to a man, Valid in judgment or opinion, in cases of difficulty. (TA.)
gamaArN: see gamorN, latter half, in three places.
gumaArN: see gamorN, latter half, in four places.

hom.sense: gamiyrN: see gamorN, in two places.

Also A certain plant: (Ḳ:) or green herbage that is overtopped, or covered, and concealed, by what is dried up: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or herbage growing in the lower part, or at the root, of [other] herbage, (Ḳ,* TA,) so that the first [in growth] overtops, or covers, and conceals, it: (TA:) or any verdure that is little in quantity, (L, Ḳ, TA,) either ryHp [i. e. ray-iHap, meaning what becomes green after the upper parts have dried,] or nbAt [app. meaning herbage in general]: (L, TA:) or the grain of the [species of barley-grass called] buhomaI, (Ḳ, TA,) that falls from the ears thereof when it dries; so says AḤn: or somewhat that comes forth in the buhomaI in the first of the rain, succulent, or sappy, amid such as is dry; and gamiyr is not known in anything but the buhomaI: (TA:) the pl. is OagomiraMCu. (Ḳ.) gamiyrapN↓ [is app. its n. un., but] is said by AO to mean Dry [trefoil, or clover, of the species called] raTobap and qat-, with which horses are foddered when they are prepared, by being reduced to scanty food, for racing or for a military expedition. (TA.)

entry.sense: gamiyrapN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: gaAmirN Much, or abundant: applied in this sense to property. (Ḥam p. 593.) [See also gamorN.]
[In a state of immersion; immerged. (See OataAnN; and see also a verse cited voce Oano, p. 106, first col.)]
And [hence, perhaps,] gaAmirapN signifies Palm-trees (naxolN) not requiring irrigation: (AḤn, Ḳ:) but Az did not find this to be known. (TA.) [See also mugotamirN.]

Applied to land, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and to a house, (TA,) [but written with p {gaAmirapN} when OaroDN is mentioned, or daArN,] it signifies the Contr. of EaAmirN; (Ṣ, TA;) and thus, (TA,) waste; desolate; in a state the contrary of flourishing; in a state of ruin; syn. xaraAbN: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) [land to which this term is applied is thus called] because overflowed by water, so that it cannot be sown; or because it is covered with sand or dust; or because water generally exudes from it, so that it produces only reeds and the barodiI- [i. e. papyrus or other rushes]: by gaAmirN is meant cuw gamorK; like as one says ham-N naASibN, meaning cuw naSabK: (TA:) or any land that is not tilled (lamo yusotaxorajo) so as to be fit for sowing (Ḳ, TA) and planting: (TA:) or land that is unsown, but capable of being sown: so called because the water reaches it and comes over it: of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) like the epithets in sir-N kaAtimN and maMCN daAfiqN; and made of the measure fAl only to correspond to EaAmirN as its opposite: (Ṣ, TA:) waste land which water does not reach is not called gaAmirN; (Ṣ;) but such is called qaforN. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., [which shows that the last two explanations given above are correct,] that ʼOmar imposed a tax of a diroham and a qafiyz upon every jariyb [of land], both EaAmir and gaAmir: and this he did in order that the people might not be remiss in sowing. (Az, TA.)

entry.sense: Oagomaru [More, or most, abundant, copious, or deep: applied to water.]
More, or most surpassing, or excelling: so in the saying, huwa Oagomaruhumo biTuwli qawaAmihi He is the most surpassing of them by the tallness of his stature. (TA.)

hom.sense: mugam-arN A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with [gumorap, or] saffron. (M, TA.)
mugom-arapN and mutagam-irapN↓ and mugotamirapN↓ A girl having her face smeared with gumorap. (TA.)
See also gumorN.

entry.sense: mugam-irN: see mugaAmirN.
magomwurN [Overflowed, or covered, and concealed, by water, &c.]
Rained upon. (TA.)
† Overcome, subdued, or oppressed. (TA.)
† An obscure man; of no reputation: (Ḳ, TA:) as though others surpassed him. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN mgomuwru Aln-easabi † Such a one is of obscure race. (TA.)

mugaAmirN † One who plunges, or rushes without consideration, into places of peril: (Ṣ:) one who throws himself into difficulties, troubles, or distresses; as also mugam-irN↓: (Ḳ:) or one who enters into difficulties, troubles, or distresses, and makes another, or others, to do so; like mugaAmisN. (Ḥam p. 338.) Applied to a courageous man as meaning † One who incurs the rigours, or pangs, of death. (TA.) And † One who contends in an altercation, or a dispute: or who enters into the main part [or the thick or thickest] of an altercation or a dispute: and some say that it is from Algimoru, and means regarding, and regarded, with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)

hom.sense: mugotamirN Palm-trees (naxolN) imbibing water from a copious source. (AḤn, Ḳ.) [See also gaAmirapN, voce gaAmirN.]
And † A drunken man: (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA:) as though intoxication had drowned his reason. (TA.)
See also mugam-arN.

entry.sense: mutagam-irapN: see mugam-arN.

hom.sense: 1. gamazahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or gamazahu biyadihi, (Mṣb,) aor. _i {yagomizu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gamozN, (TA,) He felt him, (namely, a ram,) to know if he were fat: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and gamazahaA he put his hand upon her (a camel's) back, to see how fat she was. (TA.)

Hence, (Mṣb,) gamazahu biyadihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagomizu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gamozN, (A, Ḳ,) He pressed, or squeezed, it, [with his hand,] namely, a limb, (A, Ḳ, TA,) and a man's back. (TA.) So in a trad. of ʼOmar: daxala Ealayohi waEinodahu gulayomN yagomizu Zahorahu [He went in to him, and with him was a little boy pressing, or squeezing, or kneading, his back]. (TA.) And in a trad. respecting the ablution termed Algusol, it is said, AigomiziI quruwnaki, meaning Press thou, or squeeze thou, the locks of thy hair, in washing. (TA.) You also say, gamaza Alv-iqaAfu AlqanaApa The straightening-instrument pinched and pressed the spear. (A,* Mgh, TA.*) A poet (namely Ziyád El-Aajam, TA) says,
wakunotu UicaA gamazotu qanaApa qawomK
kasarotu kuEuwbahaA Oawo tasotaqiymaA
[And I used, when I pinched and pressed the spear of a people, to break its knots, or internodal portions, unless it became straight]. (Ṣ, TA. It is a prov., respecting which see remarks in art. Aw.)

gamaza, (A, Mṣb,) and gamazahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagomizu}, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gamozN, (Mṣb, TA,) ‡ He made a sign, (A, Mṣb,) and he made a sign to him, (Mgh, Ḳ,*) with the eye, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or eyebrow, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or eyelid [by winking]. (Ḳ.) So in the saying, in a trad., gamazaniI EaliI-N Oano qulo naEamo ‡ '4lee made a sign to me with the eye, or eyebrow, meaning, Say thou Yes. (Mgh.) The people of the West say, gamazahu fulaAnN bifulaAnK, meaning, ‡ Such a one blinked towards such a one, to instigate him against him, or in order that he should have recourse to him for protection or the like, or seek aid of him. (Mgh.)
Hence, Algamozu biAln-aAsi: (Ṣ:) you say, gamaza biAlr-ajuli, aor. _i {yagomizu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gamozN, (TA,) ‡ He calumniated, or slandered, the man. (Ḳ.) [See also 4.]
You say also, gumizato XahaAdatahu [† His testimony was suspected (see magomuwzN), or impugned]. (TA in art. zwr.)

gamazati Ald-aAb-apu, (Ḳ,) or gamaza fiI maXoyihi, (Mṣb,) or mino rijolihi, (Ṣ,) aor. _i {yagomizu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gamozN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) † The beast limped, or it halted, with its hind leg; had a slight lameness thereof: (Ḳ,* TA:) or he had what resembled Earaj [or natural lameness] in his gait: (Mṣb:) or, as IḲṭṭ says, gamazati Ald-aAb-apu birijolihaA the beast gave an indication of a limping, or halting, or slight lameness, in its hind leg: whence it appears that this signification may be tropical. (TA.)
gamaza said of a disease, or of a vice, or fault, of a man, It appeared. (AA, Ḳ.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 3. [This verb is mentioned by Golius as syn. with EAyb, a verb for which I find no authority: and Freytag renders it “Vitii arguit,” and refers to a passage in Ḥar (p. 427 of the see. ed.) where (like as is done by Golius) AlmugAmiz and AlmuEAyib, as syn., are erroneously put for AlmagAmiz and AlmaEAyib.]

hom.sense: 4. Oagomazato She (a camel) had fat, (O, Ḳ,) or a little fat, (ISd, IḲṭṭ, TA,) in her hump. (ISd, IḲṭṭ, O, Ḳ.) Hence the epithet gamuwzN↓, applied to her. (TA.)

Agmz fiI fulaAnK ‡ He blamed, or found fault with, such a one; attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, or fault; (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA;) deemed him weak; (TA;) lessened his rank, or dignity: (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,* TA:) he found in him that for which he should be deemed weak: (A, TA:) and Agtmzhu↓ he impugned his character; blamed him; censured him; or spoke against him. (Ḳ.) You say, faEalotu XayoYFA fQgotamazahu↓ fulaAnN ‡ I did a thing, and such a one impugned my character, or found in it that by which my character was impugned. (Ṣ, TA.) And samiEa min-iI kalimapF faQgotamazahaA↓ fiI Eaqolihi ‡ He heard from me a saying, and deemed it weak: (A, TA:) and in like manner, Oagomaza fiyhaA found in it that for which it was to be deemed weak. (TA.)

OagomazaniI AlHar-u ‡ The heat remitted, or abated, to me, so that I became emboldened to encounter it, and went upon the road: (AA, ISk, Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,* TA:) Az says gamazaniI↓ AlHar-u, on the authority of AA: (TA:) and AA mentioned AgmrnI AlHr- in this sense, but afterwards doubted, and said, I think that it is with zAI. (TA in art. gmr.)
And Oagomaza † He (a man) became gentle, so that others were emboldened against him. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
And Oagomaza [for which Oagomazah is erroneously put in the CK] He acquired cattle such as are termed gamaz [q. v.]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) like Oaqomaza. (O.)

entry.sense: 5. [This verb is said by Freytag to have a signification belonging to tagam-ara.]

6. tgAmzwA They made signs, one to another, with their eyes, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, B,) or with the eyebrow, (A,) or hand, indicating something blameable or faulty. (B.) In this sense it is expl. as used in the Ḳur lxxxiii. 30. (Ṣ, B.)
8: see 4, in three places.
gamazN Cattle (i. e. camels, and sheep or goats, TA) of a bad quality. (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And A weak man: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) like qamazN: pl. OagomaAzN, like OaqomaAzN of qamazN. (TA.)
gamuwzN A she-camel of which one doubts whether she be fat or not and therefore feels the hump: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. gumozN [or gumuzN, or both?]. (TA.) See 4, first sentence.
gamiyzN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

gamiyzapN ‡ A thing for which one's character is to be impugned; for which one is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against; a vice, or fault; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also gamiyzN↓ (TA) and magomazN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) or magomazapN↓: (Mṣb:) and weakness in work, and impotence of mind, (TA,) and ignorance: (T, TA:) the pl. of magomazN↓ is magaAmizu, (TA,) syn. with maEaAyibu. (Ṣ.) You say, layosa fiyhi gamiyzapN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and gamiyzN↓, (TA,) and magomazN↓, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) or magomazapN↓, (Mṣb,) ‡ There is not in him anything for which his character is to be impugned; or for which he is to be blamed;, &c.: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or there is not in it anything for which it is to be coveted: (Ḳ:) or maA fiyhi magomazN↓ has both of the above-mentioned significations. (A.) And fiI fulaAnapa magaAmizu↓ jam-apN ‡ In such a woman are many vices, or faults. (A.) [See magomazN, below.]

hom.sense: jaAriyapN gam-aAzapN A girl who presses, or squeezes, or kneads, the limbs well with the hand. (A, Ḳ,* TA.)
AimoraOapN gam-aAzapN ‡ A woman who makes frequent signs with the eye,, &c.; who has a habit of doing so; syn. ram-aAzapN. (TA in art. rmz.)
gam-aAzN One who blames, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually. (TA in art. hmz.)

entry.sense: gaAmizN [meaning Limping, or halting,, &c., and having a limping, or halting,, &c.,] is like ZaAliEN: sometimes used as a possessive noun; and [therefore] one does not say gaAmizapN. (O and TA in art. ZlE.)

magomazN [should by rule be magomizN: its primary signification is A place of feeling, to know if an animal be fat: hence, a place of pressing or squeezing a limb, &c.: and a place of pinching and pressing a spear, to straighten it].

nukotapN laAmagomaza liqanaAtihaA walaA maqoraEa liSafaAtihaA ‡ [lit. A nice or subtile saying, the spear of which has no place where it requires to be pinched and pressed to straiten it, and the rock of which has no rough place requiring to be beaten, or for the rock of which there is no beating,] means, † that has no crookedness: mqrE is an inf. n., or means “a place of beating,” and SfAp is “a rock;” and the above-mentioned use of these two words is borrowed from the phrase qaraEa SafaAtahu, meaning ‡ “he impugned his character; blamed, or censured, him; or spoke against him.” (Mgh.)
See also gamiyzapN, in five places.
magomazapN: see gamiyzapN, in two places.
magomuwzN ‡ A man (A, TA) suspected (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ) of a vice, or fault. (TA.)

1. gamasahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagomisu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gamosN, (Mṣb, TA,) He immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, (JK, TA,) syn. maqalahu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in water, (JK, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or other fluid; (JK,* TA;) as, for instance, a morsel of food in vinegar, and the hand in Hin-aMC, (A,) and a garment, or piece of cloth, [for Alv-adoI in the TA, I read Alv-awob,] in water or in dye. (TA.)

AixotaDabato gamosFA, so in the T and the Tekmileh; [and so in the JK;] but in the [O and] Ḳ, Aigotasamato↓ gamosFA; (TA;) She (a woman, O, TA) immersed her hand, (Ḳ,) or, as in the [O and other] correct lexicons, her hands, (TA,) [in the Hin-aMC] so as to dye [it or them] uniformly, without taSowiyr [or figuring], (O, Ḳ,) for which last word Ṣgh [in the TṢ] writes tSryr, and for which we find in the A naqoX [meaning the same as the word in the Ḳ]. (TA.)
gamasahumo fiI AlbalaMCi ‡ [It (an event) plunged them into trial, or affliction]. (A.) [See also a similar usage of the verb below, voce gamuwsN.]

gamasa HalifFA fiI Mli AlEaASi He took a share in the compact and confederacy of the family of El-'Ás, and swore to it: for it was their custom to bring, in a wooden bowl, some perfume or blood or ashes, and they inserted their hands into it on the occasion of swearing, one to another, that their compact might be completed by their sharing together in one thing. (TA, from a trad. respecting the Hijreh.)
yagomisu Als-inaAna Hat-aI yanofuca [He thrusts in the spear-head so that it may pass through, or that its extremity may protrude]. (A.)
gamasa Ealayohimu Alxabara † He concealed from them the news, or information. (TA.)
gumisa Aln-ajomu, (so in a copy of the A,) or gamasa, (so in the JK and O and Ḳ,) The star set. (JK, A, O, Ḳ.)
2. tagomiysN signifies The making a drinking to be little in quantity: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to Kr, a man's watering his camels and then going away. (TA.)
3. [gAmshu, inf. n. mugaAmasapN, He vied, or contended, with him in plunging, or diving, in water:] mugaAmasapN is syn. with mumaAqalapN. (Ṣ, TA.)

mugaAmasapN also signifies ‡ The throwing one's self into the midst of war or fight. (Ṣ, TA,) or of an affair or a great affair or an affliction: (TA:) and the mixing, or engaging, in fight or conflict. (TA.) You say, gaAmasa fiI AlqitaAli ‡ He plunged, or threw himself, into the midst of fight or conflict; or he rushed headlong into it. (TA.) And gaAmasahumo ‡ He mixed, or engaged, with them in fight or conflict. (TA). [See also mugaAmisN].
6. tgAmsA They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, in water; syn. tamaAqalaA and tagaATasaA. (TA in art. gTs.)

7. Angms (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and Agtms↓ (Ṣ, A) He, or it, became immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, in water: or he immersed or immerged himself, plunged, or dived, in water: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) or he did so remaining long therein. (TA in this art. and in art. rms.) [See Artms.]
[Hence,] ↓the latter also signifies, [and so app. the former,] † He hid, or concealed, himself. (T, O.)
8: see 7, in two places.
Aigotamasato gamosFA: see 1.

gamasN, [like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN, &c., or perhaps a mistranscription for gamosN, like garosN in the sense of magoruwsN, and many other instances,] Immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk. (TA.)

TaEonapN gamuwsN ‡ A spear-wound, or the like, that passes through: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the epithet properly applies to the person who inflicts the wound, because he thrusts in (yagomis) the spearhead so that it passes through, or so that its extremity protrudes: and it is such as cleaves the flesh: (A:) or wide, and passing through; that plunges into the flesh. (ISd, TA.)
OamorN gamuwsN ‡ A difficult, or distressful, affair; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) that plunges people into trial, or affliction. (A, Ḳ.*)

Hence, (A,) yamiynN gamuwsN ‡ An oath that plunges its swearer (tagomisuhu) into sin, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and then into the fire [of Hell]: (Ḳ:) or a false oath, (Mgh, Mṣb,) known by its swearer to be so; (Mṣb;) so called because it plunges its swearer into sin, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) and then into the fire [of Hell]: (A, Mgh:) or a false oath which one purposely swears, knowing the case to be the contrary thereof, (Ḳ, TA,) in order to cut off the rights of others: (TA:) or an oath by which one cuts off for himself the property of another: (Ḳ:) or an oath in which there is made no exception [by saying Uino XaMCa Qll-ehu (if God will), or the like]. (TA.) [See also Algamiysap.]

rajulN gamuwsN † A strong, courageous man; as also mugaAmisN↓: which latter epithet is also applied to a lion. (TA.) And † A man who, in journeying, does not alight to rest in the night until he enters upon the time of dawn or morning. (TA.)

And naAqapN gamuwsN A she-camel whose pregnancy is not plainly known (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) until she is near to bringing forth (Hat-aI tuqoriba). (Ṣ, O.) And (O, Ḳ) accord. to En-Naḍr, (O,) A she-camel that has a young one in her belly and that does not raise her tail so that the case should become manifest: (O, Ḳ:) pl. gms [app. gumusN, agreeably with analogy, like SuburN pl. of SabuwrN, &c.]. (TA.) And (some say, TA) A she-camel respecting whose marrow one doubts whether it be in a corrupt and melting state or be fat, or thick and fat. (O, Ḳ.)
gamiysN Such as is termed gamiyr [q. v.] of herbage; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. such as has become green in consequence of rain, in the lower parts of that which is dry. (O.) See also gamiymN.
And A thing that has not appeared to men, and that is not known, as yet: whence the phrase qaSiydapN gamiysN [an ode that has not become known: the epithet being masc. and fem.]. (O, Ḳ.)

And A water-course, or channel in which water flows, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or (TA) such as is small, amid [plants such as are termed] baqol and nabaAt, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or, as in the L, combining (yajomaEu) [app. within it] trees, or shrubs, and baqol. (TA.)
Also Night: (O:) or dark night. (Ḳ.) And Darkness. (O, Ḳ.)

And AO is related by El-Athram to have said, Almajoru is what is in the belly of the she-camel; and the second [i. e. the offspring of the major] is [called] Habalu AlHabalapi; and the third is Algamiysu [i. e. this last signifies The offspring of the offspring of the major: see majorN and HabalN]. (TA.)

hom.sense: gamyisapN A collection of dense reeds or canes; or a bed, or place of growth, thereof. (TA. [See also gamiysN.])
Halafa EalaI Algamiysapi He swore a false oath. (TA. [See gamwusN.])

entry.sense: gam-aAsN: see what next follows, in two places.

gam-aAsapN [A bird of the kind termed divers, or plungeons: thus called in the present day; expl. by Golius and Freytag as meaning “mergus avis;”] a certain aquatic bird, (O, Ḳ,) that dives, or plunges, much: (O:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] gam-aAsN↓: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, gum-AsN:]) IDrd says, the gam-aAs↓ is a wellknown bird. (O.)

mugaAmisN One who plunges into wars, or battles, (yagoXaI AlHuruwba,) and engages in them repeatedly: (Ḥam p. 27:) or one who enters into difficulties, troubles, or distresses, and makes another, or others, to do so; like mugaAmirN. (Id. p. 338.) See also gamuwsN.

hom.sense: 1. gamaSahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagomiSu}, inf. n. gamoSN; (Ṣ;) and gamiSahu, aor. _a {yagomaSu}, inf. n. gamoSN; and gamiSahu, aor. _a {yagomaSu}, inf. n. gamaSN; (Ḳ,* TA;) but the first is the most chaste; (TA;) He despised him; held him in contempt; (A, Mgh, Ḳ;) accounted him little, or vile; regarded him as nothing; (Ṣ;) as also AgtmShu↓. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say also, raMhu fagamaSatohu Eayonuhu He saw him and his eye despised him. (A.)

He blamed him; found fault with him; imputed to him a vice, or fault; and despised his right. (A, Ḳ.) You say, wajadato Aln-aAsa yagomiSu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [I found the people blaming one another,, &c.]; as also yagotamiSu↓. (A.) And gamaSotahu bisuwoCK [Thou imputedst evil to him]. (TA, from a trad.) And gamaSotu Ealayohi qawolFA qaAlahu I blamed him, or found fault with him, for a saying that he said. (Ṣ.)

And hence, (TA,) gamaSa Aln-iEomapa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and gamiSahaA, (Ḳ,) the latter is the form authorized by the T and the Deewán el-Adab, this verb and [its syn.] gmT being there said to be both with kesr to the m, (TA,) He was ungrateful, or unthankful, for the favour or benefit; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) he despised it, and disacknowledged it. (TA.)

[Hence also, app.,] gamaSa Qll-ehu Alxaloqa God diminished the height, and breadth, and strength, and might in war, or valour, of mankind; and made them small and contemptible: occurring in a trad. of ʼAlee respecting the slaughter of his brother by a son of Adam. (TA.)
gamaSato Eayonuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yagomaSu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gamaSN, (Ṣ,) His eye had in it what is termed gamaSN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence, perhaps,] gamiSa hecaA AlOamoru EalaI-a This thing, or affair, turned against me, and became attended with trouble. (JK.)

[And hence, perhaps,] laA tagomaSo EalaI-a [in the CK tagomiSo] Be not thou angry with me: so accord. to the O [and the JK]: but accord. to the Ḳ, do not thou lie against me, or utter falsehood. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in two places.

gamaSN Fluid filth [or foul matter] in the inner corner of the eye: (Mgh:) or what is fluid of [the filth, or foul matter, or white filth, which collects in the inner corner of the eye, and which, when concrete, is called] ramaS: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a thing like froth, which the eye emits; a portion whereof is termed gamaSapN↓: (TA:) or what resembles white froth, in the side of the eye: but ramaSN is in the side of the eyelashes: (ISh:) or both these words signify dirt which the eye emits: or gamaSN is what is concrete. (M in art. rmS.)
gamiSN, a possessive epithet, A great imputer of vices or faults. (TA.)
gamaSapN: see gamaSN.

hom.sense: gamuwSN i. q. gamuwsN.
huwa gamuwSu AlHanojarapi He is a liar. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
AlgamuwSu: see AlgumayoSaMCu.

entry.sense: maA fiI fulaAnK gamiySapN There is not in such a one anything for which his character is to be impugned, or for which he is to be blamed, censured, or spoken against; any vice, or fault; i. q. gamiyzapN. (A.)

gumayoSaMCu dim. of gamoSaMCu [fem. of OagomaSu]. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) AlgumayoSaMCu [The star Procyon;] one of the XiEorayaAni, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) whereof the other is AlX-iEoraI AlEabuwru [i. e. Sirius]: (TA:) the former is also called AlgamuwSu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Alr-umayoSaMCu, (TA,) and AlX-iEoraI AlX-aAmiy-apu: (IAth:) it is one of the Mansions of the Moon [accord. to those who make the term nawoCN to signify the auroral setting; namely, the Seventh]; (TA;) and is in the ciraAE; (Ṣ;) i. e., it is the greater of the two stars called Alc-iraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu: (IAth:)
it is called AlgmySAC because of its smallness and its littleness of light [in comparison with the other XErI], from gamaSu AlEayoni: (TA:) [or the reason of its being so called is this:] the Arabs assert that the XiEorayaAni are the sisters of suhayol [or Canopus]; (IDrd, Ṣ;) and that they [three] were together; but that shyl descended into the south, and AlX-iEoraI AlyamaAniy-apu [which is Sirius] followed it; (IDrd;) this latter, they say, crossed the Milky way, and was therefore named AlEabuwru; and AlgmySAC remained in her place, weeping for the loss of the two others until her eye became affected with gamaS: (IDrd, Ḳ:*) they also assert that thou seest AlEbwr when she rises as though she desired to cross [the Milky Way] (kaOan-ahaA tasotaEobiru); but AlgmySAC thou seest not [as yet in any part of Arabia], she having wept until she has become affected with gamaS. (Ṣ.)

OagomaSu Having, in his eye, what is termed gamaSN, q. v.: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or disordered in the eye; whose eyes are dim, or watery; like OaEomaXu: (L and TA in art. EmX:) fem. gamoSaMCu: and pl. gumoSN. (TA.)

huwa magomuwSN Ealayohi He is censured, or blamed, or reproached, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with respect to his religion, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and with respect to his grounds of pretension to respect. (A.) It is said in a trad., Uil-aA magomwSN Ealayohi Aln-ifaAqu, meaning, Except one censured,, &c., with respect to his religion; accused, or suspected, of hypocrisy. (TA.)

OanaA musotagomiSN mino hecaA Alxabari wamutawah-imN [I am suspicious of this information, and opining;] is said by one when a piece of information rejoices him but he fears that it may not be true; or when he fears it and yet it rejoices him. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gamaDa, and gamuDa, aor. of each _u and inf. n. of each gumuwDN, It (a thing) was, or became, unperceived, unapparent, hidden, or concealed. (TA.)
gamaDa AlHaq-u, aor. and inf. n. as above; and gamuDa; The way of attaining, or obtaining, the right, or due, was, or became, unapparent, or hidden. (Mṣb.)

gamuDa AlkalaAmu, inf. n. gumuwDapN; (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) and gamaDa, aor. _u {yagomuDu}, inf. n. gumuwDN; (IB, Ḳ; [but IB seems to express a doubt of the correctness of the latter form of the verb in this case;]) The speech, or language, was unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (Ṣ, IB, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

gamuDa Ealayohi AlOamoru The affair was not easy to him; (L, TA;*) and you say also, gamaDa AlOamoru, inf. n. gumuwDN: and fiyhi gumuwDN [In it is a want of easiness]: but, Lḥ says, they scarcely ever, or never, say fiyhi gumuwDapN. (TA.)

gamaDa AlmakaAnu, aor. _u {yagomuDu}, inf. n. gumuwDN; and gamuDa, inf. n. gumuwDapN and gamaADapN; The place was, or became, low, or depressed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [because a place that is so is unseen from a distance.]
gamaDa AlxaloxaAlu fiI Als-aAqi, inf. n. gumuwDN, The anklet was, or became, depressed in the leg; lit., choked therein. (A, TA.)
gamaDati Ald-aAru, aor. _u {yagomuDu}, inf. n. as above, The house was not upon a common thoroughfare-road or street. (Lth, L.)
gamaDa Als-ayofu fiI All-aHomi, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagomuDu}, (Ibn-ʼAbbád,) The sword became hidden in the flesh. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

gamaDa fiI AlOaroDi, (Lḥ, A, Ḳ,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, fI AlOamori, which is a mistake, (TA,) aor. _u {yagomuDu} and _i {yagomiDu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gumuwDN, (A,) He went away in, or into, the land, or country: (Lḥ:) or he went away and disappeared therein: (A, L:) or he went away and journeyed therein. (Ḳ.)
And gamaDa, aor. _u {yagomuDu}, also signifies It (a thing) was, or became, small. (IḲṭṭ.)
See also 4, under AgmS Enh, in four places.
2. gm-D AlkalaAma, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagomiyDN, (Ṣ,) He made the speech, or language, unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
gm-D Had-a Als-ayofi, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He made the edge of the sword thin [so that it might become hidden in the flesh when one smote with it]; (A, TA;) as also OagomaDahu↓. (Ḳ.)
See also 4, in twelve places.

entry.sense: 4. AgmD Had-a Als-ayofi: see 2.

AgmD Eayonayohi, (Mgh,) or AlEayona, (Mṣb,) inf. n. UigomaADN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and gam-aDahumaA↓, (Mgh,) or gam-aDahaA, (Mṣb,) inf. n. tagomiyDN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) He shut, or closed, (Mgh, Mṣb,) [his eyes, or] his eyelids, (Mgh,) or [the eye, or] the eyelids. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] maA OagomaDotu, (A, TA,) and maA gam-aDotu↓, (TA,) I have not slept; (TA;) and maA QgotamaDotu↓ [signifies the same]; (JK;) and so maA QkotaHalotu UigomaADFA, (ISd, Ḳ,) and tagomaADFA↓ (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ) and tagomiyDFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [two inf. ns. of 2,] and gamaADFA↓, and gimaADFA↓, and gumoDFA↓ with damm, (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) [and app. gumaADFA↓, and gumuwDFA↓, and gamoDFA↓, for] IB says that gamoDN and gumuwDN and gumaADN are inf. ns. of a verb not used: (TA:) and maA cuqotu gumoDFA↓, [in a copy of the A gamoDFA↓,] and gamaA DFA↓, I have not tasted sleep. (JK.) [And hence,] AgtmD↓ Albaroqu ‡ The lightning ceased to gleam; as though sleeping. (TA.)

You say also, AgmD Tarofahu Ean-iI, and gm-Dhu↓, He shut, or closed, his eye, or eyes, at, or upon, or against, me: and AgmD Ealayohi, and gm-D↓, he shut, or closed, his eyes at, or upon, or against, him, or it. (TA.)

And [hence,] AgmD Eanohu, and Ealayohi, ‡ [He shut his eyes at it, or upon it, or against it], namely a thing that he had heard: a metonymical phrase, denoting patience. (TA.) And AgmD Eanohu ‡ He connived at it; feigned himself neglectful of it; passed it by; (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) as also gm-D↓ Eanohu, inf. n. tagomiyDN; and gamaDa↓; and AgtmD↓; namely a thing that he had heard; and an evil action: (A, TA:) and gm-D↓ Eayonayohi Eanohu he feigned himself blind to it. (TA.) And AgmD Eanohu fiI AlbayoEi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or AlX-iraMCi, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ He acted, or affected to act, in an easy, or a facile, manner towards him, (tasaAhala Ealayohi,) in selling, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or buying; (Ṣ;) as also gamaDa↓ Eanohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yagomiDu}. (Ḳ.) And OagomiDo liI fiymaA biEotaniI, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ like AiDoribo, [i. e. AigomiDo↓,] but the former is the right reading, (TA,) [though the latter is perhaps allowable, as will presently be seen,] meaning, (A, TA,) or as though it meant, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) ‡ Give thou to me more of what thou hast sold to me, on account of its badness; or [so in the A, but in the Ṣ and Ḳ “and,”] lower thou to me the price thereof; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) as also gam-iDo↓ liI fiyhi. (Ḳ, TA.) And AgmD fiI AlbayoEi ‡ He demanded that another should give him more of the thing sold; and that he should lower the price [thereof]; and he complied with his demand. (IAth.) And AgmD fiI Als-iloEapi ‡ He demanded a lowering of the price of the commodity, on account of its badness. (TA.) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 270], walasotumo biMxiciyhi Uil-aA Oano tugomiDuwA fiyhi, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,) or, accord. to one reading, tagomiDuwA↓, (TA,) i. e. ‡ When ye do not take it unless ye lower the price; (Lth, Zj,* Ḳ;) meaning, EalaI UigomaADK, or biUigomaADK. (Fr.)

[Hence also,] gam-aDa↓ fulaAnN EalaI hecaA AlOamori † Such a one executed, performed, or accomplished, this affair: or kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it; (maDaI Ealayohi;) [as though he shut his eyes at it;] knowing what was in it. (O, Ḳ.) And gam-aDati↓ Aln-aAqapu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagomiyDN, (Ḳ,) The she-camel, being driven away (rud-ato, as in the Ḳ, and in some copies of the Ṣ, or ciydato, as in other copies of the Ṣ, and in the A, as is said in the TA,) from the watering-trough, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) rushed upon the driver, (Alc-aAYid, [in the CK, erroneously, AlzAYid,]) closing her eyes, and came to the water. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) tagomiyDN↓ also signifies The embarking [in an affair], or undertaking [it], blindly. (TA.)

[Hence also,] OagomaDati AlmafaAzapu Ealayohimo ‡ [The desert concealed them;] they did not appear in the desert, (A, TA,) being concealed by the mirage, and in the depressed parts; (TA;) as though it closed its eyelids upon them. (A, TA.)
AgmD Aln-aZara ‡ He considered, or judged, well, and gave a good opinion: (M, TA:) and AgmD fiI Aln-aZari ‡ he gave a right opinion: (A:) or † he considered, or judged, minutely. (IḲṭṭ.)
OagomaDati AlEayonu fulaAnFA † The eye despised such a one: (Ḳ, TA:) or you say OagomaDatohu EayoniI meaning I despised him:

and likewise meaning I vied, or contended, in running with him, (HaADarotuhu,) and outstripped him, after he had outstripped me: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O:) or AgmD fulaAnN fulaAnFA means Such a one vied, or contended, in running with such a one, (HaADarahu,) and outstripped him, after having been outstripped by him. (Ḳ.)
AgmD Almay-ita, (A, Mgh, TA,) inf. n. UigomaADN; (TA;) and gam-aDahu↓, (A, TA,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) He closed the eyelids of the dead man. (Mgh.)
7. AngmD AlT-arofu i. q. AinogaD-a: (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) [or the former more probably signifies The eye, or eyes, became closed: and the latter, the eye, or eyes, became contracted. See also 8.]
8. maA QgotamaDato EayonaAIa My eyes slept not, or have not slept. (Ṣ,* Ṣgh, Ḳ.) See also 4, in the first half of the paragraph, in three places.
OataAniI celika EalaI QgotimaADK ‡ That came to me easily, without trouble, or pains-taking. (Aṣ, A, Ḳ.)
gamoDN: see gaAmiDN, in four places:
See also 4, in the third sentence, in two places.
gumoDN: see 4, in the third sentence, in two places.
gamaADN: see 4, in the third sentence, in two places.
gumaADN: see 4, in the third sentence.
gimaADN: see 4, in the third sentence.
gumuwDN: see 4, in the third sentence.
gumuwDapN: see what next follows.
maA fiI hecaA AlOamori gamiyDapN, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) and gumuwDapN↓, (L,) There is not, in this affair, any fault, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) liI [to be imputed to me]. (TA, where this is added next after mA.)

hom.sense: gaAmiDN [Unperceived; unapparent; hidden, or concealed. (See 1, first signification.)]

Unapparent to the mind, not plain or perspicuous, obscure, recondite, or abstruse, speech, or language. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say also, maEonFI gaAmiDN A nice, subtile, or quaint, meaning. (TA.) And masoOalapN gaAmiDapN A question in which is matter for consideration, and subtility, or nicety. (TA.) And masoOalapN fiyhaA gawaAmiDu [A question in which are obscurities, abstrusities, subtilities, or niceties: the last word being pl. of gaAmiDapN↓, an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates]. (A.)

Obscure; not well known: (A:) or not known: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) applied to rank or quality (Hasab), (A, Ḳ,) or to parentage or relationship (nasab): (Mṣb:) pl. OagomaADN, like as OaSoHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN: or, as some say, this is pl. of gamoDN↓. (TA.)

Obscure, or of no reputation; low, mean, or vile; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man: (TA:) such is termed cuw gamoDK↓, (Ṣ, O, TA,) also. (TA.) [And hence, perhaps,] A man remiss in the charge, or in rushing on the enemy: (Lth, Ḳ:) pl. gawaAmiDu [which is anomalous, like fawaArisu, &c.]. (Lth.)

Low, or depressed; applied to land, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and a place; (A;) [because unseen from a distance;] as also gamoDN↓; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) applied to a place: (Ṣ, A:) or this latter signifies land very low, or very much depressed, so that what is in it is not seen: (AḤn:) and in like manner magomaDN↓, a place more depressed (Ṣ, TA) than what is termed gamoDN: (TA:) pl. of the first, gawaAmiDu: (Ḳ:) and of ↓the second, OagomaADN [a pl. of pauc.] (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gumuwDN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and of the third, magaAmiDu. (Ṣ.)

An anklet depressed, lit. choked, (gaAS-N, [in the CK gAD-,]) in the leg: (JK, A, L, Ḳ:) and, applied to an ankle-bone, concealed by the flesh: (TA:) or fat: (Ḳ:) and in this latter sense applied to a leg, or shank. (Ḳ, TA.)
A house not upon a common thoroughfare-road or street; (Lth, A, L, Ḳ;) retired therefrom. (A, TA.)
A young camel; the young one of a camel: pl. gawaAmiDu: (TA:) which also signifies camels not accustomed to drawing water. (JK.)

entry.sense: mugam-aDaAtu All-ayoli The darknesses of night. (TA.)
See also the following paragraph.

Almugam-iDaAtu mina Alc-unuwbi, (O, Ḳ,* TA,) or mugam-iDaAtu AlOumuwri, accord. to different relations of a trad. in which it occurs, (TA,) Sins, or offences, which a man commits knowing them [to be such]: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or enormities which a man commits knowing them [to be such]; as though he closed his eyes upon them, feigning himself blind while he saw them: (TA:) IAth says that accord. to one relation it is with fet-ḥ to the second m, [mugam-aDaAt↓,] and means small sins, or offences; so called because minute and unapparent, so that a man commits them with a kind of doubt, not knowing that he will be punished for committing them. (TA.)

1. gamiTa, aor. _a {yagomaTu}; and gamaTa, aor. _i {yagomiTu}; inf. n. gamoTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of both; (Ṣ;) He despised men; held them in contempt; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) accounted them little, or vile. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Uin-amaA celika mano safiha AlHaq-a wagamiTa Aln-aAsa That (Ṣ, TA,) meaning transgression, iniquity, or injustice, (TA,) is only (Ṣ, TA) the action of (TA) such as regards the truth, or right, as foolishness, or ignorance, and despises men: (Ṣ, TA:) Ṣgh says that accord. to one relation, it is gamaSa: and Az relates it thus; Alkiboru Oano tasofaha AlHaq-a watagomiTa Aln-aAsa [Pride is thy regarding the truth, or right, as foolishness, or ignorance, and thy despising men]. (TA.)

Also the former, (TA,) or both, (Ḳ,) He was ungrateful for health, and safety, (Ḳ, TA,) and a favour, or benefit, or blessing: (Ṣ,* TA:) and both, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) he held in light estimation, was ungrateful for, and despised, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a favour, or benefit, or blessing, (Ḳ, TA,) and his life. (Ṣ, TA.)
And the former, He denied, or disacknowledged, a right, or due. (TA.)
4. AgmT It continued; it kept, or clave; (Ḳ;) like AgbT. (TA.) Hence, (TA,) OagomaTato Ealayohi AlHum-aI, a dial. var. of AgbTt, q. v. (Ṣ, TA.)
8. AgtmThu baAlkalaAmi He treated him contemptuously with speech: (O:) and (O) he overcame, and subdued, him therewith; (O, L, Ḳ;) and so AigotaT-apu. (O, L.)

And AgtmThu He vied, or contended, in running with him, and outstripped him, after he had been outstripped (O, Ḳ) by him; mentioned by Ibn-ʼAbbád; (O;) and so AigotaT-ahu; (TA;) and OagomaDahu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád and O in art. gmD.)
samaMCN gamaTaI i. q. gabaTaI, q. v. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
sayorN mugomaTN i. q. mugobaTN, q. v. (ISh.)

hom.sense: 1. gamala Aljiloda, (Ṣ, O,) or AlOadiyma, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagomulu}, inf. n. gamolN, He folded the skin, or hide, and buried it, in order that it might become soft, or flaccid, and pliant, when its wool was pulled: (Ṣ, O:*) if neglected for a while, it becomes spoiled, or marred: the epithet applied to it is gamiylN↓; (Ṣ, O;) and gamiynN also: (Ṣ:) or he spoiled, or marred, the skin, or hide: or he put it in the bottom of some receptacle (fiI gum-apK), [and left it a while,] in order that its wool might become detached: (Ḳ:) or he buried it, (Ḳ, TA,) having folded it, (TA,) in the sand, (Ḳ, TA,) after moistening [it], (TA,) in order that it might become stinking, and its hair [or wool] might be plucked off: (Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to AḤn, he folded it while it was moist, and left it folded longer than it required, so that it became spoiled, or marred: or, as some say, he folded it after it was tanned, then covered it a day and a night, so that its hair, or its wool, became loose, when it was plucked off: if left more than a day and a night, it becomes spoiled, or marred: (TA:) and Agml↓ signifies [the same: (see gaSaba Aljiloda:) or] he left his skin, or hide, [buried, or put in the bottom of some receptacle,, &c., while moist,] until it became spoiled, or marred. (TA.)

And gamala Alt-amora, (Ṣ,) or Albusora, (O, Ḳ,) He did in like manner to the dates, or the unripe dates, in order that they might become ripe: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and the epithet applied to them is magomuwlN↓; and magomuwnN. (TA.)
And gamala AlEinaba, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put the grapes together, in quantities one above another, (Ḳ, TA,) in the basket of palm-leaves. (TA.)
gamala fulaAnaA He covered such a one, (Ḳ, TA,) with clothes, (TA,) in order that he should sweat. (Ḳ, TA.)
gamala AljuroHa He put pieces of rag, one above another, upon the wound. (O, TA.)
gamala AlOamora He hid, concealed, or covered, the affair, or case. (TA.)
And gamala AlX-ayoCa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gamolN, (O,) He put the thing into a good, sound, right, or proper, state. (O, Ḳ.)

gamala Aln-abaAtu, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. gamolN, (TA,) The plants, or herbage, became accumulated, one, or one part, overlying another, (O, Ḳ, TA,) so as to become withered, and decayed. (TA.) [See also 5.]
gamila Aln-abotu, the verb being like fariHa, The plant, or plants, or herbage, became in a bad, or corrupt, state. (TA.)

And one says gamila hecaA AlmakaAnu biAln-aboti [app. meaning This place became, or has become, in a bad, or corrupt, state by reason of the herbage: or concealed, or covered, by herbage; as may be inferred from an explanation of OaroDN gamilapN]. (O.)
And gamila AljuroHu, (TA,) inf. n. gamalN, (Ḳ,) The wound became in a bad, or corrupt, state, by reason of the bandage. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see the preceding paragraph {1}, former half.
5. tgm-l Aln-abaAtu The plants, or herbage, became accumulated, one, or one part, overlying another. (TA.) [See also gamala Aln-abaAtu.]
And tgm-l He became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, syn. tawas-aEa, (O, Ḳ,) in wealth. (O.)

7. Angml, said of a skin, quasi-pass. of gamala signifying as expl. in the first sentence of this art. [i. e. It was, or became, such as is termed gamiyl, or in the state denoted by the pass. part. n. of the latter verb]. (Ḳ.)
gimolN A certain tree of the [kind called] HamoD, that grows surmounted by a fruit, or produce, white like the [garments called] mulaMC. (AA, O, TA.)
gamilN [accord. to rule, part. n. of gamila, q. v.].
OaroDN gamilapN Land abounding with herbage, having its surface concealed, or covered, thereby. (TA.)
gamiylN: see 1, first sentence.

Applied to herbage, (Ṣ,* O,*) or to such as is called naS-iI, (Ḳ, TA,) Accumulated, one part above another, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,* TA,) so as to be withered: (TA:) pl. gamolaI, (Ṣ, O, TA,) [which is also expl. as] meaning herbage tangled and dense, one part above another. (O voce XurobubN.)
And Low, or depressed, land. (Aṣ, O, TA.)

gumoluwlN A valley containing trees, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or containing numerous trees, (TA,) and plants, or herbage, (Ṣ, O,) tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense: (Ṣ:) or such as is long, of little width, and tangled or luxuriant or abundant and dense [in its trees]: (Ḳ:) or a narrow valley having much of such produce: or a deeplydepressed tract of land: or, accord. to ISh, a tract having the form of a [road such as is termed] sik-ap, in the ground, narrow, and having two [lateral] acclivities, each acclivity two cubits in height, extending to the measure of a bow-shot, producing an abundance [of trees or herbage], and narrower than what is termed a maliyE: (TA:) and [its pl.] gamaAliylu is said to signify low, or depressed, tracts of land, covered with herbage. (O.)

And (in like manner, Ṣ, O) Anything that is collected together, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) obscure, and accumulated, one part upon another, (Ḳ,) of trees, or of clouds, or of darkness, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or a raAwiyap, or zaAwiyap, (the former in the CK, and the latter in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) [or] so that a raAwiyap, or zaAwiyap, (the former in my copies of the Ṣ, and the latter in the O,) is thus called: (Ṣ, O:) [but I think that these two words rAwyp and zAwyp are both mistranscriptions for raAbiyap, which is mentioned in the Ḳ as one of the meaning of gumoluwlN; i. e. a hill:] pl. gamaAliylu. (TA.)

Also, (O, Ḳ,) as is said by AḤn on the authority of some other or others, (O,) A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN, O, Ḳ,) likewise called qun-aAbiraI, [thus accord. to the O in art. qnbr, and there said in the TA to be correctly with teshdeed to the n and with kesr to the b, but in the present art. written in the O qun-aAbaraI,] in Pers. barogasot; a herb of the desert (baqolapN daXotiy-apN), which come forth early in the [season called] rabiyE; (O;) eaten (O, Ḳ) by men, (O,) cooked. (Ḳ.)
magomuwlN: see 1, near the middle.
Also A man having clothes thrown upon him in order that he may sweat. (Ṣ, O.)
And Flesh-meat covered over; whether cooked by roasting or the like or with broth or gravy; as also magomuwnN. (TA.)
And Palm-trees (naxol) near together. (TA.)
And A man obscure, unnoted, or reputeless. (Aṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gamana Aljiloda, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yagomunu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. gamonN, (TA,) i. q. gamalahu; (Ḳ;) [see the latter;] He put together the skin after it had been stripped off, and covered it over until its wool became loose, for the purpose of tanning: (TA:) or he covered over the skin (Ṣ, TA) for two nights, for the purpose of tanning, (TA,) in order that its wool might become loosened from it: (Ṣ, TA:) and the epithet applied to it is gamiynN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like gamiylN. (Ṣ.)

And gamana Alt-amora, (Ṣ,) or Albusora, (Ḳ, TA,) has the like meaning, (Ṣ,) i. q. gamalahu; (Ḳ;) He covered over [the dates, or] the unripe dates, in order that they might become ripe; (TA:) and the epithet applied to them is magomuwnN↓, like magomuwlN. (TA in art. gml.)
And gamana fulaAnFA [like gamalahu] He threw his clothes upon such a one, in order that he should sweat. (Ḳ.)
gumina fiI AlOaroDi means Oadoxila fiyhaA [app. It, or perhaps he, was put into the earth; or made to enter into it]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 7. Angmn It, or he, entered [into the earth: see gumina (immediately preceding); of which it is expl. as denoting the consequence]. (Ḳ.)
gumonapN [A mixture of] white lead (UisofiydaAj) and [the cosmetic termed] gumorap [q. v.] with which a woman rubs over her face: (Ḳ:) pl. gumanN [meaning sorts thereof]. (TA.)
gamiynN: see 1, first sentence.
magomuwnN: see 1, second sentence.
