Also, applied to flesh-meat, i. q. magomuwlN, q. v. (TA in art. gml.)
And Palm-trees (naxol) near together; like magomuwlN. (TA.)
1. gamaA Albayota, aor. yagomuwhu, inf. n. gamowN: see 1 in art. gmI.
gamaA in the phrase gamaA waQll-ehi, i. q. OamaA [expl. in art. AmA]; (Ḳ, TA;) as also with E. (TA.)
gamFA; dual gamawaAni: see gamFI in art. gmI.

1. gamayotu Albayota, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. Oagomiyhi, inf. n. gamoIN, (TA,) I roofed the house, or chamber: (Ḳ, TA:) or covered its roof (Ṣ, Ḳ) with earth, &c. (Ḳ) or with reeds, or canes, and earth, and the like: (Ṣ:) and gam-ayotuhu↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) and gamaA Albayota, aor. yagomuwhu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. gamowN, (TA,) signifies he covered [the roof of] the house, or chamber, [in like manner, or] with clay, or earth, and wood. (Ḳ, TA.) And gamaIi AlX-aIoCa He covered the thing. (Ḥar p. 422.)

gumiIa Alyawomu, and All-ayolu, The day, and the night, was constantly clouded, so that the sun was not seen therein nor the new moon: so accord. to Es-Sara- kustee: and he says that faUino OugomiIa↓ Ealayokumo means And if your day be constantly clouded, so that ye see not the new moon, then complete ye [the reckoning of the days of] Shaabán: (Mṣb:) or faUino gum-a Ealayokumo and gumiIa and OugomiIa↓, thus differently related, all mean, and if it, i. e. the new moon, be covered, or concealed: or and if there be a covering [of clouds] over you: (Mgh:) [see also 1 in art. gm:] or OugomiIa↓ yawomunaA means Our day was one whereof the covering of clouds was constant: and Ougomiyato↓ layolatunaA, Our night was one whereof the new moon was veiled, or concealed. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also 4.
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, first sentence.
4: see 1, in four places.

One says also, OugomiIa Ealayohi Alxabaru The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, or vague, to him; such as was difficult to be understood; or such as was not to be understood; like gum-a: (Ṣ:) or was obscure, or unapparent, to him. (Mṣb.)

And OugomiIa Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UigomaMCN; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and gumiIa↓ Elyh; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) said of a sick man, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He swooned, i. e. became senseless, (guXiIa Ealayohi, Ṣ,* Ḳ,) and then recovered his senses: (Ḳ:) or UigomaMCN is a weakness of the faculties by reason of the overpowering effect of disease: (Mgh:) or it is an abstraction, or absence of mind, that overtakes a man, with languor of the limbs, or members, or organs, by reason of a malady; (Mgh, Mṣb;) thus it is defined by the scholastic theologians; and is the same as guXoIN: (Mgh:) or it is a repletion of the venters of the brain with a cold, thick, phlegm; (Mgh, Mṣb;) thus accord. to the physicians, who distinguish between it and guXoIN, as do the lawyers: (Mgh:) [see also guXiIa Ealayohi:] the patient is said to be mugomFI↓ Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mgh, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and magomiI-N↓ Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and gamFI↓, which last epithet is applied to a single person, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to two persons, (Ṣ,) and to a pl. number, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to a female [as well as a male], (Ṣ,) or (if you will, Ṣ) you say humaA gamayaAni and humo OagomaMCN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

fiI Als-amaMCi gamoIN, (Ḳ,) or kaAna EalaI Als-amaMCi gamoIN, (Mṣb,) and gamFI↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) mean [Upon the sky is, or was,] what veiled, or concealed, the new moon: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) not from gum-a: (Ḳ:) this addition in the Ḳ is meant as an indirect slur upon J, for his having mentioned [in this art.] the statement of Fr that one says SumonaA lilogum-aI and lilogam-aI, meaning We fasted when the new moon was veiled, or concealed, to us; and hiIa layolapu Algam-aI [or Algum-aI]; the [proper] place of which is [the section of words whereof the last radical is] m: (TA:) [see gam-N, in that art.: but accord. to Fei,] one says [also], SumonaA lilogumoyapi↓. (Mṣb. [It is there added that this noun is like mudoyap in measure: otherwise I should think that the right reading is lilogum-iy-ap, which has been mentioned voce gam-N.])

hom.sense: gamFI and gimaMCN↓ (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) The roof of a house, or chamber: (T, Ḳ:) or the covering of the roof, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) consisting of earth, &c., (Ḳ,) or consisting of reeds, or canes, and earth, and the like; (Ṣ;) and gamFA also signifies [the same, or] the covering of a house, or chamber, consisting of clay, or earth, and wood: (TA in art. gmw:) the dual [of the first and last] is gamayaAni and gamawaAni: and the pl. is OagomaMCN, (Ḳ, TA,) which is [of the same] like OanoqaMCN pl. of naqFI [and naqFA], (TA,) and OagomiyapN, (Ḳ, TA,) which is of gimaMCN↓. (TA.)
Also, the first, [in the CK, erroneously, gamAC,] A covering that is put upon a horse in order that he may sweat. (ISd, Ḳ.)
See also gamoIN.
And see 4, near the end.

entry.sense: SumonaA lilogumoyapi: see gamoIN.
gimaMCN: see gamFI, in two places.
gaAmiyaMCu One of the entrances to the burrow of the jerboa. (Ḳ.)
mugomFI Ealayohi and magomiI-N Ealayohi: see 4, near the end.

1. gan-a, (MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally ganina, (Mṣb, MF,) [sec. pers. ganinota,] aor. yagin-u, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gun-apN (MA, KL) and gananN, (MA, [and the same seems to be indicated in the Mṣb by its being said that the verb is of the class of taEiba,]) or gan-N, (TḲ, [but this I think a mistake,]) He spoke (MA, Mṣb, KL) in, (MA,) or from, (Mṣb, KL,) or [rather] through, (KL,) his nose, (MA, KL,) or his xayaAXiym [app. here meaning the innermost parts of the air-passages of the nose]. (Mṣb.) [The author of the Ḳ gives no indication of the proper signification of this verb but that of its implying what he states to be meant by gun-apN, which see below.]
See also 4, in two places.
2. gn-nhu, inf. n. tagoniynN, It rendered him Oagan- [q. v.]. (Ḳ.) One says, maA OadoriI maA gan-anahu I know not what rendered him, or has rendered him Oagan-. (TA.)
And gn-n Sawotahu He made his voice to have in it a gun-ap [q. v.]. (Mughnee, art. Harofu Aln-uwni. [See mugan-K, voce gan-aMCN, in art. gnI.])

hom.sense: 4. Agn- said of a man, He made one to hear his gun-ap↓, i. e. soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious, voice, in singing. (Ḥar p. 645.)
Agn- Alc-ubaAbu The flies made a sound [or humming]. (Ḳ.)
Agn-t AlOaroD † The land had its herbs, or herbage, tall, full-grown, or of full height, and in blossom. (TA.)
And Agn- Als-iqaMCu ‡ The skin became filled (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) with water. (Ṣ, TA.)
And [it is also trans.:] one says, Agn- Qll-ehu guSonahu ‡ God made its branch beautiful and bright. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: gun-apN [mentioned above as an inf. n. of gan-a but generally expl. as a simple subst. signifying A sort of nasal sound, or twang:] a sound that comes forth from the nose; (Ḥam p. 339;) a sound (Ṣ, Mṣb) in, (Ṣ,) or that comes forth from, (Mṣb,) the xayoXuwm [app. here meaning the innermost part of the air-passages of the nose]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or a sound from the lahaAp [q. v., app. here meaning the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth,] and the nose, like [that which is heard in the utterance of] the n of minoka and Eanoka, for the tongue has not part in it: (Mgh:) or the flowing [or passage] of the speech in the lahaAp [app. here also meaning as expl. above]: (Ḳ:) or a mixture of the sound of the xayoXuwm [expl. above] in the pronunciation of a letter: (Mbr, TA:) n is that one of the letters in which it is greatest in degree: (Kh, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) xun-apN is [a sound] greater in degree than gun-apN. (TA.)

[Also The roughness of the voice, of a boy, consequent upon the attaining to puberty; or, as Mṭr says,] Algun-apu signifies also what is incident to the boy on the occasion of his attaining to puberty, when his voice becomes rough. (Mgh.)
And A soft, or gentle, plaintive, and melodious, voice, in singing. (Ḥar p. 645.) See 4.

And The sound [or humming] produced by the flying of flies; (TA;) and gunaAnN↓ [likewise] signifies the sound of flies. (Ḳ, TA.) [See mugin-N and Oagan-u. And see also an ex. voce vun-apN: and another voce Eun-apN.]
And the poet Yezeed Ibn-El-Aawar has used it in relation to the sounding of stones: (Ḳ:) [or rather] he has so used the epithet Oagan-↓. (TA.)
EunaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

Oagan-u One who speaks [with a nasal sound, or twang, i. e.] in [or rather through] his nose; (TA;) who speaks from his xayaAXiym [app. here meaning (as expl. before) the innermost parts of the airpassages of the nose]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, accord. to AZ, (Mgh, TA,) whose speech flows, (Mgh, Ḳ,*) or passes forth, (TA,) in his lahaAp [app. (as expl. voce gun-apN) the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth]: (Mgh, Ḳ, TA:) fem. gan-aMCu, applied to a woman. (Mṣb.)

It is also applied to a gazelle (ZaboIN), meaning Whose cry issues from his xayaAXiym [expl. above]: J has erred in saying that it is applied to Tayor [i. e. birds, or flying things]: (Ḳ:) or if by Tyr he mean flies (cubaAbN), his saying thus is not a mistake, for it is applied to them [as meaning making a humming sound]. (TA.)

[Hence,] waAdK Oagan-u † A valley abounding with herbs or herbage: for to such the flies constantly keep, and in their sounds is a gun-ap. (Ṣ. [See also mugin-N.]) And (for this reason, TA) one says rawoDapN gan-aMCu i. e. † [A meadow, or garden,] abounding with herbs or herbage: or in which the winds pass with a sound that is not clear, [i. e. with a confused, humming, or murmuring, sound,] by reason of the denseness of its herbs or herbage. (Ḳ, TA.) And [for the same reason one says] EuXobN Oagan-u † Herbs, or herbage, tall, full-grown, or of full height, and in blossom. (TA.)

And (hence also, Ṣ) qaroyapN gan-aMCu ‡ [A town, or village,] abounding with inhabitants (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and buildings (Ḳ, TA) and herbs or herbage [so that in it is heard the hum of men and women and of flies, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.)
HarofN Oagon-u means A letter from [the utterance of] which results what is termed gun-ap [i. e. the nasal sound thus termed]. (TA.)
See also gun-apN, last sentence.

waAdK mugin-N ‡ A valley in which is [heard] the sound [or humming] of flies; these not being in any valley but such as abounds with herbs or herbage; (Ṣ;) a valley of which the flies are abundant, by reason of the denseness, or luxuriance, of its herbs or herbage, so that a gun-ap [or humming] is heard, produced by their flying: the epithet being applied to it, but being properly applicable to the flies. (TA.) [See also Oagan-u.]

1. ganijato, (Ṣ, A, MA, O, Ḳ;) aor. _a {yagonaju}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gunojN (Ṣ, MA) and ganaAjapN; (MA;) and gunijato; (MA;) and tgn-jt↓; (Ṣ, A, MA, Ḳ;) said of a girl, or young woman, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a woman, (A, MA,) She used amorous gesture or behaviour, or such gesture or behaviour combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition, (Ṣ,* A,* MA, O,* Ḳ,* TA,) and an affecting of languor. (TA.) [See gunojN below.]
5: see the preceding paragraph {1}.

hom.sense: gunojN [mentioned above as an inf. n.] and gunujN↓ (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and gunaAjN↓ and ginaAjN↓, (O, Ḳ,) in a girl, or young woman, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Amorous gesture or behaviour, or such gesture or behaviour combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition, (Bkh, Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ,* TA,) and an affecting of languor: (Bkh, TA:) [in the present day generally used to signify lascivious motion, or a wriggling of the body or hips, under the excitement of sexual passion, or to excite such passion:] accord. to some, beauty of the eyes. (TA.)

And gunojN and ginaAjN↓ signify also Smoke-black (duxaAnu Aln-aWuwri [see the latter of these two nouns in art. nwr] AA, O, Ḳ) which a woman performing the operation of tattooing puts upon her green colour in order that it may become black. (AA, O, TA.)

entry.sense: ganajN An old man: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a man: (TA:) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the saying ganajN EalaI XanajK (TA) meaning A man upon a camel: (Lth, IDrd, O, all in art. Xnj:) or a man or an old man, upon a heavy camel: (L in that art.:) a phrase of the tribe of Hudheyl. (TA.) [See EanajN.]
gunujN: see gunojN.
gunojapu, (O,) or gunajapu, (TA,) without Aalo, and imperfectly decl., (O, TA,) The qunofuc [or hedge-hog], (O,) or the qunofucap [or female hedgehog]. (TA.)

ganijapN (Bkh, Ṣ, A, MA, O, Ḳ) and magonuwjapN↓ (A, MA) and [in an intensive sense] migonaAjN↓, (O, Ḳ) applied to a girl, or young woman, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to a woman, (A, MA,) Using or who uses, amorous gesture or behaviour,, &c., such as is termed gunoj. (Bkh, Ṣ, A, MA, O, Ḳ, TA.)
gunaAjN: see gunojN.
ginaAjN: see gunoj, in two places.
gawonajN A quick, or swift, camel: mentioned by Kr, but said to be not known on the authority of any other. (TA.)

OagonuwjapN A gesture, or an action, of the kind termed gunoj: pl. OagaAniyju: Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
lawaI raOosahu Eani-I wamaAla biwud-ihi
OagaAniyju xawodK kaAna fiynaA yazuwruhaA
[The amorous gestures or actions,, &c., of a soft or tender, or goodly-shaped and young, damsel, whom he used to visit among us, turned his head from me, and diverted his love]. (TA.)
migonaAjN: see ganijapN.
magonuwjapN: see ganijapN.
Algunodubu: see the paragraph here following.

Algunodubapu A hard portion of flesh [app. a gland] around [or app. on either side of] the Huloquwm [which seems to mean here, as it often does, the Haloq, i. e. fauces, or upper part of the throat]; (O, Ḳ;) thus expl. by Lth; as also Algunodubu↓; (O;) or Algunoduwbu↓: (Ḳ:) pl. ganaAdibu: and it is said that the gunodubataAni are [two things] like two ganglions (Xibohu gud-atayoni) in the nakofataAni; (O, Ḳ;) in each nakofap [q. v.] is a gunodubap, and between the gndbtAn is the place of swallowing: (O:) the ganaAdib and the flesh that is upon them, or above them, around the lahaAp [app. here meaning the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth], compose the lagaAniyn [pl. of lugonuwnN, q. v.], which are also called the nagaAnig, pl. of nugonugapN [or nugonugN, q. v.]: (TA:) or the gndbtAn are two glands (EuqodataAni) in, or at, (fiI,) the root of the tongue: (Ḳ, TA:) and they are said to be the two amygdalæ of the fauces; i. e. the tonsils: (All-awozataAni: TA:) or two portions of flesh which are situate on either side of the lahaAp [app. meaning as expl. above, i. e. the arches, or pillars, of the soft palate, or the furthest part of the mouth], (Ḳ, TA,) and between which is a space: (TA:) and gunodubataA AlEuroXayoni is expl. as meaning the two things that conjoin (All-ataAni taDum-aAni) the lagaAniyn [above mentioned (I read AllgAnyn instead of AlEyn, an evident mistranscription in my original, for I can only suppose the description to mean the tonsils, as lodged between, and thus conjoining, the anterior and posterior pillars of the soft palate,)] on the right and left. (TA.)
Algunoduwbu: see the preceding paragraph.

1. ganaZahu, aor. _i {yagoniZu} (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) and _u {yagonuZu}, (TA,) inf. n. ganoZN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) It, (an affair, or event, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and he, (a man, O, TA,) distressed him. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) And It, or he, filled him with wrath. (TA.) And It (anxiety) clave, or kept constantly, to him; as also AgnZhu↓. (TA.) [See also ganoZN below.]
3. gAnZhu, inf. n. ginaAZN, He acted with him contrariously, or adversely, and inimically, each doing to the other that which was distressing, or grievous; syn. XaAq-ahu. (TA.)
4: see the first paragraph {1}.
Q. Q. 1. ganoZaI bihi He reviled him; made him to hear that which was disliked, hated, or abominable; (Ṣ, O;) like EanoZaI bihi. (Ḳ.)

ganoZN [an inf. n.: used as a simple subst.,] Grief, or distress, syn. karobN, (IDrd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) as also ganaZN↓, (IDrd, O,) and maXaq-apN, (TA,) [or] such as is vehement, (TA,) [or] such as is most vehement: (Ṣ, TA:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to IF, (O,) constant anxiety; (O, Ḳ;) as also ganaZN↓: (Ḳ:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to AO, (Ṣ, O,) a man's being at the point of death (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) by reason of distress, or grief, and then escaping therefrom. (Ṣ, O.) It is related of ʼOmar Ibn-ʼAbd-el-'Azeez, that he mentioned death, and said, ganoZN layosa kaAlganoZi wakaZ-N layosa kaAlkaZ-i [i. e. Distress,, &c., that is not like other distress,, &c., and grief,, &c., that is not like other grief,, &c.: see kaZ-N]. (Ṣ, O.) [See also ginaAZN.]
ganaZN: see ganoZN, in two places.
Also A plant's becoming altered [for the worse] by heat. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)
ganaAZN: see an ex. of its dual in the next paragraph.
ginaAZN inf. n. of 3 [q. v.]. (TA.)

And Distress; syn. jahodN, and karobN: El-Fak'asee says, [of a camel,]
tanotaHu ciforaAhu mina AlginaAZi
[His two protuberances behind the ears drip with sweat by reason of distress]. (TA.) [See also ganoZN.] faEala celika ginaAZayoka, as also ganaAZayoka↓, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to Lḥ, ganaAZayoka and EanaAZayoka, with g and E, (TA, [in which it is implied that ginaAZayoka is wrong, but this I think improbable,]) means He did that in order to distress thee time after time; (Ḳ;) like giyaAZaka and giyaAZayoka. (Ḳ in art. gyZ.)

ganiyZN Unripe dates that are cut off from the palm-trees, (AA, O, Ḳ,) after they have become yellow or red, or that are upon the racemes when the fruit of the palm-tree is cut off, (AA, O,) and are left (AA, O, Ḳ) upon the racemes (Ḳ) until they become ripe. (AA, O, Ḳ.)
gan-aAZN an epithet applied by Ru-beh, or by El-ʼAjjáj, to a sword [app. as meaning That causes, or causing, much distress]. (IDrd, O, TA.)

ginoZiyaAnN A man foul, unseemly, or obscene, in speech; (Aṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) coarse, rude, or rough: (O, TA:) or who mocks at, derides, or ridicules, others: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, TA:) and EinoZiyAnN signifies the same: fem. with p {ginoZiyaAnapN}. (O, TA.)
huwa OagonaZuhumo He is the most vehemently grieved, or distressed, of them. (TA.)
magonuwZN Distressed. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also 1, of which it is the pass. part. n.]
rajulN mugaAniZN (Ṣ, O) A man acting, or who acts, with another, contrariously, or adversely, and inimically, each doing to the other that which is distressing, or grievous; syn. muXaAq-N. (O.)

1. ganima, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yagonamu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gunomN (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb,* Ḳ, KL) and ganomN, (Ḳ,) or, as some say, the former is a simple subst. and the latter is an inf. n., (TA,) and ganamN and ganiymapN and gunomaAnN, (Ḳ,) He, or they, (i. e. a man, Mṣb, or a party of men, Ṣ,) obtained, got, or took, (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TḲ,) spoil, (Ḳ,* TḲ,) or a thing [as spoil]. (Mṣb, TA.) [And He acquired, or gained, a thing without difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience: or in this sense the inf. n. is gunomN, which see below, voce ganiymapN.] maA ganimotumo in the Ḳur viii. 42 means What ye take by force [in war] from the unbelievers. (Bḍ, Jel.) [See also 8.]

2. gan-amotuhu, inf. n. tagoniymN, I gave him spoil, or a free and disinterested gift; syn. naf-alotuhu: (Ṣ:) or gan-amahu kacaA, inf. n. as above, he gave him such a thing as spoil, or as a free and disinterested gift; syn. naf-alahu Uiy-aAhu. (Ḳ.)
4. Oagonamahu AlX-aIoCa He made the thing to be to him spoil. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5: see 8.
One says also, huwa yatagan-amu AlOamora, meaning He eagerly desires the affair like as one eagerly desires spoil. (TA.)

And tgn-m, (TA in the present art.,) or tgn-m ganamFA, (AZ, T and TA in art. Abl,) He took for himself, got, gained, or acquired, sheep or goats or both: like as one says tOb-l UibilFA. (AZ, T and TA in art. Abl; and TA * in the present art.)

entry.sense: 8. Agtnmhu, as also tgn-mhu↓, He reckoned it spoil: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or both signify he took, seized, caught, or snatched, it as spoil. (KL.)
And [hence] one says, Agtnm AlfuroSapa He took, or seized, or [availed himself of,] the opportunity; or he hastened to take it; syn. AinotahazahaA. (Ṣ and A and Ḳ in art. nhz.)

hom.sense: gunomN: see ganiymapN, in three places.

It signifies also [The regaining (as is shown by an explanation of AʼObeyd cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. glq), and] the increase, and growth, and excess in value, of a pledge. (O in art. glq, and TA in the present art.) Thus in a trad., in which it is said, Alr-ahonu limano rahanahu lahu gunomuhu waEalayohi guromuhu [The pledge pertains to him who pledged it; to him pertains the regaining of it, and its increase, and growth, and excess in value, if such there be, and upon him lies the obligation to pay the debt for it, without requiring any abatement thereof if the pledge have unavoidably suffered damage or total loss: see the explanation of AʼObeyd mentioned above]. (TA.) Algunomu biAlguromi means The gunom is compensated (muqaAbalN) by the gurom [i. e. the regaining of the pledge, with the increase and the growth and the excess in value thereof if such there be, is compensated by the payment of the debt for it]; for like as the owner [of the pledge] is exclusively entitled to the gunom, no one sharing it with him, so he bears the gurom, no one bearing it with him: and this is the meaning of their saying, Alguromu majobuwrN biAlgunomi [which may therefore be rendered The loss suffered by the payment of the debt is repaired by the regaining of the pledge; app. a phrase of the lawyers, implying that such is to be considered as the case whatever be the state of the pledge at the time of its being restored unless it have suffered damage through the fault of the pledgee]. (Mṣb.) [See more in the first paragraph {1} of art. glq.]
See also gunaAmaAka.
gnm [app. gunomN] is mentioned by Suh as the name of A certain idol. (TA.)

entry.sense: ganamN i. q. XaMCN, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning Sheep and goats; (Mṣb;) [and both together;] a gen. n., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the fem. gender, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to the males and the females, and to both together: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it has no sing. from which it is derived, the sing. being XAp: the dual ganamaAni is used as meaning two flocks or herds [of sheep or of goats or of both together]; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) each flock or herd having its distinct place of pasture and its pastor: (Mṣb, TA:*) and hence it is said in a trad. that the poor-rate [meaning a portion thereof] is to be given to him to whom the year of drought has left a ganam, but not to him to whom it has left ganamayoni: (TA:) the pl. is OagonaAmN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [properly a pl. of pauc.,] sometimes used, (Mṣb,) meaning flocks or herds of ganam, (Mṣb and TA in art. Abl,) and also gunuwmN and OagaAnimu, (Ḳ,) the last used in an ode of Aboo-Jundab El-Hudhalee: (TA:) the dim. is gunayomapN↓, with p, because quasi-pl. ns. of the class having no sing. from which they are derived, when applied to what are not human beings, are constantly fem.; so one says xamosN mina Alganami cukuwrN [five of sheep, males], making the n. of number fem., though one means rams, when it is followed by mina Alganami, for the n. of number is masc. and fem. accord. to the word, not accord. to the meaning. (Ṣ.)

In the saying laA Mtiyka ganama Alfizori i. e. Hat-aI tajotamiEa ganamu Alfizori [I will not come to thee until the sheep, or goats, of El-Fizr congregate], gnm [with its complement] is made to stand in the place of Ald-ahor, [the meaning being, I will not come to thee ever,] and is [therefore] put in the accus. case as though it were an adv. n. [of time]. (TA. [This saying with miEozaI in the place of ganama is mentioned by El-Meydánee in his “Proverbs,” and thus in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. fzr. For an explanation of its origin see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 484.])
AlOagonaAmu is the name of † Certain small stars between the legs of Cepheus and the star AljadoIu. (Ḳzw, in his descr. of Cepheus.) [See XaApN (in art. Xwh), last sentence.]
ganiymN: see what next follows.

ganiymapN and magonamN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and ganiymN↓ and gunomN↓ all signify faIoCN [as meaning Spoil, booty, or plunder]: and the acquisition of a thing without difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience: or this is termed gunomN↓, and faIoCN is termed ganiymapN: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to AʼObeyd, Alganiymapu signifies what is obtained from the believers in a plurality of gods, by force, during war; (Mgh, Mṣb:) and of this, a fifth is to be taken, [and applied in the manner prescribed in the Ḳur viii. 42,] and what remains after the fifth is for those who have obtained it, exclusively; (Mgh;) the horseman having three shares, and the foot-soldier having one share: (Az, TA:) and AlfaIoCu signifies what is obtained from them after the laying-down of arms, (Mgh, Mṣb,) when the country, or place, becomes a country, or place, of Islám; and this is for all of the Muslims, and is not to be divided into fifths: (Mgh:) or the faIoC is what God has given, or restored, of the possessions of the believers in a plurality of gods, to the Muslims, without war, such as the poll-tax, and that for which peace has been made with them; and of this also a fifth is to be applied in the manner prescribed by God, and the remainder is to be expended in the purchase of horses and weapons and other apparatus for the defence of the frontiers: (Az, TA:) and Aln-afalu is what is given to the warrior in addition to his share; and is when the Imám or the commander says, “He who slays one shall have his spoil;” or says to a detachment, “What ye obtain shall be yours,” or “the quarter of it,” or “the half of it;” and it is not divided into fifths; and it lies on the Imám to fulfil the promise: or, accord. to ʼAlee Ibn-ʼEesà, Alganiymapu is more general in signification than Aln-afalu; and AlfaIoCu is more so than Alganiymapu, because it is a name for everything of the possessions of the believers in a plurality of gods that becomes the property of the Muslims: accord. to the lawyers, everything that may be lawfully taken, of their possessions, is faIoC: (Mgh:) the pl. of ganiymapN is ganaAYimu; and the pl. of magonamN↓ is magaAnimu, (Mṣb, TA,) and gunuwmN occurs as pl. of gunomN↓. (TA.) ganiymapN baAridapN see expl. in art. brd.
guniyomapN dim. of ganamN, q. v. (Ṣ.)

gunaAmaAka Oano tafaEala kacaA (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA) means The utmost of thy power, or ability, and of thy case, (Ṣ,* TA,) and that which thou eagerly desirest like as one desires spoil, (Ṣ,* JM, TA,*) [is, or will be, thy doing such a thing;] i. q. quSaAraAka: (Ḳ, TA: [see also EunaAnaAka, in art. En:]) and so gunomuka↓: (TA:) and [in like manner] one says, gunayomaAWuhu↓ Oano yafoEala kacaA, like HusayonaAWuhu, meaning quSaAraAhu [The utmost of his power,, &c.]. (TA in art. Hsn.)
gunayomaAWuhu: see what next precedes.
gaAnimN Taking, or a taker, of ganiymap [or spoil]. (TA.)
See also two exs. voce XaAjibN.
magonamN: see ganiymapN, in two places.

ganamN mugonamapN and mugan-amapN Sheep, or goats, collected together: (TA:) or many or numerous: (Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to AZ, one of these two epithets, thus applied, [probably the latter, like muWab-alapN applied to UibilN, as he seems to say,] signifies [app. divided into distinct flocks or herds,] each [flock or herd] having its own pastor. (TA.)
gunowapN: see the art. here following.

hom.sense:
1. ganiIa, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) from AlmaAl, aor. yagonaI, (Mṣb,) inf. n. ginFI (Ṣ,* MA, Mṣb, Ḳ *) and ganaMCN, (MA, Ḳ,* TḲ, [but the latter is app. held by some to be a simple subst.,]) He was, or became, free from want; in the state, or condition, of having no wants; and also, of having few wants; or in a state of competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy; AlginaI being the contr. of Alfaqoru, as also AlganaMCu; (Ḳ, TA;)
and thus denoting the absence, or non-existence, of wants, which is [properly, or strictly speaking,] attributable to none but God; and also the paucity of wants; (TA;) or syn. with AlyasaAru: (Ṣ:) and the epithet applied to him of whom this is said is ganiI-N↓, (Ṣ:) or gaAnK↓, (Mṣb,) [or both, for] both signify the same [as will be shown below]. (Ḳ.) One says ganiIa and AstgnI↓ and tgn-I↓ and tgAnI↓ and AgtnI↓, (Ḳ, TA, [but wanting in the CK, and app. in several copies of the Ḳ, though it is said in one place in the Ḳ, as it is in the Ṣ, that tgn-I is syn. with AstgnI,]) all having one and the same meaning, and followed by bihi [as therewith signifying He was, or became, free from want; in the state, or condition, of having no want, or need; or in a state of competence,, &c.; by means of it, or him; i. e. he was, or became, sufficed by it, or him; and hence, he was, or became, content, or satisfied, with it, or him]. (TA.) layosa min-aA mano lamo yatagan-a↓ biAlquroMni, (Mṣb, TA,) a saying of the Prophet, (Mṣb,) mentioned in a trad., (TA,) means yasotagoni↓ mn lm [i. e. He is not of us who is not content, or satisfied, with the Ḳur-án]: so says Sufyán Ibn-'Oyeyneh; not regarding it as meaning the utterance of the voice [in chanting]: and AʼObeyd says that this obtains extensively in the speech of the Arabs; that they say tagan-ayotu↓ and tagaAnayotu↓ in the sense of Aisotagonayotu↓. (Az, Mṣb, TA.) And one says, ganiIa Eanohu, inf. n. ginFI and gunoyaAnN, meaning He was in no need of it [or him]: as also AstgnI↓ Enh; and OagonaI↓ Enh [which seems to be rarely used in this sense]: and gunoyapN↓ signifies the state of being in no need: and gaAnK↓, a man free from need. (MA.) [And maA yasotagoniI↓ Eanohu He is not without need, or not free from want, of it, or him.] And ganiIa bihi Eanohu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. Eano gayorihi, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gunoyapN, (Ṣ,) or gunoyapN↓ is the subst., (Mṣb,) meaning AstgnI↓ [He was sufficed by it, or was satisfied, or content, with it, so as to be in no need, or so as to be free from want, of it, i. e. of another thing]: and the epithet is ganiI-N↓. (Mṣb.) And [in like manner] ganiyati AlmaroOapu bizawojihaA (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) Eano gayorihi, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gunoyaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and ganaMCN also, (TA,) meaning Aisotagonat↓ [The woman was satisfied, or content, with her husband, so as to have no want of other than him]. (Ṣ, Ḳ) And ganiyato [alone], (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. ginFA [for ginFI, or perhaps a mistranscription for ganaMCN, as in the next preceding sentence], She (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed gaAniyapN [q. v. voce gaAnK]. (Ḳ.)

ganiIa, (TḲ,) inf. n. ginFI, (Ḳ, TḲ,) also signifies He married, or took a wife; [as also tgn-I↓; (see Ḥam p. 226 l. 1, where tagan-ato occurs said of a woman as meaning she married;)] syn. tazaw-aja. (Ḳ,* TḲ. [In the Ḳ, only the inf. n. of the former verb in this sense is mentioned; AlginaI being there expl. in some copies as signifying Alt-azaw-uju; and in others, Alt-azowiyju.]) Hence the saying, AlginaI HiSonN liloEazabi [Marriage is a bulwark to him who has no wife; protecting him from the attacks of seductive women by rendering him free from the want of them]: mentioned by Az. (TA.)

Also, ganiIa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. ginFI, (TA,) He dwelt, or abode, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) biAlmakaAni in the place: (Ṣ:) or ganiIa Alqawomu fiI daArihimo The people, or party, dwelt long in their place of abode: (T, TA:) or ganiIa fiI makaAni kacaA He dwelt long in such a place, satisfied, or content, therewith, so as to be in no need of any other. (Er-Rághib, TA.) kaOano lamo yagonawoA fiyhaA, in the Ḳur [vii. 90 and xi. 71 and 98], means As though they had not dwelt therein. (TA.) [See also the last sentence but two in this paragraph.]
And He lived; syn. EaAXa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And I. q. baqiIa: (TA:) one says, ganiytu laka min-iI biAlmawad-api, meaning baqiytu [i. e. I remained, or have remained, constant to thee with my love, or affection]. (ISd, Ḳ, TA: in the CK [erroneously] ganayotu.)

[And I. q. kaAna.] qado OagonaI AlHabiyba AlmuSaAfiIa, in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil, means Oakuwnu AlHabiyba [i. e. Certainly I will be, or shall be, the sincere friend]. (TA.) And ganiyato daArunaA tihaAmapa, (Ḳ, TA,) in a verse of another poet, (TA,) means kaAnato [i. e. Our place of abode was Tihámeh]. (Ḳ, TA.) And one says of a thing when it has perished, passed away, or come to nought, kaOano lamo yagona biAlOamosi, meaning kaOano lamo yakuno [i. e. As though it had not been in existence yesterday]. (Az, TA.)

ganiIa also signifies laqiIa: (Ḳ:) [SM doubts this; saying,] thus in the copies; but perhaps it should be baqiIa, a signification of ganiIa accord. to ISd and the Ḳ [and mentioned above]: (TA:) [it appears, however, to be correct; for it is said that] maA ganiytu fulaAnFA means lamo Oaloqahu [i. e. I did not meet, or meet with, or find, or I have not met,, &c., such a one]. (JK.) [Accord. to the TḲ, ganiIa followed by bihi signifies laqiI: but this is perhaps said conjecturally.]
2: see 4.

gn-I, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb,) inf. n. tagoniyapN, (KL,) as syn. with tgn-I↓, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb,*) He sang, or chanted, (Ṣ,* MA, KL;) or he trilled, or quavered, or prolonged his voice and modulated it sweetly, singing, or chanting. (Mṣb in explanation of the former.) You say gn-Ahu AlX-iEora [He sang, or chanted, to him the poetry], and gn-I bihi [he sang, or chanted, it, i. e., the poetry], inf. n. tagoniyapN; and tgn-I↓ bihi; tgn-I and gn-I having one and the same meaning. (Ḳ, TA.) yatagan-aI↓ biAlquroMni, in a trad. cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. Acn, means, as expl. by EshSháfi'ee, Reciting [or chanting] the Ḳur-án with a plaintive and gentle voice. (Az, Mṣb, TA. [See also that trad. somewhat differently related voce taran-ama.])
gn-I is also said of a pigeon, meaning It [cooed, or] uttered a cry; (Ḳ, TA;) and so tgn-I↓. (TA.)

gn-I biAlmaroOapi means tagaz-ala bihaA, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. He mentioned the woman [in amatory language, as an object of love,] in his poetry: (TA:) and gn-I bizayodK He eulogized Zeyd: or he satirized him: like tgn-I↓ in these two senses: (Ḳ, TA:) in that of eulogizing and that of satirizing: or, in the opinion of ISd, both of the verbs are used in these two senses and likewise in the sense mentioned immediately before them; meaning that he did thus after prolonging and modulating his voice; singing, or chanting, the same, i. e. the gazal and the eulogy and the satire. (TA.)
3: see ganaMCN. [From what is there said, it seems that gAnAhu signifies He was in no need of him, or it; like ganiIa Eanohu and AstgnI Enh: compare tagaAnawoA.]

[And app. it signifies also He spoke, or talked, to him, i. e. to a child, or boy, saying to him what was pleasing to him; for it is said that] AlmugaAnaApu means takoliymuka AlS-abiI-a bimaA yahowaI. (JK.)

4. AgnAhu He (i. e. God, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [but wanting in the CK and app. in several copies of the Ḳ,]) rendered him, or made him to be, in no need, or free from want; (Ṣ,* MA, Ḳ;*) [or in a state of competence, or sufficiency;] or possessed of wealth; (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA;) [or rich, or wealthy; (see 1, first sentence;)] and gn-Ahu↓ signifies the same; (Ḳ, TA; [but wanting in the CK and app. in several copies of the Ḳ;]) or, as some say, this latter is [used] in prayer [app. as meaning he said to him, May God enrich thee, or the like: compare saq-ayotuhu (“I said to him, May God send down rain to thee”), and Eaq-arotuhu (as expl. in art. Eqr), &c.]. (TA.) [And AgnAhu Eano kacaA He, or it, caused him to be in no need, or free from want, of such a thing. (See Ḥam p. 152.) And yugoniI Eano Oano tafoEala kacaA It renders needless thy doing such a thing: lit. it causes that there shall be no need of thy doing such a thing.]

And AgnI Eanohu kacaA Such a thing sufficed him; or stood him in stead: whence the saying in the Ḳur [lxix. 28], maA OagonaIEan-iI maAliyaho [My property has not sufficed me, or stood me in stead]: and [in iii. 8 and lviii. 18 of the same,] lano tugoniIa Eanohumo OamowaAluhumo [Their possessions will not suffice them in lieu of God]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or this last means, will not defend them from God, i. e. from his punishment. (Jel in iii. 8.) And Oagonayotu Eanoka magonaI↓ fulaAnK and magonaAtahu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and mugonaI↓ fulaAnK and mugonaAtahu↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and ganaMCa↓ fulaAnK, (Ḳ,) I sufficed, or satisfied, or contented, thee, or I have sufficed,, &c., as such a one; or I stood thee, or served thee, or I have stood, &c., in the stead of such a one. (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And maA yugoniI Eanoka hecaA This does not suffice, or satisfy, or content, thee; or stand thee, or serve thee, in any stead; and does not avail, or profit, thee. (Ṣ.)
AZ mentions maA OagonaI fulaAnN XayoYFA, thus, and with E, [i. e. OaEonaI,] as meaning Such a one did not avail, or profit, at all, in a difficult, or an arduous, affair or case; and did not suffice for such an affair or such a case, or for the supply of what was necessary for subsistence. (Mṣb, TA.) And he says also that he heard a man chide his slave, and say to him, Oagoni Ean-iI wajohaka balo Xar-aka, meaning Free me from, and avert from me, [thy face, nay, rather,] thy evil, or mischief: and hence the phrase XaOonN yugoniyhi, [respecting which see the second sentence in art. EnI,] in the Ḳur [lxxx. 37]. (TA.) [Hence also,] wamaA OugoniI Eanokumo mina Qll-ehi mino XaIoCK, in the Ḳur xii. 67, means But I do not avert from you, by my saying this, anything decreed to befall you from God: the second mn is redundant. (Jel.) And one says, Oagoni Ean-iI kacaA, meaning Put thou away from me, and remove far from me, such a thing: properly [OagoniniI Eano kacaA, originally meaning render thou me in no need of such a thing,] a phrase of the same kind as EaraDa Ald-aAb-apa EalaI AlmaMCi [for EaraDa AlmaMCa EalaI Ald-aAb-api]. (Mgh.)
OagonaI Eanohu as intrans.: see 1, former half.

maA OagonaAhu [How free from wants, or how rich, or wealthy, is he!]: this and maA Oafoqarahu are [said to be] anomalous; for their [respective] verbs are AstgnI and Aftqr, from either of which the verb of wonder may not properly [or regularly] be formed. (Ṣ in art. fqr. [But see ganiIa as syn. with AstgnI; and see also art. fqr.])
5: see 1, former half, in three places:
and again {1} in the latter half:
and see also 2, in five places.

entry.sense: 6: see 1, former half, in two places.

tagaAnuwoA means They were, or became, free from want, one of another, or, as we say, of one another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) El-Mugheereh Ibn-Habnà says,
kilaAnaA ganiI-N↓ Eano Oaxiyhi HayaAtahu
wanaHonu UicaA mutonaA OaXad-u tagaAniyaA
[Each of us is free from want of his brother in his life-time; and when we die, we shall be more free from such want]. (Ṣ.)
8: see 1, second sentence.

hom.sense: 10: see 1, in seven places.

AstgnI Qll-eha He asked, or begged, God to render him, or make him to be, in no need, or free from want; [or in a state of competence, or sufficiency;] or rich, or wealthy. (Ḳ, TA. [But wanting in the CK, and app. in several copies of the Ḳ.]) Hence the prayer, Aall-ehum-a Uin-iIa Oasotagoniyka Eano kul-i HaArimK waOasotaEiynuka [O God, I ask Thee to render me in no need of any one who refuses to give, and I beg thine aid]. (TA.)

entry.sense: ganFI, (Ḳ, TA,) with fet-ḥ, and maqoSuwr, (TA,) i. q. maYin-apN; so in the saying, makaAnu kacaA ganFI mino fulaAnK [Such a place is meet, fit, or proper, for such a one; as though meaning a place of freedom from want]; as also magonFI↓ minohu. (Ḳ, TA.)

ginFI and ganaMCN↓ signify the same; (MA, Ḳ;) both are inf. ns. of ganiIa: (MA:) [see the first sentence of this art.: used as simple substs., they mean Freedom from need or want; competence, or sufficiency; or richness, or wealthiness:] or ginFI is the inf. n. of ganiIa; (Mṣb;) and ganaMCN↓ signifies competence, or sufficiency; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as in the saying, layosa Einodahu ganaMCN He has not competence, or sufficiency: (Mṣb:) or ganaMCN signifies profit, utility, or avail; (Ṣ;) and you say, rajulN laA ganaMCa Einodahu meaning A man who is not profitable to any one: (TA voce dadaAnN; [and in like manner this phrase, occurring in the Ṣ voce dadaAnN, is expl. in the PṢ:]) and gunowapN↓ signifies the same as ginFI in the saying liI Eanohu gunowapN [I have no need of it, or him]: (Ḳ and TA in art. gnw:) so says Ks: but, as ISd says, the word commonly known is gunoyapN↓; (TA in that art.;) which see in two places in the former half of the first paragraph of this art.: this last word [said in the Ṣ to be an inf. n.] and ginoyapN↓ and gunowapN↓ and gunoyaAnN↓ [which is said in the Ṣ and in one place in the Ḳ to be an inf. n.] are substs. having one and the same meaning [syn. with ginFI used as a simple subst.]: and maA lah Eanohu ginFI [in the CK erroneously ganFI] and gunoyapN↓ and gunoyaAnN↓ and magonFI↓ mean [lit. He has not freedom from need of it, or him; and hence,] he has not any means, or way, of separating himself from, or avoiding, it, or him; syn. bud-N: (Ḳ:) and one says fiI Aln-ikaAHi gunoyapN↓ Eani Als-ifaAHi [In marriage is freedom from need of fornication]. (A and Mṣb in art. sfH.) maA kaAna Eano Zahori ginFI, in a trad. respecting alms, means What is over and above that which suffices for the sustenance of the household, or family. (TA.)
gunowapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
gunoyapN and ginoyapN: see ginFI; the former in three places.
gunoyaAnN: see ginFI, latter half, in two places.

ganaMCN: see ginFI, in two places; and see also 4, former half. A poet says,
sayugoniyniI Ql-aciI OagonaAka Ean-iI
falaA faqorN yaduwmu walaA ganaMCu
[He will render me free from need who has rendered thee free from need of me: for poverty will not always continue, nor competence, or richness]: or, as some relate it, ginaMCu, meaning thereby the inf. n. of gaAnayotu↓: [see 3, above:] but it is said that the proper reading is ganaMCu; because this has no other meaning than that of ginFI: so says ISd. (TA.)
maA fiyhi ganaMCu caAka means There is not in him [ability for] the setting-up of that, and strength, or power, to bear it, or carry it, or to raise it upon his back and rise with it. (ISd, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: ginaMCN is an inf. n. of 3. (TA, [See the next preceding paragraph.])

Also, (TA,) [Song, or vocal music; i. e.] an utterance of the voice with a prolonging and a sweet modulation thereof; (Ḳ, TA;) or a raising of the voice, and continuing it without interruption; (Nh, TA;) [a singing, and a chanting;] it is said in the Ṣ to be mina Als-amaAEi [meaning that it is a sort of musical performance]: (TA:) being an utterance of the voice, its analogical form would be with damm [i. e. gunaMCN, like HudaAdN, &c.]: (Mṣb, TA:) its pl. is OagoniyapN: (MA:) [and magonFI↓ signifies the same as ginaMCN; and a mode of singing; and any particular air, or tune; and a song, i. e. a composition in verse that is sung or to be sung: and its pl. is magaAnK: but perhaps it is post-classical: the pl. occurs in the Ḳ, in art. nSb:] ginaMCN [also] signifies [a song, i. e.] poetry, or verse, that is [sung, or chanted, or] uttered with a trilling, or quavering, or a prolonging and a sweet modulation, of the voice; (Ḥar p. 286;) and Ougoniy-apN↓ is syn. with ginaMCN (Ṣ, Ḥar) in this sense; (Ḥar;) or, as also Uigoniy-apN↓, (Fr, Ḳ, TA,) and ↓each of them also without teshdeed, (Ḳ, TA,) as mentioned by ISd, but said by him to be not of valid authority, (TA,) signifies a certain sort of ginaMC (Ḳ, TA) which they sing or chant: (TA:) and the pl. is OagaAniI-u (Ṣ, TA) [and OagaAnK, this latter being the pl. of each sing. that is without teshdeed].

AlginaMC is also used by a poet in the place of an inf. n., meaning Alt-agan-iI: he says,
tagan-i biAlX-iEori Uim-aA kunota qaAYilahu
Uin-a AlginaMCa bhecaA AlXiEori miDomaAru
[Sing thou, or chant thou, the poetry, if thou be uttering it: verily the singing, or chanting, this poetry is a mDmAr (expl. in art. Dmr)]. (TA.)

entry.sense: ganiI-N and gaAnK↓: see 1, former half; each in two places: both signify [Free from want; or in a state of competence, or sufficiency; or rich, or wealthy; or] possessing much property or wealth: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. of the former OagoniyaMCu. (Mṣb, TA.) See an ex. of the former in a verse cited above, conj. 6. One says, OanaA ganiI-N bikacaA Eano gayorihi [I am sufficed by such a thing, or satisfied, or content, with it, so as to be free from want of another thing]. (Mṣb.)
AlganiI-u as a name of God signifies [The Self-sufficient; i. e.] He who has no need of any one in any thing. (TA.)

gan-aMCN A singer; (MA;) [as also mugan-K↓; and mugan-iyapN a female singer, a songstress:] accord. to Ibn-Ya'eesh, a mugan-K↓ is thus called liOan-ahu yugan-inu Sawotahu, i. e. because he makes his voice to have in it a gun-ap [or sort of nasal sound, or twang]; the word being, in his opinion, originally, mugan-inN, with three n, the last of which is changed into I, when one says Almugan-iI, for the purpose of alleviating the utterance. (Mughnee, art. Harofu Aln-uwni.)
gaAnK: see ganiI-N.

[The fem.] gaAniyapN signifies A young woman who is sufficed by her husband; or satisfied, or content, with him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,*) so as to be in no need, or free from want, of any other: (Mṣb:) and sometimes, also, applied to a woman, (Ṣ,) such as is sufficed by her beauty, (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ, TA,) so as to be in no need of decoration (ISd, Ḳ, TA) with women's ornaments: (ISd, TA:) or such as is sought, or desired, by men, but does not seek, or desire: (ISd, Ḳ,* TA:) or such as has abode in the house, or tent, of her father and mother, and whom captivity (sibaMC) has not befallen; (IJ, ISd, Ḳ,* TA;) which is the strangest of the explanations: (TA:) or such as is youthful and chaste, whether having a husband or not: (ISd, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to AO, one that is married: (Ḥam p. 226:) or, accord. to Az, such as pleases men, and is pleased by XabaAb [which means both youthfulness and youths or young men]: (TA:) pl. gawaAnK; (Ḳ;) with the article, AlgawaAniI; [and also gaAniyaAtN: (see an ex. in a verse cited in the second paragraph {1} of art. zj:)] in the saying of Ibn-Er-Rukeiyát,
laA baAraka Qll-ehu fiI AlgawaAniIi halo
yuSobiHona Uil-aA lahun-a muT-alabu
[May God not bless those young women that are sufficed by their husbands, or by their beauty,, &c.: do they enter upon the time of dawn without their having desire (lit. a time or place, meaning an occasion, of seeking, or desire)], the I is made movent by a poetic license: (Ṣ, TA:) and another poet uses AlgawaAni for AlgawaAniI. (TA.)
OagonaMCN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] The OamolaAkaAt [meaning Goods and chattels, or paraphernalia,] of brides. (Az, Ḳ.)
Ougoniy-apN and Uigoniy-apN, and each of them also without teshdeed: see ginaMCN, latter half.

hom.sense: magonFI: see 4, former half:
and ganFI:
and ginFI, near the end.

Also A place in which were its occupants, or inhabitants: (Ṣ:) or a place of abode by which its occupants, or inhabitants, were sufficed, or with which they were satisfied, or content, and from which they then departed, or removed: or in a general sense; (Ḳ, TA;) a place of abode, absolutely; but this seems to be a distinct application: (TA:) pl. magaAnK; with the article, AlmagaAniI. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also ginaMCN.

entry.sense: mugonFI: see 4, former half.
mugonK [act. part. n. of 4,] A man sufficing, or satisfying, or contenting. (TA.)
AlmugoniI as a name of God signifies He who satisfies, or contents, whom He will, of his servants. (TA.)
And mugoniyapN A woman who satisfies, or contents, her husband, so as to render him in no need of looking at other than her. (Ḥar p. 451.)
magonaApN and mugonaApN: see 4, former half.

1. gahiba, [aor. _a {yagohabu},] inf. n. gahabN, He was unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless. (Ṣ.) You say, gahiba Eanohu He was unmindful,, &c., and forgetful, of him, or it; (Ḳ, TA;) as also Aghb↓. (TA.) And OaSaAba SayodFA gahabFA He hit an object of the chase, or objects thereof, inadvertently, unintentionally. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ, from a trad.)
And gahibahu He was ignorant of it; as also Eahibahu. (TA in art. Ehb.)
4: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
8. Agthb He (a man, TA) journeyed in the darkness: (Ḳ, TA:) and went far away therein. (TA.)
gihib-aI AlX-abaAbi and gihib-aAWuhu, and likewise with the unpointed E, The first part, or state, of youth. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: gayohabN Darkness; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also gayohabaAnN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former gayaAhibu. (Ṣ.)

And A horse, and night, intensely black: (Ḳ, TA:) or, instead of waAll-ayoli in the Ḳ, we may read waAll-ayolu; so that the meaning may be, a horse intensely black: and night: agreeably with the A, in which this latter meaning [as well as the former] is assigned to the word; and it is added that one says, OaHosanu mino bayaADi Alkawokabi fiI sawaAdi Algayohabi [More beautiful than the whiteness of the star in the blackness of night]: (TA:) or it signifies intense blackness of the night and of a camel and the like: you say jamalN gayohabN a deep-black camel: (Lth, TA:) and also Oasowadu gayohabN and gayohamN: (Lḥ, TA:) and rajulN gayohabN a black man; likened to the darkness of night: and layolN gayohabN a dark night: (Sh, TA:) and farasN Oadohamu gayohabN a horse intensely black: (Sh, Ṣ, TA:) and it is said in “the Book of Horses” by AʼObeyd that Oadohamu gayohabiI-N↓ signifies [a horse] of the deepest black hue: that the fem. is gayohabapN; and the pl., gayaAhibu: and that dajuwjiI-N is less than gayohabN in blackness, signifying “of a clear black hue.” (TA.)

Also, applied to a man, Unmindful, negligent, inattentive, inadvertent, inconsiderate, or heedless: (Ḳ, TA:) and weak, and timid: (TA:) or (Ḳ, TA, but in the CK “and,”) a heavy, troublesome man: or stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence; or inert, or wanting in vigour. (Ḳ, TA.) And Lacking ability to seek his blood-revenge, or retaliation; as also EayohabN. (TA in art. Ehb.)
And A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC having much wool; very woolly; (Ḳ, TA;) as also EayohabN. (TA.)
And A male ostrich. (R, TA.)

entry.sense: gayohabapN A clamour, or confused noise, (Ḳ, TA,) and commotion, (TA,) in fight, or conflict. (Ḳ, TA.)
gayohabiI-N: see gayohabN.

hom.sense: gayohabaAnN: see gayohabN.
Also The belly. (Ḳ.)

1. gawaI, aor. yagowiI, inf. n. gaI-N (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) and gawaAyapN; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA;) [respecting which latter see what follows;] and gawiIa (AʼObeyd, Ḳ, TA, but not in the CK,) but this is not commonly known, (TA,) aor. yagowaI, inf. n. gawFI, (AʼObeyd, TA,) accord. to the M and Ḳ gawaAyapN, mentioned above as of gawaI, (TA,) or this last, which is with fet-ḥ, (Mṣb,) not to be pronounced with kesr, (Ḳ,) is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) He erred; deviated from the right way or course, or from that which was right: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and was disappointed; or failed of attaining his desire: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and he laboured, and persisted, (IAth, Mṣb, TA,) in that which was vain, or false, (IAth, TA,) or in ignorant conduct: (Mṣb:) or he acted ignorantly from misbelief. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

gawiIa, aor. yagowaI; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and gawaI, aor. yagowiI; (Ḳ;) inf. n. [of the former] gawFI; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said of a young camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of a lamb or kid, (Ṣ,) He suffered indigestion from the milk; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. (TA) he drank the milk until he suffered indigestion; and his belly, or chest, became in a corrupt state; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* TA;) or he drank much thereof, so that he suffered indigestion: (TA:) or, accord. to ISk, (Ṣ, TA,) he did not satisfy his thirst with the biestings of his mother, (Ṣ,) or he did not drink thereof, (TA,) nor satisfy his thirst with the milk [after it], so that he died of emaciation: (Ṣ, TA:) or he (a kid, AZ, TA) was withheld from sucking (AZ, Ḳ, TA) until hunger injured him (AZ, TA) so that he became emaciated, (AZ, Ḳ, TA,) and almost perished: (Ḳ:) or he obtained not sufficient milk to satisfy his thirst so that he almost perished: (T, TA:) or, said of a child, and of a young camel, he found not a sufficiency of milk, so that he did not satisfy his thirst, and was seen to be meagre, or emaciated; thus accord. to ISh; and Sh says that his companions held this to be the correct meaning: (TA:) the epithet applied to the young camel [&c.] is gawK↓. (Ḳ.) Z has mentioned the reading in the Ḳur [xx. 119], waEaSaI Mdamu rab-ahu fagawiIa, expl. as meaning [And Adam disobeyed his Lord, and] suffered indigestion from much eating: but better than this is what Az and Er-Rághib say; that it is fagawaI; and that the meaning is, and his life became evil to him; or he was disappointed; or he acted ignorantly; or some other of the meanings mentioned by the expositors. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

gaw-ayotu All-abana, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. tagowiyapN, (TA,) I made the milk to become such as is termed raAYib [i. e. thick, or coagulated,, &c.]; (Ḳ, TA;) as though I spoiled it, so that it became thick. (TA.)

4. AgwAhu; (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and gw-Ahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tagowiyapN; (TA;) and gawaAhu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) mentioned by El-Muärrij; (TA;) [but] accord. to Aṣ, one should not say otherwise than AgwAhu; (Ṣ, TA;) He caused him to err; or to deviate from the right course, or from that which was right: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and caused him to be disappointed; or to fail of attaining his desire: (Ṣ:)
or he seduced him, misled him, or led him astray; as also AstgwAhu↓. (MA.) A poet, cited by El-Muärrij, says,
wakaAYino taraI mino jaAhilK baEoda Eilomihi
gawaAhu↓ AlhawaI jaholFA Eani AlHaq-i faQnogawaI↓
[How many an ignorant dost thou see, whom, after his knowledge, love, or desire, has urged to turn, in ignorance, from that which was right, and who has turned: or has turned, in ignorance, from that which was right, and who has suffered himself to be turned; for,] accord. to Az, gawaAhu AlhawaI is most correctly rendered as meaning lawaAhu, and Sarafahu; and AngwI is quasi-pass. thereof. (TA.) The saying in the Ḳur [vii. 15], related as from Iblees, fabimaA OagowayotaniI means [Then by, or because of,] thy having caused me to err: or, as some say, invited me to [do] a thing whereby I have erred. (TA.) But the saying in the same [xi. 36], Uino kaAna Qll-ehu yuriydu Oano yugowiyakumo is said to mean If God desire to punish you for erring: or to decree, against you, your erring [i. e. that ye shall err]. (TA.)

6. tagaAwawoA Ealayohi They collected themselves together, or combined, and aided one another, against him; (Ṣ, TA;) originally, (TA,) in an evil affair; from AlgaI- and AlgawaAyap: (Ṣ, TA:) or they aided one another against him, and slew him; (Ḳ;) but this addition “and slew him” is from a trad. respecting the slaying of ʼOthmán, in which it is said, fatagaAwawoA Ealayohi waQll-ehi Hat-aI qataluwhu [and they collected themselves together,, &c., against him, by God, so that they slew him]: (TA:) or they came against him from this quarter and from that; though they did not slay him: (ISd, Ḳ, TA:) or they collected themselves together, and aided one another, against him, as do those who err, or deviate from the right way or course; thus expl. by Z. (TA.) [See also 6 in arts. gI and Ew.]

7. AngwI signifies AinohawaI and maAla [app. He declined from the right way or course; for all of these three verbs seem to be here used in one and the same sense, agreeably with a saying in the JK, AlmunogawiI Xibohu AlmunohawiI AlmaAYilu]: (Ḳ:) [or rather,] accord. to Az, [it signifies he was, or became, or suffered himself to be, made to decline, or to turn, from the right way or course, by love, or desire; for he says that] it is quasi-pass. of gawaAhu AlhawaI, which signifies OamaAlahu and Sarafahu: (TA:) or he fell into error by yielding to love and desire. (TḲ: there given as the meaning of the explanation in the Ḳ.) See also 4.
10: see 4, first sentence.
R. Q. 2. R. Q. 2. if belonging to art. gw, or Q. Q. 2 if belonging to art. gwg. tagaAgaI Ealayohi AlgawogaMCu [as though originally tagawogaI]: see art. gwg.
gawFI Thirst. (TA.)

And one says, bit-u gawFI, and gawiy-FA↓, and mugowiyFA↓, (Ḳ, TA,) in the T mugaw-FI↓, (TA,) [in the CK magowiy-FA,] meaning muxoliyFA (Ḳ, TA) [in the CK muxal-ayFA] muwHiXFA (TA) [i. e. I passed the night empty]: and so qawiyFA, and qaAwiyFA, and muqowiyFA. (TA.) [See also gawiI-N.]

hom.sense: gawK: see gaAwK:
and see also 1, near the end.

entry.sense: gaI-N is an inf. n.; as also gawaAyapN↓; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, &c.; [see 1, first sentence;]) or the latter is a simple subst.: (Mṣb:) [both, used as substs., signify Error;, &c.: gay-apN↓, of which the pl. (gay-aAtN) is mentioned by Freytag as meaning errors, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, is an inf. n. of un., and signifies an error,, &c.:] and gaI-N signifies also a state of perdition. (Ḥam p. 643.) See also gay-apN.

Also A certain valley in Hell: or a river [therein]: (Ḳ, TA:) prepared by God for those who err: it is said that it has one or the other of these meanings in the Ḳur xix. 60: (TA:) or it there means † punishment; because it is the consequence of gaI- [properly thus termed]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it there means evil: or the recompense of gaI- [i. e. of error]: or deviation from the way of Paradise. (Bḍ.)
gaw-apN: see the next paragraph.
gay-apN: see gaI-N. gaw-apN↓ and gay-apN signify the same.

[Hence,] waladu gay-apK, and giy-apK↓, (Ḳ, TA,) but the latter is said by Lḥ to be rare, (TA,) The offspring of fornication or adultery; (Ḳ, TA;) contr. of waladu riXodapK. (TA.) And one says also Aibonu AlgaI-i↓ [meaning The son of fornication or adultery]. (L in art. bhv.) And huwa ligay-apK, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and ligiy-apK↓, said in reviling a person, He is, or was, unlawfully begotten; (Mṣb;) contr. of liriXodapK. (Ṣ.)
giy-apN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: gawiI-N: see gaAwK:
and see also gawFI. You say of a hungry person, raOayotuhu gawiy-FA mina AljuwoEi [I saw him empty, or lean, from hunger]; like as one says qawiyFA and DawiyFA [or DaAwiyFA] and TawiyFA. (TA.)

entry.sense: gawaAyapN: see gaI-N, above.
gay-aAnu [as though originally gawoyaAnu]: see what next follows.

gaAwK, and gawiI-N↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and gawK↓, (Ṣ, TA,) and gay-aAnu↓, (Ḳ,) [or the first is an act. part. n., and the others are intensive epithets,] Erring; deviating from the right way or course, or from that which is right: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining his desire: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) [&c.: (see 1, first sentence:)] and the first signifies also perishing: (Ḥam p. 643:) the pl. of the first is guwaApN, (Mṣb, TA,) like quDaApN pl. of qaADK, (Mṣb,) and gaAwawna. (Ḳ.) AlgaAwuwna in the saying waQlX-uEaraMCu yat-abiEuhumu AlgaAwuwna [in the Ḳur xxvi. 224] means The devils: or those, of mankind, who err: (Ḳ, TA:) or those who love the poet when he satirizes a people, or party, (Zj, Ḳ, TA,) by saying that which is not allowable: (Zj, TA:) or those who love him for his praising them for that which is not in them. (Zj, Ḳ, TA.)

And AlgaAwiI signifies The locust, or locusts collectively: (Ḳ, TA:) one says, jaMCa AlhaAwiI waAlgaAwiI, meaning The wolf and the locust, or locusts, came: (TA:) so says IAạr. (TA in art. hwI, where, in the Ḳ, AlhaAwiI is said to signify “the locust” or “locusts.”)
raOosN gaAwK is a tropical phrase, meaning, accord. to the Ḳ, A small head: but accord. to the A, a head that turns, or looks, aside, much, or often. (TA.)
gaAwiyapN i. q. raAwiyapN, (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA,) [as meaning] A camel that carries water: pl. gawaAyaA: [the sing. and pl. being] like zaAwiyapN and zawaAyaA. (JK.)
gaAgN and gaAgapN, the latter mentioned in the Ḳ in this art. as meaning A certain plant: see art. gwg.
gawogaMCN and gawogaMCu: see art. gwg.

Ougowiy-apN A [pitfall such as is termed] zuboyap; (Ḳ, TA;) or a hollow, or pit, dug in the ground, like a zuboyap, for the wolf, and in which a kid is put; and when he [the wolf] looks at it, he falls, desiring to obtain it, and so is taken: (TA:) and mugaw-aApN↓ [likewise] signifies a zuboyap, (TA,) or a hollow, or pit, dug in the ground, like a zaboyap, (Ṣ,) for [catching] beasts of prey: (TA:) whence the saying, (Ṣ, TA,) which is a prov., (TA,) mano Hafara mugaw-aApF OawoXaka Oano yaqaEa fiyhaA [He who digs a pitfall is near to his falling into it]: (Ṣ,* TA:) pl. mugaw-ayaAtN. (Ṣ.)

And A cause, or place, of perdition or death; (Ḳ, TA;) as also mugaw-aApN↓: (TA:) or a calamity, or misfortune; thus in the saying, waqaEa Aln-aAsu fiI Ougowiy-apK [The people fell into a calamity, or misfortune]. (Ṣ.)
magowaApN: see mugaw-aApN, in two places.
mugaw-FI, in the phrase bitu mugaw-FI: see gawFI.
mugaw-aApN: see Ougowiy-apN, in two places.

Also A land in which one errs from the right way; syn. maDil-apN; (Ḳ, TA; in the CK miDal-ap;) as also magowaApN↓, like mihowaApN; (Ḳ, TA; in the CK migowAp, like mihowAp;) and so OaroDN mugaw-aApN: (TA:) the pl. of mugaw-aApN is mugaw-ayaAtN; (Ḳ, TA;) and that of magowaApN↓ is magaAwK. (TA.)
Also Any well. (AA, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gaAva: see 4.
[And see also gawiyvN.]

2. gw-v, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagowiyvN; (Ḳ;) and AstgAv↓; (TA;) He cried out, (TA,) and said, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) waA gawovaAhu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) [Alas! a cry for aid, or succour! also pronounced wA gawovaAhi (accord. to one of my copies of the Ṣ) and wA gawovaAho].
You say, Duriba fulaAnN fagaw-ava Such a one was beaten, and cried wA gwvAh. (TA.) This is declared by the leading grammarians to be the primary signification of gw-v: then they used it as meaning He cried out, or called, desiring, or demanding, aid, or succour. (MF.)
See also gawiyvN.

entry.sense: 4. AgAvhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UigaAvapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maguwvapN↓ [which is anomalous], (Ḳ,) He aided, or succoured, him; (Mṣb;) He (i. e. God, Mṣb) removed from him trouble, or affliction: (Mṣb, TA:) gaAvahu↓, aor. yagiyvuhu, is used in the sense of AgAvhu, but is rare, and is said [by some] to be from Algayovu, not AlUigaAvapu: gAvhu, aor. yaguwvuhu, is mentioned by Az as not heard by him from any one; but ISd mentions gAvhu, inf. n. gawovN and giyaAvN, though saying that AgAvhu is more approved. (TA.) And one says also, OagaAvanaA AlmaTaru † [The rain gave us relief]. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: [6. tagaAwavuwA, accord. to Freytag, appears to be used in the Deewán of the Hudhalees as signifying They said, one to another, waA gawovaAhu:]
[and tgAwv as syn. with OagaAva.]

entry.sense: 10. AstgAvhu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AstgAv bihi, (O, Mṣb, TA,) the latter disallowed by some, but used by Sb, (TA,) He sought, desired, or demanded, aid, or succour, of, or by means of, him, or it; he sought,, &c., [or called for,] his aid, or succour. (O, MF, TA.)
See also 2. [Hence, AstgAv AlEuwdu † The lute sent forth plaintive sounds: a modern phrase.]

gawovN and guwaAvN↓ and gawaAvN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the last deviating from the common course of speech, (Ḳ, TA,) with respect to analogy, as will be seen from what follows, (TA,) A cry for aid, or succour. (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL, PṢ.) One says, OajaAba Qll-ehu duEaMCahu wguwaAvahu↓ and gawaAvahu↓ [God answered his prayer, and his cry for aid]. (Fr, Ṣ.) gawaAvN↓ is said by Fr to be the only word significant of a sound, or cry, having fet-ḥ [to the first letter]; other words of this kind being with damm, as bukaMCN and duEaMCN, or with kesr, as nidaMCN and SiyaAHN. (Ṣ.) See also 2.
And see giyaAvN.
gawaAvN: see gawovN, in three places:
and see also giyaAvN.
In the dial. of Himyer it signifies † Travelling-provision. (TA.)
guwaAvN: see gawovN, in two places:
and see also the paragraph here following.

giyaAvN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) in which the w is changed into I because of the kesreh preceding it, (Ṣ,) a form disapproved by some of the lexicographers, but several others assign to it priority, (MF,) a subst. from OagaAvahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) as also gawaAvN↓, ascribed by Ibn-Hajar to the majority, and guwaAvN↓, mentioned on the authority of Aboo-Dharr, (MF,) and gawovN↓; (Mṣb;) signifying Aid, or succour; (Mṣb;) or deliverance from difficulty, distress, or adversity, and [from] revenge; and aid to release from difficulties, distresses, or adverse circumstances. (MF.) In the T, AlgiyaAvu is expl. as signifying That with which God aids, or succours, one. (TA.)

And giyaAvN signifies also An aider, or a succourer: you say, fulaAnN giyaAvunaA Such a one is our aider, or succourer; i. q. mugiyvunaA↓: (TA in art. nwr:) and God is said to be giyaAvu Almusotagiyviyna [The Aider of the seekers of aid]. (O.)
[Hence,] Oum-u giyaAvK is a name for † The cooking-pot. (T in art. Am.)

hom.sense: gawiyvN Food, or other succour, with which one aids a person in necessity. (O, Ḳ.)
Also, (O, Ḳ,) in one copy of the Ḳ tagowiyvN↓, (TA,) [both perhaps inf. ns., the former like dabiybN, &c.,] Vehemence of running (Xid-apu EadowK). (O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mugiyvN: see giyaAvN, last sentence but one.
maguwvapN, an [anomalous] inf. n.: see 4.
magaAwivu Waters: (O, Ḳ:) said to be one of those plurals that have no singulars. (TA.)

yaguwvu A certain idol which belonged to [the tribe of] Medhhij: (Zj, ISd, Ḳ, TA:) or a certain good man, who lived between [the times of] Adam and Noah, and of whom, after his death, was made an image, which, after a long time, became an object of worship; like wad-N and suwaAEN and yaguwqu and nasorN, mentioned therewith in the Ḳur lxxi. 22 and 23. (Bḍ.)

1. gaAja, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. yaguwju, (Ṣ, O,) said of a man; (TA;) and tgw-j↓, (O, Ḳ,) likewise, (TA,) or this is said of a horse; (O;) He affected a bending of his body, syn. tavan-aI and taEaT-afa, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and inclined from side to side, in his gait. (TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
EaXiy-apa qaAmato biAlfinaMCi kaOan-ahaA
Eaqiylapu nahobK tuSoTafaI wataguwju
[In the evening when she arose, in the yard of the dwelling, as though she were the most excellent portion of booty, to be selected therefrom, and affecting a bending of her body, and inclining from side to side]: i. e. displaying herself to the chief of the army, in order that he might take her for himself. (Ṣ, O.)
5: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
gawojN, applied to a horse, Pliant, pliable, limber, or lithe; syn. lay-inu AlOaEoTaAfi: pl. guwjN. (En-Naḍr, TA.)
And A man relaxed by reason of drowsiness. (TA.)
And A broad-breasted camel. (TA.)

And gawoju All-abaAni A horse ample in the skin of the breast, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) but not unless he be saholu AlmaEoTifi [i. e. pliant, pliable, limber, or lithe]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or a horse long in the qaSab [or bones of the legs]: or that bends, going and coming. (TA.)
And gawojN mawojN, the latter word being an imitative sequent, A horse fleet, or swift; excellent in running; or that outstrips others. (TA.)
gaw-aAjN That goes with energy: an epithet applied by Aboo-Wejzeh to a camel. (O.)

hom.sense:
1. gaAra, (Aṣ, Fr, IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.,) aor. yaguwru, (Ṣ, &c.,) inf. n. gaworN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and guWuwrN; (Ḳ;) and AgAr↓, (Fr, Mṣb,) inf. n. UigaArapN; (Ḳ;) but IAth says that this form of the verb is of rare occurrence, (TA,) and Aṣ disallows it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and gw-r↓, inf. n. tagowiyrN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and tgw-r↓; (Ḳ, TA;) He came to the gawor, (Aṣ, Fr, IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e., low land or country, (Mṣb,) [or the region so called, in Arabia:] or gAr signifies he journeyed in the region of the gwr: (Aṣ, TA:) or gAr and AgAr↓ signify he took his way towards the gawor. (TA.) There is a difference of opinion respecting the saying of El-Aạshà,
nabiI-N yaraI maA laA tarawona wacikoruhu
OagaAra↓ laEamoriI fiI AlbilaAdi waOanojadaA
[meaning, accord. to the first explanation of AgAr, A prophet who seeth what ye see not, and whose fame has come to the low lands, by my life, or by my religion, in the several regions, and has come to the high lands]: Aṣ says that AgAr signifies has gone quickly; and Anjd, has risen; and that the poet does not mean has come to the low lands nor to the high lands; holding gAr only to signify the coming to the low land: but Fr asserts that AgAr is a dial. var. of gAr; and cites this verse as authority: and some say AgAr wAnjd, but when they do not conjoin the two verbs they say gAr; like as they say hanaOaniI AlT-aEaAmu wamaraOaniI, but when they do not conjoin these two verbs they say OamoraOaniI: (Ṣ:) Aṣ also mentions another relation of the second hemistich, commencing AgAm [app. a mistake for OaqaAma or some other word]: (IḲṭṭ:) and there is another relation, accord. to which the second hemistich is maxoruwm, commencing with gaAra. (L.) You say also gaAra waOanojada meaning † He became famous in the low countries and the high. (A in art. njd.)
gAr fiI XaIoCK, inf. n. gaworN and guWuwrN (Ḳ) and giyaArN, (Sb, Ḳ,) He, or it, entered [or entered deeply] into a thing. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] gAr fiI OamorK ‡ He examined minutely [or deeply] into an affair; (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb;) as also AgAr↓. (IḲṭṭ.) You say fulaAnN biEiydu Algawori ‡ Such a one is a deep examiner: (TA:) or acquainted [deeply] with affairs: or very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful. (Mṣb.) [See also gaworN, below.]

gAr AlmaMCu, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) fiI AlOaroDi (Ḳ,) inf. n. gaworN (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and guWuwrN; (Ṣ, TA;) and gw-r↓, (Lḥ, TA,) inf. n. tagowiyrN; (Ḳ;) The water sank, (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ,) or went away, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) into the ground, or earth: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or went away into the sources, or springs. (Lḥ.)

gaArati AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. taguwru, (Ṣ,) inf. n. giyaArN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and guWuwrN; (Ḳ;) and gw-rt↓; (Ḳ;) The sun set: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner one says [gAr and gw-r↓] of the moon and of a star. (TA.)

gaArato Eayonuhu, aor. taguwru, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. gaworN (Ṣ, TA) and guWuwrN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and gaArato, aor. tagaAru; (Ṣ, TA;) and gw-rt↓; (TA;) His eye sank, or became depressed, (lit. entered,) in the head; (Ṣ, TA;) i. q. Ainoxasafato. (Mṣb.)
gaAra Aln-ahaAru † The day became intensely hot [app., like gaw-ara, meaning when the sun had declined from the meridian]: (Ḳ:) hence AlgaAYirapu [q. v.]. (TA.)
See also 2.
gaAra XayoYFA, aor. yaguwru, He sought for, or after, a thing. (TA.)
gaArahumo, and gaAra lahumo, [aor. yaguwru,] inf. n. giyaArN, He (God) bestowed upon them giyrap, (Ḳ,) i. e. miyrap [a provision of corn, or wheat,, &c.]. (TA.) [See also art. gyr.]

He benefited them; (Ṣ in art. gyr, and TA;) and so gaArahumo bixayorK: (Ṣ:) and gaArahumo, aor. yaguwru, (Ḳ,) inf. n. giyaArN; (TA;) or gaArahumo bixayorK; (TA;) He (God) bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth, and rain: (Ḳ, TA:) and gaArahumo birizoqK He bestowed upon them means of subsistence. (TA.) You say also Aall-ehum-a guronaA bigayovK, (Ḳ,) and bimaTarK, and bixayorK, (TA,) and guronaA minoka bigayovK, (Ṣ,) O God, aid us, or succour us, with rain (Ṣ, Ḳ) from Thee, (Ṣ,) and with prosperity. (TA.) [See also art. gyr.]
gaAra Alr-ajula, aor. yaguwruhu and yagiyruhu, He gave the man the bloodwit [which is termed giwarN and giyarN]: (ISk, TA:) and so gay-arahu. (TA in art. gyr.)

gaAra EalaI Oaholihi, aor. yagaAru, inf. n. giyrapN [or rather gayorapN (see art. gyr)] and gaArN, [He was jealous of his wife.] (IḲṭṭ.) gaArN and gayorapN, (Ṣ, so in my two copies,) or gaArN and giyrapN, with kesr, (Ḳ,) signify the same. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say fulaAnN Xadiydu AlgaAri EalaI Oaholihi i. e. Algyrp [Such a one is vehemently jealous of his wife]. (TA.) See also art. gyr.
2. gw-r, inf. n. tagowiyrN: see 1, in five places.
Also He slept in the middle of the day; (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA;) and so gaAra↓. (Ḳ, TA.)

And He alighted (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) to sleep (Lth, Ṣ, TA) in the middle of the day. (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And gaw-iruwA binaA Make ye the camels to lie down with us during the vehement midday-heat. (Jm and TA in art. rmD.) IAạr says that mugaw-irN↓ signifies One alighting in the middle of the day for a little while and then departing [i. e. resuming his journey]. (TA.) And maA bit-u hecihi All-ayolapa Uil-aA tagowiyrFA occurs in a trad. as meaning [I did not tarry, or have not tarried, this night,] save in taking a nap [like the sleep in the middle of the day]. (TA.)
Also He entered upon the middle of the day. (Ḳ, TA.)

And He journeyed in the middle of the day: (Lth, Ḳ:) or he (a rider upon a camel, or upon a horse or other beast,) journeyed until the declining of the sun from the meridian, and then alighted. (ISh, TA.)
And gw-r Aln-ahaAru ‡ [app. The day became intensely hot when] the sun declined from the meridian. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA. [See also gaAra Aln-ahaAru.])
gw-rhu, inf. n. as above, He put it, or made it to enter, into a low, or depressed, place: he hid, or concealed, it; or caused it to disappear. (Ḥar p. 165.)
And gw-r, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) signifies also He routed, defeated, or put to flight; and he drove away. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 3: see 4; and see also 6.

hom.sense: 4. AgAr Eayonahu [He made his eye to sink, or become depressed, in his head: see 1]. (TA.)
AgAr as intrans.: see 1, in four places.
Also He went away in, or into, the country, or land. (Ḳ.)

And, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UigaArapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and gaArapN, (Mgh,) or the latter is a simple subst., [or quasi-inf. n.,] (Mṣb,) He hastened, (Ḳ,) or was quick, (Mṣb,) in walking, or marching, or journeying: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) he was quick, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, (dafaEa, Ṣ,) in his running; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) said of a horse, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and of a fox: (Ṣ, Mgh:) he (a horse, Ḳ) ran vehemently, and was quick, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in a gaArap [or raid, or sudden attack upon a people, or their dwellings,] &c. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying, (in a trad. respecting the pilgrimage, TA,) OaXoriqo vabiyro kayomaA nugiyro [Enter thou upon the time of sunrise, Thebeer, (the name of a mountain near Mekkeh,)] that we may proceed quickly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or push, or press, on, or forward, (Yaạḳoob, Mṣb,) to the sacrifice of the pilgrimage: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or to the return from Minè: (Yaạḳoob:) or that we may plunder the meats of the sacrifices: or that we may enter into the low land. (TA. [See also 2 in art. Xrq.]) Hence also the saying, OagaAra UigaArapa Alv-aEolabi He was quick, and pushed, or pressed, on, or forward, like as does the fox. (Ṣ.)

AgAr EalaI AlEaduw-i, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and EalaI Alqawomi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UigaArapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and gaArapN, (Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., [or quasi-inf. n., as in the case mentioned above,] (TA,) and mugaArN, (Ṣ, TA,) He made [a raid, or hostile or predatory incursion, into the territory of the enemy; or] a sudden, or an unexpected, attack [upon the enemy, or] upon the territory or dwellings of the enemy, [with a party of armed horsemen, generally meaning a predatory incursion,] and engaged with them in conflict; (Mṣb,) or he urged the horses upon, or against, the people; as also AstgAr↓: (Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner you say gAwr↓ AlEaduw-a, inf. n. mugaAwarapN and giwaArN. (Ṣ.) See also 6. And AgAr Alc-iYobu fiI Alganami The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; (Ḳ * and TA in art. XE;) as also AstgAr↓. (TA ibid.)
Also AgAr Ealayohi He plundered it; took it by pillage. (TA.)
And AgAr bibaniI fulaAnK, and sometimes UilaI bnI flAn, He came to the sons of such a one to aid, or succour, them: (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ:) or to be aided, or succoured, by them. (IḲṭṭ.)
AgAr, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UigaArapN and quasi-inf. n. gaArapN, (TA,) signifies also He twisted hard (Ṣ, Ḳ) a rope. (Ṣ.)
AgAr Oaholahu He married another in addition to his wife [and so caused her to be jealous: see 1]. (Ṣ.) [See also art. gyr.]

entry.sense: 5: see 1, first signification.

6. tgAwrwA They made [raids, or hostile or predatory incursions, into each other's territories; or] sudden attacks, one upon another, or one party upon the dwellings of another party, and engaged in conflict, one with another; or urged their horses one upon, or against, another; expl. by OagaAra↓ baEoDuhumo EalaI baEoDK: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so gAwrwA↓, inf. n. mugaAwarapN. (TA.)
8. AgtAr He procured miyrap [or provision of corn, or wheat,, &c.]. (TA.)
And He derived, or obtained, benefit, advantage, or profit. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 10. Uisotagowara He, or it, descended: (TA:) or he desired to descend into a low land or country. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

Also He became fat; and fat entered into him: (Ṣ, TA:) or you say, AstgAr AlX-aHomu fiyhi fat spread in him; and he became fat; (Ḳ, TA;) the pronoun referring to a horse, which is not mentioned in the Ḳ; but the explanation in the Ṣ is better: or, accord. to Az, AstgAr is said of the fat and flesh of a she-camel, meaning it became hard, and compact; like the rope of which one says yasotagiyru i. e. it is twisted hard: or, accord. to some, said of the fat of a camel, it means it entered his inside. (TA.)
AstgArt said of a wound, (qaroHapN, Ṣ, in the Ḳ juroHap,) means It became swollen. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Aisotagowara Qll-eha He asked, or begged, of God, giyrap, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. miyrap [provision of corn, or wheat,, &c.]. (TA.)

gaArN A cave, or cavern; syn. kahofN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in a mountain; (Ṣ;) as also magaArapN↓ and magaArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mugaArapN↓ and mugaArN↓ and gaworN↓: (Ḳ: [but gaArN in this sense is omitted in the CK:]) or what resembles a khf in a mountain, [only differing in being less large,] like a sarab: (TA:) or what is hewn out in a mountain, resembling a magaArap: when it is large, or spacious, it is called khf: (Mṣb:) or what resembles a house, or chamber, in a mountain: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or a low, or depressed, place in a mountain: (Th, Ḳ:) or any low, or depressed, land, country, or ground: (Ḳ:) see also gaworN [and xaworN]: or the hole, or burrow, to which a wild animal betakes itself: (Ḳ: [see an instance in art. smw, conj. 8:]) and sometimes magaArN↓ is applied to the coverts of gazelles, among trees: (Ṣ:) the dim. of gaArN is guwayorN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [of which see two exs. (a prov. and a verse) voce buWosN:] and the pl. (of pauc., TA) OagowaArN (IJ, Ḳ) and (of mult., TA) giyraAnN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also The portion of the upper part of the mouth which is behind the faraAXap [or thin bone of the palate]: or the hollow (Ouxoduwd) which is between the two jaws: or the interior of the mouth: (Ḳ: [for daAxila Alfami, in the CK, I read daAxilu Alfm, as in the TA:]) or, as some say, the two parts whereof each is called niToEN, [app. meaning the anterior part of the palate and the corresponding part next the lower gums,] in the HanakaAni [or the palate and the part corresponding to it below]. (TA.)
And AlgaAraAni signifies The [sockets of the eyes; or] two bones in which are the eyes. (ISd, Ḳ.)
And The belly and the pudendum: (Ṣ:) or the mouth and the pudendum. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying of a poet, yasoEaI ligaArayohi [He works, or earns, for his belly, or his mouth, and his pudendum]. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also (gaArN) An army: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a numerous army. (TA.) You say AilotaqaI AlgaAraAni The two armies met. (Ṣ.)
And A company, or body, of men: (TA:) or a numerous company or body of men. (ISd, Ḳ.)
And I. q. gayorapN, (Ṣ,) or giyrapN. (Ḳ.) [See 1, last signification.]

And A kind of tree, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) of large size, (Mgh, Ḳ,) having leaves longer than those of the xilaAf, (Mgh, TA,) and a fruit [or berry] smaller than the hazel-nut, which is black, and which, being divested of its covering, discloses a heart that is employed in medicine [that is designed to produce a narcotic or an intoxicating effect: the berries are called Hab-u AlgaAri]: its leaves have a sweet odour, (Mgh, TA,) and are employed in perfume: (TA:) its fruit is called [in Persian] dahomasot: (Mgh, TA:) and it has an oil, (Ḳ,) which is called duhonu AlgaAri: (Ṣ:) [it is the bay-tree; or female laurel-tree; the laurus nobilis; also called the sweet bay; of which there are several sorts, as the broad-leaved bay, the narrow-leaved bay, &c.: it is commonly supposed to be the laurus of the ancients:] n. un. with p {gaArapN}. (TA.)
And The leaves of the grapevine. (Ḳ.)
gaworN The bottom, or lowest part, of anything; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also gaworaI↓: (Ḳ:) and its depth. (TA.)

You say, Earafotu gawora hecihi AlmasoOalapi ‡ [I have become acquainted with the bottom of this question]. (TA.) And fulaAnN baEiydu Algawori (Ṣ) ‡ Such a one is deep and excellent in judgment; one who examines deeply. (TA.) [See also 1.] And hawa baHorN laA yudoraku gaworuhu ‡ [He is a sea whereof the bottom shall not be reached]. (TA.) And mano OaboEadu gaworFA fiI AlbaATili min-iI ‡ [Who is deeper in knowledge with respect to what is vain, or false, than I?]. (TA, from a trad.)
Low, or depressed, land, country, or ground; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [like xaworN;] as also gaArN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also gaArN, in the first of its senses expl. above.
Applied to water, i. q. gaAYirN [Sinking, or going away, into the ground, or earth]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an inf. n. used as an epithet, like maMCN sakobN, and dirohamN DarobN. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: giwarN A bloodwit; syn. diyapN: (Ḳ, TA:) a dial. var. of giyarN: (TA:) or the latter is a pl., of which the sing. is giyrapN. (AA, Ḳ in art. gyr, q. v.)

hom.sense: gaArapN, a subst. from OagaAra; A going away into a country, or land. (TA.)
A quick running, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or vehement running, (TA,) of a horse, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) and of a fox; (Mgh;) as also gawiyrN↓, of a fox. (TA.)
