[A raid; or an incursion into the territory of an enemy; or a sudden, or an unexpected, attack upon an enemy, or upon the territories or dwellings of an enemy, with a party of armed horsemen, and engagement with them in conflict; an urging of horses upon, or against, a people; generally, a hostile, or predatory, incursion: or the making such an incursion:] a subst. [or quasi-inf. n.] from OagaAra EalaI AlEaduw-i. (Ṣ, TA.)
And Plunder, or pillage. (TA.)

And hence, (Mgh, Mṣb,) [Horsemen making a raid, or a sudden, or an unexpected, attack, upon an enemy, or upon the dwellings of an enemy, and engaging with them in conflict: horsemen urging their horses upon, or against, a people:] i. q. xayolN mugiyrapN↓: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and one says also xyl migiyrapN↓, with kesr. (TA.) You say Xan-a Ealayohimu AlgaArapa i. e. He scattered, (Ṣ in art. Xn, and Mgh * and Mṣb,*) or poured, (Ḳ in art. Xn,) upon them [the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, and engaging in conflict, or the horsemen urging their horses]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The poet (El-Kumeyt Ibn-Maạroof, TA) says,
wanaHonu SabaHonaA Mla najoraAna gaArapF
tamiyma bona mur-K waAlr-imaAHa Aln-awaAdisaA
[And we gave as a morning-drink to the people of Nejrán a troop of horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, upon them, or urging their horses against them, namely the tribe of Temeem Ibn-Murr, and the piercing spears]: he means, saqayonaAhumo xayolFA mugiyrapF: and tmym bn mr- is put in the accus. case as a substitute for gArp. (Ṣ, TA.)

HabolN Xadiydu AlgaArapi means A rope twisted hard; or hard in respect of the twisting; (Ṣ, TA;) gaArapN being in this case [as in that first mentioned above] a subst. standing in stead of the inf. n. UigaArap: (TA:) and so HabolN mugaArN↓; (Ṣ, TA;) applied to a rope that is twisted with another. (TA voce misoHalN.)
And AlgaArapu signifies The navel: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) app. so called because of its depth. (Ṣgh, TA.)
Algaworapu The sun. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)
See also gaAYirapN.
giyrapN Abundance of the produce of the earth: and rain: and i. q. miyrapN [a provision of corn, or wheat,, &c.]: belonging to this art. and to art. gyr. (TA.)
[See also 1, last signification.]

entry.sense: gaworaI: see gaworN.
gawiyrN: see gaArapN, second sentence.

gaAYirapN i. q. qaAYilapN [app. as syn. with qayoluwlapN, i. e. A sleeping in the middle of the day; though the primary signification of qaAYilapN is that which here next follows]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also gaworapN↓. (O, Ḳ.)
And The middle of the day [itself]. (Ḳ.)
And one says, buniIa hecaA Albayotu EalaI gaAYirapi AlX-amosi, meaning ‡ [This house, or tent, was, or has been, built, or set up,] facing the place of sunrise. (TA.)
magaArN: see gaArN, in two places.

Also A place of entrance: and a place where a thing is sought for: you say, Uin-aka gurota fiI gayori magaArK Verily thou hast entered into that which is not a place of entrance: and verily thou hast sought in that which is not a place where a thing is sought for. (TA.)

hom.sense: mugaArN: see gaArN.
Also A place of a gaArap [or raid, or sudden attack upon an enemy, or upon the dwellings of an enemy, with a party of armed horsemen,, &c.]. (TA.)
See also gaArapN, last sentence but one.

Hence, ‡ A horse strong, or compact, in make; as though twisted: (Az, TA:) or a horse strong in the joints: (Lth, TA:) or, applied to a horse, i. q. muDam-arN [made lean, or light of flesh;, &c.: see 2 in art. Eyr: and see also miEaArN in that art.]. (Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer, TA in art. Eyr.) And A horse that runs swiftly. (TA. [But in this last sense, the word should be, accord. to rule, as here next follows.])

entry.sense: mugiyrN A horse swift in running: [see also what next precedes:] and migowaArN↓ [likewise] signifies a swift horse: or this latter, accord. to Lḥ, vehement in running: and its pl. is magaAwiyru. (TA.)
xayolu mugiyrapN and migiyrapN: see gaArapN.
mugaw-irN: see 2.
magaArapN and mugaArapN: see gaArN, first sentence.
migowaArN: see mugiyrN.

Also A fighting man; and so mugaAwirN↓: (Ṣ:) or the former signifies one who occupies himself much in gaAraAt [or raids, or sudden attacks upon enemies, or upon the dwellings of enemies, with armed horsemen,, &c., pl. of gaArapN]; (Ḳ, TA;) as also mugaAwirN↓: (TA:) pl. magaAwiyru: (Ṣ:) and magaAwiru may be a contracted pl. of migowaArN or a pl. of mugaAwirN. (TA.)
mugaAwirN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1. gaASa fiI AlmaMCi, aor. yaguwSu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. gawoSN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and magaASN and giyaASapN and giyaASN, (Ḳ,) He dived in, or descended beneath, the water; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) or entered into the water; (TA;) to fetch out what was in it. (Mṣb [in my copy of which, the particle fI is omitted, app. by a slip of the transcriber].)
giyaASapN [also] signifies The diving in the sea for pearls; (Ṣ;) and gawoSN signifies [the same: or both signify] the fetching out pearls from beneath the water. (Mgh.)

[Hence,] you say also, gaASa EalaI AlOamori, (Ḳ,) inf. n. gawoSN, (TA,) ‡ [He dived for the thing, or affair, so as to elicit it; or] he knew the thing, or affair. (Ḳ, TA.) And gaASa EalaI AlmaEaAniI Hat-aI balaga OaqoSaAhaA waQsotaxoraja maA baEuda minohaA wadaq-a fahomuhu ‡ [He dived for the meanings so that he reached the uttermost of them, and elicited what was remote of them, and the understanding whereof was subtile]. (Mṣb.) And fulaAnN yaguwSu EalaI HaqaAYiqi AlEilomi ‡ [Such a one dives for the verities of science]. (A, TA.)
And maA OaHosana gawoSahu EalayohaA ‡ [How good is his diving for them!]. (A, TA.) And maA gaASa gawoSapF Uil-aA Oaxoraja dur-apF ‡ [He did not dive a single diving but he fetched out what was like a pearl, or a large pearl]. (A, TA.)
You say also, gaASa EalaI AlX-aIoCi, aor. yaguwSu, inf. n. gawoSN, He pounced, or came suddenly, or at unawares, upon the thing. (Mṣb.)
2. gw-Shu fiI AlmaMCi He made him to dive in, or descend beneath, the water; (A;) he immersed, immerged, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him therein. (TA.)
gawoSN [originally an inf. n.]: see magaASN, in two places.
gawoSapN [A single diving in, or descent beneath, water: see 1, last sentence but one]. (A.)
gaw-aASN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

gaAYiSN One who dives in, or descends beneath, or enters into, water; as also gaw-aASN↓ [which, however, has an intensive signification, or implies the habit of so doing]: (TA:) and ↓the latter, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or both, (Az, TA,) particularly one who dives in the sea for pearls, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or for pearl-shells, and fetches them out: (Az, TA:) pl. guw-aASN, (A, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and gaASapN, (A, TA,) [also of the former,] and [of the latter] gaw-aASuwna. (TA.)

[Hence the saying,] hawa mino SaAgapi Alfiqari wagaASapi Ald-urari ‡ [He is of the moulders of fiqar, lit., as thus used, ornaments fashioned in the form of the vertebræ of the back, but here meaning choice phrases or sentences; and of the divers for, and producers of, (expressions like) pearls, or large pearls]. (A, TA.)
[Hence likewise,] gaw-aASN↓ also signifies ‡ One who exercises art, craft, cunning, or skill, in ordering the means of obtaining subsistence. (TA.)

And gaAYiSN also signifies One who pounces, or comes suddenly, or at unawares, upon a thing; (JK, Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also, (JK, Mṣb,) but in an intensive sense, (Mṣb,) gaw-aASN↓: (JK, Mṣb:) pl. of the former gaASapN. (Mṣb.)

magaASN A place where one dives in, or descends beneath, water; (Lth, A, Ḳ;) as also gawoSN↓: (Lth, Mgh:) or ↓the latter signifies particularly a place [where one dives and] whence pearls are fetched out. (JK, Mgh.*) You say also, hecaA magaASu All-uWoluWi This is the diving-place for pearls. (A.)
Also The upper part of the saAq [or shank,, &c.]. (JK, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. gaATa, aor. yaguwTu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. gawoTN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It entered, or sank, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) into (fiI) a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as, for instance, the foot into sand; (Ṣ, TA;) and a man into mud, (TA,) or into water; (Mṣb;) and into a valley; (TA, in this art. and in art. gyT; in the former expl. by Ainogamasa;) and gaATa, aor. yagiyTu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. gayoTN, (Ḳ,) signifies the same: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) both also signify he, or it, became hidden, (Aṣ, and Ḳ in art. gyT,) in the ground. (Aṣ.) You say also, gaATato OanosaAEu Aln-aAqapi, aor. and inf. n. as above, The plaited thongs of the she-camel clave to her belly, and so entered, or sank, therein. (TA.) And gaATati AlOanosaAEu fiI daf-i Aln-aAqapi The plaited thongs caused their impressions to be visible in the side of the she-camel. (TA.)
It (a place) sank, or became depressed, in the ground. (ISh.) And It (anything) descended, or sloped downwards, in the ground. (TA.)

Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, He dug, excavated, or hollowed out. (TA: and in some copies of the Ḳ, AlgawoTu is expl. by AlHaforu; but the reading given in the TA, in that instance, is AlHuforapu.)

guTo guTo means Be thou with the jamaAEap [i. e. the mass, or main body], (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) who are termed the gaAT, (O,) [be thou with them, not with the factious,] when fitan [i. e. factions, &c.,] come. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.)
2. gw-T, inf. n. tagowiyTN, He gobbled [food]: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:*) or gobbled largely, or in large mouthfuls: (Ḳ,* TA:) from gawoTN meaning variyd. (TA.)
And tagowiyTN signifies also The making a well deep. (Ḳ. [See also 4.])

entry.sense: 4. OagowaTa He made deep a well. (Fr, O, TA. [See also 2.])
5. tgw-T ‡ He voided excrement, or ordure. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, AanodIe is put by mistake for AbdI.])
6. tagaAwaTaA fiI AlmaMCi They two vied, or contended, each with the other, in plunging, or diving, in the water. (Ḳ,* TA.)
7. AngAT It (a branch, or twig, or the like,) bent. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: gaATN: see gaAYiTN.

AlgaATu signifies also AljamaAEapu [meaning The mass, or main body, of the people]. (O, Ḳ.) One says, maA fiI AlgaATi mivoluhu [There is not in the mass, or main body, of the people, the like of him]. (O, TA.)

gawoTN A hollow, cavity, pit, or the like, dug, or excavated, in the ground; syn. HuforapN. (So in the Ḳ, accord. to the TA, on the authority of AA: but in some copies of the Ḳ, AlgawoTu in this instance is expl. by AlHaforu: see 1, last sentence.) See also gaAYiTu.
And i. q. variydN [Crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (O: in the Ḳ variydap.)

entry.sense: gayoTN: see gaAYiTN, latter half.
gawoTapN A [low, or depressed, place, or hollow, such as is called] wahodap, in the ground. (ISh, Ḳ.) [See also gaAYiTN.]
guwTapN A place comprising water and herbage: whence guwTapu dimaXoqa, (Ḥar pp. 130, et seq.,) i. e. the city, or district, of Damascus, (Ḳ,) which is a place abounding with water and trees. (Ṣ.)
biYorN gawiyTapN A deep well. (TA.)

gaAYiTN A wide, depressed piece of ground or land, (ISh, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but not much depressed, and in some instances having acclivities [bordering it]; (ISh;) sometimes, as they assert, a league (farosax) in extent, and having in it meadows; (AḤn;) and gaATN↓ and gawoTN↓ signify the same; (O, Ḳ;) or the last is more depressed than the gAYT: (IDrd, O:) and gAYT is also applied to a valley: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OagowaATN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or this is pl. of gawoTN, (IB,) and [of mult.] giyTaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is pl. of both these sings., (IB,) and guwTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and giyaATN. (Ḳ.)

Hence, ‡ A place in which one satisfies a want of nature; the custom being to do so in a depressed place, where one is concealed. (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA.) In the Ḳur [iv. 46, or v. 9], accord. to an extraordinary reading, it is written gayoT↓, [a form now commonly used, and signifying a garden, but there meaning a privy place,] the original form of which may be gayowiT, and then gay-iT, [and then gayoT,] it being contracted; or, accord. to Abu-l- Ḥasan, the I may be originally w, these two letters being in this instance interchangeable. (IJ.) You say, OataI AlgaAYiTa, (Ṣ, TA,) and Daraba AlgaAYiTa, (TA,) ‡ He satisfied a want of nature; (Ṣ, TA;) voided excrement, or ordure. (TA.)
And hence, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ Human excrement, or ordure: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) because they used to cast it away in a gAYT: or because they used to go thither to satisfy a want of nature. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2. if belonging to this art., or R. Q. 2 if belonging to art. gw. tagaAgaI Ealayohi AlgawogaMCu [as though originally tagawogI] i. q. rakibuwhu [i. e. The mixed multitude, or the low, base, vile,, &c., of men, bore, or pressed, or crowded, (as though mounting,) upon him]. (TA in art. gw.)

gaAgN The Habaq [q. v.], (IDrd, Ḳ, TA,) a species of sweet-smelling plants, (TA,) i. e. the fuwcanoj, (IDrd, Ḳ, TA,) an arabicized word from [the Pers.] Puwdiynaho: (TA:) [accord. to the TḲ, the plant called in Turkish yArPwz, which is marjoram:] gaAgapN↓ [the n. un.] is said by Lth to mean a certain plant resembling the haronawaI [a word of which both the orthography and the application are disputed]. (TA.)

hom.sense: gaAgapN: see what here precedes:
and see also the paragraph here following.

entry.sense:
gawogaMC [i. e. gawogaMCN and gawogaMCu, as will be shown by what follows; mentioned in this art. in the Mṣb and Ḳ; and in the Ṣ, and again in the Ḳ and TA, in art. gw;] masc. and fem., [being] perfectly and imperfectly decl., (Ṣ and TA in art. gw,) in the former case like qamoqaAmN, the C being substituted for w, and in the latter case like EaworaMCu, (Ṣ,) Locusts after the growth of their wings, (AO, T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. (AO, T, Mṣb) after the state in which they are called dabFA or dabFI; (AO, T, Ṣ, Mṣb;) before which earlier state they are called sirowap [or rather saroC]: (AʼObeyd, T, Mṣb: [see also jaraAdN:])
or locusts when they become light, or active, so as to fly; thus accord. to AO, and IAth says the like thereof: (TA:) or locusts when they have wings, and almost fly, before they raise themselves and fly; thus says Aṣ: (Ṣ:) or locusts, when they have become divested of the [changing] colours, and are becoming in a state of transition to redness. (Aṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And A sort of insects resembling baEuwD [or gnats], that do not bite, (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) nor hurt, (AO, Ṣ, Mṣb,) by reason of their weakness. (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to Aṣ, (Ṣ,) or AO, (Mṣb,) as being likened to the locusts thus termed, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) applied to men, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning ‡ A mixed multitude of men; as also gaAgapN↓: (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. gw:) or the safilap [i. e. low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, or sordid; or lowest or lower, basest or baser,, &c.;] of men; and such as haste to do evil: and it may be from the signification here following, because of the muchness of their clamour, or confused noise, and vociferation. (TA.)
[Like gawogaA in Pers., and probably from this latter, if the converse be not the case,] it signifies also Clamour, and a confusion of cries or shouts or noises. (TA.)

1. gaAlahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaguwluhu, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. gawolN, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) He, or it, [accord. to the TA said of a thing,] destroyed him; (Lth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AgtAlhu↓: (Ḳ:) and (Ḳ) it (a thing, Ṣ, O) took him, seized him, or took him away, unexpectedly, at unawares, or from an unknown quarter; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so AgtAlhu↓: (Ṣ: [see also an ex. of this latter voce xaruwjN:]) and accord. to IAạr, gAl AlX-aIoCu zayodFA signifies The thing took away Zeyd. (TA.) One says, gaAlatohu guwlN↓ A [cause of] destruction destroyed him: (Ḳ, TA:) or [destroyed him so that it was not known whither he had gone away; for] it is said of one who has fallen into destruction (Ṣ, TA) and it is not known whither he has gone away: (TA:) and it also signifies Death or the decree of death [destroyed him, or took him away]. (TA.) One says also when persons have perished in a land, gaAlatohumo tiloka AlOaroDu [That land caused them, or has caused them, to perish in it]: and tagaw-alati↓ AlOaroDu bifulaAnK means The land caused such a one to perish; and to pursue a course that led him astray. (TA.) And one says of a land (OaroD), taguwlu Als-aAbilapa, meaning It casts away the travellers, or wayfarers; causes them to fall, or drop down; and removes them far away. (TA.)

gaAlati Alxamoru fulaAnFA means † The wine that he had drunk deprived such a one of his reason: or, of the soundness of his body: (AHeyth, TA:) [or corrupted, or vitiated, him; for] gaAlahu, aor. yaguwluhu, signifies Oafosadahu; (Ksh and Bḍ in xxxvii. 46;) as well as Oaholakahu: (Ksh, ibid:) and a poet, cited by AO, says,
wamaA zaAlati AlkaOosu tagotaAlunaA
† [And the cup of wine caused not to deprive us of our reason]. (Ṣ, O.)

taguwlu Alv-iyaAba fataqoSuru EanohaA is said of a tall woman [app. as meaning She exceeds the measure of the clothes, so that they are too short for her]: such a woman is said to be caAtu gawolK↓. (TA.)
And one says, maA gaAlaka Ean-aA i. e. What withheld, or debarred, or has withheld or debarred, thee from us? (O.)
And gulotuhu, inf. n. giyaAlapN and giyaAlN and guWuwlN, signifies I stole it. (O and TA in art. gyl [though belonging to art. gwl].)
2. falaApN tugaw-ilu, inf. n. tagowiylN, [A desert, or water-less desert,] of which the roads, or ways, are unapparent, so that it causes the people thereof [who traverse it] to go astray. (TA.)

3. mugaAwalapN is syn. with mubaAdarapN [The hastening, making haste, or striving to be first or beforehand, in doing or attaining or obtaining a thing], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) [or] in journeying, &c. (TA.) Jereer says, (Ṣ, O,) or El-Akhtal, (so in the TA,) mentioning a man upon whom horsemen had made a sudden attack, (Ṣ, TA,)
EaAyanotu muXoEilapa AlriEaAli kaOan-ahaA
TayorN tugaAwilu fiI XamaAmK wukuwraA
[I saw those that were spreading themselves of the small parties of horsemen, as though they were birds hastening to nests in (the mountain of) Shemám]. (Ṣ, O, TA.) And it is related in a trad. of 'Ammár, that he was brief in prayer, and said, kunotu OugaAwilu HaAjapF liI [I was hastening to accomplish a want that I had]. (TA.) And in a trad. of Keys Ibn-'Ásim, [it is related that he said,] kunotu OugaAwiluhumo fiI AljaAhiliy-api i. e. I used to strive to be beforehand with them (OubaAdiruhumo) in making a sudden attack or incursion, and in doing mischief, [in the Time of Ignorance:] or, as some relate it, it is with r [i. e. kunotu OugaAwiruhumo I used to make sudden attacks or incursions upon them]. (TA.)

5. tagaw-ulN is syn. with talaw-unN [which primarily signifies The becoming altered in colour; but here, the varying in state or condition, or in form or appearance; or, agreeably with explanations of its verb by Esh-Shereeshee, (cited in Ḥar p. 480,) the becoming altered in state or condition; and the becoming of various sorts or species]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) One says, tgw-lt AlmaroOapu, meaning tlw-nt [The woman varied in state or condition, or in form or appearance,, &c.]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and in like manner tgw-lt is said of the guwl [q. v.]. (TA.) And The woman made herself to be like the guwl. (TA.) And tagaw-ulu AlfalaApi means The dubious, and varying, state or condition, of the desert, or waterless desert. (TA.) And one says also, tgw-l AlOamoru ‡ The affair, or case, became altered so as to be unknown; [for tanaAkara, in my original, I read tanak-ara;] and became dubious, or confused. (TA.)
And tgw-lt AlOaroDu bifulaAnK: see 1, former half.
And tagaw-alatohumu Alguwlu is said of them who have been made to deviate from, miss, or lose, the right way [by the guwl; i. e. it means The gwl made them to deviate, &c.]. (TA.)

[6. tagaAwaluwA i. q. tabaAdaruwA i. e. They hastened together; vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening; made haste to be, or get, before one another; strove, one with another, to be first, or beforehand, (comp. 3:) expl. by Freytag as meaning “sese invicem studuerunt capere.”]

hom.sense: 8. AgtAlhu: see 1, first sentence, in two places.
Also (Ṣ) He slew him (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb) covertly (Ṣ,* Mgh, O *) or on an occasion of inadvertence; (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb;) syn. qatalahu giylapF↓. (Ṣ, Mgh, O.)
See also 1, latter half.

laA yagotaAluhu AlX-abaEu, said of a hawk, (Ṣ, O, TA,), &c., (TA,) signifies ‡ Satiety will not deprive him of his strength, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and his vehemence of flight: meaning that he will not become satiated: (TA:) [it is said that] it occurs in a verse of Zuheyr, [but I do not find it in his Deewán,] describing a hawk. (Ṣ, O, TA.)

hecihi OaroDN tagotaAlu AlmaXoIa means † This is a land that renders unapparent in it the footing, or marching, [of travellers,] by reason of its far extent and its width: an ex. of the verb [in this sense] occurs in a verse of El-ʼAjjáj cited voce niyaATN, in art. nwT. (Ṣ, O.)
[And Freytag adds, in art. gyl, the two following significations: the former, or both, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees: He overtook him in running: (compare 3 and 6 in this art.:)]
[and He filled it so that the space became too contracted to take, or hold.]

gawolN Far extent of a desert, or waterless desert; (Ṣ, O, TA;) because it destroys him who passes along in it: (Ṣ, TA:) or of a land; because it casts away the travellers, or wayfarers, causes them to fall, or drop down, and removes them far away: and accord. to Lḥ, it is said of a land when one journeys in it without stopping. (TA.) One says, maA OaboEada gawola hecihi AlOaroDi How far is the extent of this land! and Uin-ahaA labaEiydapu Algawoli [Verily it is far in extent]. (ISh, TA.) And OaroDN caAtu gawolK A land far extending, though in the view of the eye of little extent: (IKh, TA:) and gay-ilN applied to land is said to have the same meaning. (TA in art. gyl.) And OagowaAlu AlOaroDi [in which AgwAl is app. pl. of gawolN] signifies The extremities of the land. (TA.)
AimoraOapN caAtu gawolK A tall woman. (TA.) See 1, last sentence but two. [And see also gay-ilapN, voce gay-ilN, in art. gyl.]
[nAqp gwl AlnjMC is a phrase mentioned without any indication of the meaning in the TA: perhaps naAqapu gawoli Aln-ajaMCi, and signifying A she-camel of an exceeding degree of swiftness.]

In the saying in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 46], laA fiyhaA gawolN, [referring to the wine of Paradise,] it means The evil result of headache; because it is said in another place, [lvi. 19,] laA yuSad-aEuwna EanohaA: (Ṣ, O, TA:) or it [there] means [simply] headache: or intoxication: (Ḳ, TA:) thus some expl. it as used in that instance: (TA:) or, as expl. by AO, it there means privation of the intellectual faculties. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
See also guwlN, latter half.
Also Distress, trouble, or molestation: (Ḳ, TA:) thus expl. by some as used in the Ḳur ubi suprà. (TA.)
And Unfaithfulness; or unfaithful acting. (TA.)
OataI gawolFA gaAYilapF↓ means He did a cunning, bad, action. (Ḳ.)
Also Much earth. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) Hence the phrase gawolFA mina Alr-amoli, [app. meaning A large quantity of sand,] in a verse of Lebeed. (Ṣ, O.)
And A collection of [the trees called] TaloH, (Ḳ, TA,) with which nothing participates. (TA.)
And A low, or depressed, part of the earth, or of land. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: guwlN A kind of [goblin,] demon, devil, or jinnee, which, the Arabs assert, appears to men in the desert, assuming various forms, causing them to wander from the way, and destroying them; (JM, and TA * on the authority of IAth;) but this the Prophet denied, saying, laA guwla; by which, however, accord. to some, he did not mean to deny the existence of the gwl, but only the assertion of the Arabs respecting its assuming various forms and its being able to cause any one to go astray: (IAth, JM,* TA:) i. q. siEolaApN [q. v.]: or a sort of siEolaAp: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) or a male jinnee; the female being called siEolaAp: (Abu-l-Wefee El-Aarábee, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OagowaAlN and [of mult.] giylaAnN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and giwalapN: (O, TA:) and it signifies also an enchantress of the jinn: (Ḳ:) and a demon, or devil, that eats men: (En-Naḍr, O, Ḳ:) or any jinnee, or devil, or animal of prey, that destroys a man: (TA:) or a certain beast, (Ḳ, TA,) terrible [in appearance], having tusks, or fangs, (TA,) seen by the Arabs, and known by them; and killed by Taäbbata Sharrà: (Ḳ, TA:) and such as varies in form or appearance, of the enchanters and of the jinn; (Ḳ, TA;) on his doing which, as is said in a trad., one should hastily utter the call to prayer, to prevent his mischief by the mention of God: (TA:) or anything by reason of which the intellect departs; as also gawolN↓: (Ḳ:) and anything that takes a man unexpectedly and destroys him: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) [whence] one says, AlgaDabu guwlu AlHilomi Anger [is that which] destroys, and does away with, forbearance, or clemency. (Ṣ, O.)
Also Destruction: [or a cause thereof:] and death; or the decree of death. (Ḳ.) See 1, second sentence.
And A calamity, or misfortune; (Ḳ, TA;) as also gaAYilapN↓; (TA;) of which latter the pl. in this sense is gawaAYilu; (Ḳ,* TA;) thus mentioned by Ks. (Mṣb.)

And A serpent: pl. OagowaAlN: (Ḳ:) accord. to Az, the Arabs call serpents OagowaAl; and thus this word is said to mean in the verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys,
liyaqotulaniI waAlmaXorafiI-u muDaAjiEiI
wamasonuwnapN zuroqN kaOanoyaAbi OagowaAli
[To slay me, while the Meshrefee sword was my bedfellow, and so were sharpened, polished arrowheads, like the fangs of serpents]: (O, TA:*) but AḤát says that this is meant as an exaggeration: (TA:) and it is said that the poet here means devils. (O, TA.)
giylapN The slaying covertly, (Mgh,) or on an occasion of inadvertence; a subst. from AigotaAlahu: (Mṣb:) originally with w [i. e. giwolapN]. (Ṣ.) See 8: and see also art. gyl.

hom.sense: gawolaAnN A plant of the [kind called] HamoD, (AʼObeyd, AḤn, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) like the OuXonaAn [i. e. kali, or glasswort], (Ḳ,) or, accord. to AḤn, resembling the EunoZuwaAn [which is described as a plant of the HamoD, or, as some say, the best of the OuXonaAn], except that it is more slender; and it is a pasture. (TA.)
Also sing. of gawaAliynu, which signifies [The ribs of a ship or boat, i. e.] the things that resemble the DuluwE in a ship or boat. (AA, O, TA.)

entry.sense: gaAYilN [act. part. n. of 1].
[Hence,] OaroDN gaAYilapu Aln-iTaMCi A land that destroys its inhabitant by reason of its far extent. (TA.)
And gaAYilapN [as an epithet applied to a fem. n.] signifies Caused to become absent, or to disappear; hidden, or concealed: or stolen. (ISh, TA.)

hom.sense: gaAYilapN [as a subst.] Bad, or corrupt, conduct; and evil, or mischief. (Mṣb.) See also gawolN, last quarter. [And see art. gyl.]
And [particularly] Wickedness, or disobedience, of a slave; and his running away; (Mgh in art. Edw, and Mṣb;) and the like thereof: pl. gawaAYilu. (Mṣb.)

And [hence, perhaps, (as denoting a cause for reclaiming the price of a slave,) it is said that] it signifies A right which another than the seller has to the possession of a slave, whereby the sale is annulled, and the seller is obliged to return the price to the purchaser. (TA. voce xibovapN.)
See also guwlN, latter half.
[Its pl.] gawaAYilu also signifies Places of destruction. (TA.)
And you say, OaxaAfu gaAYilatahu, meaning I fear the result, and the evil, or mischief, thereof. (TA.)
Also A hole, or perforation, of a watering-trough, or tank, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,* TA,) that causes the water to pass away: (TA:) pl. gawaAYilu. (IAạr, O, TA.)

entry.sense: EayoXN guw-alN: see Oagowalu.
OaroDN gay-ilapN A land far extending. (Lḥ, TA.) [Mentioned also in art. gyl.]

Oagowalu [More, and most, destructive]. One says, Oay-apu guwlK Oagowalu mina AlgaDabi [What destroyer is more destructive than anger?]. (Ṣ, O: immediately following the explanation of the saying, AlgaDabu guwlu AlHilomi.)
[Hence, perhaps,] EayoXN Oagowalu A soft, or plentiful and easy, life; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) as also guw-alN↓. (Ḳ.)
migowalN [primarily] An instrument with which a thing is destroyed. (Ḥam p. 648.)

And [hence] used as meaning A knife: and in common acceptation, a knife that is put in the midst of a whip which is as a sheath to it: (Ḥam ibid.:) a knife to which a whip is a sheath: (Mgh:) or a slender sword, having a flat back (lahu qafFA), (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) like the knife, (Mṣb,) the sheath of which is like the whip: (Ṣ, O:) or an iron [weapon] that is put within a whip, which thus becomes to it a sheath: (Ḳ:) or a whip in the interior of which is a sword: (AʼObeyd, TA:) said to be thus called because its owner destroys with it his enemy unexpectedly: pl. magaAwilu: (TA:) and a thing like a miXomal [or short and slender sword over which a man covers himself with his garment], except that it is more slender, and longer: (Ḳ:) and a long naSol [or blade], (AḤn, Ḳ, TA,) of little breadth, thick in the maton [which generally means the part in the middle of which is the ridge, but may here mean the back]: (AḤn, TA:) or a short sword which a man wears inwrapped beneath his clothes: (TA:) or a slender sword, having a flat back (lahu qafFA): (Ḳ:) or a slender iron [weapon], having a sharp edge and a flat back (waqafFA), which the assassin binds upon his waist in order that he may therewith destroy men. (TA.)
[Hence,] farasN caAtu migowalK ‡ A mare having a quality, or faculty, of outstripping: (O, Ḳ, TA:) as though she destroyed the [other] horses so that they fell short of reaching her. (TA.)

nazaluwA mugaAwiliyna, occurring in a trad. respecting the lie [that was uttered against ʼÁïsheh, to which allusion is made in the Ḳur xxiv. 11], means They alighted [after] going far in the journeying. (TA.)
1: see what next follows {2}.

hom.sense: 2. gay-ayotu gaAyapF, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. tagoyiyapN; (TA;) [in the CK gayayotuhaA↓, which is wrong, unless they said thus as well as gay-ayotuhaA, like as they say rayayotu raAyapF as well as ray-ayotuhaA;] and OagoyayotuhaA↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA; but in the last as not found in the Ḳ;) I set up the banner, or standard; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) from AʼObeyd. (Ṣ.)
And gay-aI liloqawomi He set up a banner, or standard, for the people, or party: or he made it for them. (TA.)

And gay-ati AlT-ayoru The birds flapped their wings, or fluttered, in the air, without moving from their place; or did thus around a thing, desiring to alight upon it; syn. raforafato. (TA.) [See also 6.]
gay-ayotu gaAyapF signifies [also] bay-anotuhaA [i. e. I made apparent, or manifest, or known, an utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, or the like; or I set it]. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 3. gaAyaA Alqawomu fawoqa raOosi fulaAnK biAls-ayofi [The people, or party, acted with the sword above the head of such a one] as though they shadowed him with it; [i. e., flourished it above his head;] from Aṣ; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) inf. n. mugaAyaApN. (TA.)
4: see 2.
OagoyaA AlsaHaAbu The clouds were, or became, stationary, (Ḳ, TA,) Ealayohi upon, or over, him, or it; shadowing him, or it. (TA.)
AgyA Alr-ajulu The man attained the utmost limit, or reach, in eminence, or nobility, and in command: and in like manner, Alfarasu fiI sibaAqihi [the horse in his contending in a race]. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

hom.sense: 6. tagaAyati AlT-ayoru EalaI AlX-aIoCi The birds hovered, or circled, round about the thing. (TA.) [See also 2.]
tagaAyawoA Ealayohi Hat-aI qataluwhu signifies the same as tagaAwawoA. (TA.) [See the latter {6}, in art. gw or gwI.]

entry.sense: gaI-N: see art. gw or gwI.
gay-apN and giy-apN: see art. gw or gwI.
gay-aAnu: see art. gw or gwI.
gaAIN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: gaAyapN, originally gyyp [i. e. gayayapN], (TA,) The utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach; or the extremity; of a thing; (MA, KL, PṢ;) in respect of time and of place; (MA, PṢ;) syn. madFI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and munotahFI: (M, TA:) pl. gaAIN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] gaAyaAtN. (Mṣb.) [Hence, A goal to which racers run; as is indicated in the TA. And A scope; an object to be reached or accomplished, or that one has in view. And The ultimate object or intent of an action or a saying. And The ultimate import of a word: thus in the phrase, yuTolaqu biQEotibaAri gaAyatihi It is used with regard, or respect, to its ultimate import: opposed in this sense to mabodaON. And The utmost degree, maximum, climax, or acme, that is, or may be, attained.] And The utmost of one's power or ability, i. e., of one's deed: thus in the saying, gaAyatuka Oano tafoEala kacaA [The utmost of thy power or ability, or of thy deed, is, or will be, thy doing such a thing]. (Mṣb.) [And A person or thing, and persons or things, superlative, or consummate, in eminence or baseness, in goodness or evilness; that has, or have, attained the utmost degree therein. And, applied to a medicine, &c., Possessing the utmost efficacy, or efficiency, likacaA for such a thing.]

[Also, like madFI, A space that is, or that is to be, traversed; or an extent, or the space between two points or limits: whence AibotidaMCu gaAyapK, and AinotihaMCu gaAyapK, The beginning, and the end, of a space between two points or limits.]
And i. q. galowapN, meaning [A bow-shot; or] a shot of an arrow to the utmost possible distance. (Mṣb in art. glw.)
Also A banner, or standard: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. gaAyaAtN (Mṣb, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] gaAIN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A banner (raAyap) which the vintner used to raise [or set up] in order that he might be known to be a seller of wine. (TA.) [See an ex. voce EuqaAbN.]
And A cloud that is alone; apart from others: or that is falling, or alighting. (TA.)
And Birds flapping their wings, or fluttering, in the air, without moving from their place; or doing thus around a thing, desiring to alight upon it. (TA. [See 2.])
And The qSbp [app. qaSabap, generally meaning reed, or cane, but what is meant by it here I know not,] with which small birds (EaSaAfiyz) are taken, or caught, or sought to be taken or caught. (TA.)

entry.sense: gaAYiI-N [the rel. n. gaAyapN]. AlEil-apu AlgaAYiy-apu, with the scholastic theologians, means The final cause. (TA.)

gayaAyapN The light of the rays of the sun; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not the rays themselves: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, the shade of the sun [i. e. the shade that is cast by the sun] in the morning and in the evening: (TA:) pl. gayaAyaAtN. (Ṣ, TA.)
And Anything that shades a man, over his head, such as a cloud, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and dust, and darkness, and the like. (AA, Ṣ.)
And The bottom of a well; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like gayaAbapN. (Ṣ.)
gayaAyaMCu A man heavy in spirit; as though he were a dark, dense shadow, in which is no brightness. (TA.)

Almugay-aA That to which a limit is set, or put: so in the saying, AlgaAyapu laA tadoxulu fiI Almugay-aA [The limit shall not enter into, or be included in, that to which the limit is set]. (Mgh.) [And,] as used by the lawyers and the scholastic theologians, The end of the gaAyap [or space between two points or limits]: a post-classical term. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. gaAba, (Ṣ, O, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) aor. yagiybu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. gayobapN [the most common form] (Ṣ, O, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gayobN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gayaAbN, (Ṣ, O,) or giyaAbN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and guyuwbN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and guyuwbapN (O, Ḳ) and gayobuwbapN, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to some of the measure faEoluwlapN, but accord. to others of the measure fayoEaluwlapN i. e. originally gay-abuwbapN, (MF,) and magiybN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and magaAbN; (Ḳ;) and tgy-b↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) He, or it, was, or became, absent; gaAba being the contr. of HaDara; (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. HDr;) or distant, or remote; (Mgh;) or hidden, concealed, or unapparent; (TA;) [or absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception: see gayobN.] You say, gAb Eanohu, inf. n. gayobapN (Ṣ, Mgh, TA), &c., as above, (Ṣ, TA,) He, or it, was, or became, [absent from him; or] distant, or remote, from him; (Mgh;) or hidden, or concealed, from him; [&c.;] as also tgy-b↓. (TA.) And OawoHaXatoniI gayobapu fulaAnK [The absence of such a one has made me to feel lonely]: and OaTalota gayobataka [Thou hast made thine absence to be long]. (A.) And OanaA maEakumo laA OugaAyibukumo↓ [I am with you: I will not be absent from you]. (A.) And banuw fulaAnK yaXohaduwna OaHoyaAnFA wayatagaAyabuwna↓ OaHoyaAnFA (ISk, Ṣ, TA) i. e. [The sons of such a one are present sometimes] and are absent (yagiybuwna) sometimes: but one does not say yatagay-abuwna↓ [unless with Eano following it]: (TA:) [it seems, however, that ytgy-bwn, here, is a mistranscription for yatagay-abuwnanaA or the like; for] one says, tgy-b↓ Ean-iI fulaAnN [Such a one was, or became, absent from me; or absented himself from me]; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) and tagay-abaniI↓ also in a case of necessity in verse, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) but not in any other case, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to the generality of authorities except the Koofees: (TA:) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
faZal-a lanaA yawomN laciycN binaEomapK
faqulo fiI maqiylK naHosuhu mutagay-ibiI
[thus in my copies of the Ṣ and in the TA; but we should read mutagay-ibi, whether it mean mutagay-ibiI or not, as is shown by what follows: the verse may be rendered, So a delightful day, with ease and comfort, betided us: and say thou, of a place of midday-sleep whereof the ill luck was absent from me, …]: but Fr says that the word mtgy-b is marfooa, [i. e. that the right reading is mutagay-ibu, meaning simply absent,] that the verse is mukofaO [or made faulty in the termination], and that it is not allowable to make that word refer to maqiylK, like as it is not allowable to say mararotu birajulK Oabuwhu qaAYimK. (Ṣ, TA. [One might be tempted to suppose that we should read faqilo; but this would not suit the context, which see in Ahlwardt's “Divans of the six ancient Arabic poets,” p. 119.])

[gAb, inf. n. gayobapN, is also said of the mind (Alqalob), meaning † It was, or became, absent. The inf. n. (gayobapN) is often used as meaning † Absence of mind; and particularly, from self and others by its being exclusively occupied by the contemplation of divine things: see an ex. voce XawFI; and another voce sakiynapN.]

maA gaAba Eanohu Qbonu OabiI quHaAfapa † [Ibn-Abee-Koháfeh was not a stranger to it, i. e. was not unacquainted with it,] occurs in a trad. respecting a satirical saying of Hassán against [the tribe of] Kureysh; meaning that Aboo-Bekr [the son of Aboo-Koháfeh] was skilled in genealogies and traditions, and that it was he who instructed Hassán. (TA.)

And gAbt AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. giyaAbN and gayobuwbapN (Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and gayobapN (Mgh) and guyuwbN and guyuwbapN and magiybN; (TA;) and tgy-bt↓; (Mṣb;) The sun set: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) and the like is also said of the moon, (Mṣb,) and of other celestial bodies. (TA.)
And gAb AlX-aIoCu fiI AlX-aIoCi, inf. n. giyaAbapN and guyuwbapN and giyaAbN and gayaAbN and giybapN, [The thing became hidden, or concealed, in the thing.] (Ḳ.)
See also 8, in two places.

entry.sense: 2. gy-bhu (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) He caused him, or it, to become absent, or to disappear; or he hid, or concealed, it, Eanohu from him. (TA.) See also gayaAbN.
And see 8.
3. mugaAyabapN signifies The being absent,, &c., one from the other. (KL.) See also 1, former half.

Also The addressing words to another [in his absence,] not in his presence, not face to face; (KL;) contr. of muxaATabapN. (Ṣ, TA.) [You say, AgAbt, inf. n. as above, He held a verbal communication with him in his absence, i. e. by means of a letter or letters, or by a messenger or messengers.]
4. AgAbt She (a woman) had her husband, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) or one of her family, (TA,) absent from her. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)
5: see 1, in seven places.
The inf. n. tagay-ubN occurring in a trad. respecting the contract for the sale of a slave means The selling a stray slave, or one who has been found and whose owner is not known. (L, TA.)
6: see 1, former half.

8. AgtAbhu [He spoke evil of him; or did so in his absence, i. e. backbit him; (the latter being obviously the primary signification;) not always, though generally, meaning with truth:] he spoke evil of him in his absence; (TA;) or said of him, in his absence, what would grieve him (Ṣ, TA) if he heard it; (Ṣ;) with truth: (Ṣ, TA:) he carped at him behind the back, or in absence, by saying what would grieve him, (tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi↓ bimaA yasuwWuhu,) of what was [reprehensible] in him: (TA:) or he spoke of him imputing to him what he disliked, of vices, or faults, with truth: (Mṣb:) when the charge is false, it is termed buhotaAnN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) or he attributed, or imputed, to him a vice, or fault, or the like; and mentioned him with what was in him of evil; (Ḳ, TA;) or said of him what would grieve him: (TA:) and gaAbahu↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ, TA:) [so does gy-bhu↓: (see Ksh in civ. 1:) that AgtAbhu does not always signify he spoke evil of him, or the like, in his absence, appears from several instances, such as the phrases AlmugotaAbu fiI Alwajohi (Ḳ in art. lmz) and AlmugotaAbuwna biAlHaDorapi (IAạr, TA in that art.): nor does it always signify he spoke evil of him, or the like, with truth; for the verb is used in the Ksh and by Bḍ and Jel in civ. 1 having for its object the Prophet:] IAar says that gAb↓ is syn. with AgtAb, and signifies he mentioned a man with the imputation of good or of evil. (TA.) [It may also mean He expressed, or signified, an evil opinion of him by making signs with the side of the mouth, or with the eye, or with the head, or otherwise; as is indicated in the TA in arts. lmz and hmz.]
gaAbN: see gaAbapN, in three places.

hom.sense: gayobN Whatever is absent, or hidden, from one; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as though it were an inf. n. used in the sense of the act. part. n. [in which the meaning of a subst. is predominant]; (TA;) and so gaAYibN↓, which [in this sense] is a subst., like kaAhilN, (Ḳ, TA,) or an act. part. n. used in the sense of a subst.: (MF:) anything that is absent, or hidden, from the eyes; invisible, unseen, or unapparent; whether it be, or be not, perceived in the heart, or mind: (IAạr, TA:) [or anything unperceivable; absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception; or undiscoverable unless by means of divine revelation; a mystery, or secret, such as an event of futurity;] a thing that has been hidden from men, and with which the Prophet has acquainted them, of the events of the resurrection and of Paradise and of Hell, &c.; thus in the Ḳur ii. 2; (Zj, TA;) and [hence] Zj explains Algayob as meaning, in the Ḳur lxxxi. 24, that which has been revealed: (TA in art. Dn:) pl. guyuwbN. (Mṣb.) [See also the Ksh and Bḍ in ii. 2.] [Hence, EaAlamu Algayobi The world of the unseen; the invisible world.] And [hence also] one says, rajama biAlgayobi [and qacafa biAlgayobi (see art. qcf)] He spoke of that which he did not know: (Ḥam p. 494:) and qaAla rajomFA biAlgayobi He said conjecturally, [or speaking of that which was hidden from him or unknown by him,] without evidence, and without proof. (Mṣb in art. rjm, q. v.)

And † Doubt, or a doubting: (Ḳ:) but some disapprove this: some regard it as tropical: and some pronounce it correct: (MF, TA:) pl. giyaAbN and guyuwbN. (Ḳ.) A poet says,
Oanota nabiI-N taEolamu AlgiyaAbaA
laA qaAYilFA UifokFA walaA murotaAbaA
[Thou art a prophet, knowing doubts, or things doubted; not saying a lie, nor a thing suspected: or, more probably, the meaning is, the things unseen]. (TA.)

Also A place, in the ground, that hides, or conceals, one: (TA:) a low, or depressed, place in the ground, or in a tract of land: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or any place such that one knows not what is in it: and a place such that one knows not what is behind it: (Sh, TA:) pl. guyuwbN. (TA.) Hence the phrase Eano Zahori gayobK in a verse of Lebeed cited voce ZahorN, q. v. (TA.) [Hence also] one says, samiEotu SawotFA mino waraMCi Algayobi i. e. [I heard a sound, or voice,] from [behind] a place that I saw not. (A, TA.) And tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi bimaA yasuwWuhu: see 8. And takal-ama bihi Eano Zahori gayobK (A) or Eano Zahori Algayobi (TA, and A and O in art. Zhr) [app. He spoke of it by memory; in the absence of a book or the like; as one says in modern Arabic, EalaI AlgaAYib. See also ZahorN.]

Also The xamoSap [i. e. pit, or depression, as is shown by what here follows, (thus in the A, and in the Ksh in ii. 2, in the TA Huforap, which has a similar meaning,)] that is in the place where the kidney is situate, (Ksh, A, TA,) and which swells up when the beast becomes big in the belly: so says ISh: (Ksh ubi suprà:) or the xamoSap that is next to the kidney: (Bḍ in ii. 2: [De Sacy doubted respecting its meaning, but conjectured that it might be thus: see his Anthol. Gramm. Arabe p. 55:]) pl. guyuwbN: one says, Xaribati Ald-aAb-apu Hat-aI waArato guyuwba kulaAhaA, (ISh, Ksh ubi suprà, A, TA,) meaning huzuwmahaA [i. e. The beast drank until it concealed the pits of its kidneys]. (A, TA.)
And Fat: (Ḳ, TA:) i. e. the fat of the varob [q. v.] of a sheep or goat: so called because it is hidden from the eye. (TA.)
See also gaAYibN.

entry.sense: gayabN: see gaAYibN, in two places.

gaAbapN is originally [gayabapN] of the measure faEalapN, with fet-ḥ to the E. (Mṣb.) It signifies A low, or depressed, place, or a hollow in the ground, (El-Hawázinee, Ḳ, TA,) before which, or in the way to which, (duwnahaA,) is an eminence. (El-Hawá- zinee, TA.)

And (Ḳ) i. q. OajamapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) [i. e.] A bed of canes or reeds: (AḤn, Mṣb, TA:) and [a thicket, wood, or forest; like OajamapN;] a collection of trees, (AḤn, ISd, TA,) densely disposed; so called because it conceals what is in it: (ISd, TA:) or a tall Oajamap, having high, or very high, extremities [app. to its canes or reeds]: (TA:) pl. gaAbaAtN (Mṣb, TA) and [coll. gen. n.] gaAbN↓. (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA.)

And † A long spear (Ḳ, TA) that has extremities like those of the Oajamap [expl. above]: (TA:) [but I think that this addition in the TA correctly applies to gaAbapN signifying a number of spears, like a bed of canes or reeds, or like a forest; agreeably with two of the explanations here following:] or a spear that quivers in the wind: (Ḳ, TA:) or ‡ numerous spears, like abundant and dense trees: (A:) or an assemblage of spears; app. so called as being likened to a gAbp meaning an Oajamap of dense trees: (ISd, TA:) pl. gaAbaAt and [coll. gen. n.] gaAbN↓. (TA.) One says, OatawonaA fiI gaAbapK i. e. ‡ [They came to us] amid numerous spears, like abundant and dense trees: (A:) or gAbp may be used in this case in the sense here following. (TA.)
And A company, or congregated body, of men: (Aboo-Jábir El-Asadee, Ḳ, TA:) pl. gaAbaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] gaAbN↓. (TA.)
gayobapN an inf. n. [See 1, in several places.]

Also, and gayaAbapN↓, A low, or depressed, piece of land or ground: so in the phrases waqaEonaA fiI gayobapK and gayaAbapK [app. meaning We lighted upon a low, or depressed, piece, &c.; or perhaps the meaning may be we fell into, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
See also gayaAbapN.

giybapN the subst. from AigotaAbahu: (Mṣb:) it signifies [Evil speech respecting a person; or such speech in his absence; not always, though generally, meaning with truth:] evil speech respecting a person in his absence; (TA;) or a saying of him, in his absence, what would grieve him (Ṣ, TA) if he heard it; (Ṣ;) with truth: (Ṣ, TA:) or speech respecting a person imputing to him what he dislikes, of vices, or faults, with truth: (Mṣb:) when it is false, it is termed buhotaAnN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) or an imputing to a person a vice, or fault, or the like; and a mentioning him with what is in him of evil; (Ḳ, TA;) or a saying of him what would grieve him: (TA:) or it may be speech imputing good or evil. (Ḳ,* TA.)

gayibaAnN or gayobaAnN, [accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, between which the TA does not enable us to decide with certainty, as it only states, with respect to the I, that it is muxaf-afap, which may mean either the contr. of doubled or the contr. of movent, though the former is the more general meaning, (in the TA it is said to be erroneously written in a copy of the Ḳ with a final t instead of n,)] and gay-ibaAnN↓, The roots of trees, (Ḳ, TA,) that are hidden from view: or, accord. to AḤn, the gybAn and gy-bAn↓ and gayaAbap↓, of plants, or herbage, are, with the Arabs, what the sun has not shone upon: and accord. to Aboo-Ziyád El-Kilábee, the gybAn and gy-bAn↓ of plants, or herbage, and also of their roots, are what is concealed from the sun, so as to be not shone upon by it. (L, TA.)
gay-ibaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

gayaAbN A thing that hides, or conceals, a thing from one: (Meyd:) and hence, (Meyd, TA,) a grave; (Ṣ, Meyd, TA;) and so gayaAbapN↓: (TA:) one says, gay-abahu↓ gayaAbuhu (Ṣ, Meyd, TA) and gayaAbatuhu↓ (TA) meaning dufina fiI qaborihi (Ṣ, Meyd, TA) [i. e. May he be buried in his grave]: an imprecation of death against the man. (Meyd.)

gayaAbapN The part of anything that veils, or conceals, one. (Ḳ.) And hence, (Ḳ,) The bottom of a jub- [or well]; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) or this, accord. to some, is the primary signification; as also gayobapN↓, accord. to one reading, in the Ḳur xii. 10; (TA;) [and gayaAyapN;] and of a valley; (Ṣ, TA;), &c.: (TA:) pl. gayaAbaAtN. (Ḳ, TA.) [And A covert, or place of concealment, of birds. (See ZilaAlapN.)] See also gayaAbN, in two places: and gayobapN.
And see gayibaAnN.

gaAYibN act. part. n. of 1 [signifying Absent; distant, or remote; and hidden, concealed, or unapparent; or absent from the range, or beyond the reach, of perception by sense, or of mental perception]: pl. (applied to men, Ḳ, TA) guy-abN and guy-aAbN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gaAYibuwna (Ḳ) and gayabN↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or rather the last is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and gayobN↓, [which is also properly speaking a quasi-pl. n.,] like SaHobN: (Mṣb [in which gayabN is not mentioned]:) the I in gayabN↓ remains unchanged, notwithstanding the two fet-ḥahs, because it is likened to SayadN, and, although it is a pl. [in signification] and SayadN is an inf. n., it may be used as meant for an inf. n. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also gayobN, first sentence.
Also A run in which a horse reserves [somewhat of his force for the time of need]. (A in art. Xhd: see XaAhidN.)
magiybN [an inf. n.:]
[and also a n. of place and of time, signifying] The place [and the time] of setting of the sun and of the moon [&c.]. (Mṣb.)

mugiybN and mugiybapN, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or you say mugiybapN [only], with p, and [in the contr. sense] muXohidN, without p, (IDrd, Ṣ,) and mugoyibN (Ḳ) and mugay-ibN↓, (TA,) A woman having her husband (or one of her family, TA) absent from her. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)
mugay-bN: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. gaAva Qll-ehu AlbilaAda, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yagiyvu, inf. n. gayovN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) God watered the country, or countries, with rain. (O, Mṣb, TA.) And gaAvanaA He (God) sent down rain upon us. (TA.) And gAv Algayovu AlOaroDa, (aor. and inf. n. as above, Mṣb,) The rain fell upon the earth. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And giyvati AlOaroDu, aor. tugaAvu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, O,) The land was watered with rain. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) giyva Alqawomu The people were rained upon; rain fell upon the people [or upon their land]. (TA.) And givanoA maA XiYonaA [We were rained upon as much as we desired]: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA:) originally guyivonaA. (TA.)
gAv Aln-aworu ‡ The blossom shone. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
See also 4 in art. gwv.

entry.sense: 2. gy-v, said of a blind man, He sought, or searched, [or groped, with the hand,] for a thing: (Kr, TA:) also written [Ey-v] with [the unpointed] E, and thus correctly, though ISd thought this latter to be a mistranscription. (TA.)
5. tgy-v He became fat: (Ḳ:) said of a camel. (TḲ.)
gayovN inf. n. of gaAva [q. v.]. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.)

And [a subst.] signifying Rain: (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or rain that occupies the space of a bariyd [i. e. six miles, or twelve miles,] in width: (AA, O, Ḳ:) or rain that is productive of much good; [supposed to belong to art. gwv, for it is added,] because mankind are aided thereby; thus expl. in the “Sharh esh-Shifè:” pl. OagoyaAvN [a pl. of pauc.] and guyuwvN. (TA.) [Hence a tropical usage in a saying mentioned voce vaj-aAjN.]

And [hence] cubaAbu gayovK [or cubaAbu Algayovi (see cubaAbN) lit. The fly of rain or the fly of the rain] signifies † the bee, or bees collectively: so called because the bee seeks after herbage and flowers, which are consequent upon the rain: (IAth, TA:) [for]
gayovN signifies also ‡ Herbage (Lth, Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) which grows by means of the water of the sky: (Lth, A, O, Ḳ:) called thus by the name of its cause. (Mṣb.)
And ‡ Clouds. (Ṣ, O, TA.) [See an ex. voce faruwqapN.]
giyaAvN, originally giwaAvN, see in art. gwv.
gay-ivN i. q. Eayolamu maMCK [i. e. Water that is beneath a stratum of rock]. (TA.) [Hence] biYorN caAtu gay-ivK A well having a constant accession of water. (O, Ḳ.)
And [hence] farasN cuw gay-ivK ‡ A horse that performs, (O,) or that increases [his running], (Ḳ, TA,) run after run. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
OaroDN magiyvapN, and magoyuwvapN↓, (the latter being the original form, TA,) Land watered with rain. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
gayovN mugiyvN A general rain. (TA.) [But the epithet mugiyvN evidently belongs to art. gwv; and the phrase properly signifies A rain that gives aid, or succour.]
OaroDN magoyuwvapN: see magiyvapN.
1. gayida, aor. _a {yagoyadu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. gayadN, (L,) He had a bending neck, and limber sides: (L, Ḳ:) or he had a lax, or limber, neck. (L.)
[And gayidat is app. said of a young woman as meaning She was soft, or tender; or soft, or tender, and limber in the sides. (See gayadN below.)]
[And gayida He was, or became, drowsy; or drowsy and with a bending of the neck. (See, again, gayadN below.)]

6. tgAyd He affected a bending of his body, or he bent his body, from side to side, in his gait. (A.) And tgAydt She (a woman, L) affected a bending of her body, or bent her body, (L, Ḳ, TA,) from side to side, (TA,) in her gait, by reason of softness, or limberness. (L, Ḳ, TA.)
gaAdN A fresh, tender, juicy twig: (L:) and so gaAdapN applied to a tree (XajarapN). (L, Ḳ.)

And the latter, A soft, or tender, goodly, thin-skinned, plump, and fresh, or flourishing, young woman: (L:) or, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) as also gayodaMCu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) a woman, soft, or tender: (Ṣ, A:) or soft, or tender, and limber (L, Ḳ, TA) in the sides. (TA.)
giydi giydi, or giydo giydo, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) Hasten thou; make haste; be quick: (Ḳ:) a word of the people of Esh-Shihr. (TA.)
gayadN [mentioned above as an inf. n.], in a woman, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in a young woman, (L,) Softness, or tenderness, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and limberness (L, Ḳ) of the sides. (L.)
And Drowiness: (A:) [or drowsiness with a bending of the neck: see Oagoyadu.]
gayodaAnN The prime, spring, or first part, of youth. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA.)
Oagoyadu A plant, or herbage, soft, or tender, and bending. (L, Ḳ.)
And ‡ A place abounding with plants, or herbage, (O, Ḳ, TA,) bending by reason of softness. (O.)

Also A man, and a gazelle, having a bending neck, and limber sides: or having a lax, or limber, neck. (L.) And [the fem.] gayodaMCu (L, Ḳ) A woman (L) who bends her body, or affects a bending thereof, by reason of her softness, or limberness. (L, Ḳ.) See also gaAdN.

Also Drowsy, and having a bending of the neck: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) fem. gayodaMCu: (TA:) and pl. giydN. (L.) AlkaraI AlOagoyadu, occurring in a verse cited voce SubaAbapN [q. v.], means ‡ Drowsiness that makes one to bend the neck from side to side. (L, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gaAra Oaholahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and gAr lahumo, (TA,) aor. yagiyru, inf. n. giyaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and gayorN, (Mṣb, TA,) i. q. maArahumo, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) i. e. He brought, or conveyed, to his family, miyrap [or a provision of corn, or wheat,, &c.] (Mṣb.) [See also art. gwr.]

And He benefited them. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.) 'AbdMenáf Ibn-Riba El-Hudhalee says
maA caA yagiyru QbonataIo riboEK EawiyluhumaA
[What will their loud weeping benefit, or avail, the two daughters of Riba?] meaning that their weeping for their father will not avail them aught in lieu of seeking his blood-revenge. (Ṣ, TA.)
You say gaArahumo bixayorK, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (God) bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth, and rain; (TA in art. gwr;) like as you say OaEoTaAhumo xayorFA: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so gArhm birizoqi [He bestowed upon them means of subsistence]. (TA.) And Aall-ehum-a gironaA bixayorK (Ṣ, Mṣb) O God, benefit us with prosperity. (Mṣb.) And gaArahumo bimaTarK He (God) watered them with rain, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and bestowed upon them abundance of the produce of the earth. (TA.) And gaAra AlOaroDa Algayovu The rain watered the land. (Fr, Ṣ.) [See also art. gwr.]

gaArahu, aor. yagiyruhu, (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. gayorN, (TA,) He gave him the bloodwit; (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also gArhu, aor. yaguwruhu; (AO, Ṣ, TA;) mino Oaxiyhi [for his brother]: and so gy-rhu↓. (TA.) [See giyrapN.]

gaAra EalaI Oaholihi, (Ṣ,) or ElI QmoraOatihi, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yagaAru, inf. n. gayorapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with fet-ḥ, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and gayorN and gaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and giyaArN, (Ḳ,) [He was jealous of his wife:] he was jealous for her (mino fulaAnK of such a one: Mgh): [he was careful of her, to avoid suspicion: or he regarded her conduct with disdain, scorn, or indignation: (see gayorapN, below:) or] he was angry at the conduct, or action, of his wife. (Mṣb.) And gaArati QmoraOatuhu Ealayohi [His wife was jealous of him:, &c.]. (M, b, Ḳ.) [See also art. gwr.] And you say also, fulaAnN laA yatagay-aru↓ EalaI Oaholihi, meaning laA yagaAru [Such a one is not jealous of his wife:, &c.]. (TA.)

2. gy-r AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) inf. n. tagoyiyrN, (Mṣb,) He made the thing other than it was; (Ḳ;) made it cease to have the quality which it had; (Mṣb;) altered it; changed it. (Ḳ.) He, or it, altered, or changed, the thing in odour, or otherwise, for the worse; corrupted, tainted, or infected, it; rendered it ill-smelling, stinking, fetid, rancid, rank, fusty, or frouzy. (The lexicons passim.) It is said in the Ḳur [viii. 55], celika biOan-a Qll-eha lamo yaku mugay-irFA niEomapF OanoEamahaA EalaI qawomK Hat-aI yugay-iruwA maA biOanofusihimo [This was because God changeth not favour which He hath conferred upon a people until they change what is in themselves: or] until they change what God hath commanded them to do. (Th, TA.)
[And He exchanged the thing for another thing.]
gy-r AlX-ayoba He plucked out the white, or hoary, hairs. (TA.)

gy-r Eano baEiyrihi He put down the saddle from his camel, and put it to rights, or adjusted it, or repaired it. (TA.) One says taraka Alqawoma yugay-iruwna He left the people putting to rights, or adjusting, or repairing, the camels' saddles. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also 1, latter half.
3. [gaAyaraA, inf. n. mugaAyarapN, They differed, each from the other.] You say bayonahumaA mugaAyarapN Between them two is a difference. (Mṣb.) [See also 6.]

gAyrhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. mugaAyarapN, (Ṣ,) He bartered, or exchanged, with him, in buying and selling. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And gAyrhu biAls-iloEapi, inf. n. as above, He bartered, or exchanged, the article of merchandise with him. (TA.) And gAyr Als-iloEapa, (TA,) inf. n. giyaArN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) He exchanged the article of merchandise. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA.) El-Aạshà says
falaA taHosiban-iI lakumo kaAfirFA
walaA taHosiban-iI Ouriydu AlgiyaAraA
[Therefore do thou by no means think me ungrateful towards you; and do thou by no means think I desire the making an exchange]. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AgAr Oaholahu [He made his wife jealous;] he married another in addition to his wife, so she became jealous (gArt): (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Mṣb, Ḳ:) belonging to this art. and to art. gwr. (TA.)

5. tgy-r quasi-pass. of gy-r, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [It became other than it was;] it ceased to have the quality which it had; (Mṣb;) it became altered, or changed, Eano HaAlihi, from its state or condition. (Ḳ.) It became altered, or changed, in odour, or otherwise, for the worse; turned, or turned bad; became corrupted, spoiled, tainted, infected, illsmelling, stinking, fetid, rancid, rank, fusty, or frouzy. (The lexicons passim.)
[And It became exchanged for another thing.]
See also 1, last signification.
6. tgAyrt AlOaXoyaMCu The things differed, one from another. (Ṣ.)
8. AgtAr He procured miyrap [a provision of corn, or wheat,, &c.]. (Ḳ.) You say xaraja yagotaAru liOaholihi He went forth to procure myrp for his family. (Fr, Ṣgh.)
He derived, or obtained, benefit, advantage, or profit. (TA.) See also art. gwr.

hom.sense:
gayorN signifies i. q. siwFI [Other]: and the pl. is OagoyaArN: (Ṣ:) [but gayor itself often has a pl. meaning, as will be seen in what follows:] or [accord. to general usage, as will be seen below,] gayoru signifies i. q. siwaI [other than; exclusively of; or not, as used before a substantive or an adjective]. (Mṣb, Ḳ: in the CK [erroneously] siwFI.) It is used to qualify a subst.; [governing (as a prefixed noun) the noun that follows it in the gen. case;] and when so used, it is put in the same case as the noun preceding it. (Ṣ.) It qualifies an indeterminate noun: (Mughnee, Mṣb:) you say jaMCaniI rajulN gayoruka [A man, other than, or not, thou, came to me]: (Mṣb:) and naEomalo SaAliHFA gayora Ql-aciI kun-aA naEomalu [We will in that case do good, other than, or not, what we used to do: (Ḳur xxxv. 34:)]: (Mughnee:) and mino maMCK gayori MsinK [Of water other than, or not, altered in taste and colour]. (Ḳur xlvii. 16.) It is a noun necessarily prefixed, as to the sense, to a noun which it governs in the gen. case: but sometimes it is without the latter, when the meaning is understood and it is preceded by layosa, (Mughnee, Ḳ,) or by laA: (Ḳ:) [in which case it signifies Any other person or thing; any person or thing beside, or else:] you say qabaDotu EaXarapF layosa gayoruhaA [I received ten; not other than they was received by me; i. e., not any other thing; or not anything beside, or else]; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) the enunciative, maqobuwDFA, being suppressed: (Mughnee:) and lys gayorahaA, (Mughnee, Ḳ;) the noun [of lys] being understood; i. e., layosa AlmaqobuwDu gayorahaA: (Mughnee:) and lys gayora; in which the affixed noun [for AlmDAf, in the Ḳ, I read AlmDAf Alyh, as in the Mughnee,] is suppressed, and the noun [of lys] is also understood: (Mughnee, Ḳ:) and lys gayoru; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) in which, accord. to Mbr, and the later authors, gyr is indecl., being likened to qabolu and baEodu, so that it may be either the noun or the enunciative [of lys] or, accord. to Akh, it is decl., because it is not a noun of time like qabolu and baEodu, nor of place like fawoqu and taHotu, but like kul-N and baEoDN, so that it is the noun [of lys], and the enunciative is suppressed; (Mughnee;) or it may be either indecl. or decl., (Mughnee, Ḳ,) accord. to Ibn-Kharoof: (Mughnee:) and lys gayorFA, and lys gayorN; (Mughnee, Ḳ;) in both which cases it is decl., as though the affixed noun were mentioned: (Mughnee:) and laA gayoru; for the saying, [which we find in the Mughnee,] app. taken from a statement of Seer, that this is incorrect, is not good, since it occurs in the following verse, cited by Ibn-Málik;
jawaAbFA bihi tanojuw QEotamido fawarab-inaA
laEano EamalK Oasolafota laA gayoru tusoOalu
[Aim thou at having an answer by which thou mayest be safe; for, by our Lord, respecting an action which thou shalt have done before, not any other thing, or not anything beside or else, thou wilt be asked]. (Ḳ.)

It does not become determinate by its being prefixed to another noun, because it is very vague: but it is also applied as an epithet to a determinate noun which is near to being indeterminate; as in SiraATa Ql-aciyna OanoEamota Ealayohimo gayori QlomagoDuwbi Ealayohimo [The way of those upon whom Thou hast conferred favour; the other than, or those who are not, the objects of anger; (Ḳur i. 6 and 7;)] because the noun rendered determinate by the art. Al denoting a genus is near to being indeterminate, and because when gyr occurs between two contraries its vagueness becomes weakened, (Mughnee, Ḳ,*) or altogether departs: (Ḳ:) or it is here applied as an epithet to a determinate noun because it resembles a determinate noun in its being prefixed to such a noun: (Mṣb:) Az says that gyr is here in the gen. case because it is an epithet to Alcyn; and that it may be an epithet to [what is technically termed in this instance] a determinate noun [as having the article Al prefixed to it] because Alcyn has not [in itself] a direct meaning (liOan-a Al-aciyna gayoru maSomuwdK Samoduhu), [it being merely a conjunct noun, the meaning of which is determined by what follows it,] notwithstanding it has the art. Al prefixed to it: Abu-l-ʼAbbás says that Fr holds Alcyn to have the office of an indeterminate noun; and gyr to be an epithet of it; not of any other noun; but that gyr, accord. to some, may be an epithet relating to the nouns implied in AnEmt Elyhm, these not having a direct meaning: Akh says that gyr [with what follows] is a substitute [for Alcyn with what follows], as though the meaning were SiraATa gayori AlmagoDuwbi Ealayohimo [the way of those who are not the objects of anger]. (TA.)
The reading gayora is also related, on the authority of Ibn-Ketheer, in the accus. case, as a denotative of state, [meaning they being not the objects of anger,] relating to the pronoun governed in the gen. case by the prep. [in Elyhm]; or by OaEoniI [I mean] understood; or as an exceptive, [accord. to a usage to be explained below,] if the favours be interpreted as conferred in common upon the two classes of persons. (Bḍ.)

As it resembles a determinate noun in its being prefixed to a determinate noun, [as AlmgDwb in the above-cited passage of the Ḳur,] some have presumed to prefix to it the article Al: but against this it may be urged, that its prefixion to a determinate noun is not to render the expression determinate, but for specification; and Al does not imply specification. (Mṣb.)

In the following verse of Hassán,
OataAnaA falamo naEodilo siwaAhu bigayorihi
nabiI-N badaA fiI Zulomapi All-ayoli haAdiyaA
the meaning is, [A prophet came to us, who appeared in the darkness of night, a director in the right way,] and we did not weigh another than him with another than the other, i. e., with him. (Mughnee.)
[wagayoru celika is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning Et cœtera.]
gayoru is also used in the sense of layosa [He, or it, is not]; as in the phrase kalaAmu Qll-ehi gayoru maxoluwqK [The word of God is not created], syn. layosa bimaxoluwqK. (Az, TA.)

It is also used in the sense of laA [meaning Not, as used before a participle]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and then it is in the accus. case, as a denotative of state; (Ṣ;) as in the phrase famani QDoTur-a gayora baAgK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [ii. 168, and other places], (Ṣ,) i. e., jaAYiEFA laA baAgiyFA [But whosoever is necessitated, being hungry, not transgressing the due bounds]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

It is also used as an exceptive, (Ṣ, Mughnee,) in the sense of Uil-aA [Except; save; or but]; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and then it is put in the same case in which the word following Uil-aA would be put in the same phrase, (Ṣ, Mughnee, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because it is originally a qualificative, and its use as an exceptive is adventitious: (Ṣ:) therefore you say jaMCa Alqawomu gayora zayodK [The people came, except Zeyd]; and maA jaMCaniI OaHadN gayora zayodK and gayoru zayodK [Not any one came to me, except Zeyd]: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or its case depends upon the governing words, so that you say maA qaAma gayoru zayodK [No one stood, except Zeyd], and maA raOayotu gayora zayodK [I saw not any, except Zeyd]: (Mṣb:) but Fr says that some of the Benoo-Asad and Ḳuḍáʼah put gyr in the accus. case, when used in the sense of Uil-aA, whether the phrase before it be complete or incomplete; saying maA jaMCaniI gayoraka [Not any one came to me, except thou], and mA jACnI OaHadN gayoraka [Not any one came to me, except thou]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and AA says that when gyr has the place of Uil-aA, it is put in the accus. case. (Mṣb.) In the saying laA Uileha gayoru Qll-ehi [There is no deity other than God], gyr is in the nom. case because it is the enunciative of lA; but it may be put in the accus. case, as meaning Uil-aA. (Mṣb.) When, as an exceptive, it is prefixed to an indecl. word [and not preceded by a prep.], it may be itself indecl., with fet-ḥ for its termination; as in the following verse;
lamo yamonaEi AlX-uroba minohaA gayora Oano naTaqato
HamaAmapN fiI guSuwnK caAti OawoqaAli
[Nought prevented the drinking from it, except that a pigeon cooed, upon branches having AwqAl, which app. means stumps of cut shoots]. (Mughnee, Ḳ.) [See also an ex. (of gayora Oan-a) in a verse cited voce bayoda.]
[It is often used with a prep.; as in bigayori HisaAbK Without reckoning; (Ḳur ii. 208, &c.;) and mino gayori suwoCK Without leprosy. (Ḳur xx. 23, &c.)]

gayorN (JK, Ḳ) and (JK) giyarN↓ (JK, Ṣ) signifying The act of altering, or changing, i. q. tagoyiyrN, (JK,) are substs. from gay-arahu; (Ṣ with respect to the latter, and Ḳ with respect to the former;) not inf. ns., as having no unaugmented verb. (TA.)

[Hence,] giyaru↓ Ald-ahori, the former of these two words being of the same measure as Einab, The accidents, or casualties, of time or fortune, which alter, or change, things: (Ḳ:) [or alteration, or change, of time or of fortune; for] IAmb says, with respect to the saying laA OaraAniI Qll-ehu bika giyarFA [May God not show me, in thee, alteration of state], that giyarN is from tagay-uru AlHaAli, a subst. like qiTaEN [as meaning “a portion of the night”]; or that it may be a pl., of which the sing. is giyorapN↓. (TA.)

[Hence also,] banaAtu gayorK [or giyarK↓, as in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 309,] ‡ Lying: or a lie, or falsehood: syn. kacibN: (TṢ, Ḳ:) or [rather] lies. (JK, A.) You say jaMCa bibanaAti gayorK [or giyarK↓] ‡ He uttered lies. (A.)

entry.sense: giyarN: see gayorN, last quarter, in four places:
and see also giyrapN.

gayorapN [Jealousy;] a man's dislike of another's participating in that which is his [the former's] right: (Kull p. 268:) or care of what is sacred, or inviolable, to avoid suspicion: or disdain; scorn; or indignation: syn. Hamiy-apN and OanafapN: (TA:) or anger at the conduct, or action, of a wife. (Mṣb.) [See 1, last signification.]

hom.sense: giyrapN A provision of corn, or wheat,, &c., which a man procures for himself; syn. miyrapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also giyaArN↓: (TA:) [or the latter is probably syn. with miyrapN used in the sense of an inf. n.:] pl. of the former giyarN. (Mṣb.) [See art. gwr.]
See also gayorN, last sentence but two.

Also A bloodwit; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ;) syn. diyapN: (AA, Ṣ:*) and giwarN is a dial. var. thereof: (TA in art. gwr:) pl. giyarN↓: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, this is a sing., (Ṣ, TA,) of the masc. gender; (TA;) and the pl. is OagoyaArN: (Ṣ, TA:) and the diyap is said to be termed giyarN because it is a substitute for retaliation. (TA.)

giyaArN The cognizance, or badge, of the free nonmuslim subjects of a Muslim government; such as the zun-aAr [or waist-belt] (Mgh, Ḳ) to the Magians, (Mgh,) and the like: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or, as some say, the cognizance, or badge, of the Jews. (TA.)
kalAmN bigiyaArihi † Speech, or language, having its own proper guise; not altered therefrom. (Mṣb in jlf.)
See also giyrapN.

entry.sense: gayuwrN and gayoraAnu↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gay-aArN↓ (TA) and migoyaArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) epithets [all of which are intensive] from gaAra EalaI Oaholihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e., from Algayorapu: (TA:) [Very jealous:, &c.: see gayorapN:] and gayuwrN and gayoraI (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gay-aArapN (TA) signify the same applied to a woman: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the pl. of gayuwrN is guyurN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) masc. and fem., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and he who says rusolN [for rusulN] says guyorN [or giyrN?]; (TA;) and of gayoraAnu↓, gayaAraI and guyaAraI; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and of gayoraI, also, gayaAraI (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and guyaAraI; (Mṣb;) and of migoyaArN↓, magaAyiyru. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
gay-aArN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Oagoyaru mina AlHum-aI [More jealous than fever:] because a fever cleaves fast to its patient, like as a very jealous woman cleaves to her husband. (TA.)
OaroDN magiyrapN and magoyuwrapN↓, Land watered: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or rained upon: (TA:) the former [like the latter] is with fet-ḥ to the m. (Ṣ.)
mugay-irN One who puts down the furniture of his camel from off him, to relieve and ease him. (TA.)
migoyaArN: see gayuwrN, in two places.
ArD magoyuwrapN: see magiyrapN.

hom.sense: 1. gaADa, aor. yagiyDu, inf. n. gayoDN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and magaADN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and magiyDN, (TA,) It (water) became scanty, or little in quantity, and sank into the earth, or disappeared in the earth: (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ:) or became scanty, or little in quantity, and decreased, or diminished, or became deficient: (A, and so in some copies of the Ḳ:) or sank into the earth, and went away: (TA:) or went away into the earth; (Mṣb;) [contr. of faADa, aor. yafiyDu;] as also AngAD↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz. (TA.)
It (a thing, Mṣb, a flow of milk, TA, and † the price of a commodity, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) decreased, or diminished, or became deficient. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

wamaA tagiyDu QloOaroHaAmu wamaA tazodaAdu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) in the Ḳur [xiii. 9], (Ṣ,) means And the wombs' falling short [of completion or of what is usual], (Akh, Ṣ, Bḍ,) and their exceeding [therein], in respect of the body [of the fœtus], and the period of gestation, and the number borne: (Bḍ:)
or, as some say, in respect of the menstrual blood: (Bḍ:) or the wombs' falling short of the nine months (Zj, O, L, and so in copies of the Ḳ, but in others seven months,) of gestation, and their exceeding the nine [or seven] months: (Zj, O, L:) or the wombs' falling short of completion, so that the fœtus dies, and their exceeding so that the gestation becomes complete: and accord. to this explanation, the reading of seven months in the Ḳ may be correct: see also Ḳatádeh's explanation of gayoDN, below, which favours this reading. (TA.)
You say also, gaADa AlkiraAmu wafaADa All-iYaAmu (Ṣ, A) ‡ The generous became few, (Ṣ, TA,) and failed, or perished, (TA,) and the mean became many. (Ṣ.)

gaADahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. as above, inf. n. gayoDN, (TA,) He (God, Ṣ, Mṣb) made it (i. e. water) to become scanty, or little in quantity, and to sink into the earth, or disappear in the earth: (Ṣ:) or made it to decrease, or diminish, or become deficient: (Ḳ:) or made it to go away into the earth: (Mṣb:) and AgADhu↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and so does gy-Dhu↓, inf. n. tagoyiyDN: (TA:) thus the first of these verbs is trans. as well as intrans. (Ṣ.) [It is said in the Ḳur xi. 46,] wagiyDa QlomaMCu (Ṣ, A) And the water was made to become scanty,, &c.: (Ṣ:) or was made to decrease, or diminish. (A,* Bḍ.) And hence the saying of ʼÁïsheh, describing her father, wagaADa naboEa Alr-id-api † And he did away with what appeared of apostacy. (TA.) You say also, gy-D↓ damoEahu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He made his tears to diminish, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and restrained them: (Ṣ:) or he took the tears from his eye and dashed them away. (Th.) A poet says, (TA,) namely, Jereer, (O and TA in art. gbD,)
gay-aDona↓ mino EabaraAtihin-a waqulona liI
maA caA laqiyta mina AlhawaI walaqiynaA
meaning They made their tears to flow until they exhausted them [and they said to me, What is it that thou hast experienced, of love, and we have experienced?]: ISd says that mn here denotes some; or it may be redundant, accord. to the opinion of Abu-l-Ḥasan; for he holds that it may be so in affirmative [as well as negative] phrases, mentioning, as an instance, qado kaAna mino maTarK, meaning qado kaAna maTarN. (TA.) One relation of this verse gives gab-aDona; but the former is the right. (O and TA in art. gbD.)
Also He opened a way, passage, or channel, for it (namely water) to flow forth to a magiyD [q. v.]. (Mṣb.)
† He diminished it, namely the price of a commodity; (Ks, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AgADhu↓. (Ḳ.)
And He caused him to suffer loss, or detriment; and wronged, or injured, him. (ISd, TA.)
2. gy-Dhu: see 1, latter half, in three places.
gy-D said of a lion He frequented, or kept to, the gayoDap [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ṣgh, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. AgADhu: see 1, latter half, in two places.
7: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: gayoDN An abortive fœtus, not completely formed; (Ḳatádeh, Ḳ;) i. e. less than seven months old. (TA.)
‡ Little; or a small quantity: as in the saying, or in OaEoTaAhu gayoDFA mino fayoDK ‡ He gave him little from much. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
An abundance of the trees called OaEolaAv; i. e. TarofaMC and Oavol and HaAj and EikoriX and yanobuwt. (TA.) [See also gayoDapN.]

entry.sense: giyDN The TaloE [or spadix of a palm-tree]; (IAạr, IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA;) like gaDiyDN and UigoriyDN: (TA:) or the Eajam (AA, O, Ḳ) [thus correctly (in the CK Eujom) evidently, I think, here meaning the heart (commonly called jum-aAr q. v.) of the palm-tree (the only produce that is eaten except the dates)] that comes forth, or coming forth, (Ḳ,) or that has not come forth, (O,) from [amid] its [membranous fibres termed] liyf [q. v.], and all of which is eaten. (AA, O, Ḳ.)

gayoDapN A thicket; syn. OajamapN; i. e. a collection of tangled, or confused, or dense, trees: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or an Oajamap; i. e. a magiyD↓ [q. v.] of water collected together, in which, in consequence thereof, trees grow: (Ṣ:) or an Oajamap: and a place in which is a collection of trees in a magiyD of water: (Ḳ:) or particularly, of [trees of the willow-kind called] garab; not of all trees; (AḤn, O, Ḳ;) accord. to the first Arabs of the desert; but this is at variance with what we find in the poems of the Arabs; for Ru-beh, for instance, makes it to consist of fruit-bearing trees and trees not fruit-bearing, and makes it to be a gaAbap: (AḤn, O:) [see also gayonapN:] pl. [of pauc.] OagoyaADN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and [of mult.] giyaADN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and gayoDaAtN: (Mṣb:) the first of these being formed with disregard of the augmentative [p]; not being a pl. pl., for this is not so formed: (TA:) any garab in Nejd adjacent to the garab of the cultivated lands, when they are collected therein, are termed giyaAD. (O, TA.) [See also gayoDN.]

gaAYiD as used in the following verse,
UilaI Qll-ehi OaXokuw mino xaliylK Oawad-uhu
valaAva xilaAlK kul-uhaA liIa gaAYiDu
is said by some to mean gaAYiZ, the D being substituted for Z; [so that the verse should be rendered, To God I complain of three qualities, or habits, of a friend whom I love, every one of which is to me such as angers;] thus says IJ: but ISd says that it may be without substitution, from gaADahu as expl. in the last sentence of the first paragraph of this art.; and thus the meaning may be, such as causes me to suffer loss, or detriment, and such as wrongs, or injures, me. (TA.)
magiyDN is an inf. n. (TA. [See 1, first sentence.])
And also the pass. part. n. of gaADahu; applied to water. (Mṣb, TA.*)

And a n. of place, signifying A place where water sinks, or goes away, into the earth: (Mṣb, TA:) or magiyDu maMCK signifies a place where water enters [into the earth]: and a place where water collects: (Mgh:) see also gayoDapN: pl. magaAyiDu. (Mgh.)
1. gaATa, aor. yagiyTu, inf. n. gayoTN: see gaATa, aor. yaguwTu, inf. n. gawoTN, in art. gwT.
gayoTN: see gaAYiTN in art. gwT.

1. gaAZahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yagiyZu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. gayoZN, (Mṣb, TA,) He, or it, affected him with gayoZ [or anger, wrath, or rage;, &c.; i. e. angered him; or enraged him;, &c.]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) as also gy-Zhu↓; (IAạr, Th, Ḳ; [in a copy of the Mṣb, tgy-Zhu, which is doubtless a mistranscription;]) and gAyZhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AgAZhu↓; (IAạr, Th, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but this last is not common; (Zj;) or it is not allowable. (ISk, Ṣ.) [See also gayoZN below.]
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
3. gAyZhu, inf. n. mugaAyaZapN: see 1: [originally, He angered him, or enraged him, or the like, being angered, or enraged, or the like, by him.]
[And hence, because emulation, or the like, often causes mutual anger,] ‡ He emulated him, vied with him, or strove to overcome or surpass him, and did like as he did. (TA.)
mugaAyaZapN also signifies † An acting in a leisurely manner: or it is [a] mutual [acting in that manner]. (TA.)
4: see the first paragraph {1}.
5: see 8.
samiEuwA lahaA tagay-uZFA, in the Ḳur [xxv. 13] means ‡ They shall hear it to have a sound of boiling, (Zj, Bḍ, Jel,) like the boiling of the breast of an angry man. (Bḍ,* Jel.)
tagay-aZati AlhaAjirapu ‡ The midday, or summer-midday, became [ragingly or] vehemently hot. (Ḳ, TA.)
