8. AgtAZ He was or became, affected with gayoZ [or anger; or rage;, &c.; i. e. he was, or became, angered; or enraged;, &c.]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) mino kacaA by reason of such a thing; and sometimes one says, mino laA XaIoCK by reason of nothing; (Mṣb;) as also tgy-Z↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

gayoZN Anger; wrath; syn. gaDabN: (Ḳ) or [rage, or vehement anger; for] it has a more intensive signification than gaDabN: (IDrd:) or the former is latent [anger]; and the latter is apparent: or the former is that which affects a person who has not power to exercise it; and the latter, that which affects a person who has power to exercise it: (TA:) or the former, latent anger affecting one who has not power to exercise it: (Ṣ:) or most vehement anger, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) encompassing the liver, by reason of some event that is disliked or hated, and sometimes by reason of nothing: (Mṣb:) or the outbreak, and commencement, of anger. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
takaAdu tamay-azu mina QlogayoZi, in the Kur [lxvii. 8], means † It shall almost burst asunder by reason of vehemence of heat. (TA.)

faEala celika giyaAZaka, and giyaAZayoka, (Ḳ,* TA,) [in the CK giyaADayoka,] i. q. ganaAZayoka, (Ḳ,) i. e. He did that in order to distress thee, [or anger thee, or enrage thee,] time after time. (Ḳ in art. gnZ.)
gaAYiZN Affecting with gayoZ [or anger; or rage;, &c.; i. e. angering; or enraging;, &c.]: (TA:) pl. gaAYiZuwna. (Ḳur, xxvi. 55.)

OagoyaZu [comparative and superlative of gaAYiZN]. OagoyaZu AlOasomaMCi Einoda Qll-ehi maliku AlOamolaAki means The most severely to be punished, of persons bearing names, is he who is named the king of kings: (TA:) [lit. the most angering, or enraging, of names, is the king of kings.]
magiyZN Affected with gayoZ [or anger; or rage;, &c.; i. e. angered; or enraged;, &c.]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
HaliymapN mugotaAZapN ‡ [lit. Calm, angry; or the like; because what it contains is sometimes still and sometimes boiling;] is an appellation given to a stone cooking-pot. (A, TA.)

1. gaAfati AlX-ajarapu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. tagiyfu, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. gayafaAnN; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and tgy-ft↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,*) in the copies of the Ḳ erroneously tgy-f; (TA;) as also Oagoyafat↓, inf. n. UigoyaAfN; (TA;) The tree inclined, (Ṣ,) or had its branches inclining, (O, Ḳ,) to the right and left. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

2. gy-f, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagoyiyfN, (Ḳ,) He fled, or turned away and fled; and drew back, or drew back in fear; (O, Ḳ;) and was cowardly. (Ḳ.) You say, Hamala fulaAnN fiI AlHarobi fagay-afa i. e. [Such a one charged, in war, or battle, and] was cowardly; or retreated, and was cowardly. (Ṣ.)
See also 5.

hom.sense: 4: see 1.
AgAf AlX-ajarapa, (O, Ḳ,*) inf. n. UigaAfapN, (TA,) He made the tree to bend, or incline, (O, Ḳ,* TA,*) by reason of softness, or tenderness. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.

tgy-f said of a horse, He inclined, or bent, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) towards one side, (Ṣ, O, TA,) in running. (TA.) And He [app. a man] walked with an elegant and a proud and selfconceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side, and in the manner of the tall: or he passed along easily and quickly: or, accord. to AHeyth, he affected an inclining of the body from side to side, by reason of width of step, and gentleness of pace: accord. to El-Mufaddal, he was proud, or haughty, in his gait. (TA.) The phrase mar-a AlbaEiyru yatagay-afu, mentioned by Aṣ, but not expl. by him, is said by Sh to mean [The camel passed along] going quickly. (TA.)
One says also, tgy-f Eani AlOamori, meaning He refrained, or drew back, from the affair, in fear; as also gy-f↓; this latter mentioned by Th. (TA.)
And tagay-ufN signifies also The being, or becoming, creased, or wrinkled: like tagaD-ufN. (TA in art. EDf.)

gaAfN A species of trees, (AḤn, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) growing in the sands, and becoming large, the leaves of which are smaller than those of the apple, which it resembles in character, or form, (AḤn, O,) having a very sweet fruit, (AḤn, O, Ḳ,) of the kind termed Eul-af, like the pods (quruwn) of the bean, and its wood is white; so, says AḤn, I have been informed by some of the Arabs of 'Omán, which is the place of its origin: n. un. with p {gaAfapN}: (O:) accord. to some of the Arabs, the species of trees called yanobuwt, [see this word, of which one description agrees exactly with that given above,] (O, Ḳ,* TA,*) which is found in 'Omán: (TA:) accord. to AZ, it is of the [trees called] EiDaAh, and is a tree like the qaraZ [q. v.], thorny, of the region of El-Ḥijáz, growing in the [high, or high and rugged, grounds called] qifaAf [pl. of quf-N]. (TA.)
gayofN A flock of birds. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

gayofaAnN and gay-afaAnN↓, (O, Ḳ, TA,) the latter like hay-abaAnN, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK hay-ibAn,) i. q. maraHN; (O, TA;) in the Tekmileh mariH, like katif; and in the copies of the Ḳ marox; but the first of these is the right; meaning [A proud and self-conceited carriage, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side,] in pace, or [manner of] going. (TA.)
gayofaAniI-N: see Oagoyafu.
gay-afaAnN: see gayofaAnN.
gay-aAfN One whose beard is long, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and wide on every side, (O, TA,) and very large. (Ḳ, TA.)
Oagoyafu Having a bending of the neck, (like Oagoyadu,) but without drowsiness. (O, Ḳ.)
And EayoXN Oagoyafu A soft, or an easy, and a a plentiful, life; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) like OagoDafu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)

hom.sense: And The crow, or raven: (ISd, Ḳ:) so sometimes called because of his cry. (ISd, TA.)
gaAqi is a word imitative of The cry [i. e. caw] of the crow, or raven: when indeterminate, [meaning a caw,] it is with tenween, (IJ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) i. e. gaAqK. (IJ, TA.)

entry.sense: gaAqapN: see the preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. gaAlato waladahaA, inf. n. gayolN [q. v.]: see 4.
gaAla fulaAnFA kacaA Such a thing brought evil to such a one. (TA.)
4. OagaAla and Oagoyala, (Mgh,) or OagaAla waladahu (Ṣ, Mṣb) and Oagoyalahu, (Mṣb,) He compressed the mother of his child while she was suckling it. (Ṣ, Mgh,* Mṣb.)

And OagaAlato and Oagoyalato, (Mgh,) or OagaAlato waladahaA and Oagoyalatohu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) She gave her child to drink what is termed gayol, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. the milk of her who was compressed, or the milk of her who was pregnant: (TA:) or [accord. to common usage] she suckled her child while she was pregnant: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and gaAlato↓ waladahaA, aor. tagiylu, inf. n. gayolN, signifies [the same, or] she suckled her child while she was being compressed, or while she was pregnant. (TḲ.) [See also 10.]
Oagoyalato said of sheep or goats, (O, Ḳ,) and of cows, (O, TA,) They brought forth twice in the year. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
See also the next paragraph {5}.

5. tgy-l AlX-ajaru The trees became tangled, or abundant and dense, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in their branches, having leafy coverings or shades; as also Oagoyala↓ and Aisotagoyala↓: (Ḳ:) or all signify the trees became large, and tangled, or abundant and dense. (TA.)
And tgy-lwA They became many: (O, Ḳ:) and (so in the O, but in the Ḳ “or”) their cattle, or possessions, became many. (O, Ḳ.)
tgy-l He entered the giyl [i. e. thicket, or covert]. (O.) And tgy-l AlX-ajara He (a lion) entered among the trees, and took them as a giyl [or covert.] (TA.)

8. AgtAlhu He did evil to him without his knowing whence it came so that he might prepare himself. (TA.) It is said in a trad., OaEuwcu bika Oano OugotaAla mino taHotiI i. e. [I seek protection by Thee from] my being the object of an event's befalling me whence I shall not know; meaning thereby the sinking [into the ground] and being swallowed up. (TA.) AlAigotiyaAlu and Algiylapu are syn. in a sense expl. below. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) See the latter word below: and see also 8 in art. gwl. One says, Augotiyla, meaning He was deceived, and taken to a place, and [there] slain. (TA.)
AgtAl said of a boy, He became thick and fat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

10. Aisotagoyalato, said of a woman, a verb of which the subst. is giylapN [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) [accord. to the context in the Ḳ, in which the meaning is not clearly indicated, it seems to signify She suckled her child while being compressed, or while pregnant; like OagaAlato for OagaAlato waladahaA; and this I believe to be the right meaning: or] it signifies she was compressed while suckling a child, or while pregnant. (TḲ.)
See also 5, first sentence.
gayolN: see giylapN, first sentence, in two places.

As some say, (Mṣb,) it signifies The milk with which a woman suckles while she is being compressed, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or while she is pregnant: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) you say, saqatohu gayolFA, (Mṣb,) or Algayola, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. She gave him to drink such milk. (TA.)

Also Water running upon the surface of the earth; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) thus correctly, with fet-ḥ; but giylN↓, with kesr, is a dial. var. thereof, mentioned by ISd: (TA:) both are said to signify water running amid trees: (Ḥam p. 555:) IB says that the former signifies thus; and that its pl. is guyuwlN: and it is also said to signify water running in rivers or rivulets, and in streamlets for irrigation: (TA:) and by some, to signify water running amid stones, in the interior of a valley. (Ḥam ubi suprà.) It is said in a trad., that in the case of that [produce] which is irrigated by the water thus termed (maA suqiIa baAlgayoli, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, TA, or gayolFA, Mgh) there shall be [given for the poor-rate] the tenth; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, TA;) and in the case of that which is irrigated by the bucket, half of the tenth. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also an ex. voce SubaAbapN.]

And Any valley in which are flowing springs: (Ḳ:) or a place in a collection of tangled, or abundant and dense, trees, in which is water running upon the surface of the earth: (Lth, TA:) and any place in which is water, (Ḳ, TA,) such as a valley and the like: (TA:) and giylN↓, with kesr, signifies any valley in which is water; and the pl. of this is OagoyaAlN [a pl. of pauc.] and guyuwlN. (Ḳ.)
See also giylN.

Also A plump, full, saAEid [or fore arm]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and so mugotaAlN↓: (Ḳ:) the latter said by Fr to be applied to a wrist as meaning full because from Algawolu; but this saying is not valid, as gayolN is found in the same sense. (IJ, TA.) [See an ex. of the former in a verse cited voce TafolN.] And A fat, big, boy; as also mugotaAlN↓: (Ḳ:) fem. of the former gayolapN; (TA;) which is applied to a woman as meaning fat; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or a fat, big, woman. (AO, TA.)
See also gay-ilN, in two places.
Also The ornamental, or figured, or variegated, border (syn. Ealam) in a garment: (AA, Ḳ:) pl. OagoyaAlN. (AA, TA.)
And A line that one makes, or marks, upon a thing. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: giylN A thicket; or trees in a tangled, confused, or dense, state: (Aṣ, Ṣ, O:) or an abundance of such trees, (Ḳ, TA,) not thorn-trees, amid which one may conceal himself: (TA:) and gayolN↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ:) and the former, a collection of reeds or canes, and of [the kind of high, coarse, grass called] HalofaMC: (Ḳ:) and i. q. OajamapN [i. e. a collection, or an abundant collection, of tangled, confused, or dense, trees, or of reeds or canes]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) [and in like manner gayolapN↓, occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, is expl. by Freytag, as signifying “saltus:”] and the place [meaning covert] of the lion: it may not have the termination p: the pl. is guyuwlN; (Ṣ, O;) and gayaAyiylu is said to be an anomalous pl. of giylN. (O and TA in art. Eyl, voce Eay-aAlN, q. v.)
See also gayolN, in two places.

hom.sense: gayolapN: see giylapN.
Also A single act of AigotiyaAl [q. v. voce giylapN]. (TA.)
See also giylN.
It is also fem. of the epithet gayolN [q. v.]. (TA.)

giylapN and gayolN↓ signify the same; (Mgh, O, Mṣb); i. e. The compressing one's wife while she is suckling: (Mgh, Mṣb:) thus expl. by AO as stated by AʼObeyd: (Mgh:) and thus the former signifies accord. to El-'Alkamee; and so says Málik: or, accord. to El-Munáwee, it signifies the compressing one's wife while she is suckling or pregnant: or, accord. to ISk, a woman's suckling while pregnant: (from a marginal note in a copy of the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer of Es-Suyootee, in explanation of a trad. mentioned in what here follows, commencing with the words laqado hamamotu:) and gayolN↓ has this last signification (Mgh, TA) accord. to Ks: (Mgh:) giylapN is the subst. from Aisotagoyalato: (Ḳ:) and IAth says that gayolapN↓ is a dial. var. thereof; or, as some say, this denotes a single act [of what is termed giylap]; or the pronunciation with fet-ḥ is not allowable unless with the elision of the p. (TA.) One says, OaDar-ati Algiylapu biwaladi fulaAnK, meaning His mother's being compressed while she was suckling him [injured the child of such a one], and likewise his mother's being pregnant while she was suckling him. (Ṣ, O.) [But] in a trad. is related the saying, (of the Prophet, O) “Verily I had intended to forbid Algiylap (Ṣ, Mgh,* O, Mṣb, Ḳ) until I remembered that the Persians and the Greeks practise it and it does not injure their children.” (Mgh, O, Mṣb.) [See also 4 in art. fsd.]

Also The act of deceiving, or beguiling: (Ḳ:) and i. q. AigotiyaAlN↓: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: [see 8, and giylapN, as expl. in art. gwl:]) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, in the language of the Arabs it signifies the causing evil, or slaughter, to come to another from an unknown quarter. (TA.) One says, qatalahu giylapF, meaning He deceived, or, beguiled, him, and went with him, or took him, to a place, and slew him (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) when he reached it: (Ṣ, O:) or he slew him at unawares. (Abu-l- ʼAbbás, TA.)
Also The XaqoXiqap [or faucial bag of the he-camel]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Oum-u gayolaAna [in Pers. mugayolaAn] A species of the [trees called] giDaAh; (Mgh, Mṣb;) the [species of lote-] trees called sidor; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) the fruit of which is said to be sweeter than honey: the saying, of some, that it is with kesr to the g, and that it is thus called because the giylAn [pl. of guwlN] are often found before it, is rejected and false: (TA:) Lth and ISh say that it is the same as the TaloH [q. v.]. (TA in art. TlH.)

gayuwlN, as stated by IJ, on the authority of Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, who had it from his grandfather, is sing. of guyulN, (TA,) which is an epithet applied to oxen, or bulls and cows, (AO, IJ, O, Ḳ, TA, [nafarN in the CK being a mistake for baqarN,]) and to camels, (Ḳ,) signifying Numerous: and also [in the Ḳ “or”] fat. (AO, IJ, O, Ḳ.)
And, applied to anything, Alone; solitary: pl. guyulN. (AA, TA.)

gay-ilN, like say-idN, (O, TA,) in the Ḳ gayolN↓, but this latter is said by ISd to be of weak authority, (TA,) applied to a garment, Wide, or ample. (O, Ḳ, TA.) And so gay-ilapN applied to a land: (O, TA: [mentioned also in art. gwl:]) or, as some say, gay-ilN, thus applied, (O, TA,) but accord. to the context in the Ḳ gayolN↓, (TA,) signifies Such as one judges to be of little extent, though it is far extending: (O, Ḳ,* TA:) and caAtu gawolK, so applied, has been mentioned in art. gwl as having this meaning. (TA.) And gay-ilapN applied to a woman signifies Tall: (O, TA:) and so does caAtu gawolK. (TA in art. gwl.)
Algay-aAlu The lion: (Ḳ) or the lion that is in the giyl [or covert]. (O.)
gaAYilN Much, or abundant, dust or earth. (TA.)

gaAYilapN Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, that is covert, or concealed. (Ḳ.) And Evil, or mischief; as also magaAlapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) thus in the saying fulaAnN qaliylu AlgaAYilapi and AlmagaAlapi↓ [Such a one is a person of little evil or mischief]. (Ṣ.)
See also the same word in art. gwl.
Oagoyalu Full; big, or large. (TA.)
mugaAlN (Mgh, Ḳ) and mugoyalN↓ (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) A child given to drink what is termed gayol: (Ṣ,* Ḳ: [See 4:]) or suckled while its mother is pregnant. (Mgh.)
mugoyalN: see the next preceding paragraph.
mugiylN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mugoyilN (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) A woman giving her child to drink what is termed gayol: (Ṣ, Ḳ: [see 4:]) or suckling it while she is pregnant. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
magaAlapN: see gaAYilapN, in two places.
mugay-ilN [in the CK mugay-al] and mutagiy-ilN↓ Continuing, or remaining fixed, or stationary, in the giyl [meaning thicket, or covert, in the CK gayol]: and entering therein. (Ḳ, TA.)
migoyaAlN A tree (XajarapN) having tangled, or abundant and dense, branches, with leafy coverings or shades. (Ḳ.)
mugotaAlN: see gayolN, latter half, in two places.
mutagay-ilN: see mugay-ilN.

hom.sense: 1. gaAmati Als-amaMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. tagiymu, inf. n. gayomN; (Mṣb;) and tgy-mt↓; and gay-amat↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tagoyiymN; (Ḳ;) and OagaAmat↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Oagoyamat; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) all signify the same; (Ṣ;) The sky was, or became, clouded, or covered with clouds. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
gaAma, aor. yagiymu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. gayomN, (KL,) He was, or became, thirsty, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,* [like EaAma,]) and affected with internal heat. (Ṣ, Ḳ)

And gAm UilaI AlmaMCi, aor. as above, inf. n. gayomapN and gayamaAnN and magoyamN, is mentioned by IAạr [as signifying He thirsted for water, or the water: or he thirsted for it vehemently, accord. to an explanation of gayomapN given below]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
[Hence,] gy-m All-ayolu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tagoyiymN, (TA,) ‡ The night became like the gayom [or clouds]; (Ḳ;) became dark, and came like the clouds. (TA.)

And gy-m AlT-aAYiru † The bird fluttered over one's head, not going to a distance; on the authority of Th: mentioned by IAạr as with gyn and tAC [evidently mistranscriptions for Eyn and vAC: see Eay-ava]. (TA.)
4. OagaAmati Als-amaMCu and Oagoyamat: see 1.
Oagoyama Alqawomu [The people, or party, had a clouded sky;] clouds came upon the people, or party. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And Oagoyama He (a man, TA) became stationary (Ḳ, TA) like the clouds. (TA.)
5: see the first paragraph {1}.

hom.sense: gayomN, originally an inf. n., from gaAmati Als-amaMCu [q. v.], (Mṣb,) Clouds; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) n. un. with p {gayomapN}: (Mṣb:) or [an expanse of clouds covering the sky,] when one sees not a sun (Kr, TA) by reason of much covering of the sky: (TA:) [and often meaning mist:] pl. guyuwmN and giyaAmN. (TA.)
Also Thirst: and internal heat. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also gayomapN.]
And Anger, wrath, or rage, (Ḳ, TA,) which is from internal heat. (TA.)

And a certain disease in camels, like that called qulaAb [q. v.], except that it does not kill: (Ḳ, TA:) it is said that the asterism of the Pleiades (Alv-uray-aA, q. v.,) does not rise nor set aurorally without there being sickness, mostly in the camels, which are then affected with the disease thus called. (Az, TA.)
XajarN gayomN Dense, or tangled, trees: like gayonN [which is a dial. var. of gayomN in other senses]. (TA.)

entry.sense: gayomap Thirst; so says AʼObeyd: or vehemence of thirst: thus in the trad. cited under EayomapN [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also gayomN.]
gayomAn Thirsty: and affected with internal heat: fem. gayomaI: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the latter applied to a woman. (Ṣ.)
yawomN gayuwm [A cloudy day;] a day having gayom [or clouds, or clouds covering the sky]. (Th, TA.)
magoyuwmN A camel affected with the disease termed gayom: (Az, Ḳ, TA:) such scarcely ever, or never, dies. (Az, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. gaAna Ealayohi kacaA, [aor. yagiynu, inf. n. gayonN,] Such a thing covered, veiled, or concealed, him, or it: (Ḥam p. 574:) [and so OagaAnahu↓; whence] one says, AgAn↓ Algayonu Als-amaMCa The clouds covered, or overspread, or wholly covered, the sky. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And giyna EalaI kacaA Such a thing was covered over. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] giyna EalaI qalobihi, inf. n. gayonN; as also Ougiyna↓ [in the CK (erroneously) Aagoyana]; † His heart was invaded by desire, or appetite, as by a thing that covered it: or was covered [so as to be rendered unsusceptible]: or was enveloped by the like of rust [or clouded or rendered dull]. (Ḳ, TA. [For Alr-ayon, meaning “the like of rust” covering the heart, the CK has Ald-ayon.]) The saying, in a trad., Uin-ahu layugaAnu EalaI qalobiI (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) Hat-aI Oasotagofira Qll-eha fiI Alyawomi saboEiyna mar-apF (TA) is from the phrase giyna EalaI kacaA signifying as expl. above, (Ṣ,) and means † Verily my heart is invaded as though it were covered, by unmindfulness from which mankind will not be free so that I beg forgiveness of God in the day seventy times: (TA:) or it means, being used metonymically, verily I become diverted from AlmuraAqabap [meaning the fear of God, or, as a conventional term, the constant knowledge of God's cognition of me in all my states or circumstances,] by the affairs that are for good relating to the present world; for these, though matters of importance, are, in comparison with the affairs relating to the other world, as idle sport, in the estimation of the people who follow the rule of AlmuraAqabap. (Mṣb.)

One says also, giynati Als-amaMCu, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. gayonN; as also gaAnat, inf. n. gayonN; [like gaAmat;] (TA;) The sky became covered (Mṣb, TA) with gayon (Mṣb) or gayom (TA) [i. e. clouds, or an expanse of clouds].
ginotu, aor. Oagiynu, [inf. n. gayonN,] I was, or became, thirsty. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And gaAnati AlUibilu i. q. gaAmat (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) i. e. The camels were, or became, thirsty. (TA.)
And gaAnato nafosuhu, (Ṣ,) or nafosiI, (Ḳ,) aor. tagiynu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. gayonN, (TA,) His, or my, soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. gay-ana gayonFA↓ HasanapF and HasanFA He wrote a beautiful g. (TA.)
4: see the first paragraph {1}, in three places.
gaAnN: see gayonapN.

hom.sense: gayonN [mentioned above as an inf. n. is also a subst., as such] i. q. gayomN, (Ḳ, TA,) a dial. var. of the latter word, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) signifying clouds; (TA;) [or an expanse of clouds;] as in the phrase fiI yawomi gayonK in a day of clouds: (Ṣ,* TA:) or, meaning “clouds,” it is from gaAna Ealayohi kacaA signifying as expl. in the beginning of this art. (Ḥam p. 574.)
And XajarN gayonN Dense, or tangled, trees: (TA:) like gayomN. (TA in art. gym.)
Also [like gayomN signifying] Thirst. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also 1.])
And [The letter g;] one of the letters of the alphabet: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of mult.] guyuwnN and [of pauc.] OagoyaAnN and gayonaAtN. (TA.) See 2, and art. g.

entry.sense: gaAnapN The ring at the head of the bow-string. (Ḳ.) [See EunotuwtN.]

gayonapN i. q. OajamapN; [like gayoDapN, q. v.;] so in the M; (TA;) [and it is said that] Algayonapu AlX-ajoraMCu is like AlgayoDapu AlxaDoraMCu: or, accord. to Abu-l- 'Ameythel [or ʼOmeythil], (Ṣ, TA,) gayonapN signifies [A collection of] tangled, or confused, or dense, trees, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in the mountains, and in the plain, or soft, land, (TA,) without water; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) if with water, called gayoDapN: (Ṣ, TA:) [and Golius states, as on the authority of Yákoot, that gaAnN↓ signifies the same as gayonapN.]

hom.sense: giynapN The fluid that runs from a carcass, or corpse, (Ṣ,) or from the dead: and [the humour, or matter, termed] Sadiyd, q. v. (Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph.

entry.sense: Oagoyanu Green: (Ṣ, TA:) or green inclining to blackness: (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ:) and [its fem.] gayonaMCu is applied to a tree (XajarapN) as meaning green, (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) abounding with leaves, having tangled, or dense, branches, (AO, Ṣ, TA,) and soft, or tender: and sometimes it is thus applied to herbs: (TA:) or [applied to a tree] it signifies great, having wide shade: from the phrase gaAna Ealayohi kacaA, expl. in the beginning of this art.: (Ḥam p. 574:) and Oagoyanu signifies [also] such as is tall, (Ḳ, TA,) of trees, or, by way of comparison [thereto], of men: (TA:) the pl. is giynN: (Ṣ, TA:) which is expl. by Kr as meaning the abundance, and collected state, and beauty, of [the trees called] OaraAk and sidor; but what is well known is that it is pl. of gayonaMC applied to a tree; of which giynapN↓, with kesr, has also been mentioned as a pl., though, as ISd says, this is not known in the [genuine] language, nor is it agreeable with the analogy of Arabic. (TA.)

mugoyin, in the original form, [for mugiyn, act. part. n. of OagaAna,] is used by Ru-beh in the following verse:
OamosaI bilaAlN kaAlr-abiyEi Almudojini
OamoTara fiI OakonaAfi gayonK mugoyini
[There was, or came, in the evening, a moisture like the continual rain of winter that has rained in the tracts of overspreading clouds]. (Ṣ.)
